HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
2 Schools, 2 Strategies, One Goal: Keeping Top Students

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
Emily Armstrong's first child was a pioneering kindergartner at a new experimental public school on the Lower East Side nine years ago. Her daughter, Brighid, thrived, and so did her school, the Neighborhood School, turning its funky mix of children of ex-hippies, professionals and working-class immigrants into the top-ranked elementary school in the district, and one of the best in New York City.
But when it came time for Brighid to go to middle school, her mother jumped ship, sending her to a school in East Harlem, a long subway ride from home. And Ms. Armstrong cannot imagine, when Brighid's younger brother, Kevin, is ready for middle school in two years, staying in the district. 
 "I love my neighborhood; I'm a real die-hard East Village person," said Ms. Armstrong, who closed down her video training company to spend more time with her children -- and their schools.
But the difficulty of finding a good public school has overshadowed much of the pleasure that she and her neighbors take in a neighborhood once known for its crime and drugs, but now bursting with art galleries, restaurants, community gardens and democratic ideals.
"I never realized what an insane place it was till I sent my kids to school," she said. "The hysteria about schools is just unbelievable."
Across New York City, there is a brain drain not just of talented teachers or brilliant principals, but also of an equally scarce commodity: ambitious, well-informed and choosy students, as parents shop around for better schools. Those who stay in the neighborhood through elementary school often leave in middle school, unable to find a nearby school that can handle both the turbulence of budding adolescence and serious academics.
Frustrated by the loss of students to neighborhoods as close as TriBeCa or as far as East Harlem, officials of District 1 on the Lower East Side have begun a recruitment drive, which they hope will retain enough students to become the core of a new crop of stronger schools.
Over the last few weeks, district officials have crisscrossed the neighborhood, a sometimes uneasy mix of Puerto Ricans and Dominicans who send their children to public schools, Orthodox Jews who do not, artists, Bengalis and Eastern Europeans. From 14th Street to Chinatown, Astor Place to the East River, officials have dropped off fliers at day care centers, community organizations, local newspapers and ethnic radio stations, encouraging families to take a closer look at Lower East Side schools.
A public-school fair this fall attracted 150 people, more than any similar event in the district in 20 years, said Laksmi A. Nor, the district's director of instruction.
The district superintendent, Sonia Diaz Salcedo, hopes that the drive will call attention to district schools that work and keep enough families with high-scoring children to help lift District 1 out of the mediocre middle of achievement among the city's 32 school districts.
It is a strategy that wealthy suburbs seldom have to think about. And it is one that leads to arguments about equity. Is it possible, parents and school officials ask, to create good schools by attracting strong students without further damaging the struggling schools they leave behind?
The district began, Ms. Salcedo said, by strengthening its elementary schools, using two models, the Neighborhood School, founded by teachers, and Public School 34, a classic neighborhood school. In the last two years, P.S. 34 has been expanded to eighth grade, hoping to keep the families in the district until the children are ready to go to high school.
Many parents at the Neighborhood School say they would like their school to do the same.
At the Neighborhood School, which has grown increasingly popular over the years, the atmosphere is folksy and informal. Its philosophy is so egalitarian that the school shies away from celebrating any holidays, for fear of offending someone. It shunned textbooks for many years, though social studies and math books have begun to creep into classrooms, as parents complained that without a text, it was hard for them to help their children at home.
Parents can follow the curriculum through letters sent home by every teacher. In kindergarten, children write that they have been feeding food scraps to their worms and sketching trees in Tompkins Square Park. In sixth grade, children plan to write a screenplay based on the Salem witch trials.
 It is hard to walk down the halls without bumping into a mother or father. Last week, Ken Gilbert, a lawyer wearing a dress shirt, tie and dreadlocks, led 4- and 5-year-olds in singing "how oats, peas, beans and barley grow," and then, by request, "You Are My Sunshine," while they inspected plants in the greenhouse.
Judith Foster, the director, an Ed Koren cartoon come to life with frizzy black hair and a look of erudite intensity, proudly tells how a father arrived, demanding a tour, after hearing about the school in Katmandu, Nepal. Asked what makes the school tick, she talks about community and empathy in the same breath as academics, and tells another story, of a little boy who could not find the bathroom. But he knew, she said, where to find his reading buddy, and he turned to the older child for help.
"What's important about our school is that children's ideas are treated seriously," she said.
Where the Neighborhood School breaks tradition, P.S. 34 embraces it. A miniature American flag hangs in every classroom. Bells ring loudly to signal times to change classes. When Virginia Hutchinson, the principal, who typically looks understated in a gray pantsuit, arrived six years ago, the library was closed. She reopened it, and students can drop in to do research any time.
Violin cases piled in classrooms are testament to the school's music program. Using a combination of grant money, city money and a partnership with the Third Street Music School, every child has an instrument and takes music class two to four times a week.
Every morning, Ms. Hutchinson makes her ritual announcements over the public address system: "Stand up and be counted if you had 100 percent attendance." "Stand up and be counted if you read six books so far this year." "Stand up and be counted if you were a good citizen and helped keep your school clean today." The floors gleam.
Most of her families come from nearby low-income housing projects, and for them "a big issue is a safe environment," Ms. Hutchinson said.
The P.T.A. president of P.S. 34, Lorraine Pattiasina, lives in nearby Section 8 housing and has returned to college while her husband, an Indonesian immigrant, works as a doorman. Eight of her 11 children have attended P.S. 34, and she has watched it improve.
But with 45 percent of the students in elementary school reading at or above grade level in 1997-98, the school performs well behind the Neighborhood School, with 73 percent reading at or above grade.
Mrs. Pattiasina is convinced -- despite the denials of district officials -- that the Neighborhood School receives more public money than her school.
"There is a constant battle of who gets more, who gets less," she said.
Ms. Pattiasina plans to stay at P.S. 34 and fight for more resources, even if it means pitting her school against another. Ms. Armstrong, who sent her daughter, Brighid, to middle school in East Harlem, says she might be persuaded to stay if she could get past the neighborhood politics that sees the expansion of her school as a victory for elitism.
"The saddest thing is this bad attitude about other people, other schools," she said. "You get into this 'circle your wagons' mentality. You are driven to isolation."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Senseless in Seattle

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Is there anything more ridiculous in the news today then the protests against the World Trade Organization in Seattle? I doubt it.
These anti-W.T.O. protesters -- who are a Noah's ark of flat-earth advocates, protectionist trade unions and yuppies looking for their 1960's fix -- are protesting against the wrong target with the wrong tools. Here's why: 
 What unites the anti-W.T.O. crowd is their realization that we now live in a world without walls. The cold-war system we just emerged from was built around division and walls; the globalization system that we are now in is built around integration and webs. In this new system, jobs, cultures, environmental problems and labor standards can much more easily flow back and forth.
The ridiculous thing about the protesters is that they find fault with this, and blame the W.T.O. The W.T.O. is not the cause of this world without walls, it's the effect. The more countries trade with one another, the more they need an institution to set the basic rules of trade, and that is all the W.T.O. does. "Rules are a substitute for walls -- when you don't have walls you need more rules," notes the Council on Foreign Relations expert Michael Mandelbaum.
Because some countries try to use their own rules to erect new walls against trade, the W.T.O. adjudicates such cases. For instance, there was the famous "Flipper vs. GATTzilla" dispute. (The W.T.O. used to be known as GATT.) America has rules against catching tuna in nets that might also snare dolphins; other countries don't, and those other countries took the U.S. before a GATT tribunal and charged that our insistence on Flipper-free tuna was a trade barrier. The anti-W.T.O. protesters extrapolate from such narrow cases that the W.T.O. is going to become a Big Brother and tell us how to live generally. Nonsense.
What's crazy is that the protesters want the W.T.O. to become precisely what they accuse it of already being -- a global government. They want it to set more rules -- their rules, which would impose our labor and environmental standards on everyone else. I'm for such higher standards, and over time the W.T.O. may be a vehicle to enforce them, but it's not the main vehicle to achieve them. And they are certainly not going to be achieved by putting up new trade walls.
Every country and company that has improved its labor, legal and environmental standards has done so because of more global trade, more integration, more Internet -- not less. These are the best tools we have for improving global governance.
Who is one of the top environmental advisers to DuPont today? Paul Gilding, the former head of Greenpeace! How could that be? A DuPont official told me that in the old days, if DuPont wanted to put a chemical factory in a city, it knew it just had to persuade the local neighbors. "Now we have six billion neighbors," said the DuPont official -- meaning that DuPont knows that in a world without walls if it wants to put up a chemical plant in a country, every environmentalist is watching. And if that factory makes even a tiny spill those environmentalists will put it on the World Wide Web and soil DuPont's name from one end of the earth to the other.
I recently visited a Victoria's Secret garment factory in Sri Lanka that, in terms of conditions, I would let my own daughters work in. Why does it have such a high standard? Because anti-sweatshop activists have started to mobilize enough consumers to impress Victoria's Secret that if it doesn't get its shop standards up, consumers won't buy its goods. Sri Lanka is about to pass new copyright laws, which Sri Lankan software writers have been seeking for years to protect their own innovations. Why the new law now? Because Microsoft told Sri Lanka it wouldn't sell its products in a country with such weak intellectual property laws.
Hey, I want to save Flipper too. It's a question of how. If the protesters in Seattle stopped yapping, they would realize that they have been duped by knaves like Pat Buchanan -- duped into thinking that power lies with the W.T.O. It doesn't. There's never going to be a global government to impose the rules the protesters want. But there can be better global governance -- on the environment, intellectual property and labor. You achieve that not by adopting 1960's tactics in a Web-based world -- not by blocking trade, choking globalization or getting the W.T.O. to put up more walls. That's a fool's errand.
You make a difference today by using globalization -- by mobilizing the power of trade, the power of the Internet and the power of consumers to persuade, or embarrass, global corporations and nations to upgrade their standards. You change the world when you get the big players to do the right things for the wrong reasons. But that takes hard work -- coalition-building with companies and consumers, and follow-up. It's not as much fun as a circus in Seattle. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Bush to Propose Broad Tax Cut In Iowa Speech

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush will lay out the centerpiece of his economic agenda on Wednesday, calling for sweeping cuts in income tax rates, a tax break for many married couples and an increase in the child credit, his aides said today.
The proposal, valued by the Bush campaign at $483 billion over five years starting in 2002, seemed certain to ignite debate among his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, and drew fire today from Vice President Al Gore, who called it fiscally irresponsible even before its details were disclosed. 
 The tax-cutting package, which would be financed out of anticipated budget surpluses, would be larger than the tax cut passed by the Republican-led Congress last summer and vetoed by President Clinton.
The plan seeks to shore up Mr. Bush's standing as a traditional economic conservative even as it addresses his theme of helping the working poor. But like Republicans in Congress, Mr. Bush faces a complicated task in selling a big tax reduction. At a time when the economy is strong and many people are feeling prosperous, polls show that the electorate is more interested in using the nation's newfound fiscal health to address issues like education and Social Security's solvency.
Mr. Bush's proposal -- to be unveiled in a speech in Des Moines on Wednesday -- would reduce taxes across the income spectrum gradually over five years.
The wealthy would see the top income tax rates reduced to 33 percent from 36 percent and 39.6 percent. The 28 percent and 31 percent rates paid by many middle-class taxpayers would be consolidated at 25 percent. Lower-income families would benefit from the creation of a new 10 percent tax bracket that would apply to much of the income currently taxed at 15 percent.
The plan would also double the child credit to $1,000 and allow more affluent families to claim the credit than under current law. It would benefit many married couples by reviving a deduction based on the lower-earning spouse's income. And it would phase out over eight years the inheritance tax on large estates.
The plan does not contain any reduction in taxes on capital gains, long a primary goal of conservatives. But in most ways, the plan sticks closely to Republican orthodoxy, concentrating its benefits on the upper end of the income scale, the people who pay the most taxes, while also appealing to middle-income families.
One of its unstated messages is that Governor Bush -- more than his father, who as president broke a vow not to raise taxes and who once derided the supply-side tax-cutting philosophy as "voodoo economics" -- can be counted on by his party's conservative base to do the right thing.
"This is simply an effort to show that he's a serious candidate who has ticked off all the little boxes of things you're supposed to do when you run for president," said Bruce Bartlett, a former Treasury Department official in the Reagan and Bush administrations. "The important thing is that it touches all the various bases, that it's small enough not to be considered fiscally irresponsible but substantial enough that it means something to the people who he feels need to be given something in the tax area."
Mr. Bush's proposal is also his first major effort to put a detailed policy behind his theme of "compassionate conservatism."
His advisers said the combination of the new 10 percent rate and the increase in the child credit was intended to help working poor families. Under the current tax code, those families lose a substantial portion of tax breaks available to them through the earned income tax credit -- and therefore face much bigger tax bills -- as their income approaches middle-class levels.
By the Bush campaign's calculations, the changes would remove six million families from the federal income tax rolls, or 20 percent of all families with children.
"It's a plan that will reduce the upper rate," Mr. Bush told reporters in Chicago today. "It's a plan also that recognizes that our current system is not fair. If you're a single mother with children, and you live on the outskirts of poverty, and you work hard, as you move toward the middle class, you pay an enormous rate."
But some analysts said the tax cuts would overwhelmingly go to the wealthy and would do less for low-income people than Mr. Bush suggested.
"I disagree that there's much for low income," said Iris J. Lav, deputy director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal-leaning research organization in Washington. "Even the things that look like low income are really middle income, and as I understand the rate structure, you're really talking about a massive tax cut for high-income people."
Mr. Bush is putting out his economic plan as he prepares for his first debate with his rivals for the Republican nomination on Thursday night in New Hampshire, and is clearly eager to show that he has a detailed agenda.
But he is also risking criticism from some of his Republican opponents as being too timid on tax cuts. From the Democratic side, Mr. Bush is already under attack.
Mr. Gore criticized the Bush approach today, saying that like the tax bill passed by Republicans in Congress this year it would endanger the nation's fiscal health. Campaigning in New Hampshire, Mr. Gore said Mr. Bush had endorsed "a truly reckless tax scheme that would immediately put our country back into deficits."
The Bush plan was developed by a team of economists headed by Lawrence B. Lindsey, a former Federal Reserve governor and policy aide to President Bush. The team also included Michael Boskin, who was chief economist in the Bush White House, and John F. Cogan, who was a budget official in the Reagan administration.
The size of Mr. Bush's plan was determined in part by projections of the size of the budget surplus. Both parties in Washington have agreed that the part of the projected surplus generated by excess Social Security revenue -- about $2 trillion over the next decade -- should be off limits for tax cuts or new spending. But the rest of the surplus -- the part generated by general tax revenue -- is up for grabs.
Mr. Bush's economic team estimated that the non-Social Security surplus in the first five years of their tax cut would be $586 billion. That estimate is higher than current surplus estimates by the Congressional Budget Office and the White House, although their estimates are likely to be increased in coming months.
But analysts said there was still considerable uncertainty about how big the surpluses will be, in part because the current projections are based on assumptions that spending increases will remain far more limited than they have been in each of the last few years.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A Tax Plan Paid For With the Budget Surplus"
Highlights of the tax plan to be laid out by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
 
FEDERAL INCOME TAX RATES
The plan would reduce the top two income tax rates, 39.6 and 36 percent, to 33 percent. The middle rates, 28 and 31 percent, would be reduced to 25 percent. The current 15 percent rate would remain, but some of the income now subject to it would move into a new 10 percent bracket.
 
CHILD CREDIT
The child credit would be doubled, to $1,000 a child. The income cutoff on eligibility for the credit would rise to $200,000 for a married couple filing jointly from $110,000.
 
MARRIAGE PENALTY
The plan would reinstate a deduction available to couples in the mid-1980's. It would allow couples filing jointly to deduct 10 percent of the earnings of the lower-earning spouse, up to an earnings limit of $30,000.
 
INHERITANCE TAX
The plan would phase out the tax on large estates and gifts over eight years.
 
CHARITABLE GIVING
Taxpayers who do not otherwise itemize deductions would be allowed to itemize charitable contributions.
 
CORPORATE RESEARCH
A current provision giving credit to companies that engage in research would be made permanent.
(Source: George W. Bush for President campaign)(pg. A20)

HEADLINE: A Group Without a Center;
Rockefeller Investment Arm Trying Not to Look Back

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
There's finally a nip in the air, and the energy level around Rockefeller Center is ratcheting up. The Christmas tree will be lighted tonight, the refurbished skating rink is full of figure eights and the new Banana Republic flagship store is drawing crowds. The buildings somehow seem to glitter.
All in all, the center has the kind of rich sheen that one would normally associate with the Rockefeller name, so that makes it hard to remember that the Rockefeller family has not owned it for years. 
 "We never had a strategy of holding onto anything forever because our name is on it," said Peter J. Johnson, an adviser to David Rockefeller, who is now just a minority partner in the investor group that owns Rockefeller Center.
Sometimes, it seems as though this quintessentially American landmark has been through more owners than moviedom's Red Violin. In the last 15 years, it moved from American hands to Japanese hands and back to American ones and was in and out of bankruptcy.
Now, it is safely ensconced in the hands of a deep-pocketed investor group led by the venerable Goldman Sachs, and it is again operating as though nothing ever went wrong.
All of which makes this a bittersweet time for the folks at Rockefeller Group International, which used to own the place. It, too, is "Rockefeller" in name only now, having been sold to a Japanese company several years ago. Perched in their offices in the McGraw-Hill Building across the Avenue of the Americas, the Rockefeller Group people are onlookers, not participants, when the center is center stage.
"We always expected that we'd somehow keep control of the property," said Alan L. Stein, a senior vice president of Rock Group, as it is often called. Karen A. Treadwell, its treasurer, put it more emotionally: "That first year, I couldn't even go to the tree lighting, knowing we weren't part of it anymore," she said.
Still, the Rock Group staff is spending a lot less time these days looking wistfully at its past. Instead, staff members much prefer looking west toward Seventh Avenue, where a sign of their future is starting to rise.
There, on the site of a former parking lot on 49th Street, Rock Group has broken ground on a 33-story office tower, to be owned and mainly occupied by the financial powerhouse Morgan Stanley.
"This building is a visible sign that we've made it all the way back, that we're true real estate developers again," said Lorian L. Marlantes, Rock Group's chief executive.
In the New York real estate world, a tight little community where every developer's ups and downs are the fodder of power-lunch chatter, Rock Group's fall and rise has provided the spice at countless expense-account meals. Rock Group, now a wholly owned subsidiary of a Japanese company, Mitsubishi Estate, has a lot fewer employees than it did in its glory days. And while they still get a lot of the cushy benefits that the Rockefeller family's largess once guaranteed, they no longer have the cocktail-party cachet that their employer once conveyed.
Still, they finally have something that eluded them for much of this decade: a seemingly solid future.
Like most real estate companies, Rock Group is thriving in a boom market. It has several building projects going outside New York, and "developers and tenants are calling us," said Jonathan D. Green, president of its development unit.
It still manages four skyscrapers on the Avenue of the Americas, including the McGraw-Hill Building, which it partly owns. It owns a slew of industrial properties in New Jersey, a telecommunications company, even a division that runs temporary office suites. It also owns 77 percent of Cushman & Wakefield, a huge real estate services company.
And all of those units are expanding apace. "We have stopped looking in the rearview mirror," Mr. Marlantes said.
That past view is not a pretty sight. Rock Group, which until 1984 was called Rockefeller Center Inc., was set up by the Rockefeller family trusts in 1932 to funnel some of their vast fortunes into real estate. It soon also owned television and radio stations, a paper bag company, Radio City, even an oil and gas company. But starting in the 1970's, the 14 Rockefeller family trusts that owned Rock Group began divesting assets.
The beginning of the end came in 1985, when the trust funds borrowed $1.3 billion from a real estate investment trust. Then, the trusts sold close to 58 percent of Rock Group to Mitsubishi Estate in 1990.
People cringed at the thought of a Japanese company owning so American a symbol as Rockefeller Center. But Mitsubishi's ownership was short-lived. Financing had been based on the assumption that annual rents would rise as high as $65 a square foot by the early 1990's. In fact, the center was lucky to get rents half that high after the 1989 real estate recession hit.
Mitsubishi refused to pay the debt itself. Rock Group was forced to put the landmarked part of the center into bankruptcy in 1995. "You couldn't go to a party without getting asked, 'How did you ever get into that kind of position?' " Ms. Treadwell, the Rock Group treasurer, said.
When Rockefeller Center emerged from bankruptcy in 1996, the real estate investment trust sold it to a group led by Goldman Sachs and Tishman Speyer Properties. The Rockefeller family trusts sold an additional 22 percent of Rock Group to Mitsubishi in 1991 and sold their remaining 20 percent stake to the Japanese company in 1997.
"The trustees felt it was imprudent to have so much of the family's value tied to the Rockefeller Group," said Mr. Johnson, David Rockefeller's adviser.
It was left to Mr. Marlantes, who has headed Rock Group since 1995, to pick up the pieces. "We had to convince ourselves and our people that the past was the past, that they hadn't screwed up and that they had a bright future," Mr. Marlantes said.
It was no small task. About 865 employees left Rock Group when the center was sold in 1996. While most got jobs with the new owners, many did not. The remaining 346 employees felt shellshocked.
"It was so depressing to see longtime colleagues leave, and to see job security become such a big issue," Ms. Treadwell said.
A few months after the center was sold, Mr. Marlantes moved Rock Group's offices from 1230 Avenue of the Americas, one of the landmarked Rockefeller Center buildings, to the McGraw-Hill Building across the street. "Psychologically, it was better to make a clean break, and be in a building we still owned," he said.
And he mandated that the most beloved benefits, like scholarships for employees' children, be continued. "They came to me right away and said, 'We have to maintain a corporate culture of caring,' " said Maureen Sullivan-Byrne, a 31-year employee who is now director of employee services.
Now, three years later, Rock Group is back up to 370 employees. And even rivals say they are an energized lot. "They've actually become more aggressive since they emerged from the bankruptcy," said Stephen B. Siegel, chief executive of the ESG unit of Insignia, which is Cushman's largest rival.
Rock Group does have to contend with Japanese owners. Six of its nine board members are Japanese, and two have set up offices in Rock Group's space. Although Rock Group executives play down the difficulties, other American executives who work for Japanese subsidiaries say the culture shock can be monumental.
"Americans are used to looking at facts, making decisions and moving on," said Jim Ivy, chief executive of the Savin Corporation, which Japan's Ricoh bought in 1995. "Japanese companies spend twice as much time keeping everyone informed and involved."
Rock Group executives do not deny that they spend a lot more time catering to the Japanese bosses than they did to the Rockefellers. But many say that in a funny sort of way they feel more unfettered as a lesser-known Japanese subsidiary than they did when Rockefeller Center was their raison d'etre.
"Those landmarked buildings are old, everything breaks; they were awfully expensive to run," said one Rock Group higher-up, who refused to be identified lest he seem to be dining on sour grapes. "Owning them was a labor of love, not profit."
And the spirit is more aggressive. "The Rockefeller family was selling off real estate, not expanding," said Leslie E. Smith Jr., a senior vice president of Rock Group who runs development projects outside New York. "Mitsubishi said to me, 'You want to go out and fly, go ahead.' "
Until Mitsubishi took full control, Mr. Smith had concentrated solely on building Rock Group's 700-acre industrial park in Mount Olive, N.J. Lately, he has been negotiating two big deals in Florida, in partnership with an investment firm. His group has also built a research center for AT&T in Florham Park, N.J., and has bought adjacent land that it will soon develop. Rock Group is helping Mitsubishi Estate develop an office complex in London. Mitsubishi now enlists Rock Group's help in designing buildings in Japan. And it is encouraging Cushman to open an office in Tokyo.
But Rock Group has not cut the umbilical chord entirely: its management company and its office suites group still use the Rockefeller Center name in their logos.
"When I identify myself as the senior vice president of leasing at Rockefeller Center Management, people ask about the buildings around the skating rink." Mr. Stein conceded. "Having a great American name in our masthead makes a significant difference, but it also leaves a residue of confusion."
It's not that the Rock Group folks don't ever gaze wistfully across at their old homestead. But its loss has gone from a sharp pain to an all but unnoticeable dull ache.
"We're on an upswing," Ms. Sullivan-Byrne said. "We feel more security in our jobs and we do still have the Rockefeller name. It no longer seems as painful not to be lighting the Christmas tree."
Ms. Treadwell agreed. "That first year, I didn't go the Christmas tree ceremony because it was too hard, too painful," she said. "I don't go now, either, but just because I don't like the crowds."

HEADLINE: Fed Governor Says Rates Might Increase

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers may decide to raise interest rates again to keep the United States economy on a low-inflation growth path, a Fed governor, Laurence H. Meyer, said yesterday.
"The fundamental challenge for monetary policy is to facilitate a transition from the current exceptional but unsustainable state to a more sustainable, though still excellent, state," Mr. Meyer said in the text of remarks to be delivered at the Stern Graduate School of Business at New York University. 
 Three interest rate increases by the Fed since June may not be enough to slow the economy to the point where inflation is not likely to accelerate, he said.
On Nov. 16, the Fed's policy-setting Open Market Committee raised the overnight bank lending rate a quarter-point, to 5.50 percent, saying that the increase "should markedly diminish the risk of inflation going forward."
This year's rate increases could be seen merely as a reversal of the rate cuts in 1998, Mr. Meyer said. Still, "any policy action has to be justified on the basis of how it contributes going forward to achieving the broad macro objectives assigned to monetary policy," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Conseco, Its Stock Sagging, Focuses on Balance Sheet
Conseco, an insurance holding company with a sagging stock price, announced a reversal of strategy. It cut its common stock dividend and agreed to raise $478 million by selling convertible preferred stock on extraordinarily generous terms to a private investment firm.
Conseco's shares rose $1.6875, to $20.25, on the news. And Moody's Investors Service said that when the financing by the investment firm is completed, it would raise Conseco's rating from junk bond level to investment grade. Floyd Norris: Market Place. Page C18. 

Moved by the Entrepreneurial Spirit
Umang Gupta, the chairman and chief executive of Keynote Systems, which measures Web site performance for e-commerce companies, did not start out wanting to be an entrepreneur. But Mr. Gupta eventually caught the entrepreneurial bug, joined some start-ups and started his own company. In 1997, he made an investment in Keynote. A few months later the board asked him to take over as chief executive. Mr. Gupta's stake in the company is now worth more than $125 million. Management. C14.
 
Stocks Fall as Bond Prices Climb
Stocks declined after selling erased gains in financial stocks spurred by an increase in bond prices. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 70.11 points, to 10,877.81. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index decreased 18.76 points, to 1,389.07. The Nasdaq composite index fell 85.21 points, to 3,336.16. C19.
 
Consumer Confidence Index Rises
The consumer confidence index climbed to 135.8 in November from 130.5 in October just as retailers geared up for the holiday shopping season, the Conference Board said. C8.
 
Police and W.T.O. Protesters Clash
The meeting of the World Trade Organization was thrown into turmoil as thousands of protesters poured into downtown Seattle, forcing the postponement of opening ceremonies. Police used tear gas, pepper spray and rubber bullets to break up the demonstrators. A1.
 
It took Mike Moore nearly a year to become director general of the World Trade Organization. It could take a just a few days for him to be judged a success or a failure. C4.
 
Higher Warner Bid Seen as Possible
American Home Products said that it would work to give Warner-Lambert shareholders "additional value" under their merger agreement to reflect possible increased revenue from the cholesterol-reducing drug Lipitor. The move was interpreted by some analysts as a signal from American Home that it might raise its $70 billion offer. C10.
 
SBC Considers Two Tracking Stocks
SBC Communications is considering issuing separately traded tracking stocks to follow the company's wireless communications unit and its international operations. C10.
 
Judge Approves Dow Corning Plan
A federal judge approved Dow Corning's $4.5 billion plan to emerge from bankruptcy, including $3.2 billion to settle claims the company's silicone breast implants made thousands of women sick. A19.
 
Microsoft Settlement Talks Begin
Lawyers for Microsoft, the federal government and 19 states met for about two hours with a federal judge appointed to seek a settlement in the antitrust case against the company. No one involved in the talks would comment on their progress. C2.

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS;
STRONG GROWTH IN CANADA

BYLINE: By Timothy Pritchard 

 BODY:
The economy in Canada grew at a robust 4.7 percent annual pace in the third quarter, buoyed by a 15 percent increase in exports, Statistics Canada reported. Third-quarter growth was slightly less than economists' expectations, but growth in the last 12 months was on a par with the United States economy at 4.2 percent.

HEADLINE: National Guard Is Called to Quell Trade-Talk Protests;
Seattle Is Under Curfew After Disruptions

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK and STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 30

 BODY:
Downtown Seattle was placed under curfew and the National Guard was called in tonight, after the city was engulfed in demonstrations that threw the opening of global trade talks into turmoil.
The protesters surrounded the convention hall, pinned trade dignitaries in their hotels and stopped traffic at several intersections. By late afternoon, clouds of tear gas set off by the police wafted through downtown streets populated by Nordstrom, Nike and Starbucks, and Mayor Paul Schell declared a state of emergency and a curfew that he said would last until sunrise on Wednesday. 
 The protests forced the postponement of opening ceremonies for a meeting of the World Trade Organization that President Clinton, who is scheduled to arrive here early Wednesday, had hoped would showcase American leadership on free trade.
The global organization is meant to resolve trade disputes and promote free trade, and the Seattle meeting is intended to open a new round of negotiations.
But the protesters have descended on Seattle with an eclectic array of grievances, most centered around the sentiment that the trade organization is a handmaiden of corporate interests whose rulings undermine health, labor and environmental protections around the world.
In Seattle the police used tear gas, pepper spray and rubber pellets at some intersections to break up the groups of demonstrators.
A small group of men, dressed in black clothing and masks and ignoring cries of "Shame on you!" from other protesters, smashed windows and spray-painted graffiti at downtown stores like Nordstrom, Niketown, Starbucks and the Gap. Both were jarring sights in a city that prides itself on its laid-back image.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and other scheduled speakers for opening ceremonies this morning were unable to get through the crowd, which in many cases blocked intersections by linking hands or lying down in the street.
With thousands of protesters already gathered downtown and about 20,000 additional marchers in a union-backed rally headed that way, the trade body's director general, Mike Moore, a former prime minister of New Zealand, announced early this afternoon that the opening ceremonies would be put off. But he vowed that the trade talks would go on. In fact, he held meetings today with a few trade ministers who managed to leave their hotels.
"Negotiating groups are in full swing," Mr. Moore said. "This conference will be a success."
Outside, protesters chanted: "Whose world? Our world! Whose streets? Our streets!"
Reaction of the trade delegates here seemed to run the gamut, from bewilderment to bemusement to, in some cases, anger. As demonstrators shouted "Go home! Go home!" a German delegate, Arnold Schwez, made his way back inside the Sheraton Hotel after he could not get through the crowd.
"These people don't understand the benefits of free trade to the developing nations," Mr. Schwez said.
Early tonight, as Christmas lights and displays came on in parts of downtown streets, demonstrators continued to hold their positions, and a few fires, most set in trash cans, burned in the street.
The governor of Washington State, Gary Locke, in announcing that he was calling in at least 200 troops from the state National Guard, said the troops were "trained in crowd control" and would be unarmed.
Mr. Moore told reporters: "This is a sad day. To those who argue that we should stop our work, I say: tell that to the poor, to the marginalized around the world who are looking to us to help them."
A spokesman for the Seattle police, Clem Benton, said tonight that he could confirm at least 19 arrests of protesters, several of whom were charged with assault, and that number appeared likely to rise.
The police continued to move through parts of downtown with armored personnel carriers. As white clouds of tear gas passed down the streets, protesters coughed, cried and asked for water. Further back, groups of demonstrators chanted, "The whole world is watching!"
In at least a few instances, uniformed officers fired rubber-coated capsules at protesters who the police believed were charging police lines. The pellets, which the police said contained chemical irritants, hit some of the protesters in the leg or the arm, causing visible welts.
"We are here peacefully; we just want our message to be heard," said Gloria Haselwander, a 21-year-old clerk in a Seattle music store who said she believes that the world trade group's rulings contributed to environmental destruction and ever-greater gaps between the world's richest people and its poorest. "We kept saying, 'No violence, no violence,' " she added, "but there was just this mass of gas. My throat hurts, my lungs still hurt."
Bill Simpich, a lawyer from San Francisco, said most protesters were intent on being nonviolent, but were also intent on continuing their demonstrations until the trade body's procedures were reformed to take account of health and environmental issues.
"We will keep marching until the process is open and until they let the people in the door when the decisions are made," said Mr. Simpich, who started his day in the rainy, pre-dawn darkness by gathering with other protesters in a park near the Pike Place Market and then marching toward the convention hall. Rain continued intermittently through the morning, but then stopped for most of the rest of the day.
For Mayor Schell and other city leaders, who had once eagerly sought the meeting to showcase Seattle's role as a major exporter in one of the most trade-dependent regions of the country, the immediate focus tonight was simply on restoring order. But they were bound to face questions in the days ahead about their preparations for protests and, perhaps, to face conflicting criticism that the police moved too harshly on the protesters or did not act aggressively enough to head off the chaos.
Most of the demonstrators were clearly opposed to the window-smashing and other destructive acts by a small knot of protesters, most of whom were young men wearing masks and declining to give their names when asked by reporters.
"Anarchy rules!" said one, carrying a trash can down the street and then using it to smash a window of a Starbucks coffee shop.
At a news conference tonight, both the mayor and the police chief said they respected the right of protesters to gather here, and they blamed a small percentage of them for the violence. "We have demonstrators who are continuing to express their point of view," Chief Stamper said. "Most are doing it nonviolently; some are doing it violently."
The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, was unable to deliver his speech to delegates. In his prepared text, he said: "Unless we convince developing countries that globalization really does benefit them, the backlash against it will become irresistible. That would be a tragedy for the developing world."
This morning, close to 20,000 union members and their allies packed Memorial Stadium, next to the Space Needle, to hear speeches by opponents of the trade organization. The speakers ranged from James P. Hoffa, the Teamsters union president, to Carl Pope, the executive director of the Sierra Club, and Wei Jingsheng, a Chinese dissident.
Speaker after speaker voiced anger that, in their depiction, the trade organization favored corporations and overturned national laws that protected the environment, endangered species and consumers.
Several union leaders also belittled the organization's push for free trade, saying it has encouraged American companies to move operations overseas where workers are paid far less and have few rights.
To thunderous applause, Jay Mazur, president of the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, said, "The rules of this new global economy have been rigged against workers, and we're not going to play by them anymore."
A few union leaders took a protectionist tone, condemning the flood of imports, which they said had wiped out hundreds of thousands of well-paying American manufacturing jobs. But most union leaders focused on pressing the trade organization to protect workers' rights as a way to lift living standards around the world and to close the growing gap between rich and poor in many developing countries.
John Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, said, "Until the W.T.O. addresses these issues, we should not and must not permit our country to participate in a new round of trade negotiations."
After the rally, the union members, joined by environmentalists and other protesters, began a two-mile-long march that skirted the area of the sit-ins and the tear gas. Protesters carried signs that included, "Labor Rights Not Trade Wrongs" and "End Corporate Rule."
As the marchers snaked through downtown, most of the best-known department stores, including Nordstrom and Bon Marche, were closed. Even many Starbucks were shut, with a protester painting "We Want Fair Wages" on the door of one.
The protesters marched past the Westin Hotel, where the American delegation is staying. The hotel was ringed by city buses that were purposely parked bumper to bumper to prevent the organization's critics from approaching the hotel.
The sit-ins brought traffic in many parts of the city to a standstill and angered many motorists. A sit-in at the corner of Sixth Avenue and Seneca Street prevented cars from leaving a freeway exit during the morning rush.
Stephanie Derouin, a customer service worker for Amazon.com. who was trapped for half an hour after taking the Seneca exit, said: "I sympathize with them, but I wish they didn't put me out like this. But if I didn't have a job, I'd probably be out there protesting with them."

WHO'S PROTESTING AND WHAT THEY OBJECT TO:
United Steelworkers of America, A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Teamsters.
 
STEEL: Several steel unions are out in force in Seattle protesting the dumping of imported low-cost steel that eliminates jobs in the U.S. The W.T.O. may consider doing away with U.S. anti-dumping laws.
 
The Sierra Club, the National Wildlife Federation and Friends of the Earth are among the many environmental groups protesting the W.T.O.
SEA TURTLES: , an endangered species, have become the leading symbol for environmental groups that accuse the W.T.O. of ignoring the environmental impact of its decision to force the United States to amend an import ban on shrimp. The rule said shrimpers must use nets that allow sea turtles to escape. The W.T.O. said the rule was unfairly applied.
 
The Center for Science in the Public Interest, the Consumer Federation of America, and Public Citizen are among the Seattle protest groups.
BEEF: The groups are protesting the W.T.O.'s support of the American desire to export hormone-treated beef.
 
Some of the diverse groups include the Corporation for Enterprise Development, the Ruckus Society, the International Forum on Globalization and Pat Buchanan, the presidential candidate.
POWER: The W.T.O.'s secretive, Geneva-based bureaucracy has become the target of think tanks and political action groups that oppose large international corporations.
 
WHAT THEY WANT:
 
STEEL: The United Steelworkers want to prevent foreign steel from being dumped in the United States at below market prices.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Teamsters have different concerns, calling for the W.T.O. to set international labor standards that would prevent poor countries from using child labor, or lax labor laws, to lure jobs away from wealthy countries.
 
SEA TURTLES: Many environmental groups have called for the trade group to weigh environmental impact more carefully when making trade decisions, but some more radical groups have pushed for the W.T.O. to be eliminated.
 
BEEF: The W.T.O. ruled that the European Union did not have a sufficient scientific basis for banning imports of American hormone-treated beef. Both American and European consumer groups have vigorously protested the decision. The groups argue that governments should put concerns about food safety on above free trade.
 
POWER: They object, in part, to the closed-door nature of the W.T.O.'s decision making, as well as what they see as its tendency to ride roughshod over the legislative process of local and national governments. Many also see the W.T.O. as having too much power to impose financial penalties on countries that violate its decisions. The International Forum on Globalization says that the W.T.O. represents the most fundamental redesign and centralization of the world's political and economic arrangements since the industrial revolution.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14
 
National Guard Called In To Quell Trade Protests
Downtown Seattle was placed under curfew and the National Guard was called in after thousands of protesters, some of whom clashed with the police, disrupted the opening of a meeting of the World Trade Organization, a gathering that President Clinton had hoped would be a showcase for American leadership on free trade. The president was scheduled to arrive in Seattle today. A1
 
Kohl Admits Money Scheme
The former German chancellor, Helmut Kohl, who has been facing accusations of having run illegal political slush funds, admitted that he had used secret bank accounts to help branches of his party. A7 

Looking for Bodies in Mexico
American and Mexican officials searched farm buildings outside Ciudad Juarez, a Mexican city near the United States border, and three nearby sites for the bodies of more than 100 Mexican and United States citizens who have disappeared, most of them linked at least peripherally to the drug trade. They found some remains that could be human. A3
 
Moscow Accusation of Spying
Russian officials said they had arrested a low-level diplomat at the United States Embassy in Moscow as she was preparing to meet with a Russian informer. They identified the diplomat as Cheri Leberknight, shown on Russian television. The United States said a diplomat had been briefly detained but refused to comment on charges of spying. A8
 
Arrest in Bank Case
Federal authorities arrested a former Bank of New York employee, Svetlana Kudryavtsev, of Brooklyn, on charges of making false statements to investigators in a money-laundering inquiry involving the bank and its clients in Russia. She entered a plea of not guilty. A8
 
Russia Attacks Chechnya Sites
Russia used bombs and rockets to help troops hold positions around the capital, Grozny, where they have met the stiffest resistance yet from Islamic rebels. A European human rights official arrived to assess the condition of refugees. A8
 
Kuwait Denies Women Rights
The all-male Parliament rejected granting women full political rights for the second time in a week. A5
 
Namibia Voting Troubled
Problems plagued the first day of voting in Namibia's third all-race election, but the director of elections said he remained confident that the vote would be fair. A11
 
Payments in Gondola Accident
Italy's Senate passed a bill to award almost $2 million in compensation to the families of each of the 20 people killed when an American military jet sheared a gondola cable in the Italian Alps last year. The bill was passed after receiving initial approval from the lower house Chamber of Deputies this month. (Reuters)
 
World Briefing A10
 
NATIONAL A18-21
 
Bush Would Use Tax Cuts To Anchor Economic Policy
Gov. George W. Bush will lay out the centerpiece of his economic agenda today, calling for sweeping cuts in income tax rates, a tax break for many married couples and an increase in the child credit, his aides said. The tax cuts would be financed out of anticipated budget surpluses. A1
 
Gore Emphasizes Prosperity
Vice President Al Gore asserted that the nation's prosperity was the central imperative of his campaign, and he gave credit to President Clinton -- and himself -- for the economy. A20
 
No Consensus on Altered Food
Several F.D.A. officials have disagreed with the agency's conclusion that genetically engineered foods can be regulated in the same way as conventional food varieties, according to internal memorandums. A18
 
F.B.I. Chief on EgyptAir Inquiry
Director Louis J. Freeh said Egyptian authorities were cooperating with the Flight 990 crash inquiry and would investigate a list of leads provided by American officials. A21
 
Judge Acts in Implant Case
A federal judge approved Dow Corning $4.5 billion plan to emerge from bankruptcy. The plan includes $3.2 billion to settle claims by more than 170,000 women who said their health was harmed by breast implants. A19
 
Cable TV Pornography Law
The Supreme Court heard arguments on a recent federal law intended to shield children from sexually explicit cable television signals that are only partly scrambled. A19
 
The Court temporarily blocked enforcement of abortion restrictions in Wisconsin and Illinois. A19
 
SCIENCE/HEALTH
 
Gulf War Brain Damage
Some veterans of the Persian Gulf war who have complained of chronic illnesses have signs of brain damage caused by exposure to toxic chemicals, the authors of a study partly financed by the Pentagon said. A18
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-24
 
Hillary Clinton Assails Mayor's Homeless Policy
Hillary Rodham Clinton condemned Mayor Giuliani's policy that has resulted in the arrests of homeless people sleeping on the street. She called for more federal funds for low-income housing and pledged that if elected to the Senate she would seek more money for housing and programs that treat mentally ill people. The mayor defended his policy, saying just a small percentage of the homeless had been arrested. A1
 
Man Charged in Brick Attack
The police charged a 31-year-old panhandler, Paris Drake, with attempted murder in the brick attack on a woman in Midtown on Nov. 16. A1
 
Findings on Police Searches
Blacks and Hispanics are much more likely than whites to be stopped and searched by New York City police officers, even when the numbers are adjusted to reflect higher crime rates in some neighborhoods where members of minority groups live, according to a report by State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer. Police officials disputed the report. A1
 
Illegal Tax on Some Workers
New York City has illegally collected income tax from thousands of its employees who do not live in the city, the state's highest court ruled, opening the way for repayment of perhaps $40 million. B1
 
Freed Egyptian's Plans
Nasser K. Ahmed, who was held for three years on secret evidence, said he would reconstitute an Islamic religious movement that federal officials say harbored terrorists. B1
 
SPORTS D1-8
 
Umpires' Union Leader Out
Umpires voted to decertify the Major League Umpires Association and replace it with a new union, ending Richie Phillips's 21-year reign. D1
 
Meeting Planned on Rose Ban
A senior baseball official will meet with Pete Rose's lawyer in about a month to discuss Rose's effort to end his lifetime ban for gambling. D2

The staff of the F.T.C. was said to have concluded that the proposed $29 billion merger between BP Amoco and Atlantic Richfield would violate antitrust law and wants the full commission to block it. The disclosure came as the commission approved the Exxon-Mobil merger. C1

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
MOYLES, WILLIAM P.

 BODY:
MOYLES-William P., 69, a business executive and lawyer, died at his home in Sewickley, PA. from complications resulting from Parkinson's Disease on Saturday, November 6, 1999. Born on June 1, 1930 in Brooklyn, NY, He was educated at Xavier High School, NY., earned a Bachelor's Degree at Georgetown University and after serving in the United States Air Force, received a law degree from Harvard University. Mr. Moyles practiced law with Mendes & Mount and Donovan & Leisure in New York from 1957 to 1967. At that time, he became Head of the Legal and Mergers and Acquisitions Departments for Control Data Corporation in Minneapolis. He was with Control Data from 1967 to 1973. In 1973, he accepted an executive position with Gulf Oil Corporation in Pittsburgh where over the next eleven years, he was a Group Vice President in charge of Corporate Development and Administration as well as President and CEO of Gulf Oil's Real Estate subsidiary. After the Chevron Corporation purchasesd Gulf Oil in 1984, Mr. Moyles became one of the founding partners and President of MMC Group in Pittsburgh, a private equity investment firm focused on leveraged buyouts where he worked until his retirement in 1994. Mr. Moyles served on various corporate boards and was a member of the Board of the School for the Blind. He was a member of Allegheny Country Club, The Duquesne Club, and The Rolling Rock Club. Surviving immediate family are his wife Virginia Moyles, three daughters, Virginia St. Pierre of Alexandria, VA, Margaret Curran of Philadelphia, PA, Frances Fisher of San Francisco, CA, a sister, Mary Jane Murray of New Rochelle, NY, two brothers, Phillip Moyles of New York, NY, Kevin Moyles of Dallas, TX, and seven grandchildren. The family suggests that in lieu of flowers to please send memorial contributions to the Movement Research Disorder Foundation, Department of Neurology, Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, Ohio 44195.

HEADLINE: Gore Borrows Clinton's Shadow Back to Share a Bow

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.H., Nov. 30

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore asserted today that the nation's prosperity was the central imperative of his campaign, and he gave credit to President Clinton -- and himself -- for the booming economy.
"In this campaign for president, economic policy should be front and center," Mr. Gore told a group of business executives here this morning as he allied himself fully with the President whose shadow he has otherwise been trying to escape. 
 "President Clinton has presided over an economic policy in the current administration that has been historic in its realism about what works and what doesn't work," Mr. Gore said, "and I'm proud to have been a part of the deliberations that have helped to set this economic policy in place."
Mr. Gore's comments were his strongest about his role in the current prosperity, and the remarks were striking in their full embrace of Mr. Clinton. Far from separating himself from the President, as he had been doing so frequently, Mr. Gore praised him often and used the word "we" to describe the administration's economic successes.
"I want you to know that I am determined to continue the prosperity and to continue the policies that have worked to build that prosperity," he said, pledging that as president he would invest in public education and job training for workers.
In his talk to the business group, he promised to reduce the deficit "every single year" of his presidency. Background papers issued by his staff said that he pledged to "make certain that America stays on the path to be debt-free by 2015," but he did not say that to this audience.
Later in the day, Mr. Gore, who suffered some embarrassment this year when he took credit for the development of the Internet, said he was the one who had first drawn attention to the toxic contamination of Love Canal. He was telling a school audience that each person can make a difference in the world and he recalled a child writing to him when he was in Congress about a hazardous-waste site in Tennessee.
He then added: "I found a little place in upstate New York called Love Canal. I had the first hearing on that issue and Toone, Tenn.," he said. "But I was the one that started it all. And it all happened because one high school student got involved."
Mr. Gore held Congressional hearings on the matter in October 1978. But two months earlier President Jimmy Carter had declared Love Canal a disaster area, and the federal government, after much howling by local residents, had offered to buy the homes.
Mr. Gore was not available to answer questions from reporters after he made this statement.
In his economic speech Mr. Gore also discussed his little-known work as a real estate developer in the early 1970's in Daleville, Ala.
"For a brief time I was a home builder, after I came back from Vietnam," he told the audience. "Tipper and I borrowed some money and bought 20 acres on the edge of the town where we lived and made it into a subdivision, 35 lots, and I had a partner who built several homes and then sold the rest of the lots. I know a good bit about how to make money that way -- that was our nest egg. To build this country is a great thing."
Peace and prosperity are traditionally overriding issues in national elections, but mostly when they are threatened. Mr. Gore's advisers said he had not focused on prosperity until now because the economy was humming and voters were more concerned about education, health care and school safety. But Mr. Gore has been preoccupied over the last several months with the mechanics of his campaign and changing his image. And today's assertion was as much a declaration that he wanted to turn the conversation to the pocketbook issues that voters focus on increasingly as an election approaches. As one adviser put it, Mr. Gore deserved some credit for the nation's prosperity and he planned to take it.
But claiming credit for the economy has its hazards. It directly links him with Mr. Clinton.
Marshall Wittman, an analyst at the conservative Heritage Foundation, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Gore's taking credit for the economy illuminated both the cloud and the silver lining of being vice president. "If he is going to take credit for the good, he has to take the bad with it," Mr. Wittman said.
The question of how responsible a president is for the economy is always an open one; a vice president's share is even more open.
Robert Reischauer, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office, appointed by Democrats, and now an analyst at the Brookings Institution, said that the Clinton administration had made "some very gutsy decisions" that helped vanquish the deficits and that Mr. Gore was influential in those decisions.
"Gore was known as a voice of moderation and perseverance when it came to deficit reduction," Mr. Reischauer said, "and he was on the side of the president."
But Mr. Reischauer added, "There were a lot of other factors, not the least of which was Lady Luck."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 1 about a campaign appearance by Vice President Al Gore in New Hampshire rendered a passage incorrectly in a comment he made about the contamination of Love Canal. Mr. Gore said: "I found a little place in upstate New York called Love Canal. I had the first hearing on that issue and Toone, Tenn. But that was the one that started it all." He did not say "But I was the one that started it all."

HEADLINE: Rebels in Search of Rules

BYLINE: By Naomi Klein; Naomi Klein is the author of the "No Logo: Taking Aim at the Brand Bullies."

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
It is all too easy to dismiss the protesters at the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle as radicals with 60's envy. A seemingly more trenchant criticism is that they are simply behind the curve, fighting against a tide of globalization that has already swamped them. Mike Moore, the director of the W.T.O., describes his opponents as nothing more than protectionists launching an assault on internationalism.
The truth, however, is that the protesters in Seattle have been bitten by the globalization bug as surely as the trade lawyers inside the Seattle hotels -- though by globalization of a different sort -- and they know it. The confusion about the protesters' political goals is understandable: this is the first movement born of the anarchic pathways of the Internet. There is no top-down hierarchy, no universally recognized leaders, and nobody knows what is going to happen next. 
 This protest movement is really anti-corporate rather than anti-globalist, and its roots are in the anti-sweatshop campaigns taking aim at Nike, the human rights campaign focusing on Royal Dutch/Shell in Nigeria and the backlash against Monsanto's genetically engineered foods in Europe.
At any time, one huge multinational company may be involved in several disputes -- on labor, human rights and environmental issues, for example. Activists learn of one another as they aim at the same corporate target. Inadvertently, individual corporations have become symbols of the global economy in miniature, ultimately providing activists with name-brand entry points to the arcane world of the W.T.O.
This is the most internationally minded, globally linked movement the world has ever seen. There are no more faceless Mexicans or Chinese workers stealing our jobs, in part because those workers' representatives are now on the same e-mail lists and at the same conferences as the Western activists. When protesters shout about the evils of globalization, most are not calling for a return to narrow nationalism, but for the borders of globalization to be expanded, for trade to be linked to democratic reform, higher wages, labor rights and environmental protections.
This is what sets the young protesters in Seattle apart from their 60's predecessors. In the age of Woodstock, refusing to play by state and school rules was regarded as a political act in itself. Now, opponents of the W.T.O. -- even those who call themselves anarchists -- are outraged about a lack of rules and authority. They are demanding that national governments be free to exercise their authority without interference from the W.T.O. and asking for stricter international rules governing labor standards, environmental protection and scientific research.
Everyone, of course, claims to be all for rules, from President Clinton to Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates. In an odd turn of events, the need for "rules-based trade" has become the mantra of the era of deregulation. But deregulation is by definition about the removal of rules. The W.T.O., charged with defining and enforcing deregulation, is only concerned with rules that regulate the removal of rules.
The W.T.O. has consistently sought to sever trade, quite unnaturally, from everything and everyone affected by it: workers, the environment, culture. This is why President Clinton's suggestion yesterday that the rift between the protesters and the delegates can be smoothed over with small compromises and consultation is so misguided.
The face-off is not between globalizers and protectionists, but between two radically different visions of globalization. One has had a monopoly for the last 10 years. Then other just had its coming-out party.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Yen Fallson Hints of Move by Central Bank

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The yen fell against the dollar yesterday on speculation that the Bank of Japan would step up efforts to curb the yen's strength, which threatens to stymie economic recovery in Japan.
The yen backed off a four-year high against the dollar after the central bank suggested that it might increase the amount of yen in the banking system, effectively lowering its value. A bank official later denied that, adding that no change in policy was planned. Some traders said the bank might have been trying to slow the yen's gains. 
 "The market is starting to understand the Bank of Japan is prepared to maintain sufficient funds for stability" of the yen, said Michael Kahn, chief currency dealer at State Street Bank and Trust Company in Boston.
The yen fell to 102.78 per dollar from 102.15 late Tuesday in New York. It fell against the euro for the first day in eight sessions, to 103.575 yen from 103.13 yen. On Friday, the yen rose to 101.25 per dollar, its highest level since Dec. 12, 1995.
That prompted the central bank, which acts for the Ministry of Finance in the currency market, to sell yen on Monday and Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Shows Steady Expansion

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Manufacturing expanded in November for a 10th consecutive month and was on track to finish 1999 with the highest rate of growth in five years, a survey of business executives showed today.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index was 56.2 last month as rising demand for exports helped fuel growth. The index has held above 50 since February, showing that more manufacturers reported improved conditions than declining ones. 
 The index of prices paid fell to 65.3 in November from 69.4 in October, showing that price increases for raw materials were abating. October's reading had been the highest since 70.5 in May 1995.
"I haven't seen better business conditions for manufacturing," said Norbert J. Ore, chairman of the association and director of corporate purchasing for the Chesapeake Corporation in Richmond, Va.
Manufacturing is on course to have its best three-month showing in five years. The index for October and November averaged 56.4. If that holds for this month, the quarterly reading would be the highest since 58.2 in the fourth quarter of 1994.
The index has signaled growth almost all year after falling last December to 45.3, the lowest since May 1991, when the economy was emerging from the last recession.
A separate report from the Commerce Department showed that construction spending increased three-tenths of a percent in October, the first rise in three months, as builders stepped up work on new homes and public projects.
And a report from the Conference Board, a private research group, pointed to further growth, though at a slower rate in the next six months. The group's index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in October after a drop of one-tenth of a percent in September that was the first decline in five months.
Manufacturing has been on the rebound since Asia and Latin America started to recover this year from economic troubles. There was further evidence of that in today's purchasing management report. The index of export orders rose to 54.5 in November from 52.4 during October. It was also the 10th consecutive month above 50 for that gauge.
The overall new orders index also rose, climbing to 59.9 in November from 59.5 during October, which means factories should stay busy for some time, analysts said.
Manufacturers all the same are having to cope with rising costs of raw materials, including natural gas, aluminum and steel. Counting November, the prices-paid index has showed a majority of manufacturers reporting that they have paid more for seven months.
The decline in the prices index for November will remove some pressure for companies to pass along those higher costs to their customers, Mr. Ore said. "It's difficult still to pass through price increases in this market," he said. "Many industries are being very restrained in raising prices and very cautious about raising prices."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
BroadRally Led by Blue Chips Lifts the Dow 120 Points

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday with the blue chips leading the way on positive news from General Electric and the Exxon Mobil Corporation, the newly merged oil giant.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 120.58 points, or 1.11 percent, to 10,998.39. 
 The Nasdaq composite index climbed 17.55 points, or 0.53 percent, to 3,353.71.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 8.81 points, or 0.63 percent, at 1,397.72.
Analysts said softer-than-anticipated November data from the National Association of Purchasing Management offered some relief from fears that the Federal Reserve bank could raise interest rates to stem inflation.
The association's manufacturing activity index for November was 56.2 versus an expected 56.3 percent. A figure above 50 indicates the nation's manufacturing sector is expanding.
"I think the N.A.P.M. numbers are part of it," said Roy Blumberg, money manager at Sheer Asset Management. "We had a pretty good pull-back here over the past five or six days. Basically, I think the major trend is up."
Declines overtook advances by about a 17 to 14 margin, on heavy volume of 907 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. There were 31 stocks at new highs while 261 made new lows.
But a big tide of positive company news bolstered the Dow.
"That is really why the Dow is rallying today," said John Cleland, chief investment strategist at Security Benefit Group of Companies in Topeka, Kan.
General Electric gained 4 7/16, at 134 9/16, after Salomon Smith Barney raised its price target on the conglomerate to $150 from $135.
Shares of Exxon Mobil rose 3 3/16, to 82 1/2, on their first day of trading after the two oil giants combined to become the world's largest publicly traded oil company.
AlliedSignal Inc. rose 3/4, to 60 3/4, and Honeywell Inc. strengthened 2 1/4, to 114 3/16, after the European Union said it had cleared the proposed merger between the two companies.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq recovered some of its losses from its drop Tuesday but traders said the market was still prone to some profittaking.
"If you want to talk about Internet stocks and technology stocks, they have had a long hard run," said Dick Stein, vice president, chief technical analyst at Noble International Investments, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla. "Some would say they are overbought."
Yahoo Inc. jumped 16 1/8, to 229, after Standard & Poor's said it would add the Internet media network to its benchmark 500-share index. Yahoo replaces the Canadian transit services company Laidlaw Inc. Laidlaw fell 1/2, to 5 5/8.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasuries Unchanged
 By Bloomberg News
 Treasury bond prices were unchanged yesterday, as investors awaited the jobs report tomorrow.
Treasuries fell and then recouped early losses after a report showed manufacturing activity expanded at a slower-than-expected pace in November. Even so, comments from the Fed governor, Laurence Meyer, suggesting that the central bank was prepared to raise rates again, and expectations that the report tomorrow will show a booming labor market, kept bonds in check.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 97 26/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, was also unchanged at 6.29 percent.

HEADLINE: Anger as Mexico Begins Foreign Car Restriction

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY and SAM DILLON

DATELINE: EL PASO, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Despite threats of economic boycotts from Mexican-American groups and growing political opposition in Washington, the Mexican government today instituted a customs policy requiring deposits of as much as $800 for all cars with non-Mexican license plates entering the interior of the country from the United States.
Mexican officials say the program is in response to widespread problems of motorists leaving unregistered foreign cars in the country, the equivalent of illegal imports. Including taxes, cars cost roughly 13 percent more in Mexico than in the United States, and officials say 1.5 million vehicles have been illegally brought into the country, a statistic that infuriates Mexican car dealers. 
 The Mexican government delayed the new policy for a month after criticism from lawmakers in Washington and Mexico City, but this morning customs officials at checkpoints along the 2,000-mile border began enforcing the deposit. Critics predict the plan will harm tourism in Mexico. The deposit also represents a hardship for poorer, recent immigrants from Mexico who usually return to visit relatives for Christmas.
"Everybody knows it's not fair," said Jose Alvarez, a construction worker from California, as a border guard inspected his late model van this morning at the main Mexican checkpoint in Ciudad Juarez, across the Rio Grande from El Paso. Mr. Alvarez and his family must pay a $400 deposit to visit relatives in Guanto, Mexico.
"We had to work all year for a vacation with our family, and now we have to give some money for a deposit," Mr. Alvarez said.
The controversy is another reminder of the occasional friction between Mexico and the United States even as the two nations remove trade barriers through the North American Free Trade Agreement.
In recent weeks, the policy has prompted organized protests by Mexican-American groups in Houston, San Antonio, Chicago and Los Angeles, including threats to boycott Mexican products like Tecate beer. A bipartisan Congressional delegation has asked President Clinton to intervene, and Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, announced this week that she would call Senate hearings early next year.
The deposit plan creates a sliding scale under which motorists post a refundable cash or credit deposit of $400 to $800, depending on the age of the vehicle. Drivers who remain in a 16-mile zone near the border are exempt from the deposit, which also does not apply to Baja California.
On Tuesday night, hundreds of motorists lined up for hours in Texas border cities like Del Rio and Laredo to enter Mexico before the deposit was instituted.
In Laredo, which has the heaviest traffic into Mexico, Mayor Betty Flores said this week that the city would offer free parking in the expectation that many poorer, newer immigrants would leave their cars in the United States rather than pay the deposit.
By this morning, motorists like Mr. Alvarez seemed resigned to the deposit, if not happy about it. Deposits are made with Mexico's National Bank of the Army, and officials have promised that the deposits will be refunded when a motorist returns to a border checkpoint. But because Mexico is often plagued by corruption, some motorists fear that their money will not be returned.
Mr. Alvarez, for example, said he would pay with a credit card. "You give cash, and you may not see that money anymore," he said. The family left San Jose on Monday, hoping to reach the border in time to avoid the deposit but failing.
Marco Provencio, a spokesman for the Mexican Treasury Ministry, said the government guaranteed the return of the deposits and called the program necessary to "to help us attack illegal vehicle introduction." He called the problem a "complex matter" and said the government did not intend to bring hardship to poor, recent immigrants.
But many Mexican-Americans and new immigrants from Mexico consider the program a slap in the face.
"It is a total attack of our people's pockets," said Cristobal Hinojosa of Mexicans in Action, an advocacy group in Houston. "The Mexican government knows very well that this is the season when our people travel to see their families."
Last year, United States motorists spent $679 million in Mexico, and Mexican tourism officials initially expressed surprise over the deposit program.
Much of the traffic comes from United States and Canadian snowbirds, but Olivia Bravo, the co-owner of an insurance agency in Laredo, said her company did not get a single request for a Mexican car insurance policy last month compared with about 400 in November 1998.
At the border checkpoint in Ciudad Juarez, a motorist from California traveling to Mexico City said, "The Mexican government has gone wacko." The man, who would only give his first name, Luke, said he planned to spend two weeks on a vacation with his niece. As a customs guard examined the suitcases and boxes stuffed into his van, the man watched a succession of cars, many old and banged up, enter Mexico.
"Like everything, only the poor people get hurt," he said.
