HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks an Opening to Iran, But Efforts Have Been Rebuffed

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ and JAMES RISEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
With a series of quiet approaches and inducements, the White House has tried to achieve a politically risky opening to Iran before President Clinton leaves office, administration officials say. But all of its efforts have been rebuffed.
The most dramatic of these initiatives, they said, was a secret message sent in August seeking the cooperation of Iran's reformist president, Mohammad Khatami, in solving the 1996 bombing of Khobar Towers, in Saudi Arabia, which killed 19 American servicemen and wounded hundreds. 
 Last month the administration also sought talks on reopening consular offices in Tehran for the first time since relations were cut after the 1979 Islamic revolution. And it appears ready to waive sanctions against foreign oil companies that have signed multimillion-dollar contracts to do business in Iran.
While none of those efforts have borne fruit, Mr. Khatami's seemingly more open attitude toward the West has convinced the White House that Mr. Clinton has a political opening, if a narrow one, to turn the tide on 20 years of acrimony and failed relations with Iran.
Less clear, however, is whether Iran's reformers, who appear increasingly on the defensive, have that same room for maneuver.
Although it would like to re-establish some relations with Iran, the administration faces strong anti-Iranian sentiment in Congress and remains highly concerned about Iranian support of terrorism and the possibility that Tehran may seek to undermine Middle East peace talks as they near a critical, final phase.
The concern over terrorism is in part why the Khobar Towers bombing has provided the most immediate obstacle to resuming ties. And the attempt to gain Iranian cooperation in the case was the White House's most significant effort yet to try and tease out the moderates in Tehran and test their willingness and ability to engage the United States.
An agreement on Iranian cooperation would also leave the White House less vulnerable to criticism from Congress, where members have complained that the administration downplayed evidence that Iran was behind the Khobar attack so as to avoid having to retaliate.
Early this year or late last, American intelligence officials say, they obtained the most convincing information yet that Iranian officials may have been behind the attack.
These officials refused to describe that information, except to say it was not the kind that would stand up in court. But it was used, administration officials say, to try and exploit a deepening power struggle within Iran's government and see if Mr. Khatami was ready, or able, to split from the hard-liners and disavow his country's long support of terrorism.
A message from Mr. Clinton to Mr. Khatami was secretly drafted, requesting his cooperation in the Khobar case and asking him to try and stop other terrorist-related activities. That message sat unsent in the White House for months, until August, when it was finally delivered by Assistant Secretary of State Martin Indyk and a National Security Council aide, Bruce Reidel, at a meeting in Paris with officials from Oman, who passed it on.
While the message had been addressed personally to Mr. Khatami, the response came back from the government of Iran: it was not interested. Though the attempt failed, it was just one signal that Washington was eager to settle old disputes and deal with Tehran.
The administration has also gradually moved to soften economic and trade sanctions against Iran, which have in any case proven porous as American allies in Europe trade with Iran and have begun to normalize their relations with Tehran.
In April, the White House announced an exemption of commercial sales of food, medicine and medical equipment, enabling bulk sales of American grain to Iranian buyers. Last month, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group announced that it had reached an agreement with Iran to spend $800 million to develop two Iranian offshore oil fields.
American law prohibits investments of more than $40 million a year in Iran. Shell, with headquarters in Amsterdam and London, has large operating units in the United States, but a company official said it expected Washington to waive the sanctions, as it has with other oil companies that have signed contracts with Iran.
As the economic barriers start to slip, the administration continues to pursue what it calls its people-to-people initiatives, including visits of Iranian wrestling teams, scholars and artists to the United States.
At times in recent months, Mr. Clinton has seemed passionate about Iran. He has even talked in terms of reconciliation with an Islamic country that had suffered at the hands of the West.
At a black tie White House dinner in April, Mr. Clinton went out of his way to say he was trying to understand Iran. He said it was important to recognize that Iran "has been the subject of quite a lot of abuse from various Western nations."
"I think sometimes it's quite important to tell people, look, you have a right to be angry at something my country or my culture or others that are generally allied with us today did to you 50 or 60 or 100 or 150 years ago," the president said.
Saudi Arabia, one of America's most important allies in the Middle East, has already reached a kind of detente with the Iranians and an understanding that Tehran will end its support for terrorism in Saudi Arabia, American officials say. Iran has also agreed to Saudi demands to cut oil production to keep it in line with OPEC quotas, a move that has been a major factor behind the recent sharp rise in oil prices.
But while the Iranians are in the process of normalizing relations with many European and Arab nations, the United States still represents a deeply emotional issue for the country's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and other conservative clerics who hold decisive power in the country.
In searching for an opening to Iran, the administration must try to deal with Ayatollah Khamenei, who has final authority over the intelligence services, the army, the police and the judiciary.
The less conservative Mr. Khatami, elected overwhelmingly two years ago, does not have control over the vital institutions of law and order. Though widely popular, he and his reform movement have struggled to assert themselves against the conservative clerical hierarchy. And they received a devastating blow last month when one of Iran's most outspoken reformers was sentenced to five years in prison.
Despite that setback, the Clinton administration has been encouraged by the fact that quiet pressure from the West prompted Mr. Khatami to intervene in the cases of 13 Iranian Jews arrested for spying.
American officials say they believe that Mr. Khatami was able to put the cases against the Iranian Jews on hold after Western allies made it clear to him that Iran could forget about relations with the West if their trials went forward. Mr. Khatami's intervention has led American officials to believe that his influence over Iran's security apparatus may be slowly growing.
Still, the White House knows that it has to wait for the outcome of parliamentary elections in Iran scheduled for February, in which the administration hopes that Mr. Khatami's candidates will come out on top.
"We are going to have elections in February in Iran, which we think will be very important and will, I think, give a signal as to the direction in which Iran wants to move," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said last month.
Even if there is a positive outcome in February, the United States has demanded that Tehran disavow terrorism and give up efforts to obtain weapons of mass destruction. Most urgently, administration officials believe that Iran represents a major threat to Middle East peace.
Indeed, in a major speech to the Asia Society in October, Mr. Indyk, the assistant secretary of state, said Iran stood out as a stronghold of terrorist groups while other countries were moderating their behavior. American officials say there are new and troubling signs of activity by Iranian-backed groups that could lead to terrorist attacks aimed at disrupting the ongoing Middle East peace negotiations.
Tehran's refusal to cooperate on Khobar Towers has led the administration to discuss Iranian involvement in the attack publicly for the first time. Officials said the United States had information concerning the involvement of "Iranian government officials and others."
Previously, the administration had been "very careful in skirting the issue that the Iranians were responsible for Khobar Towers," an official said. But recently, officials said that "we have not reached a conclusion regarding whether the attack was directed by the government of Iran," as one put it.
Such statements seem designed to separate Mr. Khatami from the Iranian religious hard-liners and intelligence officials who may have been behind the attack. American officials suggested that by making it clear that the United States does not hold Mr. Khatami and his supporters responsible, the administration might be able to come up with a solution to Khobar similar to that found in the case of the bombing of Pan Am 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988 that killed 270 people.
There, the United States, Britain and the United Nations negotiated Libya's handover of two intelligence officers for trial in a specially arranged court in the Netherlands. But the government of Libya was not held responsible for the bombing.
The White House has already faced strong criticism from Congress that it has for years ignored or played down reports of Iranian involvement in the Khobar bombing in order to avoid having to take action against Tehran.
Early after the blast, the United States was told by Saudi and Jordanian intelligence officials that they believed that Iran was behind the attack, American intelligence officials said. The Jordanians also said Syria had provided logistical support.
American intelligence and law enforcement officials were at first skeptical of the reports, but have gradually began to reach a consensus that the Saudis were right.
In fact, the Saudis provided much circumstantial evidence of Iran's role early in the investigation, including the names of the Saudi Hezbollah suspects in Tehran. The administration also knew several months after the attack, according to officials, of the role played by a senior Iranian intelligence official based in Bahrain.
Now, three years later and with the new information on the Khobar case that prompted the message to Mr. Khatami, the attack remains a roadblock to relations with Iran, one that many in Congress would like to see cleared before the White House proceeds further.
At the recent Senate confirmation hearing for Mr. Indyk, nominated as ambassador to Israel, Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, said of the Khobar Tower case, "My big fear is we won't pursue it because of some rapprochement with Iran."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Insurers Changing Tactics But Keeping Cost Controls
Some of the nation's biggest health insurers say they are changing their tactics as they face a backlash against managed care, eliminating or cutting back on unpopular rules. 
 But the insurers still have powerful cost-control weapons, and they have not forgotten how to negotiate lower fees for doctors and hospitals, argue over and delay payments or refuse to pay for certain treatments. And they continue to shift more costs to patients. Page A1.
 
Retail Sales Rose 2.9% in November
Warm weather put a damper on retail sales for much of November, but strong sales after Thanksgiving helped the nation's merchants. Sales in stores open a year rose 2.9 percent, and department and specialty stores did not do particularly well. For example, sales at Gap climbed just 1 percent. Its shares declined 87.5 cents, to $43.125. C2.
 
Nasdaq Increases 3% to a New High
The Nasdaq composite index rose 99.07 points, or 3 percent, to 3,452.78, a record. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 40.67 points, to 11,039.06, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 11.32 points, to 1,409.04. C8.
 
U.S. Hires Adviser in Microsoft Case
The Justice Department said that it had hired the investment bank Greenhill & Company to help determine the financial effect of various proposals for restructuring Microsoft. C2.
 
November Sales Rose 4.9% at Ford
A surprising 4.9 percent jump in car sales allowed Ford to post an unexpectedly strong November as the industry's sales of cars increased faster than those of high-profit sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and vans. C6.
 
Big Board Eliminates a Trading Rule
Directors of the New York Stock Exchange voted to eliminate a rule that bars brokerage members from trading some stocks away from the floor of an exchange. The move will open the door to additional competition. C8.
 
Fuji Stock Rises on Talks With G.M.
Shares of Fuji Heavy Industries surged 13 percent after Japan's leading business daily said the company, which makes Subaru cars, was in the final stages of negotiations to sell a 20 percent stake to General Motors. C4.
 
Ben & Jerry's Receives an Offer
Shares of Ben & Jerry's rose sharply after the company said it had received "indications of interest" to buy it for more than the $21 close on Wednesday. The stock finished up $3.6875, to $24.6875. Advertising. C7.
 
U.S. Suffers Setback at Trade Talks
The Clinton administration failed to rally broad support to add labor standards to the world trade agenda, threatening one of its goals for the meeting in Seattle. A1.
 
BMG Seeks to Close Country Label
BMG Entertainment is preparing to shut its 10-year-old country label, Arista Nashville, executives inside the company said. C7.
 
Amazon.com Wins a Patent Ruling
A federal judge has ordered Barnesandnoble.com to stop using a "one click ordering" system that Amazon.com patented. C24.

HEADLINE: Medical Insurers Revise Cost-Control Efforts

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Some of the nation's biggest insurance companies say they are changing their tactics as they face a surging backlash against managed care.
Hoping to blunt the attack in Congress and the states, which has upset investors and depressed stocks of managed care companies, some insurers have eliminated or cut back on unpopular rules. They no longer require prior approvals for diagnostic tests or admission to a hospital, or referrals by a gatekeeper doctor for consultations with specialists. 
 Employers and economists worry that relaxing these mainstays of cost restraint may unleash a new round of inflation; cost increases are already climbing into double-digits.
But the insurance companies still have powerful cost-control weapons, both old and new, including some that are resented by doctors, hospitals and patients. Among the most important is more pressure than ever on hospitals to send patients home as soon as possible. Insurers like Humana and Kaiser Permanente are paying doctors to take over patients' cases in hospitals with an eye toward speeding up care and blocking unnecessary tests. Empire Blue Cross and many other companies are also monitoring patients with serious illnesses more closely to avert the need for hospitalization or emergency room care.
The insurers are also trying to persuade doctors to practice the way the most effective doctors do. Companies like Aetna U.S. Healthcare and UnitedHealthcare provide computerized records that show doctors how they compare with peers around the country on everything from timely cancer screenings to flu shots.
Insurers like Aetna and Empire are also prodding doctors by sending them lists of patients due for a reminder that it is time for a test.
The insurers have not forgotten, of course, how to negotiate lower fees for doctors and hospitals, argue over and delay payments, or refuse to pay for certain treatments. And they continue to shift more costs to patients. For instance, most health plans have sharply raised the patient's share of drug costs to as much as 30 percent or 40 percent for some expensive drugs, from as little as no charge at all or $5 to $15 per prescription.
The companies have not jettisoned all their "mechanisms" for pressuring doctors and hospitals, said Woody Grossman, a health care expert in Dallas with the PricewaterhouseCoopers consulting firm. For example, he said, they may make public doctors' and medical groups' track records.
But insurers are emphasizing most that they are softening or eliminating several unpopular practices ushered in by managed care. The UnitedHealthcare Corporation, the second-largest health insurance company after Aetna Inc., announced last month that it was virtually ending the prior reviews of medical decisions, which physicians denounced as second-guessing. United said it had been approving 99 percent of the decisions anyway.
Health insurers around the country rushed out "me, too" statements. Most companies said they were already offering employers a choice of less restrictive plans while retaining the restrictions in other plans.
United said it was retraining 1,200 nurses who used to hold sway over approvals for most requests by physicians. To save on hospital costs and improve care, the nurses will track seriously ill patients, pressing hospitals to treat and discharge them promptly, and arranging follow-up care at home.
Many of the 49 state and regional Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans are making other changes that are intended to appeal to customers. "We will have all new products next year," said Bob Greczyn, president of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of North Carolina, the state's largest health insurance company.
To reduce the expense and annoyance of cumbersome paperwork, it is consolidating and shortening forms. One new program offers Blue Cross members 25 percent discounts on services like personal trainers, massage therapists and acupuncturists, with no insurance paperwork at all.
The North Carolina plan, like a number of big insurance companies, will routinely steer members with serious or chronic diseases into programs that remind them to take their medicines, eat and exercise appropriately and have checkups, again in an effort to keep them out of emergency rooms.
A number of big national managed care companies, including United, Aetna and Humana Inc., and Blue Cross plans in New York and California, are using advanced electronic software to track doctors and patients, based on information from claims for reimbursement.
Aetna and United, for example, give doctors periodic reports comparing them with similar doctors in their region. A United report in October on members treated by the Eagle Physicians group in Greensboro, N.C., showed 87 percent received a recommended blood pressure drug after congestive heart failure, up from 76 percent in January. That compared with 70 percent, on average, for similar primary care patients in North Carolina.
"It's a step in the right direction," said Dr. Jim Osborne, an internist who is treasurer of the Eagle group, which includes 50 doctors. Eagle posted the United results on its Internet site.
At Aetna, Richard Huber, the chief executive, said quarterly reports would be sent next year to 44,000 primary care groups, describing in detail how they compare with peers in dealing with heart, asthma and diabetes problems.
For heart patients, Aetna reports on 21 items like flu and pneumonia vaccinations, taking drugs that reduce cholesterol and blood pressure levels, visits to doctors and emergency rooms and feedback on whether patients were satisfied with the care.
"Giving physicians data showing the best practices is clearly superior to giving them a couple of extra dollars" in bonus money if they meet certain standards, said Dr. Dennis Tafflin, a family physician in Doylestown, Pa., whose four-doctor group has 3,300 Aetna patients.
For pressing problems like asthma, when an Aetna member buys an oral steroid, indicating a flareup, a nurse telephones the next morning to check on the person's condition. There may be a home visit and suggestions for care to make sure that the member does not end up in the hospital, said Dr. Carol Diamond, president of USQA, an Aetna unit.
Besides making greater use of data bases and information technology, the companies can still draw on older methods to get their way. "I don't believe you are going to lose cost control," said Joe Thompson, a vice president of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, which has 36,000 United States employees.
The insurance companies can still brandish their bargaining power, based on millions of members, to keep down payments to doctors and hospitals. And they still retain, although rarely use, the threat of rejecting doctors or institutions that object. Although some states restrict financial rewards for skimping on care, some companies still offer bonuses as rewards for desired behavior. In New York and a number of other states, some insurers reject hospital charges for days when patients had no treatments.
"We still have some companies that are fairly intrusive," who make it difficult to get a test done, said Dr. Hal Stoneking, an internist with Eagle Physicians in Greensboro. "Others have been user-friendly from the get-go."
Most companies still require prior approvals for expensive procedures like M.R.I. scans. Aetna requires approvals for about 20 procedures. Even United still requires approval for treatment of mental health conditions and alcohol and drug abuse.
Even when they drop prior approval, health plans still must be notified before expensive treatments. The plans hope that notification will have "a sentinel effect," reminding doctors of company guidelines. And, of course, they still review each case after the fact and refuse payment for procedures like cosmetic surgery that they do not cover.
Using another tactic, some insurers contract with doctors called hospitalists, who take over from a patient's primary physician while the patient is hospitalized. Managed care hospitalists work closely with company nurses to shorten hospital stays.
The hospitalist typically is in full charge of the patient, and some primary care doctors contend that the practice could jeopardize patients' long-term relationships with their doctors. But Humana says its hospitalists keep the primary doctors informed. Experts who have monitored the process say that any doubts about a hospitalist's medical decisions can be taken to the hospital's own reviewers by other doctors and nurses on the case.
Analysts said that by distancing themselves from medical decision making, the insurers may insulate themselves against medical malpractice lawsuits. But the backlash intensified last month as lawyers for health plan members filed the latest of at least 12 class-action lawsuits since early October. The suits essentially seek to force seven companies -- Aetna, the Cigna Corporation, Foundation Health Systems, United, Humana, Pacificare Health Systems and the Prudential unit of Aetna -- to eliminate financial incentives for restricting care.
Congress is also working on measures to rein in managed care companies, like a bill passed by the House this year that would allow patients to sue such companies. The issue will stay alive in the pre-election session next year. Without waiting, California and Georgia recently authorized lawsuits against the companies, following the example of Texas.
"The backlash against managed care is hard to reverse," said Katherine Swartz, an associate professor at the Harvard School of Public Health. She argued that the companies had lost the trust of consumers because they failed to keep "basic promises" to "deliver better quality medical care at lower prices."
Under the heading "The Death of Managed Care as We Know It," in a special issue of The Journal of Health Politics, Policy and Law, Professor Swartz said it might be that managed care organizations "inherently contain structural problems that make it impossible for consumers to trust physicians in managed care."

HEADLINE: Membership In Key Group Within U.N. Eludes Israel

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 2

 BODY:
A move to admit Israel to a group of European and other nations so it can take part more fully in United Nations activities seems to have stalled because the Europeans cannot muster a consensus, diplomats say.
Frozen out of its own regional group by Arab animosity, Israel is the only member barred from joining any other such group. The groups' purpose is to nominate countries and delegates to important positions within the organization, including the Security Council. Israel and the United States, backed by a media campaign and lobbying by the American Jewish Committee, had hoped to change that by the end of this General Assembly session. 
 "It's not a secret that there is not a consensus in the European Union now," said Marjatta Rasi, Finland's United Nations representative, who has led the European Union's contingent here for the last six months.
Last Friday, when European Union political officials met to try to reach consensus, Spain balked. In earlier discussions Ireland and Italy had reservations, diplomats say. Under European Union rules, all members must agree. Other members are Norway, Canada, New Zealand, Australia, Iceland and Turkey.
Some members are concerned about another country's name on lists already too long to ensure that every country gets a chance to serve in coveted positions. Diplomats said that Israel could be asked to forgo claims on some nominations -- the Security Council first of all.
Kenneth Bandler, spokesman for the American Jewish Committee, said today that his organization opposed such compromises. Israel, he said, should have equal right to vie for seats on the Security Council, the Economic and Social Council and the World Court, among other bodies.
"Our principal concern today is that the European Union reach consensus on giving Israel, on a temporary basis, full membership in Weog," Mr. Bandler said in an interview, using the acronym for the Western European and Others Group. By that, he said, the panel means the right to compete across the board "just like any other member of a regional group, any other member of the United Nations."
Israel has never been accepted by the Asian regional group, which includes the Middle East. Israeli estrangement from the United Nations was at its most complete in 1975, when the General Assembly voted to list Zionism as a form of racism.
But since the end of the cold war Israel's position has improved. In 1991, during the Bush administration, the United States was able to muster the General Assembly votes to strike down the resolution on Zionism. The revival of peace talks under the government of Ehud Barak has added good will.
Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States representative to the United Nations, raised the issue when he took over here in late summer.
Until last week Israel's supporters thought the tide had turned. But the Europeans' inability to reach a consensus last Friday in Brussels has set back those hopes.

HEADLINE: Relocation Begins for Crash Site Residents

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Dec. 2

 BODY:
City and county officials today began relocating residents who did not want to return to their Kent Street neighborhood, where a small plane crashed last Friday morning, killing all 3 passengers and injuring 25 people on the ground.
At the same time, officials of the National Transportation Safety Board, which is investigating the crash, began analyzing the single-engine Beech Bonanza's three gyroscopes, which were retrieved from the scattered debris. Transcripts of radio transmissions between the pilot, Itzhak Jacoby, and air traffic controllers show that he speculated that water got into his gyroscope just five minutes into the flight from Linden Airport to Dulles International Airport outside Washington. 
 Thirty Kent Street families have asked to be relocated, although officials estimate that only 11 of their homes are no longer habitable. At least two families had met city and county welfare requirements that would allow them into other apartments immediately. They have been living in temporary quarters at hotels or with relatives. Essex County welfare officials said that they had authorized a furniture allocation for one family and expected delivery within two days.
Newark's mayor, Sharpe James, said that the city had apartments available at five locations and that city workers had been taking victims of the crash to look at them.
Today, he showed off newly painted apartments in a city-owned building that had been scheduled to be auctioned. He said that he had removed the building from the auction and directed city workers to get it ready as an emergency housing resource.
The mayor said that the city's welfare office was ready to help some people immediately with rent and relocation assistance, but that office handles only the cases of single, unemployed people. Those who qualify for that program or who receive disability payments would qualify immediately for housing.
Others who qualify immediately for relocation aid are families in welfare programs administered by the county and state governments and financed in part by the federal government, said James J. Williams, director of the county division of welfare. Under that program, families can receive security deposits and up to $300 a month in rent assistance for a year.
All others, including working families without money for new furniture, rent and security payments and single people not receiving welfare, face a longer wait, perhaps three weeks, while they apply for the programs.
Mayor James said that many of those seeking relocation were not displaced by damage to their homes and apartments, but felt traumatized and did not want to remain or were seeking to upgrade their living conditions.
"We expect some opportunism," he said, "but we are addressing everyone up there as a victim and we are not debating the merits of their claims." He said priority would be given to those whose former homes were no longer habitable.
Across town as he showed off apartments at 374 Hillside Avenue, Mayor James renewed his criticism of the state for failing to declare the neighborhood where the plane crashed a disaster area, which would have freed money for cash payments for everyone.
For Rosella Reese, 84, today marked her return to the 27 Kent Street house where she has lived for 45 years and which she said was the only place she wanted to be. Standing in her cluttered living room, which looks out onto the site of the spot where the small plane hit before careering down Kent Street, setting cars ablaze, she pointed to the new windows that city workers had put in to replace those shattered and blown out by the radiating impact of the crash. She was also provided with two portable heaters with the help of city officials.
"I didn't want to get relocated because I had a hard enough time getting here," Mrs. Reese said, recalling the struggle that she and her late husband and six sons had scraping together the money to buy the two-story yellow frame house in 1954. "I'm not traumatized and I'm not worried about the neighborhood. I'll be the same."

HEADLINE: TALKS AND TURMOIL: NEWS ANALYSIS;
After Clinton's Push, Questions About Motive

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The rebellion that is getting all the attention here is the one that is happening on the streets, as protest groups who argue vociferously with each other about what's wrong with the global economy march together to insist that the system must change.
But an equally fascinating struggle is happening six floors up, in the convention center where President Clinton made a last appeal today to the representatives of the 135 nations gathered here. It is a struggle over how much influence the United States should have in rewriting the rules of the global economy. In those negotiations, the protests are fueled by suspicions that what's going on is an effort to tailor the global trading system to America's competitive strengths and Vice President Al Gore's campaign needs. 
 Mr. Clinton used his appearances to contend that developing countries can have it both ways. They can pay workers more and allow them to unionize, he said, or keep from spewing more pollutants into the air and water, without sacrificing economic growth. "I don't know if I've persuaded many of you," he said.
By all appearances, he has not persuaded many. The pervasive sense in the hallways here is that Mr. Clinton is making a shrewd calculation about how to protect two vital constituencies for Mr. Gore -- labor unions and environmental groups -- that have felt angry and alienated since the signing of the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993.
Talk to the Indians or the French or the Japanese, and all say the same thing: behind the high-minded statements, the United States is hoping to seize an astounding moment of American power to satisfy powerful domestic constituencies. Why else, some have asked, would the United States insist that all e-commerce remain tariff-free? "Because you are the Microsoft economy," said one Japanese negotiator, referring to Seattle's hometown team.
And why else would the United States refuse to discuss its powerful antidumping laws as part of the negotiations, while insisting that labor and the environment be on the agenda? Because American labor unions demand that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore preserve the most potent weapon in its trade arsenal, diplomats from China and Eastern Europe say.
The United States seems intent on preserving its unilateral power to slap huge tariffs on imports that underprice similar goods made by American steelmakers or auto companies, they say.
And if you ask the smaller countries how the game is being played in Seattle, they contend that Mr. Clinton is trying to tilt the very playing field that he insists he is trying to level.
"They have continued with the old GATT way of doing business," said Victor Manuel, the trade representative of El Salvador, referring to the group that preceded the World Trade Organization and was dominated by the United States. "They think they can meet in small gatherings and then announce that the two or three most important countries have already come to a consensus. It is very hard for small countries to have any influence on the process."
Charges of American bullying are as old as international trade negotiations. They are also tactically useful. Countries that are as divided as the protesters outside can unify behind distaste for American power.
But the Seattle negotiations reveal that the suspicion about American motives has hardened, and the sound of presidential primaries in the background only fuels the skeptics.
Take Mr. Clinton's position on making labor rights a central part of the World Trade Organization's mission. Officially, the United States says it wants a "study group" within the W.T.O. that will examine questions like child labor, poor working conditions and perhaps even how much workers get paid for similar work in different countries.
India, Brazil, South Africa and other developing nations abhor the idea. A study group, they say, puts them on the slippery slope toward the day when the trade organization might impose trade sanctions against countries that it judges to be coming up short. And the system, they say, would be abused by the United States and other countries to do away with one big competitive advantage that the developing nations enjoy: the ability to pay workers less.
American officials have spent weeks trying to convince Asians, Africans and others that they have no such intent: the study group is there to study. Then Mr. Clinton stepped on their lines. In an interview with The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, published on the first day of the talks, he said the working group "should develop these core labor standards, and then they ought to be a part of every trade agreement, and ultimately I would favor a system in which sanctions would come for violating any provision of a trade agreement."
That confirmed the worst suspicions of many countries. A few reportedly threatened to walk out of the labor talks. Mr. Clinton's aides have spent the past day here backtracking, beginning sentences with phrases like, "What the President meant to convey was." The question is: Did Mr. Clinton's position harden perhaps to satisfy union leaders who are still fuming about letting China into the W.T.O. and are threatening to do little to help Mr. Gore, or was he just speaking carelessly?
Richard Feinberg, a former National Security Council official attending the meeting, said the president's comments on sanctions "undercut the position of his own negotiators."
"Clinton is spending an inordinate amount of his remaining political capital pushing this will-o'-the-wisp that his negotiating team told him is not obtainable," he added. "In balancing domestic and international concerns, he is clearly tilting very far in the domestic direction."
Even some of Mr. Clinton's toughest critics, though, say he is in an impossible situation: he needs to press a political agenda at home -- a pro-labor, pro-environment agenda -- that he cannot sell abroad.
"Personally, I thought he made a very good speech," said Francois Huwart, the French minister of trade, reflecting in an interview this afternoon on Mr. Clinton's contention that over time, countries with high labor and environmental standards will attract new investment and boost their productivity.
"But it is a speech," he said. "And you have to look closely at the negotiations. There may be a decalage between the way Mr. Clinton's speech sounds and the negotiations."

HEADLINE: Public Interests;
Flash-Frozen G.O.P.

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H.

 BODY:
The Republican presidential debate last night was awesome. George W. Bush chained himself to the podium to protest a rule banning use of consultants on stage, while Steve Forbes, who was dressed up as a giant turtle, attacked Captain Nemo's Fast Food Fish Fry restaurant in downtown Manchester . . .
Stopstopstopstop. Sorry, we've gotten the debate mixed up with the far more eventful World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle. All that excitement over something that used to be called GATT has given the presidential campaigns new hope. If people are taking a genuine interest in the W.T.O. today, perhaps tomorrow they'll become enthralled with John McCain's position on the Internet tax and Mr. Bush's plan for the Department of Education. 
 Mr. Bush seemed pretty confident as he faced off against Senator McCain, Mr. Forbes et al., considering this was only the third political debate of his entire life. Granted, the format was actually closer to a spelling bee. And granted, he might be well advised to quit bragging about the foreign-policy experience he got as governor of Texas. But Mr. Bush bore up bravely, even when Senator Orrin Hatch had the temerity to attack his Web page as "not user-friendly."
(Many of you have called to ask for tips on how to distinguish Mr. Forbes from Mr. Hatch, each of whom resembles an assistant principal in one of those high school high-jinks movies. The answer is that Mr. Forbes is the one who doesn't blink, while Mr. Hatch is the one who looks as if he just smelled something awful.)
Although Senator Hatch called the debate "kind of boring," it had its moments, the most hilarious of which was Mr. Hatch's own proposal that he and the other candidates all get on a bus together and spend two weeks traveling through Iowa and New Hampshire "like Lincoln and Douglas." Mr. Bush repeatedly demonstrated his incredible ability to respond to virtually any query by pointing out that he had been elected governor twice. It worked last night, even when the original question was what he reads. Unfortunately, Mr. Bush is the one candidate whom we need these debates in order to get to know better.
Senator McCain, like Al Gore, has become almost compulsively available -- he's done more than 50 town hall forums in New Hampshire alone. We will not even go into the other candidates. Express a little interest, and they'll not only answer questions, they'll come to your house and paint your kitchen.
In another primary milestone this week, the weather in New Hampshire has gotten extremely cold. That enables us to determine how many of the contenders plan to follow the old tradition, pioneered by John Kennedy, and demonstrate their toughness by dressing as if it's springtime in Los Angeles, even when the temperature is hovering around zero. "The report was that Kennedy had long underwear on, but he denied it," says Michael York, the state librarian.
Bill Bradley, ever the sartorial iconoclast, has already been spotted wearing a long dark-blue overcoat, although he has not gone so far as to put on a hat or gloves. A spokesman for Mr. McCain said the Arizona senator had a coat on hand, but had yet to actually wear it. Mr. Bush seems to be plowing yet another moderate path -- coat on, but unbuttoned.
This time of year, you always start worrying about the William Henry Harrison effect. Harrison, the Whig candidate for president in 1840, was troubled by talk that he was too old for the job -- or, as one newspaper put it, "a living mass of ruined matter." (Those were the days, people, when snippy columnists really knew how to snip.) In response, Harrison started demonstrating his youthful endurance by giving extremely long speeches -- although, of course, he was always careful never to say anything specific in them. He gave the longest speech of all at his inauguration, in the cold rain, thus proving his virility so conclusively he died a month later of pneumonia.
Nothing quite that bad -- or interesting -- has ever happened in New Hampshire, but this particular race is full of people from places like Texas and Arizona, so you always worry. Just as you wonder whether voter turnout would improve if the candidates started being tailed by hundreds of protesters dressed as endangered species.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Sales Begin at New Phase Of Hudson River Complex

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Sales are under way at the 134 condominium apartments and town houses that make up the first new phase of housing in a decade at Port Liberte, the luxury community on a slice of the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City.
The project now moving forward is a less elaborate version of the original, which was conceived during the mid-80's construction boom as a 125-acre village on Venetian-style canals. That plan was derailed by a subsequent recession and became a symbol of the real estate market's slide in the early 1990's. Only 363 of the 1,690 units proposed were built -- 189 of them completed and sold and 174 unsold and unfinished -- when construction halted in 1990. 
 The new units, with 800 to 2,700 square feet each, will be slightly smaller than the earlier ones, but will have the same brick and stucco exteriors, gabled roof and views of the Statue of Liberty and the Manhattan skyline. Plans to complete what had been planned as 2 1/2 miles of canals have been scrapped -- half a mile was completed in the earlier phase -- but an 18-hole golf course, a first for Jersey City, is to be added.
In the month since sales began, contracts have been signed for 40 of the one- to three-bedroom units, said David B. Barry, a senior vice president at the Applied Companies of Hoboken, N.J., the developer that took over the project in 1994, three years after the original developer went bankrupt.
Mr. Barry said prices for the units, most with garages and some of the larger ones with dens, are $180,000 to $650,000, or an average of $225 a square foot, compared with the $200 a square foot buyers paid for the original units. Over the years, Mr. Barry said, the value of the original units dropped by as much as half before rebounding.
Bernard Hartnett, president of the Port Liberte Homeowners Association, said of the project's seesawing fortunes, "From where we were, in the pit, we've come back pretty well."
He said he had paid $360,000 for his two-bedroom, 1,700 square foot duplex with harbor views in 1988 and would have been lucky to sell it for $200,000 when the market, and the project, collapsed. Today, based on sales of the original units at the complex in the last six months, he estimates he would be able to sell his unit for about $450,000.
Most residents, he added, knew there would be changes, particularly to the canals, which he said were "extraordinarily expensive and probably the sinkhole" of the first phase, when construction resumed.
Applied paid $9 million in 1994 to take over the unfinished portion of the project from its lenders after the original developer, Port Liberte Partners, went bankrupt.
The partners, including Tex McCrary, the onetime TV personality, and Francois Spoerry, a French architect, unsuccessfully tried to adapt Mr. Spoerry's concept at Port Grimaud, a waterfront project in St.-Tropez, France.
By 1996, Applied had completed and sold the 174 unfinished units in the first phase of the project. The next year, it acquired the rest of the project for $7 million, reduced it by 37 units to a total of 1,290, and substituted the planned golf course for the canals.
The course will straddle part of the existing Port Liberte site and 80 adjacent acres, once an oil-tank farm, and will be developed by Applied and the partnership that owns the former oil facility, Lasmo Petroleum Inc., the United States arm of the London-based Lasmo P.L.C., and the Pittston Company of Richmond, Va.
With the golf course, "the project gets more open space and an amenity that will be used more by residents and will add more value to the community," he said. But, he added, "we never wavered from proceeding with the project as a luxury condominium, because we think there is a market for such units."
The project's new phase reflects the second wave of development along the Hudson's west bank since the 1991-92 recession. Most of the projects in this cycle, which resumed in mid-1995, are luxury rentals, for which financing is more readily available than for condominiums, said Robert Antonicello, president of the ACI Group, a real estate services firm in Jersey City.
With the economy strong and rental rates rising, "there is a market for waterside condominiums, and demand exceeds the supply," he said.
In addition to the revived Port Liberte, a few new condominium developments are being built by K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, N.J., which has sold all but six of the 274 such units it is developing in West New York at an average price of $450,000. The firm is now building 18 more expensive units, as well as 154 additional units in adjacent Guttenberg. In Hoboken, Applied is constructing a 170-unit condominium as part of its Shipyard project, which eventually will contain 1,160 mostly rental as well as condominium units.
More condominium projects are planned along the waterfront. One is a three-building, 330-unit complex in West New York that Roseland Property Company of Short Hills, N.J., will build in phases, with the first 100-unit building to start this spring.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-20
 
Northern Ireland Begins New Era of Self-Rule
Northern Ireland gained the right to be master of its political fate, no longer ruled directly from London or subject to the territorial claims of Dublin. Under the April 1998 peace agreement that went into effect, home-rule powers moved from London to Belfast, the Republic of Ireland struck from its constitution the wish to include the North, and Protestant and Catholic rivals in the North exercised authority in government jointly for the first time. A1 

W.T.O. Rebuffs U.S. on Labor
The United States failed to rally broad support for adding labor standards to the world trade agenda, threatening the Clinton administration's most important goal for the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle. The administration struggled to eke out a compromise agreement that would set up a study group under W.T.O. auspices. A1
 
Clinton Seeks Opening to Iran
The White House has tried to achieve a politically risky opening to Iran before President Clinton leaves office, administration officials say, but all the efforts have been rebuffed. Still, a seemingly more open attitude toward the West by Iran's reformist president, Mohammad Khatami, has convinced the White House that Mr. Clinton has a political opening, if a narrow one, to turn the tide on 20 years of acrimony and failed relations with Iran. A1
 
U.S. Warning on Nuclear Threat
Defense Secretary William S. Cohen tried to convince Europeans during a meeting at NATO headquarters that Europe as well as the United States would face a threat to security if North Korea, Iran or other nations continued developing or acquiring nuclear missiles. A20
 
Russians Advance in Chechnya
Russian commanders said their troops had encircled the strategic town Argun, six miles east of Grozny, the capital of Chechnya. Each side has suffered casualties during the battle for Argun, the officials said, but they denied Chechen assertions that as many as 150 Russian troops had been killed or wounded. A6
 
U.N. Meeting on Cyprus
The leaders of the partitioned island arrived in New York to begin what Secretary General Kofi Annan hopes will be the beginning of a lengthy but final process of reconciling Greek and Turkish Cypriot factions. The Cyprus issue, which has been on the United Nations agenda since 1964, is a stumbling block to the entry of both the Mediterranean island and Turkey to the European Union. A11
 
Chernobyl Reactor Shut Down
The only working reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant has been shut down because of a leak in a water pipe, officials said, asserting that there had been no leaks of radiation. A6
 
World Briefing A8
 
NATIONAL A22-29
 
Bush Takes Stage To Debate G.O.P. Rivals
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas joined five rivals for the Republican presidential nomination for the first time in a debate. During the 90-minute forum in Manchester, N.H., Mr. Bush, seeking to preserve his status as the front-runner against a strong challenge in New Hampshire by Senator John McCain, presented himself as the one Republican candidate with experience as a chief executive and who best knows how to lead. A1
 
Bradley's Rebuttal to Gore
Former Senator Bill Bradley accused Vice President Al Gore of distorting his record on health care and Social Security, asserting that Mr. Gore was trying to divide the Democratic Party "to score a few political points" in his quest for the presidential nomination. A29
 
King Memorial Site Approved
The National Capital Planning Commission unanimously approved a four-acre site on the shores of the Tidal Basin, and between memorials to Jefferson and Lincoln, for a memorial in Washington to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. A competition will be held to choose a design. A22
 
Standards for Bunk Beds
The Consumer Product Safety Commission approved mandatory safety standards for children's bunk beds, eight years after voluntary standards for manufacturers took effect. Hundreds of thousands of the beds have been recalled because of concerns that children could get their heads caught and choke. A26
 
Nuclear Lab Policy Criticized
A committee of the National Academy of Sciences, the nation's top scientific advisory group, has criticized a federal crackdown on visits by foreign scientists to the nation's nuclear weapons laboratories, saying worries about security must be balanced by the benefits of the visits. A29
 
Greenpeace Board Resigns
The board of Greenpeace U.S.A, the American arm of the feisty but troubled environmental group, is resigning over what the chairman says are irreconcilable divisions over how to improve the group's internal workings. It is the second time in two years the group has had its board resign. A29
 
Sergeant Demoted in Sex Case
The Army demoted a drill sergeant to private, stripped him of his pay and pension and sentenced him to 44 months in prison for making sexual advances to women in his training platoons at Fort Jackson, S.C. A26
 
Miami Herald Names Editor
The Miami Herald ended a six-month search for a new editor with the announcement that Martin D. Baron, the night editor at The New York Times, would become executive editor on Jan. 1. Mr. Baron's post at The Times will be filled by Craig R. Whitney, a former foreign editor and longtime foreign correspondent who most recently was Paris bureau chief. A29
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-26
 
Federal Jury on Long Island Convicts G.O.P. Ex-Official
John Powell, 39, a former leader of the Suffolk County Republican Party and once a rising star in the state party, was found guilty of conspiracy and extortion in a bribery case. B1

HEADLINE: TALKS AND TURMOIL: WORKERS' RIGHTS;
U.S. EFFORT TO ADD LABOR STANDARDS TO AGENDA FAILS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The Clinton administration failed today to rally broad support among nations to add labor standards to the World Trade Organization agenda, threatening its most important goal at a meeting here that has been plagued by sometimes violent protests.
Caught between clashing demands of poor nations and the American labor movement, the administration struggled to work out a compromise that would have the trade organization set up a study group on labor standards. Such a move is widely seen as a first step toward having the body consider issues like child labor and workers' rights when setting trade rules. 
 But the negotiations, never easy, stumbled badly after President Clinton stunned the delegates, and even his own negotiators, when he told The Seattle Post-Intelligencer this week that the trade group should at some point use sanctions to enforce core labor rights around the world.
His suggestion went well beyond the official administration line that it was pushing members of the trade organization merely to set up a study group on labor issues -- not to punish countries that do not live up to the Western ideas of labor rights.
The president ended his day-and-a-half visit here and left Seattle today. The meeting is scheduled to end on Friday afternoon.
The Egyptian trade minister, Youssef Boutros-Ghali, said the proposal on sanctions derailed any hope of a compromise agreement on the issue. "If you start using trade as a lever to implement nontrade related issues," Mr. Boutros-Ghali said, "that will be the end of the multilateral trading system, maybe not this year, but in 10 to 15 years."
A trade minister from Pakistan, discussing labor issues at a negotiating session today, used blunt language on the matter, according to one Western official who was briefed on the meeting. "We will block consensus on every issue if the United States proposal goes ahead," the official quoted the Pakistani minister as saying. "We will explode the meeting."
Administration officials spent much of the day seeking to calm the storm that Mr. Clinton's comments had produced. Officials said they were looking to assure other countries that his use of the word sanctions did not amount to a mandate for the trade group to dictate labor standards or to punish countries that failed to live up to them.
"There's no question that our effort to have a working group of trade and labor is a tough fight, and one that has required us to do significant amounts of outreach to try to explain what the intent and purpose of this is," said Gene Sperling, the president's economic adviser. "By no means would we ever want something dealing with core labor standards to ever be used as a facade or guise to do anything that would be harmful to developing countries."
The American labor movement's campaign to link trade rules with workers' rights has emerged as a pivotal issue at the ministerial meeting of the trade organization here, where 135 nations are wrangling over a multitude of issues like biotechnology and subsidies for farm exports.
The meeting has been the target of thousands of protesters, who have demanded that the trade group do more to protect the environment and the interests of workers. The protests, which were marred by an outbreak of violence on Tuesday, dwindled today. But opponents of the group marched on the King County Jail this afternoon to demand the release of 500 people who were arrested as the police sought to restore order to downtown.
Mr. Clinton signed a treaty today that bars the most abusive forms of child labor, including the use of children as indentured laborers or in prostitution, mines and armies. Mr. Clinton said the treaty should be a model for enforcing other labor rights.
The European Union trade minister, Pascal Lamy, voiced concern that there was so much friction at the talks that they could fall apart without fulfilling the goal of setting up an agenda for a fresh round of talks, tentatively dubbed the Millennium Round, that would last for three years and aim at further reducing trade barriers.
The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, was far more upbeat, saying the talks were moving steadily forward. She said that progress had been made on a range of issues and that she remained optimistic that members would agree to a negotiating framework for the future talks.
Angering many developing countries, the American labor movement has pressed the Clinton administration to make the World Trade Organization allow members to impose trade sanctions on other nations that violate basic workers' rights like prohibitions on child labor and the right to form trade unions.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O., already upset at Mr. Clinton over his trade deal with China, pressed him fiercely this week to gain an agreement that could ultimately lead to letting trade sanctions be used against countries that violate basic workers' rights.
The thousands of protesters who paralyzed Seattle this week have also pressed the administration to use the talks to make W.T.O. rules what they consider friendlier to labor, human rights and the environment.
But India, Brazil and Egypt, taking the lead for the developing world, sought to block the creation of a panel that could lead to trade sanctions over labor rights. Many ministers from developing countries said such sanctions could be disguised protectionist measures that would be used to ban imports from developing countries.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali attacked Mr. Clinton's call to link trade with labor rights. "It is nonsensical," he said. "The question is why all of a sudden, when third world labor has proved to be competitive, why do industrial countries start feeling concerned about our workers? When all of a sudden there is a concern about the welfare of our workers, it is suspicious."
Administration officials suggested gingerly that they might move toward a compromise European Union proposal that would set up a group outside the World Trade Organization to study the link between trade and labor rights.
Opposing such a compromise, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., John Sweeney, insisted at a private meeting with Mr. Clinton that any working group should make its recommendations directly to the World Trade Organization.
Mr. Sweeney's approach, union officials say, would accelerate the timetable for the trade group to adopt enforceable labor rights. "I reiterated to the president how important it was to get these things in our trade agreements," Mr. Sweeney said in an interview. "The president says he's all for it. But he said he's having a tough time with the developing countries."
White House officials fear that if they disappoint American labor, that could badly hurt Vice President Al Gore, who is counting on unions' support in his campaign for the presidency. Mr. Sweeney indicated that if disappointed, the unions would redouble their efforts to press Congress to defeat the president's trade pact with China.
Several trade officials said Mr. Clinton clearly intended to soften developing countries' opposition to an accord on labor rights by granting them two large concessions on Wednesday. He announced that the United States would cut tariffs on developing world exports and would ease patent rules to enable developing countries to buy pharmaceuticals more cheaply.
But the administration was still having trouble having the developing countries agree to a panel that makes recommendations to the Word Trade Organization.
The trade minister of Kenya, Nicholas Biwott, said, "The best forum to deal with such matters is the International Labor Organization." That organization is an international body under the United Nations that researches labor issues and promotes workers' rights, but has minimal enforcement powers.
For years, labor leaders around the world have complained that the I.L.O. is a toothless, underfinanced agency unable to stop child labor and to protect other rights.
The European Union has proposed setting up a forum in which the World Trade Organization, the International Labor Organization, the International Monetary Fund and multilateral groups examine how globalized trade affects workers around the world.
America's organized labor, which is critical to Mr. Gore's political future, wants any such group to be a part of the World Trade Organization. "We don't care what it's called," Mr. Sweeney said. "You can call it anything you want, so long as it is done the way we want and is part of the W.T.O."

HEADLINE: Indictments Describe Reach of New Jersey Crime Family

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER 

 BODY:
New Jersey's most powerful organized crime family has broadened its reach into New York City, working with four local Mafia families to carry out murder, truck hijackings and other crimes over the last 10 years, the authorities said yesterday.
The accusations came as federal prosecutors in Manhattan unsealed indictments charging 39 people, 15 of whom were said to be members or associates of the New Jersey organization, the DeCavalcante crime family. 
 Ten other defendants were described by officials as linked to the Gambino, Bonanno, Colombo and Luchese families in New York.
The charges were the first major prosecution of the New York faction of the DeCavalcantes, said Mary Jo White, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Ms. White said the impact of the case should be to "significantly disrupt and weaken the hierarchy of the DeCavalcante family itself, and to effectively decimate" its presence in New York City.
The crime family, which until now has been "virtually untouched" in New York, as Police Commissioner Howard Safir put it yesterday, is based in Elizabeth, N.J., but has had a historic alliance with the Gambino family in New York.
A Federal Bureau of Investigation official said yesterday that the DeCavalcantes have about 75 so-called soldiers integrated into 5 crews, at least 2 of which are operating in New York City.
The family derives about 60 percent of its income from illegal activity in New York, and its members are "made," or formally accepted as members, by the Gambino family and report to it, the F.B.I. official said.
In announcing the charges yesterday, the officials made clear that despite the government's relentless pressure on the Mafia in recent years in New York, the predictions of its demise have been premature.
"This investigation confirms that those who declare the death of the mob do so at their own peril," said Lewis D. Schiliro, the assistant director of the F.B.I. in charge of its New York office.
Indeed, he and Ms. White said, the crime families have thrived over the decades, particularly in alliances and joint venture arrangements in their attempts to infiltrate and control both legal and illegal businesses.
"There is almost as long a history of interfamily negotiations and profit sharing as there is of conflict and bloodshed," Mr. Schiliro said.
Among those charged yesterday was Vincent Palermo, 54, whom officials described as an acting boss of the DeCavalcante family in charge of its operations in New York. The indictment said Mr. Palermo was also on a "ruling panel comprised of three high-ranking members," which had supervisory authority over the crime family's activities.
The charges against Mr. Palermo included racketeering, murder, extortion, loan-sharking and gambling, and Ms. White's office said that he was one of three defendants in the case who could face the death penalty, if prosecutors decided to seek it.
Mr. Schiliro said that the indictments were the culmination of a two-year investigation. Officials said 35 of the defendants were arrested yesterday in four states, including New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Nevada.
A federal magistrate judge, James C. Francis IV, ordered Mr. Palermo held without bond after a request by prosecutors last night, pending a bail hearing scheduled for Dec. 13.
Mr. Palermo's lawyer did not return a call left on his office answering machine last night.
The indictments, which totaled 76 pages, described a pattern of racketeering and other criminal activity by various defendants that dated back to 1989, and included one murder and two attempted murders, extortion and collection of loan-sharking debts from businesses, the attempted sale of counterfeit Tommy Hilfiger and Jordache goods, and a fraudulent stock scheme.
The stolen property ring's actions included the hijacking of a truck of refrigerated Kraft food, the indictment said, as well as the stealing of other truckloads of goods, including 2,250 cases of wine, 29,000 packages of Centrum vitamins, and 56 Minolta digital copiers and pallets of toner.
Prosecutors are seeking forfeiture to the United States government of $2.5 million in proceeds of the illegal activity, the indictment said.
Ms. White also announced that two other men had been indicted yesterday in a related case, the armed robbery of two Brink's security guards in January 1998 as they were delivering money to an office in the World Trade Center.
Officials would not elaborate on how the Brink's robbery was related to the organized crime indictments, except to say there was a connection. Three other men previously had been arrested in the robbery, in which about $1 million was taken.
One expert on the mob, James B. Jacobs, a law professor at New York University, said that the charges suggest that despite recent, widely publicized incursions into Wall Street and other legitimate businesses, most of the efforts of organized crime will continue to be centered in the black markets.
"The purging of the mob from the legitimate economy in many ways is easier to do," he said, "because these are all regulated industries."
"You can't really regulate people out of illegal activity," added Professor Jacobs, author of "Gotham Unbound: How New York City Was Liberated From the Grip of Organized Crime."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From New Hampshire Debate Involving G.O.P. Presidential Candidates

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from comments in the candidates forum last night in Manchester, N.H., involving Gary L. Bauer, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, Steve Forbes, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, Alan Keyes and Senator John McCain of Arizona, as recorded by The New York Times: 

Mr. McCain
 
Q. Senator McCain, in your home state of Arizona and in Washington, D.C., fellow Republicans make an issue of your temper. It is one thing to feel passionate about the issues, but why is it that those who know you best seem to like you the least? . . .
 
A. You know, a comment like that really makes me mad. The fact is I have very close and dear friends in Arizona and in the Senate and in the House and very dear friends all over America, I'm happy to say. Do I feel passionately about issues? Absolutely. When I see the Congress of the United States spend $6 billion on unnecessary, wasteful, pork-barrel spending and we have 12,000 enlisted families, brave men and women, on food stamps, yeah, I get angry.
And you know a lot of those young people have come up and said to me "Thanks for fighting for me." If everybody who wants the status quo in Washington wants that to remain so, then I'm not their guy. But I can assure you, Karen, that I'm going to change the status quo in Washington. We're going to rid the government of the special interests . . .
 
Mr. Forbes
 
Q. You've got an ad on the air now, quickly put together with a telephone call, in which you accuse Governor Bush of a betrayal on Social Security because he has considered raising the age. Is it fair to criticize someone simply for considering an option which is on nearly everybody's list of what to do about that program -- to call it a betrayal? . . .
 
A. It's typical of a political culture today to make promises and then break the promises. And Governor Bush, the other day on "Meet the Press," said he would consider raising the retirement age. It's already been raised from 65 to 67. That's a betrayal. Now what are they going to raise Governor -- 70, 75? That's not fair to the people. . . .
You know in politics, especially on Social Security -- where they've raised the retirement age, tax benefits, when they weren't supposed to -- you know that's code for we're going to do it. Guaranteed it's going to happen. And that's why the place to attack it and fight it is now. . . .
 
Mr. Bush
 
Q. I'm going to give you a chance to respond to that. Is this code for "We're going to do it"?
 
A. I was asked a question about my plans to make sure Social Security was safe and secure. I said we need to take all the payroll taxes aiming for Social Security and dedicate it to only Social Security. I said we need personal savings account for younger workers. But what I said on that show was that we're going to keep our solemn commitment to people who've retired and near retired as far as their benefits go. And they asked me about younger workers. I said, I hope we're able to keep the benefits the same for younger workers, as well. But the key thing is to have somebody who knows how to lead, to bring people together to solve the Social Security system. We need leadership in Washington, D.C., to make sure there is a sound Social Security system. . . .
 
Q. Governor you have said that you would always have people around you as president who would be able to fill in any gaps in your knowledge of the world and the players on the world stage. But let me ask you, do think that President Bush could've done the job he did in assembling and holding together the Gulf War coalition composed of many very varied nations, had he not had the knowledge of the world that he had from years of experience in diplomacy, in politics at the U.N.
 
A. In order to be a good president when it comes to foreign policy it requires someone with vision, judgment and leadership.
I've been the governor of the second biggest state in the United States. If it were a nation it would be the eleventh largest economy in the world. I was overwhelmingly re-elected because the people in my state realized I know how to lead and I've shown good judgment. . . .
There's only one person on this stage, only one person, who's been in a chief executive officer position in terms of government. That's me, governor of the second biggest state. I've had foreign policy as governor of Texas and that is with Mexico. And I've handled it well, I've got good relations with President Zedillo. I've built a -- I've built bridges of trust so that when we deal with problems, common problems, we can do so in the spirit of cooperation not a spirit of animosity.
 
Mr. Bauer
 
Q. If you could only do one thing as president, what would it be?
 
A. My goodness. What a great question. I'm tempted in a lot of different areas to answer that. Obviously, my strong position about the sanctity of life is something that I don't think we're going to get anything else right in America if we don't get this right. We've only made a mistake like this once before, Brit, and that was way back in the 1850's in the Dred Scott case when the Supreme Court, the highest court in the land, said that black men and women had no rights that the rest of us were bound to respect. And we look back on that and we're astonished that the court would say such a thing. The poison of that decision still keeps Americans apart today. . . .
 
Mr. Forbes
 
Q. Mr. Forbes, set aside your flat tax for the moment, if you would. What would you advocate, as President, to keep us away from inflation and out of economic recession?
 
A. Well, that's very easy, and that is to have a Federal Reserve that keeps the dollar sound. And unfortunately today, Karen, we have a Federal Reserve that is starting to tighten up, raise interest rates because of a bogus economic theory that says that prosperity causes inflation. So, unlike George Bush, I'm not sure I'm going to reappoint Alan Greenspan, if he's addicted to that theory. It's a destructive one. It has already done immense harm to agriculture in America. And if he continues in that course of action, it's going to do real harm to the economy. . . .
 
Mr. McCain
 
Q. Senator McCain, where do you come out on this question of this stock market as high as it is and on the issues that have just been asked of Mr. Forbes, relating to Mr. Greenspan, who seems at times alarmed by the level of the stock market. . . .
 
A. I share Mr. Greenspan's concern. And by the way, I would not only reappoint Mr. Greenspan; if Mr. Greenspan should happen to die, God forbid, I would do like they did in the movie "Weekend at Bernie's", I would prop him up and put a pair of dark glasses on him and keep him as long as we could. The fact is that Mr. Greenspan deserves great credit, great credit for this economic recovery. He's been a steady hand. He's unintelligible, but he's had a very steady hand on the tiller and I am a great admirer and an advocate of his policies and programs.
 
Mr. Hatch
 
Q. Senator Hatch, you have two minutes now for your closing statement. . . .
 
A. It seems to me that the way -- what we ought to really do is we ought to leave the entourage behind. We ought to get out there and understand that the American people, they want us as presidents for the good or the bad. They want us to be a good president during the good times, they want us to be able to help them during bad times. . . .
I just have a suggestion to all of us. Why don't we just take two weeks in the month of January and spend a week here in New Hampshire, a week in Iowa; get on a bus, all of us, leave the entourage behind, and just go throughout this state and meet with the people and let them set the standards, let them set the terms.
Do it in town meetings, and let them ask any questions they want and let's just respond to them. Let's kind of be like Lincoln and Douglas and really have a debate here rather than, you know, the stilted thing that we're doing.
The full text of the candidates forum is available from The New York Times on the Web: http://www.nytimes.com/politics

HEADLINE: Senate Republicans in Albany Propose Gradually Reducing State Utility Tax

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Setting the stage for what is likely to be a lively fight over enacting a new state budget next year, State Senate Republican leaders today proposed eliminating a tax on utility companies that adds several dollars a month to the average New Yorker's gas and electric bills.
The gross receipts tax, as it is known, has long been among the most unpopular taxes collected by the state. It is passed along by utility companies to consumers, increasing rates for residential customers as well as business owners, particularly those in industries that use a lot of electricity. 
 But the tax brings the state about $800 million a year, making many lawmakers reluctant to repeal it altogether because they worry that they will be forced to reduce important state services to make up for the lost tax revenues.
The Senate plan would gradually reduce the tax during the next three years, cutting state revenues by $710 million by 2003. Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader, said the plan would allow electric companies to reduce their rates and thereby make New York a more attractive place to live and do business.
"The gross receipts tax is a hidden tax on consumers and business, but its effects are quite clear: higher utility costs that make it more expensive to live and create jobs in New York State," Mr. Bruno said in a statement. He said the plan would bring New York's utility rates, among the highest in the nation, in line with those of other states.
The plan is the centerpiece of a wide-ranging package of tax cuts that Senate Republicans say they intend to push during the 2000 legislative session, which begins next month. Mr. Bruno's aides said he intended to release details of the Republicans' package over the next few weeks.
The Senate plan represents the opening bid in what is expected to be a lively debate over how to use a budget surplus that some estimate would total at least $2.5 billion when the state ends its fiscal year on March 31.
In the Legislature, the plan drew a tepid response from Democratic leaders, who said they intended to focus on financing for education, job creation programs and health care. Even the Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican who has championed tax cuts, declined to endorse the Senate plan. The state has cut taxes for the last five years, raising concern among independent fiscal monitors that the new multiyear tax reductions could hamper the state's ability to deliver services, particularly if there is an economic downturn.
In fact, Moody's Investors Service, one of Wall Street's major bond rating companies, released a report today showing that the state would face a $1.1 billion budget shortfall for the 2000-01 fiscal year. That figure, the report said, is expected to grow to $5.8 billion by the 2001-02 fiscal year, because state spending on multiyear tax cuts and other programs enacted in previous budgets is expected to outpace the state's revenues.
Even with that, there has been strong support across the state, particularly among business leaders, for eventually eliminating the gross receipts tax because power companies pass it directly to their customers, increasing the state's already high utility costs for the poor and the wealthy alike. The proposal has had substantial support on Long Island, where residents pay among the highest electric rates in the United States.
In recent years, lawmakers have reduced the surcharge on the gross receipts tax to 3.25 percent, from 4.25 percent. The Senate plan would eliminate the surcharge altogether, potentially passing on savings to consumers. For example, a person in New York City with a $1,377-a-year gas and electric bill would save about $55 once the tax was eliminated, according to Senate analysts.
Business leaders, who have long complained about the tax, praised the Senate's plan, saying it would encourage many companies to expand in New York. "Eliminating the gross receipts tax on electricity and gas would put a very positive jolt in New York's economic recovery," said Daniel B. Walsh, the president of the Business Council of New York State, a statewide chamber of commerce.
"Today's proposal," he added, "not only assails one of our most anticompetitive taxes, it also reminds us that we have started but not finished the job of tax reductions. The gross receipts tax is the major culprit in keeping New York's energy costs well above average."
