HEADLINE: FILM;
The Labor Pains Of a Leftist Musical In an Angry Era

BYLINE: By DAVID SCHIFF; David Schiff is a composer on the faculty of Reed College in Portland, Ore.

 BODY:
FOR the thousands who cheered it in the late 1930's, Marc Blitzstein's musical play "The Cradle Will Rock" blazed like a comet of hope in the dark Depression skies. The millennium was far away, but Armageddon was now. Germany was rearming, Mussolini had seized Ethiopia, and the Spanish Civil War seemed like a dress rehearsal for a final confrontation between Left and Right. The American economy was again on the slide, and labor strife across the country was taken as the beginnings of class warfare.
A series of razor-sharp satirical songs, "The Cradle Will Rock" presented these conflicts as a battle between the good of unionized labor and the corruption of everyone else. It opened on June 16, 1937, under circumstances so dramatic that Orson Welles, who had directed the production, later wrote a screenplay about the show's creation. But it was never filmed; and as times changed, "The Cradle" disappeared into the recesses of cultural outer space. 
 Tim Robbins, who has taken on politically charged subjects in his previous films "Dead Man Walking" and "Bob Roberts," brings Blitzstein's show back to life in his new movie, "Cradle Will Rock," opening on Friday. Not simply a cinematic rendering of Blitzstein's play, or the story of its premiere, the film is a panoramic view of New York in the Depression years, filled with such historical characters as Nelson Rockefeller, Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo, William Randolph Hearst, Margherita Sarfatti (Mussolini's former mistress who wrote pro-Fascist stories for Hearst) and the young Orson Welles, a fireball of theatrical energy. Mixing fact and fiction and blending the directorial styles of Welles and Preston Sturges, Mr. Robbins surrounds the story of the show's birth with a web of plot lines about artists and patrons and timeless questions of opportunism, compromise and integrity -- and just putting on a show.
Though his music is rarely performed today, Marc Blitzstein revolutionized American musical theater, and not just politically. Critics and composers have recognized that he created a new idiom, distinct from the Broadway musical and European opera. His style sprang from popular music yet kept a sharp edge of satire and psychological insight. In "The Cradle," he leans heavily on the manner of Kurt Weill (who referred to it, somewhat bitterly, as "my latest show"), but later he developed a lyrical, jazzy melodic style of his own. His influence has permeated the genre for the last 60 years, especially in the works of Leonard Bernstein.
In the film, Blitzstein, played by Hank Azaria, composes "The Cradle" as a man possessed. "I read that he worked in a state of white-hot inspiration," Mr. Robbins says, "and that gave me the image of Blitzstein's character." Indeed, driven by the political ideas of his wife, Eva Goldbeck, who died of anorexia in May 1936, and of Bertolt Brecht, Blitzstein wrote the words and music for "The Cradle" in just five weeks. A political soul-mate to the homosexual Blitzstein, Goldbeck had introduced the composer to Brecht's writings, and to Brecht. Before her death, the composer had played Brecht his song "Nickel Under the Foot" -- which tells of a woman forced by poverty into prostitution. According to Blitzstein's biographer, Eric Gordon, Brecht said, "Why don't you write a piece about all kinds of prostitution -- the press, the church, courts, the arts, the whole system?" Despondent after his wife's death, Blitzstein recalled Brecht's advice and feverishly set to work.
Beginning with "I'm Checking Home Now," sung by the Moll, a hungry prostitute, "The Cradle" goes on to skewer the hypocrisy of the Establishment of Steeltown U.S.A., which dances to the tune called by Mr. Mister, owner of the steel mill, and his overstuffed family. The preacher advocates peace or war depending on the price of steel, a journalist defends his antiunion distortions as "freedom of the press," a painter and violinist describe their dependence on Mrs. Mister's patronage as "art for art's sake," a doctor falsifies medical records to help the police, and a college president fires pacifists who will not endorse R.O.T.C. The two younger Misters fill their empty lives with marshmallow pop tunes. The only incorruptible character is Larry Foreman, a middle-class union supporter who rejects Mister's attempt at bribery and predicts the downfall of the social order and the coming triumph of unionism with the fiery anthem "The Cradle Will Rock."
Orson Welles and John Houseman, who had already directed and produced three shows for the Federal Theater Project, including an all-black "Macbeth" in Harlem, brought Blitzstein's musical to Hallie Flanagan, the project's head. She decided to present "The Cradle" even though she was under attack in Congress for promoting left-wing ideas. Citing Blitzstein's show as proof that the Federal Theater Project was fomenting revolution, Congress cut its funds by 30 percent. In the film, as in the actual hearings, congressmen brand Euripides and Christopher Marlowe as Communists.
THE day after the public dress rehearsal (with full orchestra and an elaborate set), the Works Progress Administration, the financing umbrella for the Theater Project, canceled "The Cradle" for lack of funds and padlocked the theater. Houseman quickly found an empty theater, the Venice, 20 blocks away. Word got out that the premiere would be moved, and the cast and an audience packed with union members -- Virgil Thomson wrote that the leftwing audience was "the most formidable army of ticket buyers in the world" -- walked uptown. One obstacle remained. Actors Equity and the Musicians Union would not let their members perform at the Venice.
Houseman and Welles explained the problem to the audience, and Blitzstein came out on a bare stage to narrate and sing his work at the piano. But as he began the Moll's song, Olive Stanton rose from the audience to play her role, soon followed by the rest of the cast, who were all seated in the theater and were risking their jobs with the Federal Theater by taking part. Art seemed to spring miraculously from life, and the evening ended with jubilation.
"I was less interested in the show," Mr. Robbins says, "than in the impact it had on people's lives, and the way it helped them understand the world around them." He centers his film on two of the actors in the show, the actual Olive Stanton, played by Emily Watson, and the fictional Aldo Silvano (John Turturro), an Italian-American anti-Fascist. Stanton, a homeless woman who had never been on stage before, found a job as a stagehand with the Federal Theater Project, then took possession of the role of the Moll as if it were her birthright.
Mr. Robbins says he invented fictions to connect facts: "Where there was an A and a C, I created a B." During rehearsals for "The Cradle," the film's Silvano, a struggling young actor, breaks with his parents because of their support of Mussolini. At the actual premiere, an audience member tore down the Italian Fascist flag hanging in the Venice Theater. Mr. Robbins gives that defining act to Silvano, who adds his own political passion to Larry Foreman's electrifying pro-union tirade. Performing in "The Cradle" despite the economic disaster sure to follow, Stanton and Silvano fuse their theatrical and political vocations.
Apiano on a bare stage and a cast emerging from the audience have become essential to performances of "The Cradle," even though Blitzstein had never imagined it that way. (For the film, David Robbins, the director's brother, has rescored the music for a klezmerish quintet.) Both Welles and Houseman later claimed that they had instructed the cast to create the illusion of a spontaneous performance. The movie script originally had Welles eloquently instructing the cast on how to make their entrances; but when he learned that members of the cast had recalled acting on their own, Mr. Robbins rewrote the scene as a spontaneous show of political courage.
As counterpoint to these stories of integrity, there are two subplots about treachery and self-betrayal: the story of the destruction of Diego Rivera's Rockefeller Center murals (which actually took place in 1934) and an account of the decline and fall of a fictional ventriloquist employed by the Theater Project. The young Nelson Rockefeller (John Cusack) commissioned Rivera (Ruben Blades) to paint a mural for the centerpiece of his family's contribution to the Manhattan skyline, after Picasso and Matisse had turned him down. When Rivera refused to remove the face of Lenin from the mural, "Man at the Crossroads," Rockefeller canceled the commission, paid Rivera handsomely and had the murals jack-hammered off the walls. The film shows Rockefeller announcing that from then on he would promote only nonpolitical art -- abstractions and nudes. It's a sly joke at the expense of the Museum of Modern Art, which was built with Rockefeller money and which still promotes an apolitical view of modernism as a series of aesthetic innovations.
Despite his credentials as a political filmmaker, Mr. Robbins has tried to balance political and nonpolitical characters in the film. "Welles didn't buy into the absolutism of politics," Mr. Robbins says. "He embraced celebrity and bacchanalia, arriving at the theater in an ambulance after partying all night in Harlem." The ventriloquist, played by Bill Murray, also seems to be non-political at first. But when he sides with the enemies of the Theater Project, his dummy turns on him, denounces his hypocrisy and dies. Mr. Robbins crosscuts the post-performance celebration for "The Cradle" with the dummy's funeral march. This slice of magic realism springs from fact. One of the Theater Projects's most successful productions was "Pinocchio." When Congress shut down the program in 1939, the cast placed the puppet in a coffin and marched up Broadway.
Blitzstein's musical play received accolades from critics spanning the political spectrum -- from The Daily Worker to Walter Winchell. The entire score was recorded -- the first original cast album of a Broadway musical (available now on a Pearl CD). Welles and Houseman went on to produce "The Cradle" on their own, touring steel towns and then returning to New York in January 1938 for a 13-week run. Productions popped up across the country, including one at Harvard, produced, directed and performed at the piano by the 20-year-old Leonard Bernstein.
Despite the avid support of Bernstein and Aaron Copland, Blitzstein became a neglected figure in the history of American music, remembered mainly as the translator of Brecht's "Three Penny Opera." His 1949 opera "Regina," based on Lillian Hellman's "Little Foxes," was praised after its premiere as "the most exciting music theater since 'Rosenkavalier.' " But it has yet to claim a place in the repertory. Blitzstein, who was murdered in 1964 at age 58 by three sailors he had met in a bar in Martinique, left three theater pieces incomplete, including an opera about Sacco and Vanzetti he was writing for the Metropolitan.
Blitzstein's work was always politically charged and far to the left, though the caricatures in "The Cradle" will not alarm anyone familiar with "The Simpsons." In both the "The Cradle" and Blitzstein's next musical play, "No for an Answer," he integrated dialogue and singing as no American had done before: the music continues the dramatic action so effectively that the audience barely notices the transitions from speech to song.
Blitzstein's shows may have languished and his hard line proved unpersuasive, but without "The Cradle Will Rock" there would have been no "On the Town," "Trouble in Tahiti," "Wonderful Town," "Candide" or "West Side Story." Indeed, two songs from "West Side Story" -- "Officer Krupke" and "A Boy Like That" -- are pure Blitzstein; "America" is Blitzstein plus Copland; and Bernstein even lifted the melody of "Maria" from "Regina." You can hear Blitzstein in Jud Fry's song, "Lonely Room," from "Oklahoma!" And Blitzstein's mordant, sleazy melodies are the models for "Cabaret" and "Sweeney Todd."
Free of the necessity (or even possibility) of producing hit tunes, and once again drawn to themes of social unrest, today's generation of music theater composers will find Blitzstein's work more relevant than ever -- even in the "miracle" economy of the late 90's. And so, Mr. Robbins hopes, will the movie audience. "They are still censoring art today," he says. "And there are still individuals who exercise their freedom of expression, and pay the price."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Compendium on Rents and Housing;
A Glitch Adds 250 Copies

 BODY:
Due to a perhaps fortunate glitch, a usually hard-to-get compendium of research on regulated rents, the city's economy and the housing market published by the New York City Rent Guidelines Board is a lot easier to come by this year -- and, for some buyers, cheaper.
"We printed 400 copies," said Anita Visser, the board's executive director, "but there was a slight glitch in the printing process -- a few pages in 250 of those 400 are a bit faded." 
 "But it's totally readable," Ms. Visser insisted.
And, she said, because "the printer kindly reprinted those 250" the board -- which annually sets rent-adjustment rates for the city's 1 million regulated apartments -- now has 650 copies of "Housing NYC: Rents, Markets and Trends '99."
The report includes research on regulated rents, owner revenues and costs, mortgages for multifamily buildings, tenant demographics, housing supply, wage rates by industry and unemployment. "Some of the tables go back as far as 1960," Ms. Visser said.
The "price for the perfect one," she said, is $23 plus tax, "but if someone wants a slightly irregular copy we'll sell them at $18."
Copies can be purchased at the Citystore, in the lobby of the Municipal Building at 1 Centre Street, or by calling (212) 669-8247.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Luxury Complexes Find Room at the Top

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
WHEN Jackie Cottrell's husband, Karl, a research engineer, was transferred two months ago from Rhode Island to Tarrytown, the couple didn't feel ready to purchase in Westchester. They decided to rent instead for a couple of years, see how the job worked out and how they liked the area.
"We're not ready to buy anything," Ms. Cottrell said. "Right now we're happy renting and are still trying to figure out the area and decide what to do next." The Cottrells now live in a one-bedroom apartment with a loft at Avalon Willow, a 144-unit luxury rental development in Mamaroneck. 
 Avalon Willow is representative of the kind of rentals now being built in the county. Started in 1998, it targets high-end customers who want amenities, such as a concierge desk, fitness center, and sometimes, if space permits, a pool. Rents for one-bedroom apartments range from $1,597 to $1,960 and $2,387 to $2,891 for two-bedroom units.
An additional 75 units are now in the final stages of construction at Avalon Willow. "We expect them to be ready for market by the spring or summer of next year," said Fred Harris, a vice president of development for Avalon Bay Communities, a real estate investment trust based in Alexandria, Va.
Avalon is by far the most active builder of rentals in Westchester, with three communities now operating in the county, and a fourth just starting construction in New Rochelle. "We're actively looking for more sites in southern Westchester now," Mr. Harris said. "We'd definitely be building more if the land were available."
Another developer, RFR/Davis, which has put up several residential buildings in Manhattan in recent years, is building an 88-unit luxury rental development called Rivervue near the Tuckahoe train station. Rents have not yet been set, said Trevor Davis, a principal of the development company.
Had the Cottrells been looking a few years ago, they would have found the rental market in Westchester practically nonexistent. "With the conversion of most of the apartment buildings into condominiums and co-ops during the 1980's, it left the rental market in negative production, especially at the upper end," said Mr. Harris. "And the kind of product we're offering just didn't exist."
The situation created a pent-up demand, according to Mr. Harris. "All of our projects have leased up quickly," he said, noting that most are near train stations for ease in commuting to midtown Manhattan as well as to White Plains or Stamford, Conn.
Last summer, in partnership with Collins Enterprises of Old Greenwich, Conn., Avalon Bay completed the Avalon, a 110-unit project in Bronxville directly across the street from the Metro-North train station. It is now fully leased, Mr. Harris said.
Rents range from $2,100 for a one-bedroom apartment to $5,000 for a three-bedroom duplex. Residents sign 15-month leases, Mr. Harris said. "Typically at the expiration of the lease, there are rent increases, based on what's happening in the market," he said. "Generally they keep pace with inflation, at around 3 to 4 percent."
FIFTY-NINE percent of Avalon residents in Bronxville commute to Manhattan, compared with 39 percent of Avalon Willow residents in Mamaroneck, according to Tracey Appelbaum, a senior development director for Avalon Bay Communities. Both projects are within walking distance to the Metro-North train stations.
"In Bronxville, around 12 percent of our residents are retirees," Ms. Appelbaum said. "That's higher than in many of our other projects. In Mamaroneck, there aren't as many retirees and more first-time Westchester residents, like the Cottrells."
Six months ago, Anita Judice and her husband, Peter, sold a house in Larchmont, "sort of on the spur of the moment," Ms. Judice said. "It just worked out that we had an opportunity to sell quickly and needed a transition," Ms. Judice said. The couple, with grown children in the area, decided to rent a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment at Avalon Willow.
They lived there for five months and have since moved, but still rent an apartment, in a prewar building in Larchmont. "We wanted to stay in the Village of Larchmont," Ms. Judice said. "But we're continuing to rent because we don't want to take care of anything after owning a house for so long. I guess we'll be renting until we get it out of our systems."
As for first-time householders, many choose rentals because, while they can afford higher-than-average rents, they don't have the money for a down payment on a house. "The down payments for houses can be prohibitive for a lot of people, even those making a good income," said Sharon Hart, an executive vice president for Summit Property Management of Valhalla, which operates two rental projects, Talleyrand Crescent in Tarrytown and Ridgeview in Elmsford.
THE majority of renters at Avalon's projects come from the local area, according to Ms. Appelbaum. In Bronxville, for instance, 17 percent come from within the Village of Bronxville, 30 percent from elsewhere in the county and 16 percent from New York City.
"The numbers vary a bit in our other projects," Ms. Appelbaum added, "but the markets we draw from are pretty consistent."
Susanna and John Le Boutillier moved to Avalon Willow last April after selling a co-op apartment in Manhattan. Ms. Le Boutillier said she sees living at the Willow "as an interim step, while we look for a house, which we're actively looking for now." The couple expects the process to take about the term of their lease, which is 15 months.
Rentals are also appealing to those on temporary work assignment, such as David Partridge, who develops business strategies for I.B.M. He and his wife, Diane, rent a one-bedroom at Avalon Willow. "We have no intention of making Westchester our permanent home," Mr. Partridge said. The couple still maintains its family home in Dover, Del. "It's a practical matter," Mr. Partridge said. "The company and I decided that renting was best for what will probably be a three-year stint at most."
While they may be transient, renters in Westchester can be extremely demanding, according to Ms. Hart. "They refuse to live anywhere more than six or seven years old," she said. "And they expect a great deal of service."
Avalon's renters in Westchester tend to be affluent, according to Ms. Appelbaum. "The average household income of our residents in Bronxville is $180,000," she said. "in Mamaroneck, it's $170,000."
Ms. Cottrell said she liked the sense of community that exists at Avalon Willow, where there are regular parties for the residents. "I've met a lot of interesting people at the parties," Ms. Cottrell said, "and they let you take home all the leftover food."

HEADLINE: Only Black Commissioner to Resign

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THE county's only black commissioner is resigning next month, prompting concern from some influential blacks that he is being unfairly forced out.
Larry Schwartz, chief adviser to County Executive Andrew J. Spano, confirmed that the transportation commissioner, Marvin V. Church, will leave his position in mid-January. 
 Asked why, he declined to say more. Mr. Church, on vacation, could not be reached for comment.
The confirmation of his resignation comes at a time when one of several employees of the Department of Transportation whose jobs are being eliminated in the proposed 2000 budget is contending, through his lawyer, "mismanagement and political patronage" in the department.
It was unclear whether the two developments were related, because Mr. Spano's office did not respond to several requests for information about the layoffs.
Andrea Stewart-Cousins, one of three black legislators on the County Board of Legislators, said Mr. Church's resignation took her by surprise and she questioned whether Mr. Church was being held to a higher standard of performance than other commissioners. "I certainly want to urge the Administration to search for quality people of minority backgrounds," she said.
M. Paul Redd Sr., the president, publisher and editor of The Westchester County Press, a weekly that focuses on news of interest to blacks, said in a front-page article last month, "It is not clear the real reason for Commissioner Church's resignation, since he apparently possessed the skills for transportation commissioner."
He went on to write: "Word of his resignation surfaced throughout Westchester and has made some leaders in the black community very unhappy. Some blacks feel we have not had enough people of color in commissioner or directorship positions and want Mr. Spano to address the issue of why Mr. Church has resigned."
The accusations of mismanagement and political patronage are included in a Nov. 18 letter to the Board of Legislators from Jonathan Lovett, a labor lawyer, who represents Terry Cameron, a transportation department employee.
Mr. Church, a Republican, was appointed transportation commissioner by Mr. Spano, a Democrat, in June 1998. The commissioner oversees the operations of the county's public bus system, transit services for the disabled and the county airport. The commissioner's salary is $104,370.
The resignation, coincidentally, leaves Mr. Redd's daughter, Paula Redd Zeman, the personnel officer, as the highest black-appointed official in the county government.
Mr. Church has worked in various government positions. He had served as Gov. George E. Pataki's regional director with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. Before that, he was appointed by William F. Weld, then governor of Massachusetts, as an associate commissioner of the Massachusetts State Highway Department.
The resignation leaves Mr. Spano with two openings in his cabinet. Dr. Harold N. Adel, who served as health commissioner for the last three years, has announced his retirement, effective Jan. 31. Mr. Spano announced that he was accepting that resignation "with deep regret." In contrast, there was no formal announcement of Mr. Church's resignation. DONNA GREENE

HEADLINE: Deregulation Ignites a Building Boom

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
AS the electric industry prepares for deregulation on Jan. 1, when many Connecticut residents will have as much choice in choosing their electric company as they do their telephone service, utility companies are rushing to put in power plants all around the state.
New natural gas-powered power plants have won state approval in Bridgeport, Meriden, Killingly and Oxford. There is an application pending on a plant in New Milford, and the Connecticut Siting Council expects applications soon from Wallingford, Haddam, South Norwalk and other towns. 
 Suddenly, Connecticut, dominated for generations by only two power companies, Northeast Utilities and United Illuminating, has become a hot electricity market. On Jan. 1, the two companies will stop selling power and instead will simply transmit the power that residents buy elsewhere (although both companies have formed subsidiaries that will still generate electricity). So others are clamoring to fill that void. And they expect it to be a profitable void to fill.
The state consumes about 30.6 million kilowatts of electricity a year, but experts predict that will rise to 39.1 million by 2018.
"In a nutshell, it's energy deregulation that's driving all the interest," said Janis G. Lipman, president of Towanic Energy, which has won approval to build a 512-megawatt plant in Oxford, where she expects to break ground early next year.
Oxford is welcoming the plant, as is Bridgeport, where developers proposed a 520-megawatt plant at the site where United Illuminating already operates three other power plants. But in other towns, plans to build the plants have been opposed by resident and environmental groups.
"The applications are very complicated, and the issues are generally very controversial, involving the environment, water use, noise and construction effects, traffic and fuel use," said Joel M. Rinebold, the executive director of the Siting Council. "People are going to be living with these plants for 30 or more years, so the council undertakes a very detailed analysis."
In Southington, neighbors turned out at state hearings to criticize plans for a 720-megawatt generating plant, and despite support from the local officials, including the Conservation Commission, Planning and Zoning Commission, and the City Council, the Siting Council rejected the plans.
"The Siting Council gave a variety of technical reasons for the decision, but I think the neighborhood opposition was the critical factor," said the Southington Town Manager, John Weichsel. "They were very organized, which made a big difference."
Mr. Rinebold, however, said the problems with that application went beyond the neighbor complaints.
"It was a combination of things, including the potential for fogging and steam plumes that could affect a residential community and an interstate highway, the fact that it was located on the Quinnipiac River flood plain and would have affected some wetlands, and the visibility of the plant," Mr. Rinebold said. "There was also concern about the location of the new gas pipeline and the electric transmission lines the plant would have needed."
In New Milford, a group known as Poweralert has been opposing the pending application for a 500-megawatt natural gas plant. Dr. Peter Orenski, a member of the group who spent 20 years helping Union Carbide win approval for chemical plants around the world, said much of the opposition stemmed from what he said was the unwillingness of the Sempra Energy Company to answer residents' questions.
"They simply refused to do the one job we asked them to do, which was to track the wind patterns so they could tell us what will happen to their 400 tons of emissions each year," Dr. Orenski said. Besides the environmental concerns, people were also worried about whether there would be a fire risk, and there were lingering questions about how much impact the plant's water use would have on groundwater sources, he said.
"The way to answer those questions would be to bring an engineer in, and say, 'here are the plants we operate, this is how we handle safety, and here is our operating record'," Dr. Orenski said. "They keep saying this is so much cleaner than coal plants, but it's not clean by comparison with what we have now, which is nothing."
William B. Keller, vice president for project development at Sempra Energy Resources, said the town's fire department had reviewed the plans for safety, the town did a $65,000 air quality study that found no problem and its health department had certified the plan as safe, and the local water authority had said water use would not be a problem. "There are a lot of independent third parties looking at this, and they have all said this will be clean and safe," Mr. Keller said. "It's not unusual for these projects to have opposition. But there's also a group, More Power To You, that has sprung up to support this proposal."
Kevin M. Case, executive director of the Farmington River Watershed Association, which was involved in the hearings on the 544-megawatt Meriden plant, said that in some cases the plants could be beneficial.
"We think in the big picture, their emissions are lower than a lot of the existing plants, they're much cheaper, and the impact on the environment should be reduced," he said.. "What we are starting to see is that some of these plants are re-using existing industrial sites, brownfield sites, which we think is wonderful. If you take a site that used to have a factory on it and re-use it for one of these natural gas plants, the impact is really minimal."
"The only issue in most of the cases is going to be the cooling water," Mr. Case said. "Gas plants can use 3 million or 4 million gallons of water a day for evaporative cooling, so our interest is, where is that water going to be coming from?"
Margery Winters, director of the Rivers Alliance of Connecticut, which intervened on the Meriden and Southington applications, is also a member of a State Rivers Advisory Committee that is looking at the issue of the diversion of water from rivers. Many rivers in the state already experience low flow during the dry months.
"If every business withdrew all the water from the rivers that they are registered to withdraw, some of our rivers would be running dry," Ms. Winters said. "We're not at that point yet, but it creates a difficult management situation."
Northeast Utilities has also intervened in the cases, although a spokesman, Frank J. Poirot, said it was only to make sure that the connections to the Connecticut power grid would be up to Northeast's standards.
"We don't have to go any further back than this past summer to realize that in Connecticut, we don't generate as much power as we consume," Mr. Poirot said. "More often than not, we're importing more power from out of state, and it would be a great help if these plants were running. If the market was so saturated these plants might exceed demand, we might have a different point of view on this, but that's not the case now, and our demand has been growing fairly steadily the last five or six years, so it's probably not going to be the case in the future."
The Connecticut Business and Industry Association has also issued a statement strongly backing the new power plants, not only because of the potential for cheaper power -- the association says power costs in Connecticut are 72 percent higher than the national average -- but for the reliability it will give to the power supply.
"Many of Connecticut's manufacturers are using extremely sensitive equipment with computer chips that require a consistent source of power to function properly," said John R. Rathgeber, executive vice president of the association. "Uncertainty about electrical capacity and reliability is a concern we now can address because of the change to a competitive electric marketplace."
In Killingly, most townspeople welcomed the late September ground-breaking for a 792-megawatt power plant on a 50-acre site in the town's industrial park, that will provide enough power for about 800,000 homes when it opens in 2001.
Elsie D. Bissette, the town's economic development coordinator, said Pacific Gas & Electric would provide about $50 million in taxes to the town over 20 years, plus $5 million during the two-year construction period. It will create 25 to 30 permanent jobs, and more important will be a steady, reliable source of inexpensive power that she hopes will draw more industry to town. In fact, the town is negotiating to buy 70 acres to expand the industrial park. The current owner, coincidentally, is Northeast Utilities.
"When P.G.& E. first came to town we had just lost about 650 jobs because of the closing of two major employers," Ms. Bissette said. "There was some discussion about the fact that they wanted to use 4 million to 6 million gallons of water a day, but then it became an air-cooled plant, which will cost them a little more, but it made a tremendous difference in the public reaction.
"They've been very proactive, willing to accommodate the concerns in town, so it has been a very good relationship," Ms. Bissette said.
Oxford's First Selectman, Paul T. Schreiber, said his town has had a similar experience. The town acquired 474 acres of industrially zoned property in 1997 in lieu of $2.1 million in back taxes. Towanic will build a 1.5 million road with all utilities to serve its property that will also open 34 industrial lots.
"So even before we start talking about the tax dollars they're going to pay, they're developing our industrial park for us," Mr. Schreiber said. "They're going to pay an average of $2.1 million a year in taxes, and it will give us the opportunity to build a high school and other public buildings that we've been putting off for years. This project means financial health for the town of Oxford."

HEADLINE: Volunteer Connections: Returning the Favor

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
BEFORE handing him their Christmas wish lists, children on the streets of New Rochelle often tug at Frank Carlson's red pants and remind him how good they have been. They do not know that in real life Mr. Carlson, 41, who donates time as a sidewalk Santa for the Volunteers of America, is a former resident of a halfway house for alcoholics who now wants to return a favor to society.
Similarly, many patients at the White Plains Hospital Center who love her gentle touch do not realize that Melita Loew, 69, a volunteer massage therapist, is coping with the death of her husband and discovering a new direction in life. 
 When Dr. Glen T. Nygreen, 81, a retired college administrator, organizes a book sale for the Scarsdale Congregational Church, what matters to his co-workers is his business acumen -- not his desire to continue being productive. The same holds true when Dr. Nygreen, a former vice president of Lehman College in the Bronx, serves on the board of directors of United Way of Westchester.
Mr. Carlson, Mrs. Loew and Dr. Nygreen are among a growing number of people who donate expertise and time to causes they espouse. The Points of Light Foundation, a nonprofit group in Washington and the leading organization for volunteering in the United States, says
109 million people -- the equivalent of 9 million full-time employees -- volunteered an estimated 19.9 billion hours last year, with the average volunteer contributing 3.5 hours a week.
And although volunteers are motivated by different reasons, they share common desires, said the organization, which was founded nine years ago.
The reasons for volunteering include a variety of personal benefits, the foundation said, with the top three being feeling compassion for those in need, having an interest in the activity or work and gaining a new perspective on things.
In the case of Mr. Carlson -- who now owns an ice supply company in the Bronx -- it was "a need to give something back to society," he said. "For so long, I took, and here was an opportunity for a second chance -- to return."
Or as Walter D. Hosp, the 41-year-old chief financial officer for the Ciba Specialty Chemicals Corporation in Tarrytown and a volunteer for United Way of Westchester and Putnam Counties, said, "When you donate your time, it affects your priorities and gives a realness to life."
Mrs. Loew said that volunteering had given her a feeling of accomplishment, "of still being connected."
And Dr. Nygreen weighed the economics of volunteering. "In many cases for nonprofits, the salary scales are so low that it's difficult to keep qualified staff," he said. "That's where someone at my point of life and with my experience fills a gap."
Ellen Del Colle, executive director of the Volunteer Center in White Plains, a clearinghouse since 1959 for volunteers in Westchester and Putnam Counties, observed that many nonprofit organizations by themselves could not generate sufficient funds to accomplish their goals without volunteers.
As part of Mr. Carlson's rehabilitation, he was assigned to a special school to learn how to be a Santa Claus and collect money for a Volunteers of America food program that gives $25 grocery store vouchers to needy families at this time of year.
Mrs. Loew is among what Tammy Mortensen, the director of volunteer services at White Plains Hospital Center, described as "a group of 300 people who are an essential part of running the hospital." Unable to find a job when her husband died two years ago, Mrs. Loew turned to the volunteer center at the 307-bed community hospital and is now booked five days a week, massaging new mothers with high blood pressure in the maternity ward and also working in the greenhouse at the Burke Rehabilitation Center in White Plains.
Dr. Nygreen, too, is fully occupied and almost as active, he said, as when he worked at Lehman College. "The only difference is I get to read the newspapers in the mornings these days instead of wedging them in later."
At the Volunteer Center, which serves about 1,400 nonprofit agencies, Mrs. Colle observed that many people "get hooked on volunteering."
Like many who donate their time to worthy causes, Mr. Hosp is not fussy about his volunteering activities, on which he spends nearly 10 hours a month. Working through United Way, he sometimes rakes leaves for a worthy cause, or serves spaghetti to hungry people, or serves as a member of the organization's finance committee.
At the Volunteer Center, which is the largest of its kind in the county, Mrs. Del Colle said 5,000 volunteers a year are assigned to hospitals, nursing homes, senior centers, food panties, museums and thrift shops.
She said the cast of volunteers is broad-ranging in both age and interests, with a 4-year-old girl folding napkins with her family at a Salvation Army soup kitchen in Westchester and a 98-year-old resident of a home for the elderly performing clerical tasks for a hospital and sewing for terminally ill patients at a nursing Home.
Among the other volunteering jobs available are driving patients undergoing chemotherapy, working in aviaries and taking birds and other animals to patients in nursing homes and hospitals and rocking young patients, like those at Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, to help them fall asleep at night.
Arthur Stein, a retired sales engineer, and his pet, Willett, a 2 1/2-year-old deaf Shetland sheepdog, travel to several area institutions, like the White Plains Hospital Center, to help comfort patients. The ill and disabled relate especially to the fact that Willett cannot hear, because as Mr. Stein of White Plains, observed: "Even though Willett has a disability, you'd never know it. Patients connect to the fact that he is happy despite his problems."
Despite the increasing need for volunteers, the Volunteer Center carefully screens all applicants, with many nonprofit organizations also requiring background checks for those who work with children and the elderly.
"We never want to make a mistake, a bad match," Mrs. Del Colle said.
In part, the increase in the popularity of volunteering is the result of growing community service requirements from schools that encourage students to make a contribution and from churches and synagogues that want confirmation and bar mitzvah students to do the same.
The youngsters working through the Volunteer Center have helped businesses create Web sites and have worked on computers, assisted at animal shelters and read mail and newspapers to people with failing eyesight, among other things.
"It has led to many warm relationships between the generations," Mrs. Del Colle said.
Clifford D. Schneider, regional director for the Mid-Hudson chapter of the Volunteers of America, said his organization places 130 volunteers a year in jobs. Some are relief workers for people caring for AIDS victims. Others -- "often former alumni of recovery programs," Mr. Schneider said -- help out at meetings for halfway house residents.
Despite the increasing interest, there are still too few volunteers to go around. "Around Christmastime, the ranks of volunteers increase, but not as much as we'd like," Mr. Schneider said, adding that there is a continuing need for people to relieve AIDS helpers, recreational workers and sidewalk Santas.
Founded in 1896, Volunteers of America provides shelter and housing for homeless people and families, services for troubled youths and treatment and recovery programs for alcoholics and drug abusers, among other things. In Westchester, Volunteers of America runs a 58-bed, 24-hour emergency shelter for homeless men at the County Airport in Harrison.
It also manages Crossroads, a 17-bed halfway house for men and women recovering from alcoholism, with a goal of preparing clients for independent living within three to nine months. In addition, it runs shelters in Yorktown and Valhalla for homeless single adults and couples.
Those interested in volunteering can approach individual agencies like Volunteers of America or clearinghouses like the Volunteer Center. Or they can try the Internet, which is fast becoming a source of referral services for volunteers.
E-volunteering, as it has been identified by philanthropic industry experts, accounted for about 1 million of the 109 millions of Americans who volunteered in 1998, according to a new study by Independent Sector, the Washington-based research organization that studies the nonprofit market.
A two-year-old online matchmaking service, volunteermatch.org, informs would-be volunteers of thousands of opportunities across the United States. Volunteermatch uses the Internet to help people nationwide find volunteer opportunities posted by local nonprofit and public sector organizations.
It works like this: type in your zip code, the number of miles you would be willing to travel and the field of work you are looking for -- like arts and culture, human and civil rights or sports and recreation, for example. And voila!
As an example, a search from postal zip code 10605 in White Plains, for a person willing to travel 10 miles to a volunteering position and eager to try a variety of jobs, yielded 10 possibilities. One could join the Prompters for productions at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College, become a mentor for the White Plains Youth Bureau, volunteer for the American Heart Association or become an assistant to Donald S. Tedesco, the elementary school teacher in Mamaroneck who recently won a Disney Teacher of the Year Award.

HEADLINE: A Locked-In Vancouver Is Bulging to the East

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING 

DATELINE: CHILLIWACK, B.C.

 BODY:
THE direction of growth in the metropolis of Vancouver has been governed by geography. It can't go west because of the Pacific Ocean, or north because of the mountains. It can't go too far south because of the United States boundary. So it has gone eastward, through the broad Fraser River Valley, and now it has reached Chilliwack 65 miles from downtown Vancouver, which is about as far as the growth can go.
Chilliwack is a picturesque farming community known for its corn and peas and its fast-running waters. Every year fishers stand elbow to elbow to catch salmon running in the Fraser and Vedder Rivers. But beyond Chilliwack the flat valley land disappears into the rugged western foothills of the Rocky Mountains, and development potential vanishes.
 "I'm here because most land elsewhere is taken up," said Rick Wellsby, one of a multitude of developers turning their sights toward Chilliwack, where there is plenty of available land. "People used to think an hour is a long commute. But if you're from Toronto, Seattle or Los Angeles, this is not the case today." 
 Three years ago, Mr. Wellsby built the Falls Golf and Country Club, with an 18-hole golf course, as the centerpiece of his development. He has a list of 900 people, especially golfers, interested in buying one of his 2,100 housing units, 75 percent of which will front on fairways. He has just reached agreement on sewer connections with the city, and construction of the housing is expected to begin early next year.
HOME builders have been active in Chilliwack since 1993 and have already constructed detached homes, town houses and apartments for about 15,000 residents, raising the city's population to 65,000. They are now attempting to fill the housing demand from an influx of new residents that could nearly double the population within 25 years.
 "To think we can stop growth is preposterous, so we must manage it well," said John Les, Mayor of Chilliwack. The city is under pressure because half of British Columbia's four million residents live in Greater Vancouver. Since 1990, some 400,000 people have moved there from other Canadian cities, Asia and the United States and planners are preparing for an additional million residents by 2021. Since 1994, $8 billion in housing has been built. (All figures are approximations in United States dollars, worth about $1.47 in Canadian dollars.)
Restricting Chilliwack's development is the fact that 70 percent of its 100 square miles is locked into farming. In 1973, the government created the Agricultural Land Reserve because the mountainous province was losing 18,000 acres of prime farmland a year to construction. In the Greater Vancouver region, 318,000 acres are protected and Chilliwack is the third largest farming center, with an agricultural revenue of $100 million a year, following neighboring Langley with $105 million and Abbotsford with $215 million.
 Chilliwack's remaining undeveloped flat land has been designated industrial for manufacturing and service industries as the city diversifies its economic base to provide jobs for residents. One of the latest companies to announce that it is moving into the city is Oak West Furniture, which plans to start building a $9 million plant early next year that will employ 50 people.
 The city is requiring new housing to be built on the only remaining land -- the steep sides of forested hills to the south of the valley that tower more than 800 feet above the valley floor, said Kim Fowler, Chilliwack's manager of development services. When fully developed the hillsides will be able to support a population in excess of 100,000, city officials say.
 Mr. Wellsby's Eastern Hillsides project, which will house 13,000 people, will be the latest in that effort. The company he heads as president, Blackburn Developments Ltd., amassed six forested properties covering 430 acres. Home buyers -- young families, retirees and golfers, about 60 percent of them from Greater Vancouver -- will be treated to a panorama of mountain peaks that form a backdrop to farms that dot the valley below.
 Mr. Wellsby expects his development will cost $400 million when completed in 15 years. His plans call for 300 detached homes, 600 town houses, 700 apartments and 500 time-share units in a resort hotel. Next year's first phase will consist of 60 single-family homes and 40 multifamily units. A lot on a fairway with a 3,000-square-foot house is expected to cost about $225,000. Town houses with 1,400 square feet are expected to start at $145,000 and range up to $240,000 for 3,300 square feet.
 Mr. Wellsby said a Chilliwack home was as much as 60 percent cheaper than one in Vancouver. City statistics indicate the average Chilliwack price of a house is $130,000 and the city's average annual household income is $40,000.
Chilliwack's first hillside neighborhood is Promontory, where there are 2,600 residents now and 7,000 are expected in a couple of years. At the Thom Creek Ranch subdivision, detached two-bedroom ranches with 1,326 square feet start at $110,000 and three-bedroom ranches with 2,268 square feet start at $150,000.
 Another hillside community, Chilliwack Mountain, now has 374 housing units and in 10 years is expected to have more than 1,100 units. City officials say they expect the neighborhood, which will have a future emphasis on town houses and multifamily development, to have 3,000 residents in a decade.
The city also plans to revitalize its aging downtown, where many buildings were erected a half century ago or longer. (Chilliwack has its roots in the 1860's when more than 30,000 prospectors passed through the pioneer farming enclave along the Fraser River on their way to the nearby Fraser River Canyon, where gold had been discovered.)
 In time, said Ms. Fowler, the manager of development services, older downtown buildings will be torn down and high density multifamily housing will spring up there.
 A crucial element in this urban renewal plan was the selection in September of RG Properties of Vancouver as developer of a $40 million project on city-owned land that will include a hotel, convention center, swimming pool complex and an arena with 5,000 seats for rodeos, rock concerts and sporting events. The project will be adjacent to the downtown on 37 acres that have served as an exhibition ground and race track. "This will be a real catalyst for the city's redevelopment," said Graham Lee, RG's president and chief executive.
SOME Chilliwack residents have successfully opposed any construction in the 11,000-acre Ryder Lake recreation area and as a result home building will be deferred there for 10 years.
 The city must now figure out geotechnical solutions for sending sewer and water up steep hillsides, which will cost an average of $8,500 per dwelling, says Mayor Les. "I sense a nervousness in our population that hillside development is fine, but do it carefully," he said. "The City Council is cognizant of this so they do not incur a growth backlash."
 Jim and Marcia Sutter, who sold a hand-held video game manufacturing business in Hong Kong and returned to North America, recently moved to Chilliwack. They also have a winter home in Mexico. "People ask me, 'Why Chilliwack?' " said Ms. Sutter. "We like the country and small-town feeling of going into shops or the bank where people know you by your first name."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Plays, Gay and Otherwise

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
ASK Craig Lucas what a gay play is and he is likely to, purposefully, reel off flip definitions: "A gay play is a play written by a gay playwright." Or, "It sleeps with another play of the same gender."
William M. Hoffman, who wrote "As Is," a so-called gay play that is one of the American theater's trailblazing dramas about AIDS perceives and emphasizes gay elements in a vast reach of plays through the ages, including Shakespeare's "Edward II," two obscure comedies by Mae West (not including "Sex") and "God of Vengeance," a Yiddish classic of 1903. Not to mention "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" by Tennessee Williams, "Streamers" by David Rabe and "The Dying Gaul" by Mr. Lucas.. 
 As director of the dramatic writing program at Purchase College, Mr. Hoffman has assigned all these plays. And, as an offshoot of the course, "Lesbian, Gay and Bisexual Theater," he holds conversations with gay and lesbian playwrights. .
His conversationalist Dec. 14 is Holly Hughes, author of "The Well of Horniness."
"I don't have to come in and do a manifesto -- or possibly I will at the slightest provocation," she said in an interview. Not to worry, Ms. Hughes, provocation awaits.
Mr. Hoffman fully expects Ms. Hughes to "do a performance," one could say a piece of a performance piece -- 10 minutes or so. Ms. Hughes's new work, "Preaching to the Perverted," by her description a "low-tech show on an almost bare stage" is to be performed at Public School 122 on the Lower East Side in April and May. It is about her Supreme Court confrontation of 1998, a case arising over a National Endowment for the Arts grant. Ms. Hughes's grant was withdrawn because of sexually explicit content, language and gesture. It was then reinstated. "I focused on the Supreme Court hearing as a piece of theater," Ms. Hughes said. "Judge Judy did not prepare me for this. In retrospect, I would rather have had Ed Koch, who represents more respect for the rule of law than the United States Supreme Court."
Given Ms. Hughes's gift for candor, not to mention ineffable charm and wit, a conversation with her is sure to elicit funny and dazzling rejoinders; it is not possible to believe that listeners will not jump to be participants. Once quoted as saying she had a "mission to change the world," Ms. Hughes will be expected to explain just what a performance artist -- her designation -- is or does.
"I can expound on that," she said. "I will entertain the questions, if not necessarily answer them."
Although she was inspired by such seminal underground theater and avant-garde influences as Charles Ludlam and his legendary Ridiculous Theater Company, Ms. Hughes said: "In the 70's, a lot of what is called performance art was coming from visual artists; Laurie Anderson started out as one. Her photos were accompanied by tapes, and she put on a headset. It is not coming out of the theater artists but was intended to push the limitations of various media to produce a hybrid art."
What started out as an anti-theatrical movement, "In the ensuing 30 years, has become autobiographically driven, like Spalding Gray, more than questioning forms of theater." she said.
Of the present arts scene, Ms. Hughes observed: "We are in a cynical comodified moment where the big impact is economic. Theater is a commodity to be consumed. It is not about asking questions or about who we are. With less funding, it has to be concerned with the bottom line."
But it is all in the cause of theater, "which will never be able to compete with the spectacle of movies," Ms. Hughes said. "What theater has to offer is unmediated human presence. That is its strongest, wonderful, irreplaceable fact."
She continued: "The need for gay and lesbian courses is almost hilarious. So many works in the canon have been disguised by closeted writers. And there is now a wealth of interest in gay and lesbian writers who have a particular sensibility and explicitly gay characters, but it is located in a larger world, as it exists in a larger community.
"A play like Christopher Durang's 'Betty's Summer Vacation' of last season is not a gay play. It follows a tradition of gay male sendups of heterosexuals, of gender, of family relationships -- without a gay character in it. I'll ask Bill, who comes out of a more naturalistic tradition (he edited a gay play anthology) some questions. 'Why is he offering this class?' 'Why is he inviting riffraff like me?' "
A conversation with Mr. Lucas is to take place on Thursday. The playwright, who lives in Putnam County with his male companion -- the couple intends to adopt an infant -- is best known for, "Prelude to a Kiss" and "Reckless," neither of them ostensibly gay. But most recently, "The Dying Gaul," which he considers his most highly praised work, was a decidedly homosexual play. A gender changed -- two men instead of one man and one woman -- version of "Marry Me a Little," a revue based on songs by Stephen Sondheim, which was developed by Mr. Lucas and Norman Rene, is a hit in Hollywood, where it opened last month to rave reviews.
Mr. Lucas said: "I balk at being called a gay playwright. It marginalizes you. I can imagine a straight woman, a black boy, an old Jewish man. I live in the real world, not in a gay village. My job is to imagine, not report on some factoid of my life. It would be odd if Shakespeare had written only what he 'knew.' I'm a white gay male in America. That's one of the reasons I want to talk to students, as an out person who speaks candidly about experience informed by art. No one has ever told them the truth about anything. To hear an adult talk about any aspect of life from a lived perspective shocks and means something to them."
Ms. Hughes, as teacher, is on the Purchase College semester list for January. The course is gay and lesbian performance art. It will be offered under gay and lesbian studies and "cross listed with dramatic studies," she explained, trying to avoid the academic jargon of complicated, overlapping departmental structures. It is sufficient to say the "lesbian, gay and bisexual theater" course, five years old and being conducted by Mr. Hoffman for the first time, is "an open course; it's out there."
Describing it that way, Mr. Hoffman intended neither a wordplay about being openly gay or gay outing. It is an elective, open to everyone. Major and dramatic writing, however, is required in order to be a member of that department, and the other two courses he is teaching this semester (dramatic writing and script analysis) go under the heading conservatory program for freshmen and sophomores, leading to a bachelor of fine arts degree.
Of the students in Mr. Hoffman's dramatic writing course, he said: "We don't offer false encouragement. You have to be obsessed and you better be someone who wants it. It's not for the casual."
On the origins of gay and lesbian drama as a course, Mr. Hoffman said: "I don't have a clue, but it must be taught."
In "Conversations With," as he prefers to call the series at the Neuberger Museum of Art, "I want to get the best playwrights and directors of national repute," he said, although his focus is on playwrights who are gay: Lanford Wilson, Christopher Durang, Terrence McNally, Nicky Silver. This year's conversations began with Mr. Kramer and then went to Maria Irene Fornes, whose body of work is being seen Off Broadway this season at the Signature Theater. The conversations with Mr. Lucas and with Ms. Hughes are being held on Thursday and on Dec. 14, respectively, at the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College at 4 p.m. Admission is free, but the capacity is about 75. For more information, the number to call is 251-6113.
Mr. Hoffman, who has also written the libretto for "The Ghosts of Versailles," with music by John Corigliano, has had teaching assignments or stints at Arizona State University in Tempe, at Juilliard (on the art of the libretto), at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst, and the New School.
"But I'm beginning to have an academic home here," he said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
An Added Anchor for Newark's Downtown Revival

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
LESS than a month after the last workers at the former Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company headquarters in downtown Newark packed up and left, a new single tenant, International Discount Telecommunications, began moving into the 20-story building.
IDT, a provider of high-speed Internet access and discount long distance telephone service, signed on to lease the 450,000-square-foot structure at 520 Broad Street as its world headquarters on Nov. 19, a Friday. That weekend it began relocating about 100 of its 1,100 workers to the building from Hackensack, replacing the insurer, which had ceased operations last summer. 
 IDT signed a 20-year lease with three 10-year options with the Kushner Companies, of Florham Park, which acquired 520 Broad Street for $10.5 million in June. People close to the deal say IDT is renting the building, which has a health club and an 850-car garage, for $4.3 million a year initially, with increases in the 10th year and every five years thereafter -- plus property taxes, utilities and operating expenses.
In the process the company gains the right to put its name on the mid-1950's structure, which is visible from the New Jersey Turnpike. It is also receiving a tax abatement and other incentives worth more than $1 million from Newark and is working with the state to arrange financing to renovate the building.
Commercial brokers say that the fact that IDT is the first sizable company in more than a decade to relocate from outside Newark is a step forward in the revitalization of the city, which has been trying to mend itself since the 1967 race riots pushed it into decline.
Mayor Sharpe James called the building, which is close to the minor league baseball stadium that opened this summer and the two-year-old performing arts center, another anchor for the downtown area. The area still has some 700,000 square feet of empty space.
The arts center "was about bricks and mortar," Mayor James said. "This is about people and about bringing life back to that corner of Broad Street."
IDT is a fast-growing company, adding more than 50 employees a month, its officials said. Most of its employees, who share the work seven days a week, 24 hours a day, will move into the Newark building over the next five months, filling about half the space. The other half is for expansion.
IDT now occupies some 150,000 square feet of space in six separate leased or owned buildings along Main and State Streets in Hackensack. For months it scoured Bergen, Essex, Passaic and Union Counties as well as Manhattan for a new home before choosing the Newark building over 60 others.
The choice also reflects the trend of telecommunications and technology-based firms moving into older cities because they offer less expensive space as well as access to labor, highways, mass transit and fiber-optic links. All of these considerations were factors in IDT's decision to move to Newark, as were proximity to Manhattan and ample parking, said James Courter, the company's president and vice chairman.
For a company competing for workers with giants like AT&T and Lucent "those factors will also help in our recruiting efforts," said Mr. Courter, a former Republican Congressman who lost the race for Governor to Jim Florio in 1989.
For Newark, said Mitchell Moss, director of the Center for Urban Studies at New York University, "this is the great story of telecommunications firms helping to revive cities," adding that Newark now has "a technological infrastructure in place."
In recent years investors have acquired nine old downtown buildings to renovate and rent them, drawing as tenants a crop of telecommunications and computer-based companies in addition to law, health-care and insurance concerns. While the vacancy rate for Class B buildings was 32.7 percent as of the third quarter, according to Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage expects that figure to drop significantly when the IDT lease is taken into account.
AT the same time average annual asking rents rose to $20.10 a square foot from $18.86 in 1998. The rate for Class B space in the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office market averaged $21.83 a square foot, reported Grubb & Ellis.
The "technological infrastructure" that Mr. Moss cited includes the tangle of fiber-optic backbones and cables under the city's streets that computer-based firms need to connect the devices they use. New Jersey Bell, the predecessor of Bell Atlantic, whose New Jersey headquarters is in Newark, laid some of the initial wires when it made the city one of its regional hubs decades ago. Its successor has enhanced them in recent years.
Other providers that have emerged since the deregulation of the telephone industry have also recently put in fiber optic backbones along the railroad right of way that runs through the city and, like branches from a tree, extended the cables into its core.
The need to locate in buildings close to fiber-optic networks, brokers said, has lured some two dozen telecommunications companies as well as a technology concerns to the city. The telecommunications companies have set up Internet switching and transmission stations, mainly at the 1.2-million-square-foot former Macy's building at 165 Halsey Street.
Other newcomers operate from the lower floors of 744 Broad Street, a 630,000-square-foot building, which its owner, Cogswell Realty Group of Manhattan is renovating at a cost of $45 million. In the two years since Cogswell bought the building its occupancy has doubled to 60 percent.
Most of the space leased by telecommunications companies is occupied by machines. But this, say downtown-revival advocates, is not enough. IDT helps give the city "legitimacy" as a corporate headquarters location, said Jonathan Meisel, an associate director at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial brokerage that handled both the sale and leasing of the 520 Broad Street building.
But Joseph Romano, managing director of the New Jersey offices of Grubb & Ellis, said he wondered whether IDT would be followed into downtown by other corporations. Since there "are only one or two other buildings that are of headquarters quality" that can support labor-intensive technology firms, he said, investors must renovate another building or build a new one.
One group planning to build is a partnership of Tishman-Speyer, Travelers and Morgan Stanley of Manhattan and Gale & Wentworth of Florham Park. The group is under contract to buy a site on Raymond Boulevard just west of the Pennsylvania Railroad Station to build a 400,000- to 600,000-square-foot office structure, said Mark Yeager, president of the Commercial Group at Gale & Wentworth. The group is also to close soon on the purchase of three prime downtown buildings totaling 1.3 million square feet.
"We intend to play to the city's strength as a hub for telecommunications and high-technology firms," Mr. Yeager said, adding that construction of the building would start once a tenant preleased half the space.
The IDT lease will bring 520 Broad Street full circle. Early this year Mutual Benefit Life -- which was seized by state regulators after it collapsed in 1991 and operated by the company under a rehabilitation plan -- sold the building. The company had earlier sold its insurance assets.
For Kushner, known mostly as a suburban residential developer, the purchase was part of a diversification strategy. "We also bought into what's happening in Newark," said Richard Stadtmauer, its managing director. He pointed to the arts center and baseball stadium as well as, among other things, plans for a downtown arena for the New Jersey Nets basketball team and a light rail system to connect downtown Newark to Newark International Airport.
"The worst-case scenario," he said, "was that we would carry an empty building and pay the taxes."
Mr. Stadtmauer said his company had been negotiating with several tenants for space before IDT entered the picture late last summer. The lease evolved following a decision by the two companies to join forces to supply Kushner's buildings with high-speed Internet and telephone access, as well as to market the service to other landlords. The result was the formation last September of a new company, Westmintech. L.L.C.
IDT initially was to lease half the building, but with the incentives from the city it took all the space. In addition to the abatement, which basically stabilizes taxes at $2 a square foot for 15 years, the city also will compensate IDT with a $1 million relocation payment and build a 500-car parking garage to supplement the existing 850-car garage and lease it to the company at a below-market rent.
Mr. Courter said the financing IDT hopes to get from the state will help the company make $20 million to $40 million in renovations to the building, mostly in advanced wiring and heating and cooling installations.
Mayor James said that with the payroll tax -- 1 percent of IDT's gross annual payroll -- and "getting people walking on the streets," the city will more than recoup its investment.
"It is," he said, referring to the IDT relocation, "a home run."

HEADLINE: Talks With Gay Playwrights Offered in Course at Purchase

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
ASK Craig Lucas what a gay play is and he is likely to, purposefully, reel off flip definitions, often heard by some people:
"A gay play is a play written by a gay playwright." Or, "It sleeps with another play of the same gender." 
 William M. Hoffman, who wrote "As Is," a so-called gay play, and one of the American theater's two trailblazing ones about AIDS -- the other is "The Normal Heart" by Larry Kramer -- perceives and emphasizes gay elements in a vast reach of plays through the ages, including Shakespeare's "Edward II," two obscure comedies by Mae West (not including "Sex") and "God of Vengeance," a Yiddish classic of 1903. Not to mention "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" by Tennessee Williams, "Streamers" by David Rabe, "The Dying Gaul" by Mr. Lucas and "The Well of Horniness" by Holly Hughes.
In his role as director of the dramatic writing program at Purchase College, Mr. Hoffman has assigned all these plays. And he holds conversations with gay and lesbian playwrights as an offshoot of the course, "Lesbian, Gay and Bisexual Theater."
"I don't have to come in and do a manifesto -- or possibly I will at the slightest provocation," said Ms. Hughes, who is Mr. Hoffman's conversationalist on Dec. 14. Not to worry, Ms. Hughes, provocation awaits.
Mr. Hoffman fully expects Ms. Hughes to "do a performance," one could say a piece of a performance piece -- 10 minutes or so. Ms. Hughes's new work, "Preaching to the Perverted," by her description a "low-tech show on an almost bare stage" is to be performed at Public School 122 on the Lower East Side in April and May.
It is about her Supreme Court confrontation of 1998, a case arising over a National Endowment for the Arts grant. Ms. Hughes's grant was withdrawn because of sexually explicit content, language and gesture. It was then reinstated.
"I focused on the Supreme Court hearing as a piece of theater," Ms. Hughes said.
"Judge Judy did not prepare me for this. In retrospect, I would rather have had Ed Koch, who represents more respect for the rule of law than the United States Supreme Court."
Given Ms. Hughes's gift for candor, not to mention ineffable charm and wit, one would not reasonably expect from an artist with an agenda in response to restrictive, oppressive powers -- Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, is one of her most acerbically and humorously used adjectives -- a conversation with Ms. Hughes is sure to elicit funny and dazzling rejoinders; it is not possible to believe that listeners will not jump to be participants. Once quoted as having a "mission to change the world," Ms. Hughes will be expected to explain just what a performance artist -- her designation -- is or does.
"I can expound on that," she said. "I will entertain the questions, if not necessarily answer them."
Although she was inspired by such seminal underground theater and avant-garde influences as the great Charles Ludlam and his legendary Ridiculous Theater Company, Ms. Hughes said:
"In the 70's, a lot of what is called performance art was coming from visual artists; Laurie Anderson started out as one. Her photos were accompanied by tapes, and she put on a headset. It is not coming out of the theater artists but was intended to push the limitations of various media to produce a hybrid art."
What started out as an anti-theatrical movement, "in the ensuing 30 years, has become autobiographically driven, like Spalding Gray, more than questioning forms of theater," she said.
Of the present arts scene, Ms. Hughes said: "We are in a cynical comodified moment where the big impact is economic. Theater is a commodity to be consumed. It is not about asking questions or about who we are. With less funding, it has to be concerned with the bottom line."
Despite the lessening of fringe movements and spaces for emerging theater artists, Ms. Hughes still spoke of going "where the excitement and energy is" -- in the South Bronx, in Dumbo the acronym for Down Under Manhattan Bridge Overpass, a section in Brooklyn -- which even has a performance group that calls itself Dumba.
But it is all in the cause of theater, "which will never be able to compete with the spectacle of movies," Ms. Hughes said. "What theater has to offer is unmediated human presence. That is its strongest, wonderful, irreplaceable fact."
She continued: "The need for gay and lesbian courses is almost hilarious. So many works in the canon have been disguised by closeted writers.
"And there is now a wealth of interest in gay and lesbian writers who have a particular sensibility and explicitly gay characters, but it is located in a larger world, as it exists in a larger community.
"A play like Christopher Durang's 'Betty's Summer Vacation' of last season is not a gay play. It follows a tradition of gay male sendups of heterosexuals, of gender, of family relationships -- without a gay character in it. I'll ask Bill, who comes out of a more naturalistic tradition (he edited a gay play anthology) some questions. 'Why is he offering this class?' 'Why is he inviting riffraff like me?' "
A conversation with Mr. Lucas is to take place on Thursday. The playwright, who lives in Putnam County with his male companion -- the couple intend to adopt an infant -- is best known for, "Prelude to a Kiss" and "Reckless," neither of them ostensibly gay.
But most recently, "The Dying Gaul," which he considers his most highly praised work, was a decidedly homosexual play. A gender changed -- two men instead of one man and one woman -- version of "Marry Me a Little," a revue based on songs by Stephen Sondheim, which was developed by Mr. Lucas and Norman Rene, is a hit in Hollywood, where it opened last month to rave reviews.
Mr. Lucas said: "I balk at being called a gay playwright. It marginalizes you. I can imagine a straight woman, a black boy, an old Jewish man. I live in the real world, not in a gay village. My job is to imagine, not report on some factoid of my life. It would be odd if Shakespeare had written only what he 'knew.' I'm a white gay male in America. That's one of the reasons I want to talk to students, as an out person who speaks candidly about experience informed by art. No one has ever told them the truth about anything. To hear an adult talk about any aspect of life from a lived perspective shocks and means something to them."
Ms. Hughes, as teacher, is on the Purchase College semester list for January. The course is gay and lesbian performance art. It will be offered under gay and lesbian studies and "cross listed with dramatic studies," she explained, trying to avoid the academic jargon of complicated, overlapping departmental structures where, in this case, courses are identified as belonging in either a division (humanities) or a conservatory (theater arts and film). It is sufficient to say that the "lesbian, gay and bisexual theater" course, five years old and being conducted by Mr. Hoffman for the first time, is "an open course; it's out there."
Describing it that way, Mr. Hoffman intended neither a wordplay about being openly gay or gay outing. It is an elective, open to everyone. Major and dramatic writing, however, is required in order to be a member of that department, and the other two courses he is teaching this semester (dramatic writing and script analysis) go under the heading conservatory program for freshmen and sophomores, leading to a bachelor of fine arts degree. Of the students in Mr. Hoffman's dramatic writing course, he said: "We don't offer false encouragement. You have to be obsessed and you better be someone who wants it. It's not for the casual."
On the origins of gay and lesbian drama as a course, Mr. Hoffman said: "I don't have a clue, but it must be taught." In "Conversations With," as he prefers to call the series at the Neuberger Museum of Art, "I want to get the best playwrights and directors of national repute," he said, although his focus is on playwrights who are gay: Lanford Wilson, Christopher Durang, Terrence McNally, Nicky Silver. This year's conversations began with Mr. Kramer and then went to Maria Irene Fornes, whose body of work is being seen Off Broadway this season at the Signature Theater.
The conversations with Mr. Lucas and with Ms. Hughes are being held on Thursday and on Dec. 14, respectively, at the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College at 4 p.m. Admission is free, but the capacity is about 75. For more information, the number to call is 251-6113.
Mr. Hoffman, who has also written the libretto for "The Ghosts of Versailles," with music by John Corigliano, has taught on various aspects of theater at Arizona State University in Tempe, at Juilliard (on the art of the libretto), at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst, and the New School.
"But I'm beginning to have an academic home here," he said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk
