HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY;
A New Idea For Unions: Forget the Past

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST

 BODY:
ASIDE from driving to work and perhaps breaking for lunch, what do more than 90 percent of private-sector employees in this country have in common?
The answer: They are not union members. The A.F.L.-C.I.O., groggily awakening to its increasing irrelevance, has lately been calling for stepped-up organizing efforts. But it might as well lobby for a ban on fax machines, for all the good it will do. 
 Recruiting new members may be tough, but it is easier than addressing the real reason for the collapse of organized labor in this country: the very nature of unions as they are currently constituted.
You won't find it displayed on union Web sites, but the motto of organized labor in this country might as well be "change is evil." Unions are most effective in situations where competition is minimal, capital is entrenched and technology cannot replace humans. Thus, unions are strongest among government workers, utilities, rust-bucket industries and transportation companies.
The picture of commercial America painted by that list is as current as a faded daguerreotype. Labor, capital and technology are just too mobile (and plentiful) in a world of six billion people and instant telecommunications. It's a joke to think you can make a cartel of some segment of the work force, raise the cost of doing business and prevent the kinds of economic changes you consider detrimental to your membership.
It has long been obvious that Luddite-ism is a dead end: Labor-saving innovation and change may be bad for, say, tollbooth attendants or Linotype operators, but everybody else gains. Trying to block such change is not only wrong (since to do so would impoverish the many to protect a few) but also very bad public relations.
Anyway, it's probably futile. The pace of economic evolution has accelerated irrevocably, even if the essentially conservative nature of organized labor has kept it from getting with the program.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s shortsightedness is most evident in its public posture on foreign trade, as events last week in Seattle underlined. Most economists agree that freer trade benefits almost everyone almost everywhere, from prosperous America to impoverished Bangladesh. But unions don't much like trade. The United Steelworkers, for example, has fought to suppress imports of low-cost foreign steel, even though doing so won't save America's doddering unionized steel giants from smaller domestic competitors. Indeed, trade barriers are much more likely to destroy jobs in industries that depend on cheap steel than to preserve them at the steel mill.
Organized labor also has an image problem. To many professionals, the word "union" implies enshrined mediocrity, indifference to customers and a closed shop, if not a closed mind. And corruption scandals haven't helped.
Yet workers do seem to benefit from the countervailing power of a union, which makes it all the more imperative that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and other labor organizations re-examine their mission and the attitudes that have made them as relevant as calligraphy to the emerging American economy.
First, unions need to act as advocates for all workers, not just the handful they happen to represent. That means changing their attitudes toward trade and technology. But it also means pushing harder for universal health insurance and other programs to help the poorest workers close the wage gap (thinking of medical coverage as a form of income) and equalize an economic burden that now falls disproportionately on the bigger corporations that can afford to pay union wages and benefits.
Second, unions should cheerfully help their members move onward and upward in life. They should sponsor training, help finance college tuition and use their large memberships to negotiate breaks on mortgage fees and other benefits. A few already do some of these things on the side; they need to be central goals.
Third, unions need to help workers become owners. Instead of just negotiating raises, they should be pushing to get stock options for workers like the ones that enrich chief executives in quantities that unions love to get upset about. Every working stiff knows that toiling for wages alone is ultimately a sucker's game.
We started with a brain teaser, so let's finish with one: What proportion of American adults own stocks? The answer is half, several times the prevalence of union membership and up from just 1 in 10 in 1965. In fact, stocks are now the largest asset families own, exceeding even home equity.
Think of how fast Marx and Engels must be spinning in their graves: At a time when organized labor is evaporating from American work life, more American workers than ever own the means of production.
The trick will be persuading them that they ought to own a union card as well.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 1; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1314 words

HEADLINE: COUNTERINTELLIGENCE;
Is The Fur Still Flying?

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel 

 BODY:
I HAVE never worn fur. Maybe because my mother did. The women of her generation got mink coats from their husbands as door prizes for surviving the perils of car-pooling and keeping the dinners warm. And it didn't hurt that the neighbors would see that business was good.
Once acquired, the mink had a privileged existence. It went only to the best places -- the opera, the ballet, the bar mitzvah -- and it was always accompanied by "the pearls." Summers, when I went to camp, the mink went to cold storage. 
 In the last 10 years, of course, furs fell out of favor. Between the recession and the animal rights protesters, no one was buying. Celebrities posed for ads saying they'd rather be naked than wear fur, and women who did wear it were terrorized by threats of spray paint. If I had even a thought of joining the ranks of glamorous career girls a la Doris Day in "That Touch of Mink," it vanished. Who needed such aggravation over a coat?
Now suddenly, the country is suffering from a case of good old American amnesia. Problem with fur? What problem with fur? Many top designers are using it, and while the fashion industry is used to turning on a dime, what about the rest of us? A few years ago, people were lining their peacoats with the furs women had dumped at flea markets. Like lingerie, the attraction was that you would wear it, but only you would know. Now, fur is no longer immoral. It's not even crassly nouveau. It seems no more of a fashion faux pas than leg warmers. Why?
One reason, naturally, is the raging economy. With extra money to spend, why not pamper yourself with the ultimate luxury? Another reason is a definite backlash to the over-the-top tactics of the antifur zealots, (throwing a dead raccoon onto Anna Wintour's plate at the Four Seasons was a low point). But somehow, the return of fur, which started haltingly last season with trims and accessories, has morphed to full-blown fashion layouts in magazines showing big coats for big money.
And no one can keep it in stock -- not just the coats, but vests, jackets, pocketbooks, even headbands.
I recently visited three designers who loaned me different fur pieces reflecting the new casual chic attitude. For once, I would actually be in fashion.
Lisa Pomerantz, director of public relations at Celine, for which Michael Kors is the designer, greeted me wearing rabbit slippers. "Our rabbit vests are $1,275, and we sold out of them in one day," she said animatedly. "Michael did mink vests for $9,000, which were also gone in a day. Our mink-lined shearling coats sold out, too."
"It's not your mom's mink anymore," Ms. Pomerantz continued. "People want to wear fur in a more interesting way. The taboo has disappeared. People are tired of Big Brother. This year, it seems the more outrageous, luxurious and impractical the piece, the more it sells."
I left Celine with Ms. Pomerantz's own rabbit vest, a swirl of white, gray and tan, which is the trendiest item of the fur trend. She instructed me to wear it with a black sweater and pants to show it off to best advantage, and I did -- to the office, then to the Russian Tea Room. "Early Sonny Bono," one co-worker offered as fashion commentary. I felt more like Fred Flintstone, a little too bulky and masculine for my taste. By dinnertime, my clothes were covered with bunny hairs. My eyes itched and there were red marks on my face. I was allergic to the vest! Never mind. I'll be trendy in my next life.
At Tuleh, an upscale line sold at Neiman Marcus and Jeffrey, Josh Patner, who owns the company with Bryan Bradley, said: "Ours is a decadent collection, and the excess and frivolity of fur is a big part of the way our customer dresses. We used it this season in baseball jackets with cashmere sleeves, and we even sold out our samples.
"We don't treat fur as precious and heirloomy. Our remedy is to wear your fur all day long, to pick up the kids and the dry cleaning. You only have one life to live."
I left Tuleh with a dark burgundy sheared-mink bomber jacket that sells for $4,600. The sleeves were too long, but over my sweat pants and T-shirt, it looked fine. No one looked twice. The bunny vest, at least, was a statement. This was so understated it didn't even look like fur.
It acted like fur, though. It kept me so warm (the unseasonal weather recently has not been fur friendly) that once I landed on the pre-Thanksgiving day line at Citarella, I had to take it off. Mindful of protecting the fur, which felt softer than feathers, I turned the jacket inside out, and that's what caught people's eyes. The lining was gorgeous -- maroon satin with ruffles sewn along the collar. Once I made it inside the store, I put the jacket back on in self-defense. People were clambering for stuffing samples, and I could just see a dollop landing on my loaner. Mr. Patner's "one life to live" theory does not go far in the face of free food.
My final stop was J. Mendel on Madison Avenue. Gilles Mendel, the owner and designer, is the fifth generation of his family to run the company, whose original store is on the Rue St.-Honore in Paris. In October, he opened a boutique in Bergdorf Goodman. Mr. Mendel says that in his first six weeks there, he sold more fur than the store sold in its entire season last year.
Mr. Mendel specializes in Legend mink, which is the finest available, and he does not subscribe to the idea that fur should become a mundane purchase. "When you buy it, it's an event," he insisted. "A special product shouldn't be high volume."
He handed me a coat -- not a mommy coat -- but one with a more modern cut, slightly fitted and shorter. I put it on over my sweat pants, and voila! If I didn't look like a million bucks, I looked every penny of the $11,000 the coat cost. It was fabulous. Light, warm, shiny, elegant and stylish all at once. I started grinning.
"This year, there is a complete revolution in the fur business," Mr. Mendel said. "Sonia Rykiel and Thierry Mugler were against fur, now they're for it. I think people are tired of being told what to do. The extreme position that PETA takes is hard to understand," he added, referring to People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. "But in America, everything goes to extremes. Americans are followers."
When I left J. Mendel, I walked along Madison Avenue and drew some admiring glances from other women. I should say, in all my fur-wearing adventures -- vest, jacket and coat -- I never got a second look from a man. Until the fur came off.
Two nights later I wore the coat to the theater even though it was 61 degrees. As my husband and I looked for a cab, it started to rain. I had no umbrella.
"Are we liable for that coat?" he yelled. I thought I would faint. I took it off and folded it under my arms, panicked. But no, it was fine. I, on the other hand, was soaked.
At the theater, the air-conditioning was on, I was still damp and I was freezing. Aah! The coat was a godsend. I never took it off even during intermission. I got some quizzical looks because of the temperature and one or two smirks from people who must have thought I was showing off, but I felt cocooned in luxury and absolutely nothing could ruin that for me.
I also wore the mink to an Indian buffet lunch, where I worried that it would smell like curry when I left (it didn't). Afterward, I walked 20 blocks up Broadway, reveling in the lushness of it. Face it, I thought. You have fallen madly, unabashedly in love -- with a coat.
Well, eventually the clock struck midnight. The coat went back. I petted it. I bid it farewell.
What I didn't do was call my mother. After years of making fun of her suburban trophy coat, I knew the last thing I would get was sympathy. She would instead reward me with four of every mother's favorite words in the English language: "I told you so."
Maybe it's time to start car-pooling.

HEADLINE: In the Glare of Baubles, Bangles, Bonuses

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
IT'S the holiday gift-buying season, of course. But at Harry Winston, where a simple bauble like a diamond pendant necklace costs $50,000, what is more important is that this is Wall Street's bonus-paying season. Investment bankers and hedge-fund managers receive the bulk of their yearly compensation in a lump sum, and so much money showing up in a bank account overnight can put one in the mood to spend spend spend.
At least, that was the hope at Harry Winston, the Fifth Avenue jeweler, which last week packed up a large selection of diamond-encrusted watches, five-carat engagement rings and $175,000 princess necklaces, like the one Gwyneth Paltrow wore to the Oscars in March, and took them to Bayard's, a restaurant in the downtown financial district. 
 Traditionally during bonus season, which runs from November through March, depending on when companies end their fiscal years, certain sectors of the New York economy -- from exotic cars to Hamptons summer rentals -- experience a sales surge. But never before, it seems, had any merchant so directly targeted Wall Street's bonus babies. Several hundred of them received engraved invitations to Bayard's over three nights for cocktails, hors d'oeuvres and an informal viewing of "the Harry Winston millennium collection." It was a case of bringing the mountain to Muhammad.
They were not just any bonus babies, either. The jewelry store specifically invited young, single Wall Streeters, primarily men, on the theory that they are sufficiently liquid to splurge on jewelry to please a friend, a fiancee or even Mom.
"The idea was to go for that group of six- and seven-figure bachelors," said Carol Brodie Gelles, the managing director of communications for Harry Winston, who put the event together.
Ms. Gelles spent many hours ferreting out the names of the newly rich for her guest list, speaking to friends like Pamela Gross, a co-founder of LuxuryFinder.com, an e-commerce site, which ended up co-sponsoring the event. She also drew on W. Randall Jones, the founder of Worth magazine, for a list of Mini-Masters of the Universe. But her networking was mostly among women. She asked whom they knew who'd recently been promoted to managing director of an investment bank, or made partner, or whose firm had gone public in 1999.
"You needed to be somebody who could afford to shop at Harry Winston," Ms. Gelles said. "It wouldn't be appropriate for someone who wasn't making $300,000 or $400,000. I went through their girlfriends or wives, so we didn't have to say, 'Do you get it?' The girls all get it."
One who got it was Rebecca Shalam, who'd chosen her wedding band at Harry Winston this year. Her husband, Ari Shalam, 29, is a graduate of the Wharton School and Harvard Business School, and Ms. Shalam was able to suggest dozens of his classmates for the invitation list for Tuesday night, including nearly 60 employees of Goldman, Sachs. Thanks to the double payoff of year-end bonuses and the company's initial public offering of stock in May, Ms. Shalam's Goldman friends are doing "frighteningly well," she said.
"We've known three or four people who have gone public with Internet startups this year," she said. "A couple of friends have started hedge funds and raised $60 or $70 million. Everyone is under 31. The investment bankers, it seems to me they're making after one year the money people used to make after three or four years." She named a figure of $750,000. (The total bonuses paid by the financial industry are expected to exceed last year's record $9.9 billion, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall says.)
Ms. Shalam arrived early on Tuesday evening at Bayard's, which is at 1 Hanover Square in a resplendently remodeled brownstone. By day the building, India House, is a private club, but in the evenings the year-old restaurant, which is all mahogany and nautical memorabilia, is open to the public.
The first guests were invited for 5 p.m., shockingly early for a cocktail party elsewhere in town, but appropriate for Wall Street, where the market closes at 4:30. Jewelry was displayed in a first-floor party room, on long tables cordoned off by security ropes (guests could lean over and ask to be shown a piece), or dangling from the necks, ears and wrists of models (even more inaccessible).
As trays of oysters and other canapes were passed and the room filled, Mr. Shalam, who works for Audiovox, an electronics company founded by his father, chatted with a group of friends from Harvard and Wharton. All in all, they seemed far less interested in jewelry shopping than in freshening old school connections. "Karin, this is John," Mr. Shalam said, introducing Karin Klein to John Troiano, who works for a leveraged buyout firm.
"Where do you work?" Mr. Troiano asked her. She named a private equity firm. Ms. Klein, in her mid-20's, had come with a younger sister, Jennifer Klein, who works at a hedge fund. They were grateful simply to have carved out time for socializing from their work schedules, never mind the gems on display. "The problem is," Karin Klein said, "we need to spend less time in the office and more time at things like this, so there'll be someone to give me these kinds of things."
Gary Millin joined the circle, dropping by from the offices at 11 Broadway of the Internet company he co-founded, Mail.com, where 250 people now work. Mail.com's I.P.O. in June has made Mr. Millin, 30, worth $26 million.
He was the only coatless man in the room but had put on a fresh tattersall shirt open at the neck. "I got dressed up," he announced. He looked bleary-eyed. "I'm the only one going back to the office after this party," he said.
A young woman hovering on the edge of the circle said in a whispered aside, "He also happens to be one of the 10 most eligible bachelors in New York." She wasn't referring to his looks (pleasant enough).
Over at the velvet rope, Ms. Shalam was being shown a watch by a Winston salesman, who described it in a metronomic cadence: "It has a blue enamel face with diamonds on the bezel. It's rectangular, with a very fine pink leather band. It's $12,500."
Ms. Shalam, who is due to give birth in May, said she hoped to buy it as a baby gift to herself. "If it's a boy, I'll have a blue band," she said.
In all, the tally of sales made on Tuesday night included three watches -- one bought for $44,000 by a woman for herself -- a pair of pearl and diamond earrings and a "suite" of matching earrings and a necklace. A half-dozen items were put on hold by customers who said they intended to look at them again at the store.
Despite the small number of items actually bought, Ms. Gelles pronounced Harry Winston's trip downtown, its first ever, "a huge success," explaining that in the ultra-luxury business, many sales aren't closed until months after a customer first inspects the goods. The store estimated it could ultimately make $2.5 million worth of sales to customers whose interest it piqued over the three nights at Bayard's.
"We won't see the full results of this exercise for at least a year," Ms. Gelles said. "We met many single men in the range where they're likely to get engaged, and maybe the guy who got a watch will be back to get his engagement ring. Getting these Wall Streeters when they're 29, that relationship will last until they're 80."
Or at least, until a market wipeout.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2000 Mazda MPV;
'Me, Too,' Said the Little Japanese Van

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
MANY Americans say they dislike conformity, but when it comes to minivans, sameness sells.
Through their purchase decisions, van owners have sent a clear message to automakers: Stick to the familiar family recipe. Buyers want a conservative look that doesn't stand out in the school parking lot. They prefer front-wheel drive. They insist on four doors -- two sliding doors in the back -- and plenty of convenient cup holders. They like flexible seating, lots of nooks and crannies for storage and ample cargo capacity.
 Those who tried other formulas quickly learned a lesson. Smaller rear-drive, truck-based vans from General Motors and Ford never caught on. Then G.M. brought out front-drive vans with a Dustbuster shape; they sold poorly. Finally, it developed conservatively styled minivans, and they have done much better. At Ford, a second version of the front-drive Windstar, with a second sliding door, has also sold well. 
 The Jetsons-style Toyota Previa never had more than a cult following, but its successor, the simple, straightforward Sienna, is selling briskly. The Honda Odyssey started as a quirky, compact van with four hinged doors, but the second-generation Odyssey, a larger van with a conventional design, has been an unqualified hit.
Now it is the turn of Mazda, which has ditched its old MPV and brought out an all-new van with the same old name.
In fact, the previous MPV was the most successful of the minivans at being different. Introduced as a 1989 model, Mazda's first van for the American market was small but won praise for its spirited acceleration, its agility around corners and its maneuverability in parking lots. Although it had rear drive, the MPV offered a four-wheel-drive option, making it a good choice for snowy climates or for towing. It had a single, hinged door for rear passengers.
With Mazda in a financial crisis, the MPV got only a cosmetic makeover in 1996. A second hinged door was added to the driver's side, and an All-Sport package gave the van the rugged look of a sport utility. But little changed under the skin.
Now, with Mazda effectively under the control of Ford, the Japanese company is playing catch-up by offering a completely fresh MPV with new front-wheel-drive architecture. The 2000 MPV remains rather small. About the size of short-wheelbase vans from Chrysler and G.M. -- most consumers prefer the longer versions -- it is slightly shorter and narrower than two of the smallest vans in this country, the Mercury Villager and Nissan Quest. Mazda is pitching the MPV as "smart sized," but I suspect that it is too small for many families -- especially those in suburban and rural areas who tend to drive bigger vans.
Still, the MPV may be just right for small families that don't take a lot of long trips, or that live in congested areas where ease of maneuvering and parking is crucial.
 The new MPV's exterior styling will blend in nicely with the minivan crowd. The van now has two rear sliding doors as standard equipment. While the manually operated sliding doors worked well -- my 7-year-old son could open and close them just fine -- I missed having power-operated sliders that open or close by remote. That feature, one that has become increasingly common on vans, is not available on the MPV.
Inside, despite its rather small dimensions, the MPV doesn't feel cramped. The space is well used.
 Even the least expensive trim level, the DX, comes with air-conditioning, a tilt steering wheel and an audio system with a CD player. The midlevel LX adds power front and rear windows, power locks, heated power mirrors and privacy glass. The top-line ES has an alarm system, remote locking, leather seats, leather-wrapped steering wheel, wood-grain trim, a nine-speaker sound system and front-seat side air bags. Anti-lock brakes are optional.
Front passengers have nine built-in storage compartments, including an overhead console, a glove box, a storage tray under the front passenger's seat, front door pockets, a coin box and a storage box that holds up to 12 CD's. The far rear also has storage compartments and a 12-volt power outlet. Separate climate controls can be ordered for rear passengers. The numerous cup holders can handle juice boxes, Big Gulps or water bottles.
 Though the MPV is relatively mainstream, it has some useful innovations, like windows on the rear sliding doors that actually roll down; on other vans, those windows are fixed in place.
Mazda has borrowed from Honda my favorite feature of the Odyssey: a third-row seat that magically folds into the floor. I find it nearly impossible to wrestle the bulky removable seats out of most minivans. And what if you find the trampoline that your daughter wants for Christmas? You have to drive home, take the seat out and return to the store to pick it up. With the Odyssey, and now with the MPV, I can single-handedly make the rear seat disappear into its footwell, creating a flat floor.
With the third-row seat upright, the deep footwell is a perfect place for grocery bags. Mazda offers another advantage: you can flip the third-row bench to the rear and use it for seating at picnics and tailgate parties.
 Another clever feature is borrowed from Ford minivans. The removable second-row seats allow you to create two captain's chairs with a demilitarized zone in between, or you can slide them together to create a bench. The bench also slides forward for more cargo space (or more legroom for passengers in the extreme rear), or it slides backward for more legroom in the second row. The second-row seats also recline, they flip forward to add cargo space and they can be removed. I could easily lift the seats (37 pounds each) out of the vehicle.
 The MPV is powered by a 2.5-liter V6 from the Mazda 626. Rated at 170 horsepower, it is among the least potent power plants in any minivan. While the test vehicle was adequate for around-town driving on Michigan's flat roads, it struggled as I tried to merge into fast freeway traffic, and I suspect it would quickly get winded in the mountains. The engine is coupled with a four-speed automatic transmission that was anything but smooth. Every gear shift felt and sounded like a major event.
The MPV still handles quite nimbly, by minivan standards, and its small size makes it easy to maneuver into tight spots.
The MPV competes most directly in size and engine power with the Villager and Quest. But its price is notably lower. Although my ES test vehicle, with just about every option, had a sticker of $27,730, the MPV starts around $20,000 -- about $3,000 less than a Villager.
 That is relatively reasonable, and with useful features like the folding third-row seat and roll-down rear windows, the MPV would be my pick of the small minivans. There is just one problem, though: Who wants a small minivan?

HEADLINE: Alter Egos Who Put the 'R' in R.S.V.P.

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
SEATED at her mahogany desk on the fifth floor of a town house on Sutton Square, surrounded by prints of thoroughbred horses, Meredith Palinjuggled the details of a busy life spent between homes in Manhattan, Southampton and Lyford Cay, in the Bahamas. Not her life, her employer's.
First, the Southampton housekeeper called to say the Christmas lights might need to be replaced before she and the handyman came to the city to decorate the Manhattan house for the holidays. Then there was a large box sitting on the desk that someone on the household staff had wrapped without noting who it was for. And the four phone lines were ringing with people R.S.V.P.-ing to one of two Christmas parties. 
 "It's tricky," said Ms. Palin, pulling out two lists from a desk drawer. "I have to make sure I put everyone on the right one."
Five days a week, eight hours a day, Ms. Palin works as a social secretary to Sandra McConnell, the lady of the house, whose late husband, Neil A. McConnell, was an heir to the Avon fortune. Mrs. McConnell is well known in Park Avenue circles for giving dinner parties, traveling the world, raising money for charity and just being, well, social.
As the uptown black-tie calendar opens to the busiest week of the year, Mrs. McConnell depends on Ms. Palin to make sure she hasn't responded to too many parties (three a night is her limit), to buy Christmas cards and gifts, to pay household bills, to return unwanted purchases and to make sure anyone she invites to lunch is reminded of the date in writing.
"I couldn't live the way I do without Meredith," said Mrs. McConnell, who this week plans to attend a Christie's auction for the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club, several private cocktail parties, a lunch at Harry Cipriani and a tree-lighting party at Brick Church.
She is not alone. As the lives of the ladies on the lunch circuit become ever busier, thanks to a booming economy and an abounding number of successful husbands who encourage their wives to circulate socially, the social secretary has returned from the musty Edith Wharton past to become a downright trendy staff member in the houses of the hugely rich.
Ricky Lauren has a social secretary. So do Nina Griscom, Audrey Gruss, Cathy Hilton, Carol Mack and Alison Stern. Ronald O. Perelman was one of the few men to have one, recalled the woman who once had the job, which at one point entailed visiting St. Barts ahead of Mr. Perelman to make sure he was on the guest lists for all the hot parties and would be seated at the No. 1 tables at restaurants. She asked not to be named, citing a confidentiality agreement. Mr. Perelman declined to comment.
"It's like having a wife," said Stephanie Stokes, a longtime decorator on the Upper East Side, who does not have a social secretary but has noticed that more of her friends do. "I think it's the only way that some of my friends could accomplish what they accomplish, by having a social secretary who books everything for them, their children and their husband," she said. Now, almost all lunch and dinner dates are made by social secretaries, she said, so she never talks to friends until she sees them in person. "No one wants to spend 10 minutes chatting just to arrange a lunch," she added.
Ann Rapp, an art consultant who divides her time between New York and Paris, said: "It's the 'in' thing now more than ever. For many of the newer set, it's about status and image. In many cases, it's imagined self-importance."
Maitres d'hotel at restaurants on the East Side report women use social secretaries the way their husbands use executive secretaries in their offices, to make reservations so they don't have to call themselves. Peter Geraghty, the manager of Swifty's, said the secretaries just mention their own first names and the number in the party. The same at La Goulue, said Sylvia Teisseire, a hostess there. It's confusing when they say " 'It's Audrey, for three,' " she said, adding, "I can't always remember who Audrey works for."
Marjane Kaswan, the owner of the 10-year-old Bouvier Agency, whose sole business is placing social secretaries, said, "I've never been busier." (The agency is named after a breed of dog Ms. Kaswan once owned.)
Similarly, Clifford Greenhouse, an owner of the Pavillion Agency, which places high-end household help, said that "there was an explosion of requests" in the last year for social secretaries.
"Men are sick of their wives asking their own personal assistants to address Christmas cards or hire a maid," he said. The assistants "find it demeaning and threaten to quit, so the husbands ask me to get their wives a social secretary."
Social secretaries are not to be confused with personal assistants or executive secretaries, who work in the business world. Social secretaries work from their employers' homes, generally for a woman who doesn't hold a full-time job (or any job, for that matter, other than socializing), and while they must be willing to write invitations and shop, their most important skill is the tact and decorum needed in the oh-so-perilous shoals of social life -- a skill their employers are sometimes lacking in.
"If you make a mistake, if you miss the social graces, you are pegged like your shoes would be at the club," said R. Couri Hay, the society editor of Ocean Drive's Palm Beach magazine. "The proper social secretary steers you through the tricky waters."
Many women who could well afford a social secretary recoil in horror at the personal helplessness it implies. Kathy Greenberg, whose husband, Alan Greenberg, is the chairman of the Bear Stearns Companies, hired a social secretary recently but let her go after a month, finding the whole concept silly. "It took more time for me to show her how to do things" than to do it herself, she said.
"My husband answers his own phone at work and writes his own letters, and so do I," she said. Her distaste was multiplied when she received a thank-you note supposedly from a friend but actually written by a social secretary who had misspelled her employer's own name.
Finding a well-qualified social secretary can be tricky, virtually everyone says. Although a few agencies place them, most are hired by word of mouth. Many seem to have grown up on the fringes of the rich -- private schools, a well-heeled neighborhood -- but never to have been rich themselves. One former social secretary put it this way: "They try to find someone with their lifestyle and taste -- but poor. Nice manners, that's the key. And discreet, discreet, discreet."
The description people give now for an ideal social secretary is not much different from the one W. Somerset Maugham gave of his character Miss Keith, the social secretary to the Princess Novemali, the wealthy American widow who marries a Roman prince, in his 1944 novel, "The Razor's Edge."
"She was a middle-aged Scotch woman, called Miss Keith," Maugham wrote, "with sandy hair, a freckled face, pince-nez and an air of determined virginity."
Mr. Greenhouse of the Pavillion Agency described social secretaries, who earn $40,000 to $160,000 a year, as "very preppy, attractive but not flashy, very well manicured but seldom wearing nail polish that's not clear." In the United States, the job has traditionally been held by women, although now, Mr. Greenhouse said, "I'm placing some wonderful gay gentlemen."
"Knowing proper etiquette is a given, and they should not care about being involved in their employer's world," he added.
When one does cross the line and aspire to the beau monde, there can be trouble. Michele Herbert, a Park Avenue social figure active in raising money for Alzheimer's research, fired her social secretary two months ago because, she said, "I had someone who wanted to be out there."
Ms. Herbert, whose husband, Lawrence Herbert, is the chief executive of Pantone Inc., which develops colors and graphics for the fashion industry, added: "That doesn't work for me. If I was holding a big dinner party, they wanted to be part of it, they wanted to be there."
But the biggest sin of all for a social secretary is to end up married to her employer's husband. The late Charles R. Lachman, a co-founder of Revlon, married Jaquine de Rochambeau, who was the social secretary to his third wife, Rita Lachman. Franklin Delano Roosevelt, though he never left Eleanor, had a liaison with Lucy Page Mercer, his wife's social secretary. And the late novelist Harold Robbins ran off with Jann Stapp, the social secretary to his fifth wife, Grace Robbins, and made her his sixth wife on Valentine's Day, 1992.
Grace Robbins, who had been married to her husband for 28 years, offered words of caution to today's ladies of the house: "Social secretaries get to know everything about you. You shouldn't let that happen. You shouldn't give her any of your clothes, and you shouldn't tell her the name of your plastic surgeon. What you'll have is an 'All About Eve' situation."
Ms. Robbins, who is writing a book titled "Cinderella and the Carpetbagger," a memoir about her life with Harold Robbins, said this of her social secretary: "She was very helpful to me and then helped herself to everything I had."
Judy Green insists that could never happen to her and her social secretary of 15 years, Marina Lakner, even though she describes Ms. Lakner as an "alter ego" and called her "a little me."
The brunette Ms. Lakner and the the blond Ms. Green, a novelist whose late husband owned the Cleve Pak Corporation, which specialized in paper packaging, don't particularly seem alike, at first glance. But after spending time with them, one finds many similarities. Ms. Lakner dresses like her employer, in a chic but conservative style, and both women share some mannerisms. "I represent Mrs. Green, so I must be dressed," Ms. Lakner said, absently twisting her Cartier watch on a brown alligator band. "You can never make a first impression twice."
One morning a few weeks ago, Ms. Lakner, who studied art and architecture at the Parsons School of Design, spoke of her job in the chintz-filled den of Ms. Green's Park Avenue apartment. "How do I descibe this?" she said, "I operate command central. I'm the hub. I feel like the control tower."
Most people who know Ms. Green know and love Ms. Lakner. They praise her handwritten place cards, invitations and reminder notes, a skill refined in private calligraphy classes. The one thing she does not write is Ms. Green's thank-you notes; that would be a faux pas.
A chief role for Ms. Lakner is to shield her employer from some of the everyday unpleasantries of human interaction. "I can't stand to break dates," Ms. Green admitted. "I have Marina close her door," she said, so she doesn't have to hear the dirty deed being done on the phone.
Ms. Green said she also has her social secretary deal with requests for money from distant relatives, visit her mother (not instead of her, but in addition to her) and arrange lunches. "Who wants to be bothered with all that stuff -- bills, insurance, addressing invitations, chatting endlessly with your friends?" Ms. Green said. "Marina does all the things I don't want to do."
Apparently, Ms. Green's friends don't begrudge her her dislike of idle chatter, because her lavish parties, some for celebrities and authors, are always well attended. Usually, Ms. Lakner greets guests in the lobby while they are checking their coats.
"I'll say, 'Hello Mr. Hayden-Guest,' " Ms. Lakner said, "and he'll say, 'How did you know my name?' They like that recognition. They may not be the people in People magazine, but I see that glitter in their eye on recognition."
Just then the phone rang, and Ms. Green left the den to take the call. When she returned she announced that the decorator Mario Buatta had been on the line and instructed her to "stop the interview." She reported what he had said: "Judy, don't do it. Marina will get a swelled head, a lot of offers, and you'll lose her. Seriously, don't let her do this."
Ms. Lakner shook her head and said, "That could never happen."
Ms. Green, fluffing her hair before an 80-woman lunch at Daniel, had one last thought about her social secretary: "If she could only do hair, I'd give her a huge raise."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Examining Nuts and Bolts In an Age of Rocketry

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
EVEN in this stock market, which continues to break all records, nothing quite compares to the history being made in the market for initial public offerings. The buckets of money pouring into fledgling companies' shares and the delirium that surrounds new-issue trading today have never been seen before.
This year, according to Sanford Bernstein & Company, capital raised in initial offerings will total more than $75 billion. That is roughly equal to the amount raised in new stock issues during all of the 1980's. 
 Monster moves in these stocks on their first day public are also breaking records. From 1986 to 1994, the average first-day move in an initial offering was about 10 percent. Today, the average stock rises 60 percent on its first day.
Many of these hot new issues are Internet concerns that operate in a sphere all their own: About one-third of those that issued shares this year paid more in investment banking fees than they booked in revenue in the most recent 12 months.
Even old-economy I.P.O.'s rise sharply today. First-day gains on all initial offerings have totaled $29 billion this year, more than the gross domestic product of Bolivia.
That is a hefty chunk of change for issuers to leave on the table. Many companies don't seem to mind; they like the buzz generated by a rocketing stock price and the investors who pile into the shares after they pop.
Nevertheless, all is not well in I.P.O. land. Steve Galbraith, the senior research analyst at Bernstein who compiled these stunning figures, says issuers and institutional investors are growing unhappy with the new-issue machinery. Many players see the big initial run-ups in these stocks as benefiting a few investors -- the lucky fund managers who get allotments in exchange for conducting fast and furious stock trading with the underwriting firm -- at the expense of the many. Big investors are restless, Mr. Galbraith says; he forecasts a change in the way I.P.O.s are issued.
For example, institutional investors, unhappy with small I.P.O. allocations, may demand more Dutch auctions, in which investors put in their bids and get allotments based on supply and demand, the same way most United States Treasury bonds are sold.
And some issuers, eager to pocket more of those first-day gains, wonder what services the investment bankers provide for their sky-high fees. Sure, bankers line up buyers when most investors are cool to initial offerings. But when the market is incendiary, as it is now, such support is unnecessary.
Some small firms have tried to change the business. But while other parts of Wall Street undergo transformation, most initial offerings are still done the old-fashioned way: with high fees and allocations to favored investors. While fees charged to debt issuers have plunged in the past decade, those charged to equity issuers have stayed remarkably high -- about 4 percent of the deal.
This cannot last. Mr. Galbraith thinks the investment banking powerhouses Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Merrill Lynch are most vulnerable to change and the lower underwriting fees it would bring. "You don't need to prop up these stocks; you need to open them up," he said. "The market is determining the price of these companies, and the issuer shouldn't have to pay as much for that."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;
Messinger's Out of Politics, but Politics Aren't Out of Her

BYLINE: By JIM O'GRADY 

 BODY:
Last Tuesday evening, in the middle of teaching a class about city government at the Hunter College School of Social Work, Ruth Messinger indulged in a fleeting self-reference.
She and her students were discussing current events when she noted that while Hillary Rodham Clinton had pledged to serve a full term if elected to the United States Senate, her presumed opponent, Mayor Giuliani, had not. 
 "Then again, Giuliani didn't announce in '97 that he would serve out the whole term as Mayor," Ms. Messinger recalled. "And you may have noticed it didn't hurt him."
She was referring to the Mayor's 1997 re-election with 57 percent of the vote against 41 percent for her.
That said, it was time to change the subject, which Ms. Messinger does frequently, especially when the subject is career setbacks of historic proportions.
She begins each class by presiding like the host of a television talk show devoted to politics. With her students playing pundits, they run through the week's big stories, such as the timing and repercussions of Ms. Clinton's announcement that she intended to run for the Senate. Ms. Messinger said the First Lady's action was partly designed to dispel the hoary notion that women had difficulty making up their minds; the class, which consisted mostly of women, seemed to agree.
As for the surcharge on collect calls from New York State prisons that is collected by Sprint and shared with the Department of Corrections, Ms. Messinger observed that "if the government were not involved, this would be called a kickback." And on the man who attacked Nicole Barrett with a paving stone, she said, "I'm just waiting to find out if the person was really homeless or not." (Subsequently, the police arrested a suspect who apparently has spent some time on the streets.)
After concluding her term as Manhattan Borough President in January 1998, Ms. Messinger was unemployed until August of that year. "I didn't like it at all," she said.
She has worked since then as the president and executive director of the American Jewish World Service, a nonprofit agency that assists developing nations. In January she expects to fly to Turkey to inspect the agency's earthquake relief program. She also teaches a night course in urban studies at Queens College.
For the semester's last class, which meets this week, Ms. Messinger's Hunter College students are assigned a paper on a social service policy they would change and how they would do so.
One student, Iris Bishop, a training specialist at the Administration for Children's Services, said after class that the assignment reflected Ms. Messinger's pedagogical agenda.
"She wants us to realize that there's always something that can be done about an issue," Ms. Bishop said. "It's all about how to play the game politically." JIM O'GRADY

HEADLINE: BUSINESS WORLD;
Selling to Argentina (As Translated From the French)

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: LA PLATA, Argentina

 BODY:
WHEN Wal-Mart opened its first store in Argentina four years ago, it found itself cast in the unaccustomed role of David -- against a Goliath of a competitor in Carrefour, the French general merchandise chain. And finding a slingshot has been anything but easy.
Carrefour's position here is formidable. Argentine shoppers have long felt at home in its stores, much as they historically have taken to other French trends and fashions. Argentine painters, architects and psychologists have all taken cues from France. Even the tango was only fully accepted by polite Argentine society after it became a hit in post-World War I Paris. Carrefour has been so readily accepted here since it arrived in 1982 that it is now the country's largest retailer. 
 Still, Wal-Mart executives felt that if Carrefour's fleur-de-lis logo could catch on in the Francophile Argentina of the 1980's, the yellow Wal-Mart smiley face could do the same when the cultural winds here seemed to be blowing America's way. Globalization, and with it American cultural influences, swept through the country in the early 1990's, and by 1995 Argentines were beginning to dress more casually, drink more beer and less wine, and even acquire a taste for jazz and the blues. And English was replacing French as the primary foreign language taught in schools.
So with typical Yankee can-do confidence -- some would call it arrogance -- Wal-Mart entered the Argentine market with a team of American managers and the same basic store model that worked from Des Moines to Dallas.
The meat counters featured American cuts like T-bone steaks, not the rib strips and tail rumps that Argentines prefer. Cosmetics counters were filled with bright-colored rouge and lipstick, though Argentine women tend to like a softer, more natural look. And jewelry displays gave prominent placement to emeralds, sapphires and diamonds, while most women here prefer wearing gold and silver.
The first few stores even had hardware departments full of tools and appliances wired for 110-volt electric power; the standard throughout Argentina is 220.
But the miscalculations went beyond the merchandise mix, and all the way to the widths of store aisles and the carpeting on the floor. Only by trial and error did Wal-Mart learn that far more Argentine customers than Americans were in the habit of stopping at a store each day. The much greater traffic meant more sales of small items, but also aisles that always seemed overcrowded and floors that always seemed dirty and wore out rapidly.
In entering Argentina, Carrefour had kept its Frenchness fairly subtle, At Wal-Mart, however, it soon became clear that the Americanness was too obvious, and counterproductive. Wal-Mart will not divulge any sales or income figures for its Argentine operations, but analysts here and on Wall Street say the company racked up huge losses in its first few years in Argentina and only began to break even, or perhaps turn a small profit, last year.
Credit Suisse First Boston estimated last year that Wal-Mart's sales in Argentina were running about $500 million a year, less than a quarter of Carrefour's. Carrefour has 23 big stores in Argentina, while Wal-Mart has 10, plus 3 warehouse membership clubs.
And Wal-Mart has overhauled its top management in Argentina four times in four years.
"Wal-Mart seemed to be learning by doing, and that can be very expensive," said Martin Redrado, an Argentine economist. "Carrefour better understood from the beginning the local idiosyncrasies and managed its strategy around local conditions."
 Wal-Mart's current leadership here concedes the point. "Following our blueprint too closely wasn't a good idea," said Donald C. Bland, president and chief executive of Wal-Mart Argentina.
It is a lesson that Wal-Mart may well take from Argentina as it expands globally and finds itself toe-to-toe with Carrefour in more and more countries. They already compete fiercely in Brazil, Mexico and South Korea, and when Carrefour has finished acquiring the Primordes chain, it will be the second-largest general merchandise retailer in the world after Wal-Mart, but with more international experience.
BUT Wal-Mart seems to be learning, as can be seen here in La Plata, 50 miles southeast of Buenos Aires. The American chain competes with a Carrefour store just down the street for an essentially suburban, middle-class clientele; in only one other place in the world -- near Sao Paulo, Brazil -- are the two companies' stores so close to each other.
When Wal-Mart came to La Plata in July 1997, it avoided repeating many of its early mistakes.
The aisles were made wider than in the first few Buenos Aires stores, and the floor was scuff-resistant tile, not carpet. Metal displays for fish gave way to ceramic tile reminiscent of traditional Argentine fish markets. Wooden wine shelves with overhanging arbors replaced metal racks, a change that bolstered wine sales by 20 percent in other stores.
Tailoring its La Plata store to Argentine tastes meant glazing doughnuts with dulce de leche, a caramel-like confection. Clothing racks hold more articles in medium sizes and fewer in large sizes, because Argentines are on average a bit smaller than Americans and like a tighter fit.
"Let's call it the tropicalized Wal-Mart way," said Cristian Corsi, an Argentine Wal-Mart district manager, with a smile.
THE chain even adopted some French touches here and in the nine other main stores around the country, like big supplies of croissants in the bakery department and tripe in the meat aisle.
"They have adapted pretty well," said David Shriver, a retail analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. "And they have stolen a lot of ideas from Carrefour."
Still, while Wal-Mart has made progress, on one recent Tuesday the Carrefour store here was decidedly busier all day, and shopping carts seemed to be piled higher. It is not obvious why. Customers interviewed in each store were divided over which was cleaner, had better prices or selection or gave better service. If competing cultural affinities are at war here, Argentine shoppers do not seem to notice -- at least not consciously; few said they thought of either store as being American or French. Both stores fly Argentine flags prominently.
But that does not mean the Wal-Mart and Carrefour stores don't say, in their own way, "Vive la difference." Carrefour's wine selection is much greater and its produce and fish displays more elaborate: piles of shrimp and lobsters look as pretty as a still life. The cheese counter is a small outpost of France, with neatly stacked Roquefort, Gruyere, Chamois d'Or and St. Albray.
At Wal-Mart, the selection of microwave ovens, gardening tools and golf supplies is larger, but the cheese section is decidedly less fragrant, with a heavier emphasis on fontina and provolone.
"American, French -- workers like me don't care about the country," said Hugo Felgueras, a 51-year-old livery driver, as he eyed Carrefour's cheeses. "We just care about our pockets and prices." Yet there he was with the French cheese. If his tastes don't change, Wal-Mart will probably stock more Gruyere.

HEADLINE: The Small-Screen City

BYLINE: By NANCY HASS

 BODY:
ON a recent fall night, a detective from the 15th Precinct ambled along a shabby street downtown. Passing beneath a street lamp, he glanced up for a moment. His face, a road map of despair, was sheathed in white light.
Cut. 
 From the shadows, an assistant director popped out. Why had no one cued the sound of a woman shouting out her window in Brooklynese? And where were those extras hired as passers-by, the girl with the nose ring, the three homeboys with the superbaggy jeans?
For that matter, where was New York itself? The scene, from the ABC drama "N.Y.P.D. Blue," did not take place on location, but on an elaborate blocklong set known familiarly as Mulberry Street, built years ago on a studio lot near Century City. The Emmy Award-winning cop show has been lauded for its evocation of New York grit, but it is entirely written, shot and produced in sunny California.
"I feel the show is emotionally expressive of the rhythms and textures of New York," said its co-creator, David Milch.
It may seem strange that a show like "N.Y.P.D. Blue," in which New York is almost a member of the cast, has no real connection to the city itself. But from a historical perspective, Mr. Milch's disclaimer makes perfect sense. It has been said -- even sung -- that New York is a state of mind. Nowhere is that more evident than on television.
Movies are expected to create their own reality, reinvent setting, elevate locales to cinematic art. But just the opposite is expected from the small screen. Television bills itself as a reflection of everyday life, not surprising for a product made too fast and too cheaply for elaborate photography. Add that network television aims to be as one-size-fits-all as possible, and the result is the bland everyburbs and generic urban wastelands many shows wallow in.
Thus it is all the more remarkable that New York is among the only places television has ever bothered to bring alive. From the Yiddish lilt of "The Goldbergs" in the 40's and the black-and-white melodrama of "Naked City" in the 50's to the baroque urban lexicon of "Seinfeld" and the couture-inspired swagger of "Sex and the City," no locale has been more exploited, deconstructed, parodied, toned down and gussied up, not to mention more culturally influential.
While critics have long attributed negative perceptions of the city to violent imagery on the evening news, an argument can be made for the influence of prime-time entertainment on popular views of New York.
"You have to wonder what's the cart and what's the horse," said David Marc, a professor of television studies at the S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University, "if how we've seen New York portrayed in sitcoms and dramas over the years reflects reality at all or whether it's just Hollywood responding to what it thinks the public wants and then creating an image to suit its purposes."
On television, New York has largely been used as shorthand for the extremes of human experience. It has at various times been cast as a way station for weirdos and ethnics, a caldron of violence, a haven for swells.
"If you look back at the progression of shows, you get a pretty clear idea of what the industry was trying to avoid and what it figured was a good idea to promote," said Norman Lear, the creator of "All in the Family," the influential sitcom of the 1970's. "You don't really need a voice-over."
 
In the Late 90's, The Picture Comes Into Focus
Lately there have been so many images of New York in prime time -- more than at any time in history -- that a big, messy composite of a big, messy city has at last emerged. Since 1996, most of the top-rated sitcoms have been have been set in New York, and increasing numbers of hourlong dramas are situated here. While movie production has fallen off this year, television production is way up. Next season 14 shows will be made in New York, including 8 new ones.
The city seen on the small screen in the last few years is both a racy, crime-infected snake pit and a latter-day Holly Golightly carnival. It is a preposterously luxurious launching pad for young things reluctant to grow up ("Friends"), a stainless steel jungle for high-end crime ("Law and Order") and a place where even a tasteless woman from Queens can marry a millionaire ("The Nanny").
There have been several golden ages for shows set in New York, and this is definitely one of the most multidimensional, though one that often seems lined with fun house mirrors. The insecurities of the young marrieds on "Mad About You" were comfortably contained in a prewar apartment that people like them would be unlikely to own. The title character in "Felicity" has had an undergraduate education free of fluorescent dorm lighting. Bill Cosby's new neighborhood in Queens is a mixed-race wonderland many New Yorkers might consider closer to Brigadoon than Kew Gardens.
But at least the New York now on screen is, like the real thing, as unclassifiable as the legendary elephant that stumped the blind men. Tom Fontana, the creator of "Oz" and "Homicide" who is now shooting his new police series, "The Beat," on the Lower East Side, said the show would be much more nuanced than it would have been 10 years ago.
"Back then," he said, "it would have been much more bleak and murderous, more full of graffiti and drug deals."
The change can be traced to the mid-1990's. Two events mark it: the slide in the crime rate and the immense success of "Seinfeld," which had its premiere in 1990. That show disproved a sacred Hollywood belief: that a series about the neurotic foibles of distinctly Jewish single people in their 30's could never be a hit in Iowa.
With site-specific references like street-parking etiquette and the trauma of having a girlfriend move "away" to downtown, the show, which was made in Los Angeles, was a virtual comedy of manners about contemporary life in Manhattan. Like Noel Coward, it limned a rarefied slice of society but touched on universal experience. That approach might not have worked if its territory were Minneapolis, but, as NBC executives discovered, there was a bankable fascination with New York in the hinterlands.
More important, the growing sense that the city was hospitable, both to residents and to production companies, induced some influential people, like Michael J. Fox of "Spin City," not merely to set shows in New York but to shoot them in the city as well.
Although his series makes more of its star's unique charm than its locale, Mr. Fox said he works hard on touches like insisting that office interiors "have some New York grime" and incorporating real passers-by instead of extras into the outside scenes. He said he was adamant about creating the show around a scrappy New York political operative rather than a Beltway type.
"I've always thought that the early career successes I've had were based a lot on the fact that I was an Irish kid with a little Cagney punim who could pick up New York rhythms," Mr. Fox said.
Even more than the networks, HBO has pursued shows with a New York sensibility, and shoots them here. Three of the cable channel's four series are set and shot in and around New York -- "The Sopranos," "Oz" and "Sex and the City." Of all the New York shows on television, "Sex and the City," with its carefully chaotic street scenes, avant-garde fashions and minutely observed social rituals, may be the one that most fully taps into the city's current mood.
"There is a reason the girls on the show pretty much only have bedrooms," said Sarah Jessica Parker, who is both the star and an executive producer. "It's not just to suggest sex. It's to convey a stylized but real idea of what life is like for girls in New York. People here don't live in their kitchens. They negotiate life from their bedroom."
 
From the Lower East Side Via the Borscht Belt
Despite the dramatically different way New York was portrayed when the medium first started, some things are strangely the same. During the late 40's, television was as New York as Broadway. The creators were the children of immigrants, straight from the Lower East Side and the Borscht Belt. They wrote about what they knew, which made economic sense as well; most of the television sets were in big cities anyway.
"The Goldbergs," originally a radio show that ran on television from 1949 to 1953, was centered on Gertrude Berg's recollections of her large Bronx family. Most of the action took place as Mrs. Berg's character, Molly Goldberg, hung out the window of her tenement, gossiping with her neighbors. "The Honeymooners," ostensibly set in the 1950's, was Jackie Gleason's homage to his Depression childhood in a Bushwick cold-water flat. Two of Sid Caesar's most popular characters on "Your Show of Shows" were the downtown jazz men Progress Hornsby and Cool Cees.
By the mid-1950's, the bulk of the writers had moved to Los Angeles. The public was also on the move, to the suburbs. Television followed them. Family sitcoms, now the most popular form of entertainment, largely abandoned New York for places like Mayfield ("Leave It to Beaver") and Springfield ("Father Knows Best"). The only other genre to emerge in the 1950's, the western, was also distant from urban life. Excitable immigrants were replaced by accentless adults and freckle-faced tots. Even the Goldbergs bailed out; in the show's last season, the family moved to the suburbs.
A handful of shows set in New York endured during the 50's and early 60's, but a clear division emerged in how Hollywood handled their inhabitants. Many New York characters were down-at-the-heels castouts, like the "Honeymooners" or the cops in "Car 54, Where Are You?" In "The Dick Van Dyke Show," Rob and Laura lived in New Rochelle, while Sally, the man-hungry spinster, lived in a dank one-bedroom apartment in Midtown Manhattan.
"The name of the town to which the Goldbergs moved said it all, Haverville," said Dr. Marc, the Syracuse professor. "Television became a place where the haves lived in the suburbs and the have-nots got left behind in the city."
The exceptions were the Ricardos and Danny Thomas's brood. Although "I Love Lucy" was shot in Hollywood, it conveyed the deeply New York sensibility of Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz, who controlled production in a deal virtually unheard of at the time. The Ricardos lived in a believable one-bedroom apartment in a building that might indeed have been in the East 60's.
Ricky was no Ozzie Nelson. He wore open-collared shirts and brilliantined hair. He worked in a smoky club brimming with chorus girls. The tone was set in the pilot: Lucy and Ethel wanted to spend an evening nightclub-hopping; Ricky and Fred lobbied for the fights.
"Make Room for Daddy" also portrayed 1950's New York with a Stork Club edge. Mr. Thomas, who was indeed a nightclub star, played one. The antithesis of the suburban dad, he was flashy, egomaniacal, sarcastic. Mr. Thomas's character was widowed in the series and remarried to a younger, prettier wife outfitted in Dior. Every season the family moved to a new apartment.
"That show was totally New York to me," said Mr. Fontana, the writer-producer who considers himself among a new breed of creators working strictly out of the city (he currently shoots HBO's "Oz" on a set above Chelsea Market). "It was so different than 'Leave It to Beaver' or 'Father Knows Best.' As a kid in Buffalo I would think to myself, 'That's why I want to come to New York.' "
Although "Naked City," the noirish crime drama shot entirely on location in New York from 1959 to 1963, began the careers of Dustin Hoffman, Robert Redford and Peter Fonda, such stylish realism never had a chance in the television industry of the era.
By the mid-1960's, Hollywood embraced a more swinging ethos that left New York in the cold. Largely avoiding the era's politics, television latched onto two genres: broad farces like "Petticoat Junction" and "The Beverly Hillbillies" and series set in the surfer culture of Southern California. The few shows that used New York as a framework, like "Family Affair" and "That Girl," rarely alluded to the city.
But as the 1960's melted into the post-Watergate 1970's, television returned to New York through a glass darkly. Film had led the way, with Martin Scorsese's "Mean Streets" and Sidney Lumet's "Serpico." The city seemed a perfect venue for the newly popular hourlong police drama.
"Kojak" epitomized the genre. Shot virtually in shadow, the brightest thing on the screen was Telly Savalas's shaven head. Kojak's New York was teeming with prostitutes and addicts, on the verge of collapse. Only Savalas's strong hand kept chaos at bay. "Who loves ya, baby?" became a quintessential New York refrain.
Another quintessentially New York voice was emerging: Mr. Lear's. He insisted on setting his ground-breaking show, whose premiere was in 1971, in a working-class area in Queens, where he was raised. Although shot in Los Angeles and set largely in one room, the sitcom tasted piquantly of the boroughs outside Manhattan. Archie Bunker saw himself not merely as a regular guy in an average ethnic neighborhood, but as a New Yorker who was essentially superior.
Mr. Lear also set "The Jeffersons" in New York, this time on the Upper East Side, and in many ways it was more essentially tied to the city. Not only did it make fun of the pretensions of wealth, regardless of race, but the Jeffersons' neighbors also included prime time's first interracial couple. "You tell me what other city that show could possibly have been set in in 1975," Mr. Lear said.
Mr. Lear was not the only sitcom producer to rediscover New York in the 1970's. Others also returned, to portray a city that derived much of its personality from a single group: Jews. "Barney Miller," "Welcome Back, Kotter," "Taxi" and "The Odd Couple," all seminal 1970's series, were each dominated by characters not only instantly recognizable as New Yorkers but also clearly, though not explicitly, Jewish.
"You always have a delicate line between what's New York and what's Jewish," said Carol Leiffer, a comedian and writer for "Seinfeld," which walked that line more boldly two decades later. "At a lot of points, depending on the characters you're writing and the situations they're in, there really is no line at all."
By the 1980's, two things again brought an end to television's love affair with New York and its kooky ethnics: a protracted labor dispute, and Hollywood's growing obsession with glamor, which resulted in money-soaked series like "Dynasty," "Knots Landing" and "Dallas." The New York-based cop-buddy show "Cagney and Lacey" was more about female bonding than a sense of place. "Night Court" descended into a sexual farce. Putting "Kate and Allie" in New York seemed simply a device to render the plight of two divorced mothers less pathetic. Ditto "Bosom Buddies," starring Tom Hanks. Where else but in New York, where apartments are so expensive, would two young men re-enact "Some Like It Hot" in an all-girl hotel?
In 1984, "The Cosby Show" became the first sitcom in decades to be shot in New York, because Mr. Cosby wanted to continue living here. But the phenomenally successful show did little to highlight the city. The Huxtables' Brooklyn Heights brownstone might just as easily have been in Mr. Cosby's hometown, Philadelphia.
 
The Competition For Authenticity
Perhaps the most significant aspect of television's return to New York this past decade has been the simmering competition for authenticity, or at least soulfulness, among the tough-talking men who specialize in creating cop shows. In the past, no one cared about doing the city justice, but these days it is a text of moxie, or perhaps machismo. Next season, it will get even more heated. Some writer-producers like Mr. Fontana insist that the shows must be written, produced and shot in New York to feel truly real. "You need to taste the food and push past people on the streets," he said.
His show for UPN, "The Beat," due in March, will focus on two uniformed officers on the Lower East Side. To add a new element, the street scenes are being shot on videotape, while the scenes about cops' personal lives are shot on film.
Dick Wolf, who created "Law and Order" in 1990, disagreed that shows set in New York had to be written and produced in the city, though he is a big believer in shooting shows here on location. "Law and Order," which led the exodus back to New York in 1990, is shot here, as is his new series, "Law and Order: Special Victims Unit." A series he is developing starring Oliver Platt is about a New York City tabloid columnist who is "a cross between Breslin and McAlary." It will be shot in New York.
Mr. Milch also wants to shoot his next show here, for the first time. After six years of shooting "N.Y.P.D. Blue" on the Mulberry Street lot and on sound stages, he conceded that "the product probably would benefit from being shot on the streets."
The new show is a logical progression in his city-obsessed oeuvre, he said. "Hill Street Blues," which took place in an unnamed ghetto, "enacted the collision of liberal impulses with unmanageability of the city, optimism encountering despair for the first time."
"N.Y.P.D. Blue," he said, was "about the deals we make with fascism, how much we're willing to pay for order."
He won't discuss his next series in detail, but it will concentrate on New York as the "emblem of the city that works, the avatar of our aspirations." But as always with Mr. Milch, there is a dark side. The New York he will next portray is the "most fully realized of our theme parks."
Despite the obvious enthusiasm for New York shared by Mr. Fontana, Mr. Wolf and Mr. Milch, there is, predictably, a growing backlash against setting shows here. Michelle Ashford, a producer who is developing a pilot called "Silent Witness" for NBC, said she unanimously ruled out New York as a venue because it was overdone. Mr. Fontana had to fight UPN executives so he could situate "The Beat" in Manhattan.
"They begged me, anywhere but here," he said. "But I made them understand that there's an immediacy, an urgency about New York that holds infinite interest for people. It definitely has infinite interest for me."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1064 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Hey, Anybody Here Know of a Good Deal on a Company?

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON

 BODY:
IMAGINE that it is 3 a.m. and you, the chief executive of a large corporation, are wide awake, worrying whether you are paying too much to buy a company you have your eye on.
You could try rolling over or taking two aspirin and calling your investment banker in the morning. Instead, still in your pajamas, you snuggle up to the computer and log on to an exclusive Web site especially for chief executives like you. There you find the newest research on how to price a deal. You scan a list of companies that are auctioning divisions you may want to buy instead. And, if you are curious about whether sharing power with a fellow chief executive in a combined company is a good idea, you dash off an e-mail message to a colleague who has done so and ask for advice. 
 However far-fetched it seems, online chat is making its way to the executive suite in the form of a new Web site, the M & A Group. Membership, and access to the juiciest parts of the site once it is up and running early next year, will be limited to one of the most exclusive clubs on Wall Street: well-heeled chief executives interested in mergers. (A mockup of the site can be viewed at www.themagroup.com.) Something of a cross between a support group for the acquisitively inclined and an eBay for corporate subsidiaries, the concept is raising eyebrows in corporate offices nationwide.
The group says it has already attracted a cadre of prominent deal makers to its ranks of subscribers, among them Michael S. Dell, chairman of Dell Computer; Richard A. McGinn, chief executive of Lucent Technologies; Harvey Golub, chief executive of American Express; and Pete Peterson, chairman of the Blackstone Group.
Members, who pay $20,000 a year and who already number 50, are invited to a power retreat, to be held twice yearly, that the Web site's organizers hope will become the deal maker's equivalent of the World Economic Forum held in Davos, Switzerland. The first retreat begins this Thursday in Scottsdale, Ariz., and promises to be yet another hotbed of incessant merger rumors for Wall Street to buzz about.
The Web site was the idea of Dennis Carey, vice chairman of Spencer Stewart, the executive search firm, along with L. Dennis Kozlowski, chairman and chief executive of Tyco International, and Jan Leschly, chief executive of SmithKline Beecham.
Mr. Kozlowski and Mr. Leschly are no strangers to the merger scene. Mr. Kozlowski has bought about 110 companies, divisions or product lines in the last three years and recently found himself deflecting criticism of Tyco's accounting practices in mergers. Mr. Leschly's company tried to combine with Glaxo Wellcome last year, but the deal fell apart when the two companies disagreed about who would run the combined entity. Just last week, Mr. Leschly said he would retire in April.
The three men met in Mr. Leschly's Philadelphia office in June and came up with the idea as a forum for chief executives. Reasoning that there are not many merger combinations that companies have not already thought about, they perceived a need for a medium through which executives could talk among themselves without having to filter ideas through intermediaries like investment bankers.
So far, investment banks see little threat to their business. For one thing, publicly traded companies are still obliged to get a bank's opinion about whether a deal is fair to shareholders. And if more executives are talking with one another about deals, the bankers say, that might just generate more deals.
Organizers of the Web site concede that the next $80 billion megamerger will probably not be negotiated in an Internet chat room, however exclusive. The most likely users will be large companies looking to buy stakes in smaller companies or make acquisitions valued at less than $1 billion. The investment banking fees that would be paid in such transactions are relatively small, typically $500,000 to $3 million.
"No one is going to buy all of Tyco," Mr. Kozlowski said. "But some people who are interested in buying or selling a division are more comfortable appealing to me directly," rather than through lawyers or bankers. And vice versa: "If I can approach someone directly on the site, I can do it in my own time," he said. "I can lay out a case better."
Privacy, confidentiality and secrecy add up to a major issue for Mr. Carey and his colleagues. The idea of chief executives spilling secrets online raises two specters: possible violation of securities laws and the chance that a hacker will tap into sensitive information and profit by trading on it. Mr. Carey pointed out that similar concerns apply to any communications medium, even the United States mail. But he agreed that member executives would use the site only if they were satisfied that it was secure.
"We hope it will work, but who knows," Mr. Kozlowski said. "That is where we are going to have to trust each other."
CHIEF executives will use a protected password and be the gatekeepers for use of the site by others at their companies. Executives will be able to post questions on the site without using their names. And while there will be chat rooms for general topics, executives will also be able to converse privately through the site, Mr. Carey said.
Most sections will be open only to chief executives. But some parts of the site, including a "virtual investment bank" that lists companies and subsidiaries that are for sale, will be made accessible to selected colleagues, like chief financial officers.
And contributors like consulting companies and investment banks will be invited to publish research reports on the site at a cost of $50,000 a year.
Even Mr. Carey does not believe that the final details of any deal will be worked out over the Internet. "Once a party thinks they hit it off with another, they will most likely just pick up the phone," Mr. Carey said.
Other Internet sites have been based on similar concepts, but so far they have received little attention, in part because they have not been able to attract a roster of such prominent charter-member executives. But Mr. Leschly said the new site was an idea whose time had come. "There has been a lot of secrecy in our business," he said. "For me to call up Michael Dell is impossible. I don't know him, but he's a smart guy. I could learn something. Now I can talk to him any time."
