In "The Pursuit of the Millennium," the historian Norman Cohn illustrates the five ways in which medieval millennialists identified salvation.
1. It will be collective.
We're here, together, waiting for the same thing. . . .
2. It will be realized on this earth.
Grinding din of workmen digging up street, heaviness of humidity. . . .
3. It is imminent.
Man on cell phone, hand held out with casual certainty. . . . Two women, both in black suits, competitors, eye each other, ready to pounce. . . .
4. It will be total -- utterly transforming life.
An undeniable truth in heavy rain. Or when it's freezing and you're not properly dressed. Or when you're late. Like increasingly frantic father with son's backpack. Mother, with squirming daughter, waving wildly. . . .
5. Finally, it will be miraculous.
Yes. Only one of blind mystical faith like the man with the cell phone, hand still out, can really expect one now. The others peer irritably into the distance. Lights atop yellow cabs unlighted -- inauspicious.
But then. . . . A golden gypsy slows, sparkles beside the believer, blinks its headlights. . . . Just one. . . . The left. . . . It's a sign!
It's a taxi.

Her flowered skirt sways above her ankles, like curtains in a breeze. She makes her way intently around the circular beacon that is the Information Booth in Grand Central Terminal, oblivious to the streams of men charging off the escalators, wielding briefcases big and battered. She walks first past the red schedules, the green, then the blue, selecting one of each -- Westport, Greenwich, Tuckahoe -- as if she were choosing fruit.
She passes through the line of harried questioners ("Can you tell me how to go to Metuchen, N.J.?") and drifts past the man who sets his coffee cup on the shelf holding the schedules, knocking some to the floor, where they lie, ignored.
Her journey complete, she files her stack carefully in her black shoulder bag. Knowing now how to get to every New York suburb at every hour of the day, she turns her back and heads toward the subway.

B - John Berendt Green-Wood Cemetery, Brooklyn
John Berendt is the author of "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil."
Except for the distant drone of a lawn mower and the higher-pitched whapping sound of an edge trimmer somewhere out of sight, all is stillness on this grassy hilltop in New York's "Garden City of the Dead."
In the shadow of an imposing bronze statue of Minerva, Charles Higgins, the inventor of India ink, slumbers in a heavy, banklike mausoleum. Some yards behind him, the remains of the musician Leonard Bernstein lie under a simple marker set flush into the ground. Five small stones have been placed on it.
Half a million people are buried in this cemetery, and five more are lowered into it every day. They tell me that 135 groundskeepers maintain these 478 lush acres, but all I know is not a single living soul came into view during the minute I stood watch.

B - Harvey Shapiro Brooklyn Promenade
Harvey Shapiro is the author, most recently, of "Selected Poems."
There they are
the water-hugging giants of Manhattan
breathing the dun-colored air of morning.
Silent, mysterious
seen through a white scrim of fog.
 
Directly beneath me, commuter traffic
of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.
Across that, on the Brooklyn docks
one lone forklift tractor, loaded with steel rods,
jockeying back and forth
before the Strober Bros. Building Supply Depot.
Across the water, dimly descried,
nested in the green arches of Battery,
a perky yellow Staten Island Ferry.
 
But the buildings pulsing in their various
shades of white
and now, as the fog thins slowly,
a pale dusty blue, out of Giotto,
seems to descend behind them.
 
These mighty presences at the end of
Manhattan Island,
fronting the East River that is not a river
but a tidal strait carrying
the North Atlantic to our very doorstep.
 
These monuments that dominate our day
as if they had been fixed there forever
though they are in flux as the waters are in flux.
 
They stand before us
like tribal gods meting out success and unsuccess,
all that we have to lift our eyes to.

Frank McCourt is the author, most recently, of "'Tis."
It is the first day of the academic year for the High School for Health Professions and Human Services. This is where I used to teach, from 1969 to 1987, back when Stuyvesant High School was in this building.
Students crowd the sidewalks between First and Second Avenues. They sit on the steps of the old brownstones opposite their school. They also lean against cars, triggering alarms, which they then imitate. They laugh till security guards or other adults from the school ask them to please stay off the cars. The students are polite, but when the adults go back into the building, they relax against the cars again.
Along the street, there are reunions, cries and hugs. Hi, Joey. Hi, Miranda. Wow, you lost weight. Love your hair.
The student population seems to be largely African-American, with smaller groups of Hispanics and Asians and an even smaller group of whites. When I taught here, the population was mostly Jewish, though as the years went on it became increasingly Asian. The school bell rings, and the boxes, bags and bottles containing foods and drinks must be disposed of. Adults from the school ask the students to please pick up their garbage and put it in the can, but there is litter and the school year has begun.

PUB-DATE: December 5, 1999
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 7;Page 38;Column 1;Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 3465 words

HEADLINE: Architecture

BYLINE: By Martin Filler; Martin Filler is the architecture critic of The New Republic and writes for The New York Review of Books and House Beautiful.

 BODY:
AMERICAN BUILDING: The Environmental Forces That Shape It. By James Marston Fitch with William Bobenhausen. (Oxford, $40.) "As completely as fish in water, people are submerged in their own environment," James Marston Fitch writes. "But, unlike fish, people act upon their environment as well as being acted upon by it." How we do that -- through our natural and artificial responses to light, heat, cold and sound, to say nothing of space, time and gravity -- is the subject of this revised version of a classic work first published by Fitch in 1947 and now thoroughly updated (with the help of the architect William Bobenhausen) to reflect the immense technological changes since then. Their masterly and surprisingly accessible investigation of the functional aspects of architecture addresses issues that few nonprofessionals consider, though the world would be greatly improved if they did.
The 90-year-old Fitch, doyen of the historic-preservation movement in America, is also an ardent champion of modernism, but he can be frank in his assessments of its physical shortcomings and failures. With a refreshing lack of ideological bias and awe-inspiring erudition, he and his co-author roam across a vast terrain, from the effects of lighting on worker productivity to global warming, from the thermal properties of the igloo to the ergonomics of bathroom fixtures. Their proposed solutions to many architectural and planning problems display so much common sense as to seem obvious, and yet the wisdom they bring to their encyclopedic topic is anything but commonplace. This book ought to be mandatory reading for every architecture student, as well as for any citizen concerned with raising the quality of the built environment. 
 POMPEII: Public and Private Life. By Paul Zanker. Translated by Deborah Lucas Schneider. (Harvard, $22.95.) The thousands of Pompeians smothered under the volcanic ash of Vesuvius on Aug. 24 in A.D. 79 survive in the modern imagination. Eerily preserved, their remains and those of their fashionable resort town -- one of the Hamptons of ancient Rome -- provide our clearest picture of urban life 2,000 years ago, illuminated by the mundane details that give Pompeii an immediacy (and profound humanity) exceeding that of other archaeological sites.
Paul Zanker, the director of the German Archaeological Institute in Rome and a professor of classical archaeology at the University of Munich, has written what is destined to become a classic study. Quietly authoritative, Zanker's brief yet endlessly suggestive overview of Pompeii and its buildings puts architecture, as it ought to be, squarely in the context of the social and spiritual attitudes that produce it.
As the austere values of the Roman republic were superseded by the exotic Hellenistic tastes of the expanding empire, houses of the well-to-do were transformed into sanctuaries for recreating the golden age of Greece, as well as private stages for Dionysiac pleasures once considered corruptly unpatriotic. Pompeii's inward-turning retreats replicated Greek architecture, wall paintings and sculptures, sometimes with gardens as miniature landscapes that gave the illusion of travel without the inconvenience.
As Zanker writes of one such Pompeian dream house: "Perspectives actually intended for wider views are cunningly inverted -- architectural elements borrowed from villas in the country or by the seaside are crammed together into a Walt Disney world. . . . The owner, eager to imitate the lavish world of villas he so clearly admired, preferred quan-
tity over quality." Readers will find several such parallels between life today and the competitively materialistic, luxury-worshiping and nostalgia-fixated inhabitants of not-so-distant Pompeii.
GERMAN CASTLES AND PALACES. Edited by Klaus Merten. Photography by Paolo Marton. (Vendome, $75.) Less familiar now than their counterparts in Britain, France and Italy, the buildings of German princes and nobles were nonetheless every bit as splendid as could have been wished during the centuries when impressive size and ornamental excess were outward signs of political might. Though there are several famous landmarks in this sumptuous collection -- including the Tiepolo-frescoed Baroque residence of the prince-bishops of Wrzburg, Frederick the Great of Prussia's Rococo bijou of Sanssouci, and Ludwig II of Bavaria's operatic, neomedieval castle of Neuschwanstein -- many of the 53 works chosen by Klaus Merten, the chief curator of palaces and gardens for the state of Baden-Wrttemberg, come as a revelation.
Among the most delightful is Favorite, the summer palace of the dukes of Wrttemberg, in Ludwigsburg. Its vigorous, warmly colored stucco exterior, built around 1720, contrasts with the cool elegance of the neo-Classical interiors, redone at the turn of the 19th century. By the 1820's, when the greatest German architect, Karl Friedrich Schinkel, remodeled and decorated the romantic hideaway of Charlottenhof on the grounds of Sanssouci for the Prussian crown prince and princess, the remarkable transition from authoritarian display to familial gemtlichkeit was complete.
JOHN SOANE: An Accidental Romantic. By Gillian Darley. (Yale University, $45.) JOHN SOANE: Architect. Edited by Margaret Richardson and Mary Anne Stevens. (Royal Academy of Art/Yale University, $75.) Sir John Soane died the year Queen Victoria ascended the British throne, but more than historical happenstance made him a pivotal figure between ancient tradition and nascent modernism. Soane, the brilliant, ambitious son of a bricklayer, immersed himself in the classical tradition, but was so sure of his talents that he played with the grand manner in ways none of his contemporaries dared. He slashed fearlessly through walls, floors and ceilings to create dynamic interiors that soar, plunge and even seem to hover in midair, none more so than those of his own London residence, which he worked on from 1792 to 1834. That intricate, obsessive remodeling of a plain Georgian row house into a private museum is a touchstone to architects mesmerized by Soane's powerful manipulations of space and scale; they are intensified by the plethora of art objects and architectural fragments with which the compulsive collector fended off his horror vacui.
This compellingly readable biography by the British architectural historian Gillian Darley brings Soane, the working-class knight, to life as a mass of contradictions: a paranoid with real enemies, a once-devoted father who became estranged from his sons and a roaring eccentric who rose to the pinnacle of his strait-laced profession. Probing deeply into the architect's now largely destroyed body of work, Darley revisits many long-forgotten structures, including the imaginative outbuildings of country houses that survived through benign bucolic neglect. In an intriguing postscript, the author notes her subject's enduring influence in Sir Giles Gilbert Scott's iconic red telephone booths of 1924, the shallow pendentive dome of which was clearly inspired by Soane's family tomb.
"John Soane: Architect," the ravishingly illustrated catalog of the superb exhibition held at the Royal Academy of Art in London this fall, vividly conveys the elusive luminosity and spatial daring of his buildings. In their rule-breaking audacity they remain accurate reflections of his singular vision and angular personality.
E. W. GODWIN: Aesthetic Movement Architect and Designer. Edited by Susan Weber Soros. (Bard Graduate Center/Yale University, $75.) Now known only to decorative arts specialists, the 19th-century British architect and critic Edward William Godwin is best remembered for his modern-looking, clean-lined ebonized furniture. But Godwin was renowned in his own time as a leader of the aesthetic movement, involving a group of well-heeled rebels who wanted to free the arts from Victorian moralizing and to foster a sensuous "art for art's sake." Enraptured by the rich visual culture of Japan, which only recently had been revealed to the West, he showed his fellow aesthetes James McNeill Whistler and Oscar Wilde (for whom he built and decorated houses in London) how to live the exquisitely rarefied life they philosophized about.
Inspired by styles from the Egyptian to the Chinese to the Gothic, Godwin designed everything from ceramics and wallpaper to costumes and theatrical scenery. He typified his period's fascination with the gesamtkunstwerk in his fully coordinated environments wherein no detail was left to chance.
Far from being a paragon of preciousness, Godwin was outrageous and contentious, carrying on an affair with the celebrated actress Ellen Terry (by whom he fathered two children, including the theatrical designer Edward Gordon Craig) and sparring with collaborators. Reform-minded but self-indulgent, he never shared the philosophical interests and political activism of his protean design rival, William Morris, and soon after Godwin died at 53 in 1886 his work slipped into oblivion.
This superlative catalog, now the essential publication on the subject, was edited by Susan Weber Soros, founder and director of New York's Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, where the Godwin exhibition she curated is on view through Feb. 27. In an excellent series of essays by Soros and nine other experts, a cumulative portrait of the multifaceted architect emerges that is strongly outlined and finely detailed.
SHINGLE STYLES: Innovation and Tradition in American Architecture, 1874 to 1982. Photography by Bret Morgan. Text by Leland M. Roth. (Norfleet/
Abrams, $49.50.) One of the bright spots on the American scene after the Civil War was the rise of the shingle style, an architectural mode that drew on the aesthetic movement as well as American colonial traditions. In contrast to the vulgar showplaces of the era's new rich, the shingle style -- named for its favored cladding material by the architectural historian Vincent Scully -- demonstrated how grand houses could be free of ostentation but full of dignity, establishing a standard for plutocratic restraint that persists in old-money circles to this day.
The multigabled, porch-wrapped mansions that were popular in resorts like Tuxedo Park, N.Y., Newport, R.I., and the East End of Long Island soon became the model for smaller domestic schemes throughout the country, a logical adaptation because the shingle style took many of its cues from modest sources. This handsome survey, selected by Leland M. Roth, an architectural historian at the University of Oregon, and illustrated with the moody color photographs of Bret Morgan, is a worthy celebration of a distinctively American way of building.
Though it was a mistake for Roth to include lesser shingle style revival work of recent decades (like an awkward postmodern pastiche by Robert A. M. Stern), in the book one can look back with unadulterated pleasure on many glorious examples of the real thing.
GAUDO: The Man and His Work. Text by Joan Bergos. Photographs by Marc Llimargas. (Bulfinch, $75.) BARCELONA ART NOUVEAU. Text by Lluis Permanyer. Photography by Melba Levick. (Rizzoli, $55.) Fueled by a booming textile-manufacturing economy, turn-of-the-century Barcelona was further fortunate in having adventurous architecture patrons who prompted a torrent of creativity. Modernisme, the Catalan variant of Art Nouveau, was a farrago of Moorish, Gothic and Classical details so strongly seasoned with Arts and Crafts elements that an entirely new style emerged, which its proudly nationalistic supporters saw as a fitting expression of Catalonia's cultural independence.
Though the sensuously molded and bizarrely detailed structures of Antonio Gaudi are well known, the Catalan photographer Marc Llimargas's eye for revelatory detail is extraordinary. The vibrant color images he took for "Gaudi: The Man and His Work" (translated from a 1947 book by Joan Bergos, a younger collaborator of the master) make it seem as though one is seeing those buildings for the first time.
In "Barcelona Art Nouveau," Lluis Permanyer, a native of the city, and the American photographer Melba Levick do equal justice to the work of Gaudi's less-acclaimed but gifted contemporaries, especially Lluis Domenech, Josep Puig and Josep Vilaseca. Domenech's Palau de la Musica Catalana of 1905-08 is the city's architectural masterpiece. No other concert hall approaches its over-the-top opulence and decorative superabundance. The ceiling of the auditorium is aglitter with fan vaults of mosaic peacock feathers, studded with ceramic roses in full bloom and culminating in a spectacular stained-glass dome that recalls an immense, inverted Tiffany lampshade. As Permanyer writes, "It is the most modernist building in the world."
IRVING GILL AND THE ARCHITECTURE OF REFORM: A Study in Modernist Architectural Culture. By Thomas S. Hines. (Monacelli, $75.) Trained in Chicago by Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright, Irving Gill found early 20th-century Southern California to be fertile ground for his rigorously unornamented architecture and progressive movement politics. Gill was captivated by the pared-down forms of Indian adobes and Spanish colonial missions, as well as the white-walled, cubic North African Arabic buildings that also inspired his like-minded European contemporaries Adolf Loos and Le Corbusier. Gill sought to sweep away retrograde historicism and supplant it with a pure, energizing architecture he believed would promote everything from better hygiene to more equitable social standards.
Gill, who was a Quaker, declared, "We must dare to be simple, and get back to the source of all architectural strength -- the straight line, the arch, the cube and the circle." That he did in a pathbreaking series of public buildings, private houses and multi-unit dwellings, culminating in his arcaded La Jolla Woman's Club of 1912-14 and the minimalist Dodge house of 1914-16 in West Hollywood. Favoring inventive new methods like slab-tilt construction -- in which concrete was poured into rectangular molds on the ground and then hoisted 90 degrees to make walls -- Gill was as innovative in practice as he was in spirit. Most touching are the dozen low-cost but highly dignified adobe-style concrete cottages he completed in 1933, three years before his death, for the Rancho Barona Indian Reservation in Lakeside, Calif., bringing full circle his homage to the architecture of the inhabitants' ancestors.
Alas, two-thirds of Gill's 300 buildings have been torn down, the majority of the remainder altered beyond recognition, and his archives were put out with the trash, making this first-ever monograph a heroic effort. Scrupulously researched and engagingly written by Thomas S. Hines, a professor of history and architecture at the University of California, Los Angeles, this long-hoped-for volume fills a shocking lapse in architectural literature.
CARLO SCARPA ARCHITECT: Intervening With History. By Nicholas Olsberg, George Ranalli, Jean-Francois Bedard, Sergio Polano, Alba di Lieto and Mildred Friedman. Photographs by Guido Guidi. (Canadian Center for Architecture/Monacelli, paper, $45.) Although the Venetian architect Carlo Scarpa (1906-78) is unknown to the general public, he has long been a cult figure among professionals. They revere Scarpa's fanatic attention to detail in his small but emotionally engaging structures, which display a rare ability to focus on the intimate and the cosmic with equal intensity. Though he built very little, and most of that consisted of remodelings of existing structures, his principled stance against rampant commercialism and internationalization have special pertinence today.
Scarpa fits neatly into no niche of the modern movement save his own. Immersed in the architecture of his birthplace and the surrounding Veneto region, he knew better than to ape it. "I have always had . . . an immense desire to belong to tradition," he said, "but without having capitals or columns." Instead, he honored the past through contemporary forms made from local materials and constructed with age-old techniques. His regionally rooted but universally resonant designs -- above all three Italian museums and several memorable tombs -- feel so authentic because he cared not a whit about style and everything about the enduring verities of architecture.
This publication of the exemplary Scarpa exhibition held at the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal earlier this year makes the architect's often cryptic schemes more intelligible to a general audience than ever before. The thoughtful essays, particularly those by the show's guest curator, Mildred Friedman, and its designer, the American architect George Ranalli, explain Scarpa's continuing hold on the architectural mind. Guido Guidi's subtle color photographs are among the most affecting architectural images in recent memory, capturing the spirit of place that was all-important to the master, as well as evoking his poignant sense of the passage of time.
VENTURI, SCOTT BROWN & ASSOCIATES: Buildings and Projects, 1986-1998. By Stanislaus von Moos. (Monacelli, cloth, $65; paper, $45.) Like their contemporary, Andy Warhol, the self-described Pop architects Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown have always been more appreciated in Europe than in America. It is easy to understand why. The deceptively superficial appearance of some work by this Philadelphia-based husband-and-wife team, as well as their nonjudgmental embrace of commercial imagery, has led certain critics to dismiss them as capitulating to the venal impulses of a celebrity-mad, consumer-driven society. Their genius for taking the givens of popular culture and transforming them into high art is more apparent to those at a safe remove from a setting where such wry (but also affectionate) appropriations hit a bit too close to home.
Among Venturi's and Scott Brown's most perceptive commentators is the Swiss architectural historian Stanislaus von Moos, a professor at the University of Zurich. This second volume in von Moos's survey of their complete works reconfirms him as a level-headed and insightful appraiser of their wildly varied output. Their schemes can be by turns appropriately majestic (like their Sainsbury Wing of 1986-91 at the National Gallery in London, which displays Renaissance paintings with immense nobility) or provocatively gaudy (the Hotel Mielparque Resort Complex of 1992-97 in Nikko, Japan, part ukiyo-e (floating-world) print, part comic book, part "Madama Butterfly" stage set). But these architects are auteurs of their medium, and every project of theirs is worthy of serious consideration.
For all their stylistic swings, Venturi and Scott Brown have developed a brisk business in campus architecture. At Princeton and the University of Pennsylvania, among other schools, they have taken the Victorian collegiate style and abstracted it into an adaptable vocabulary of lively patterned brick jolted with the odd, unexpected detail, all the while responding to traditional settings much more effectively, and subversively, than the big names of modernism ever did.
GEHRY TALKS: Architecture + Process. Edited by Mildred Friedman. (Rizzoli, $65.) Because he almost never writes, Frank Gehry has been taken to task by his theory-oriented colleagues, who think that hypothesizing about architecture is more important than making it. Since the completion of Gehry's universally praised Guggenheim Museum Bilbao in Spain two years ago, the audience of those who want to know why he designs and how he builds such idiosyncratic structures has grown exponentially.
To answer the clamor for a first-person account of his work, Gehry agreed to discuss his architecture with his old friend Mildred Friedman, the former design curator of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, who organized that museum's landmark 1986 retrospective of his work. Friedman has taped and edited a long series of conversations with the architect about his output since her show. This is the best explication yet of his creative method; it is exceptional for its comprehensiveness, clarity and extreme candor.
Friedman covers the decisive shift in Gehry's career from small-scale projects designed by conventional means to larger schemes of amazing complexity made possible by his firm's use of Catia, a computer program devised for plotting the irregular forms used in the aerospace industry. That software was the breakthrough that enabled him to retain the spontaneity of his initial sketches in the final design at Bilbao. "This is the first time I've gotten it," he says of that newfound freedom. "And once you taste blood, you're not going to give up."

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Even in Transition, A Seamless Sound

BYLINE: By SARAH BRYAN MILLER; Sarah Bryan Miller is the classical-music critic of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch.

 BODY:
A MUSICAL organization goes through constant minor transitions: changes in personnel, changes in repertory. Chanticleer, the 20-year-old male vocal ensemble based in San Francisco, has weathered its share of those. But now it faces a greater change, with a new general director and new performing ambitions.
"Chanticleer is definitely at a crossroads," said Lynn Luckow, the chairman of its board. "The question is, how do you build on past successes to ensure future significance?" 
 The 12-voice chorus, named for the rooster in Chaucer's "Nun's Priest's Tale" whose singing was "swich a joye," will perform three concerts of Christmas music in New York this week: one on Monday at Grace Church in Greenwich Village and two on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. These are among the hundred or so concerts Chanticleer gives each year, 80 of them on tour in the United States and around the world. Chanticleer, which claims to be the nation's only full-time independent classical vocal group, was founded in 1978 by Louis Botto, a tenor who served as artistic director until his death in 1997. Its male sopranos and altos, singing in well-developed falsetto, join the tenors and baritones in an unusually seamless blend.
When Philip Wilder, an alto, joined Chanticleer 10 years ago, only eight members sang full time. "The swing people sat at home and waited for a chance," said Mr. Wilder, who doubles as artistic administrator. "In 1991, they made the financial commitment to have 12. That was a major shift in the way they did things. The repertoire changed, and so did the blend. In 1994, we signed with the Teldec label, which gave us worldwide publicity and added new opportunities and new challenges. There are growing pains for any music ensemble that gets this kind of acclaim. It's both a curse and a blessing."
Joseph Jennings, the music director since 1984, agreed. "When we went full time, a lot of our people had real jobs and couldn't just run off and join the circus," he said. "But it was the right thing to do. The whole idea was to attract career singers, as opposed to those who viewed singing as an avocation."
Chanticleer rehearses five hours a day, five days a week, when in San Francisco, a regimen that together with its collaborative artistic process makes for unusual security in its music-making. It performs without a conductor, and Mr. Jennings does not always travel with it.
"Most of our concert programs are done 50 times," he said. "The music actually comes to sing itself."
If there is any constant, it may be the Chanticleer sound. "It's a clear sound but one that has lots of color to it," Mr. Jennings said. "We choose singers who are flexible vocally and stylistically, and incorporate all the voices into the total fabric. We try to be as authentic as we can to each style, but we color that authenticity with our 20th-century American existence."
Mr. Botto's death was a great loss to the group. "Louis was so much more than a founder or a boss," Mr. Wilder said. "He was a dear friend. He ran it with the passion of a parent. We're moving in a more professional direction now, but it was a hard transition."
The transition should soon be complete. Christine Bullen, an administrator with a strong background in vocal music, is taking on the newly created position of president and general director. Ms. Bullen, who was director of the San Francisco Opera Center from 1982 to 1993, where her responsibilities included a touring company, is returning from a stint as director of the opera training center at the Paris National Opera.
"In Chanticleer's first phase, they developed themselves and their market," Ms. Bullen said. "Now the need is for administration, and to figure out what their new directions are for the new millennium. It's time to address some institutional issues about the group and its future, about the line between classical and nonclassical music, which is blurring, and the line between profit and nonprofit."
Chanticleer has moved beyond its original early-music focus to incorporate gospel and popular songs, and it regularly commissions new works. "The Renaissance and Baroque were their original statement and will continue to be their statement," Ms. Bullen said. "Chanticleer is very radiogenic. That its recordings are so well received is important going into the new century. But the group is still dedicated to live performance, to looking into the eyes of its audience."
Hilde Limondjian, the general manager for concerts and lectures at the Met Museum, welcomes that dedication. She first hired Chanticleer in 1991 and has brought it back every year since.
"They've sung everything for us, from early music to contemporary to Christmas carols, and they've built a wonderful following," she said. "For all the seriousness of their presentation, there's a lightness in their presentation, a joy and sparkle, which communicates to the audience."
The mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade, who performs with Chanticleer from time to time, called them "just extraordinary." "They offer inventive programs and inventive combinations of sound," she added, "and they are so much fun to work with and to hear."
Chanticleer spends about half its time on the road. Tours are usually kept under two weeks, except overseas, where such a limitation would make neither economic nor scheduling sense.
"Yes, it's hard work, but to be immersed in music to this degree, to touch as many lives we touch, really is a privilege," Mr. Jennings said. "Some people go through their whole lives wondering what they should be doing. We're lucky to know our calling."

HEADLINE: JERSEYANA;
Woolworth in New Jersey: A Love-Hate Relationship

BYLINE: By HELEN PIKE 

DATELINE: RUMSON

 BODY:
Atlantic City's lifeguards bought tanning lotion there. Menlo Park shoppers flocked to the chain's first art show. Customers in Elizabeth bought sheet music after pianists performed requests.
Every day, patrons in Newark lined up in front of the store on Broad Street -- its largest in the state -- to wait for a seat at the popular lunch counter. 
 Frank W. Woolworth knew in the 1880's what is now taken as fact: New Jersey's cities represented the potential for enormous retail success. His first store in the state opened in Trenton in 1885, just third in the nascent chain after Utica, N.Y., and Lancaster, Pa.
Indeed, New Jersey residents spent enough nickels and dimes to rank the state behind New York City and Chicago. By 1890, Woolworth's net worth was estimated at $100,000.
"Not bad for only having 100 stores in the country," commented Karen Plunkett-Powell of Rumson, who wrote the recently published "Remembering Woolworth's: A Nostalgic History of the World's Most Famous Five-and-Dime" (St. Martin's Press, $27.95). At that time, the Trenton store led the country in sales.
By the time Mr. Woolworth died in 1919, there were 1,081 stores nationwide, 38 of which were in New Jersey.
Initially, all Woolworth looked for was a heavily trafficked sidewalk on a city street near the train depot. The rest of his high-volume, low-margin strategy lay with inventory affordable to the working poor, many of them immigrants who had left an economically depressed Europe. By 1913, with the state's industrialized cities swelling, New Jersey sales constituted a significant portion of the $13.5 million in cash Woolworth paid to build his landmark Manhattan headquarters, Ms. Plunkett-Powell said.
Simply put, Woolworth was netting one penny for every five-cent item bought at the five and dime. The coins kept pouring in because Woolworth had changed the way people shopped. He was the first merchandiser to use open, self-service displays so customers could readily examine what they wanted to buy.
And Woolworth's was the first chain to offer glass Christmas tree ornaments and the first to have in-store dining -- separate tables plus a counter.
Woolworth's competitors followed him street by street around the country, usually opening about a year later. For example, in Asbury Park, Woolworth and and J. J. Newberry were side-by-side on Cookman Avenue. His other competitors included McCrory, Kress and Kresge.
"He had a burning desire to succeed and nothing else mattered," Ms. Plunkett-Powell said of the man, who also was a tireless promoter. One year, the largest Woolworth's in Elizabeth and Newark had piano players to play on demand.
"Frank was the first retailer to do this," she said. "While other big department stores had pianists play background music as customers shopped, Frank hired them expressly to sell sheet music."
The store in Menlo Park was the first in the chain to put on an art show. "Not Elvis painted on velvet," said Ms. Plunkett-Powell, "but fine art.."
And Woolworth's was the first American chain to offer men a training program so they could work their way up from stock boy to the executive suite. But Woolworth also made his managers sign contracts stipulating they would never gamble in the stock market, though they could by buy shares of stock in F. W. Woolworth Company.
Not surprisingly, many employees considered their boss a busybody. Because of the New Jersey stores' proximity to the Manhattan headquarters, Woolworth personally kept managers on their toes by arriving in a disguise and trying to shoplift.
He also wanted highbrow retail at lowbrow prices, so his bargain stores carried products with such names as Fifth Avenue stationery, Evening in Paris perfume and Palm Beach lotion.
But those names did not unlock the door to the high society to which he desperately aspired. During the Gilded Age, he bought his way into the Deal Golf Club, said Ms. Plunkett-Powell. Other charter members included President McKinley, George M. Pullman and William Randolph Hearst.
But like their summer neighbors -- Isador Straus, who owned Macy's, and Frank Hartford of A&P -- they didn't accept the merchant who sold "Cheap John" goods, and Woolworth eventually moved his family to a mansion in Glen Cove, N.Y., on the North Shore of Long Island.
Frank Winfield Woolworth was born in 1852 on the family's meager potato farm in Rodman, N.Y., about 11 miles from Watertown, where he got his first job as a stock boy in a general store. He died in 1919 at Winfield House, his mansion in Glen Cove. He and his wife, Jennie, had three daughters who were raised to enjoy all that the nickels and dimes could buy. But neither the daughters nor their children took an active interest in the daily business of the company.
The so-called heirs to the Woolworth empire were his executives, including Hubert T. Parsons, his eventual successor, whom he treated as the son he never had. Mr. Parsons built the country's only small-scale reproduction of Versailles, in West Long Branch. Today it is the administrative building for Monmouth University.
In 1960, when the company was approaching its corporate peak with $1.35 billion in sales worldwide, there were 300 stores in New Jersey. The 287 in North Jersey generated $30 million, and the Newark stores alone $5.94 million.
The Woolworth Company's decline was a slow 20-year process that began when consumers' buying habits started to change because of the appearance of shopping malls. It reflected the change from downtowns and trolleys to automobiles and enclosed shopping arcades.
The second shift was from within the company as it diversified its divisions, beginning with the acquisition of Kinney Shoes. The Venator Group, the more upscale athletic gear unit that today owns Foot Locker and Champs, began outperforming the five-and-dime division.
It wasn't until the Woolworth doors started closing in the summer of 1997 -- when there were only 34 stores left in the state -- that Ms. Plunkett-Powell began receiving phone calls from lifelong employees.
In addition to executives giving out her phone number, Ms. Plunkett-Powell received calls, letters and e-mail responding to an ad she ran in Writer's Digest and a request she posted on the message board of the Woolworth/Venator stock page on the Internet's stock board.
"They needed to talk, to reminisce, to have someone listen to their stories," she said.
She was struck by the similarity of experiences no matter what city and state: marriages between store managers and sales clerks; the smell of grilled cheese sandwiches and the banana split giveaways; flirtatious GI's who swarmed the candy counters on V.E. and V.J. days; of teenagers who crammed the ubiquitous photo booths.
Company trivia is sprinkled throughout "Remembering Woolworth's" such as the 250 million pounds of gum sold in 1950 or the 1929 back-to-school season, when 4,000 miles of pencils and 300 miles of pen points were sold. The book also has 57 personal recollections from around the world.
"I promised my mother I would imitate the lives of the saints if she would buy me a blue parakeet," said Clare Wharton of Parsippany of the pet she chose over the menagerie of miniature turtles, hamsters, goldfish and baby chicks at the Fair Lawn store, where they shopped in the 1950's. By the time Ms. Wharton's mother finished her errands in the sewing department, she had given in to her daughter's pleadings.
"Six dollars could sure buy a lot of happiness," Ms. Wharton recalled.
As for Ms. Plunkett-Powell, a native of Jersey City, where there were four Woolworth stores, news that the Venator Group would close the variety stores to concentrate on athletic goods "touched me personally."
Ms. Plunkett-Powell, who wrote "The Nancy Drew Scrapbook: 60 Years of America's Favorite Teenage Sleuth" (St. Martins's Press, 1993), remembers buying her first Nancy Drew mystery at her neighborhood Woolworth, the hub for nearly all social activity.
"Where else could you go to meet friends?" she asked. "Or buy pantyhose in a pinch when you were on your way to meet a boy?"

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Community College Enrollment Reaches an All-Time High

BYLINE: By KAREN DEMASTERS 

 BODY:
Full-time enrollment in New Jersey's 19 community colleges reached an all-time high this year after falling slightly in 1998. Part-time enrollment remained nearly steady from last year, though drastically down from the early 1990's.
Full-time enrollment, mostly by students acquiring two-year associate's degrees, reached 55,425, a 3.3 percent increase over last year's enrollment of 53,600, according to the New Jersey Council of County Colleges. The 1999 enrollment topped the previous high of 54,600, reached in 1993. 
 Tuition freezes at most of the colleges account in part for the increase, said Lawrence Nespoli, council president.
Enrollment of part-time students held steady for 1998 and 1999 at almost 67,500, according to the survey. However, that number is a dramatic decline from the 85,000 part-time students in 1993, according to another study, conducted by the state Commission on Higher Education and expected to be released later this month, said Judy Savage, a spokeswoman for the commission.
A strong economy and high employment usually mean a decline in part-time enrollment, Ms. Savage said. KAREN DeMASTERS

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In / Murray Hill;
A Quiet Enclave Close to Midtown

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
THE Murray Hill neighborhood, an urban enclave just south of Grand Central Terminal and the Midtown office district, is known for its 19th-century brownstones, clean streets and trees -- 505 of them according to community activists. But, say real estate professionals, it is also notably undervalued.
"I've been working here for 30 years and have been waiting for prices to take off," lamented Nicholas B. Fiore, president of Brixton, Camberwell & Poole Ltd., a real estate firm that specializes in Murray Hill. "People view it as old fashioned, without the trendy bars and the action of hotter areas, such as Chelsea. So beautiful brownstones here can go for 30 percent less than similar ones in neighborhoods that I don't think are as good." 
 But the president of the 1,200-member Murray Hill Neighborhood Association has a different outlook.
"We like it quiet," said Diane G. Bartow. "We are a stable population that has remained in the area for a long time."
The main shopping street is Third Avenue, a low-key area with one supermarket, several dry cleaners, greengrocers and reasonably priced restaurants. Among the better-known eating establishments in the area are Hudson Place (American and Chinese), Nicola Paone (northern Italian), El Rio Grande (Tex-Mex), and Sarge's Deli, all in the Third Avenue corridor.
Community Board 6, which includes Murray Hill, defines the area as from 34th to 40th and from the East River to Madison Avenue.
Housing is divided between four-story, 19th-century town houses -- mostly brownstones and limestones -- on the streets, and high-rise apartment buildings, mainly on the avenues. Town houses go for between $1.5 million and $3 million, according to Mr. Fiore, with a rule of thumb being about $350 per square foot of living space. Rents in town houses range from about $1,300 per month for a studio walkup to about $2,800 for some two-bedroom units.
Co-op apartments in high-rise buildings start at about $120,000 for some small studios and go up to $450,000 or more for two-bedroom units in luxury buildings. Condos are mainly in the luxury high-rise buildings and start at about $250,000 and exceed $550,000 for some two-bedroom units.
Among the more luxurious buildings, according to Mr. Fiore, is the elegant Griffon, a 15-story prewar building at 77 Park Avenue, at 39th Street.
OF the newer luxury buildings, the largest is the 57-story, 863-unit Corinthian on First Avenue and 38th Street, where amenities include a health club with a running track and pool. Peter Katz of Madison International Real Estate, who specializes in high-rise apartments in Murray Hill, says that prices in the Corinthian start at $350,000 for some one-bedroom apartments and can go as high as $800,000 for some two-bedroom units on high floors.
The two things that residents of Murray Hill hate most, according to a survey conducted by the neighborhood association, are noise and traffic, both a which are present in abundance. The Queens Midtown Tunnel exits onto East 35th Street, funneling traffic through the neighborhood's narrow streets, just past the brownstone owned by Stephen A. Weingrad, a lawyer who is former president of the association.
"The good part is that the tunnel and our proximity to Midtown makes us convenient to everything," Mr. Weingrad explained. "The bad part is that this also makes everyone else drive through our neighborhood."
The primary school serving Murray Hill is the 820-pupil P.S. 116 at 210 East 33rd Street, which covers grades 1 to 5 and has a highly rated gifted and talented program. Enrollment has grown by 12 percent since 1996, reflecting Ms. Bartow's contention that more young families are moving into the neighborhood.
On standardized tests, P.S. 116 students consistently outperform city averages. For instance, on third grade reading tests, 95.1 percent of P.S. 116 students demonstrated they could read at grade level, compared with a city average of 65 percent; on fourth grade science tests, 98.4 percent of the students performed at state grade levels, compared with 89.3 percent of city students.
 Murray Hill takes its name from Robert Murray, a Quaker merchant who moved from Pennsylvania to New York in 1753 and built a farmhouse at what is now the corner of 37th Street and Park Avenue. Grand Central Terminal was built on what was the Murray cornfield.
Murray's wife, Mary, is said to have played a key role in the Revolutionary War. When Gen. William Howe crossed the East River from Long Island in 1776, pursuing Washington's troops and attacking New York City, Mrs. Murray and her daughters invited General Howe and his officers to tea.
They accepted and were detained long enough to allow Washington and his troops to escape. The Daughters of the American Revolution has put a plaque honoring Mary Murray at 130 East 37th Street at Lexington Avenue, the site of the Murray Mansion, which burned down in 1835.
The descendants of Robert and Mary Murray also played a key role in the preservation of the residential character of the neighborhood. In 1847, they drew up the Murray Hill Restrictive Agreement, which still applies to some of the older deeds. Those deeds contain clauses banning the use of the properties for slaughterhouses, glue factories or circuses.
LED by the neighborhood association, residents jealously guard the character of their enclave. Among the association's successes was thwarting a 1960's attempt by the city to improve traffic flow to and from the Midtown Tunnel at the expense of the neighborhood, according to Mr. Weingrad, the former association president.
"The city wanted to widen 35th and 36th Streets coming out of the tunnel," he explained "So they decided to condemn all of the stoops of the brownstones for several blocks and pay the owners to create new, street-level entrances. We fought it and they dropped the plan."
There is a small historic district in the neighborhood, covering Sniffen Court, a dead-end alley of 10 two-story houses on 36th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues. The houses were originally built by John Sniffen in the 1850's as stables for Murray Hill residents. They were converted into town houses in the 1920's.
The association has urged the Landmarks Preservation Commission to have most of Murray Hill declared a historic district, which would make it practically impossible for developers to buy up brownstones, knock them down and build larger structures. There are 13 designated historic buildings in the area, not including the first home of Franklin D. and Eleanor Roosevelt, a 14-foot-wide brownstone at 125 East 36th Street.
"There are 109 buildings in the area concerned and we have the support of 54 property owners so far," said Ronald Kahn, an architect who lives in Murray Hill and is spearheading the historic district effort.
BESIDES the historic district, the main issue that the neighborhood association is now concerned with is the proposed sale of four acres of Consolidated Edison industrial sites along the river.
"If they sell to residential developers who build 90-story apartment house towers," said Mr. Kahn, "they could double the population of the neighborhood."
The neighborhood association has joined with community groups from several other neighborhoods in the East Midtown Coalition for Sensible Development to monitor developments at the site, according to Ms. Bartow.
"We want to be able to react prior to any developer getting approvals, rather than after the fact, when it might be too late," she explained.
Among the important resources in the neighborhood are the New York City Science, Industry and Business Library on 34th Street at Madison Avenue, and Stern College, the women's branch of Yeshiva University, at Lexington and 35th Street. And its most outstanding historical site, by far, is the marble and limestone Italian-style Pierpont Morgan Library, which J. Pierpont Morgan completed next to his mansion in 1906.
The library, at 29 East 36th Street, includes Morgan's structure, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, and an annex, built in 1928 by his son, J. P. Morgan Jr.
The library houses an extensive collection of books and manuscripts, including three of the 47 remaining Gutenberg Bibles. It is open Tuesday through Saturday, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m., Sunday, noon to 6 p.m. Admission is free, but there is a requested contribution of $7 for adults and $5 for children and the elderly.
Through Jan. 9, 2000, the Morgan Library is running an exhibition called "The Great Experiment: George Washington and the American Republic." It traces Washington's evolution from loyal British subject to revolutionary leader and first president of the United States.

MORGAN'S MIGHT: On Nov. 2, 1907, the country was two weeks into an economic panic. There was a run on the banks, several of which had failed, and the New York Stock Exchange was in turmoil. The Trust Company of America, one of the largest trusts in the world, was in danger of collapsing and sparking a depression. J. Pierpont Morgan gathered 50 of the nation's leading bankers in his library in Murray Hill. He insisted that they come up with $25 million in loans and guarantees to save the Trust Company of America. Bankers who tried to leave found the doors locked. At 4:15 a.m., Morgan presented the bankers with his plan, under which each was obligated to fund a portion of the bailout package. The first of the bankers was led to the table and given a pen. He signed the agreement and the others followed suit, averting the crisis.

HEADLINE: Nouveaux Riches Learn the Rules

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
SINCE 1984, when he bought Oheka Castle, Gary Melius has met many wealthy Long Islanders who live in grand homes on the legendary Gold Coast.
The Cold Spring Hills castle, completed in 1919, was once the home of the financier Otto Hermann Kahn. With 126 rooms, a dining room that seats 200 and a full domestic staff, the castle was the site of frequent and extravagant parties. 
 Mr. Melius, a prominent developer and businessman who lives in Carle Place and restored the estate for private parties, knows a growing number of Long Islanders with "new money" who live on the Gold Coast but are unfamiliar with the rules that dominated the era.
"We live in big houses but we don't know how to manage a domestic staff and we don't throw lavish parties," Mr. Melius said. "We're not from the Gold Coast era and don't know the lifestyle from that time."
Just after the turn of the century, during a time of great prosperity, families with names like Vanderbilt, Whitney, Phipps, Kahn and Guggenheim built opulent homes in which to hold grand parties. Situated along the North Shore from Great Neck to Huntington, their mansions were run by staffs of butlers, grooms, gatekeepers and chambermaids, and their social interactions were dominated by codes of etiquette.
As F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote in "The Great Gatsby," the Gold Coast era was "a time that would never come again."
With money not from oil or copper but from Wall Street, the Internet and a booming economy, more families are moving to the Gold Coast -- some into original mansions that have been renovated, and others into newer grand homes. Yet despite their wealth and yearning for the elegant living of the past, etiquette experts say, these families often do not know how a proper table should be set, how to hold a proper dinner party or how to manage a domestic staff.
"For people with new money," said Christopher Allen of East Hampton, a former butler and an etiquette consultant, "there is often a gap between their new social status and their knowledge of etiquette. They have so much money, but nothing to back it up. Unlike those with old money, these people didn't go to charm school or learn how to dance properly, and don't know how to behave. They send their children to private school, but manners are not taught. I have no doubt that many will have to ask someone to teach their children how to eat properly."
Clifford Greenhouse, co-owner of the Pavillion Agency, a domestic agency in New York City that serves many clients on the Gold Coast, agreed.
"People with new money are hungry for acceptance into society," he said, "but have no experience and are lost as to how to achieve it. To run a 20,000-square-foot house they need a domestic staff, but don't know the rules of how to treat that staff or how to get the most out of them."
Teaching wealthy homeowners how to manage a domestic staff has become a growing part of the business at his agency, said Mr. Greenhouse, adding that over the last four years, the butler business has doubled.
"Homes often start with one key staff member who plays the most important role in managing the house," he said. "Depending on a family's lifestyle, it may be a chef or a butler who becomes the house manager, and then he educates the family on proper etiquette."
Home entertaining has become more fashionable in recent years, said Mr. Allen, requiring wealthy homeowners to increase their domestic staffs and learn how to use the appropriate utensil at dinner.
The return to home entertaining comes largely in response to the depersonalization of today's technology-driven society, said Carol Abramson, a personal etiquette coach in Muttontown.
"So many people who years ago gave away their good china now want to host dinner parties," she said, "and are going out to buy a new set."
A growing interest in learning the art of etiquette drew about 80 people to a lecture at Old Westbury Gardens on a recent Sunday afternoon.
Mr. Allen, the lecturer, told the group, "Manners have become so relaxed that people often don't know the right way to behave." He demonstrated the proper way to set a table and shared his own rules of etiquette.
"The oyster fork is the only fork that goes on the right side of the plate," he said, "placed in the bowl of the soup spoon. But more than three pieces of cutlery on either side of the plate is ostentatious."
When asked whether to place a napkin to the left or right of the dinner plate, he answered, "Personally, I like to put it in the glass."
There were questions about proper table manners, including which fork to use for salad or dessert, how to position the spoon when finished with soup, whether to wait for the host to be served before beginning to eat, and whether it is acceptable to eat certain foods with the hands.
"If it's on the bone," Mr. Allen reassured his audience, "like chicken or lamb chops, you can pick it up."
Ginny Parker, who traveled to the lecture from her Northport home, admitted: "I'm very concerned about the death of etiquette, especially among the younger generation who haven't learned the rules from their parents. There's no time today for families to spend together and they often don't eat together anymore."
This situation prompted Margaret DelVecchio of Baldwin to start etiquette classes for children ages 8 to 17. Two programs, Etiquette for Today and Dining Skills for Today, have been growing steadily over the last few years, she said.
"Those who grow up with a lack of proper etiquette become adults who lack manners," Ms. DelVecchio said. "Kids may not want to come to etiquette classes, but their parents are realizing a need for their children to learn these important skills."
Knowing the rules of etiquette makes people more relaxed, Mr. Allen said.
"The bottom line is that good manners make us feel comfortable with ourselves in social situations," he said. "Truly well-mannered individuals will make others feel comfortable as well, and will never make anyone feel below them."

HEADLINE: County's Health Chief to Retire

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
AFTER steering the county through a series of health crises -- including an increase in tuberculosis cases in 1997 and 1998, a rubella epidemic in 1998 and an outbreak of West Nile-like encephalitis virus this summer -- Dr. Harold N. Adel, the county's health commissioner, has announced his retirement, effective Jan. 31.
Citing the lure of his grandchildren, his cello and his hiking boots, Dr. Adel, 69, said his decision to step down was "one of the most difficult decisions I have ever made." 
 He continued, "My work in public health has been extraordinarily gratifying, especially during the last few months, dealing with encephalitis issues and developing strategies to bring the mosquito population under control."
Dr. Adel joined the County Health Department in 1990 as its deputy commissioner and was appointed commissioner three years ago by Andrew P. O'Rourke, who was then the county executive.
The commissioner said he had planned to retire several months ago but stayed on the job because of the encephalitis problem. The West Nile-like virus, which is spread to humans by mosquitoes, killed at least one Westchester resident this year and infected eight others in the county.
A total of 6 people in the New York City area died, and 55 others suffered from symptoms of the virus.
In fighting the outbreak, Dr. Adel developed Operation Mosquito Sting, a surveillance program to control infected insects next spring without resorting to the broad-based aerial spraying that was used this fall.
In a recent interview, Dr. Adel said the initial effort to identify the West Nile virus and control it foreshadowed a serious health concern that will most likely further occupy health officials. As the global economy expands, he said, diseases are traveling more easily from their native habitats. That mobility, he said, is requiring health officials to identify foreign viruses quickly to develop effective strategies against them.
West Nile virus, according to health experts, was most likely brought to the United States by an infected bird from Africa aboard a ship. Unsuspecting officials at first confused the disease with St. Louis encephalitis and took weeks to identify the actual virus.
Also during his tenure as commissioner, Dr. Adel started a program to prevent lead poisoning in children. It was financed by grants from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta and the State Department of Health. The program is now recognized nationally as a model for identifying lead-poisoned children and removing lead hazards from the environment.
In addition, Dr. Adel developed the Community Partnership for a Healthy Westchester, a public-private initiative that resulted in the establishment of a Child Health Task Force, which makes sure that every child has health insurance.
He was also responsible for starting an Environmental Health Task Force to teach the public, develop programs and recommend legislation to minimize the use of pesticides by county residents, businesses and government.
In large part during the last three years, the commissioner has focused on the economic and social causes of ill health (unemployment and sub-standard housing, for example) -- which he called, "the disgraceful disparity between the health of minorities and the rest of the county."
Now, even though he is formally stepping down from his duties as health commissioner, Dr. Adel will continue to work on some of the same issues. Besides teaching internal medicine at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, he plans to continue part-time with the county to oversee programs to deter cigarette smoking, for which County Executive Andrew J. Spano has allotted $2.5 million.
Before joining the County Health Department, Dr. Adel, a Larchmont resident for 37 years, was a professor of medicine at Albert Einstein College. He received his medical degree in 1954 from New York University and his master's degree in public health from Columbia University in 1981, and he served as a fellow in hospital administration at Stanford University Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif., from 1986 to 1987. He earned a bachelor's degree from New York University in 1950.
He is currently professor of medicine emeritus at at Albert Einstein College, adjunct professor of medicine at New York Medical College and distinguished lecturer at the Graduate School of Health Sciences of New York Medical College. He also serves as a member of the Health and Public Policy Committee of the New York State Chapter of the American College of Physicians/ American Society of Internal Medicine, and he is a member of the governor's advisory council on lead poisoning prevention, the Westchester Community College medical advisory board and the executive steering committee of the health care management program at Pace University in White Plains.
When he is not occupied with public health concerns, Dr. Adel said that he will, among other things, reunite with a lost love: his cello, which his daughter Lori bought him 28 years ago. He also plans to spend more time with his four grandchildren and to hike more.
The county executive has asked Dr. Adel to coordinate the search for his successor. Until a successor is appointed, Dr. Jean Hudson, the deputy commissioner for community health services, will serve as acting commissioner.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Bites and Bytes at an Old Cookie Factory

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
WITH the production lines that baked the first Oreo cookies long gone, the owners of the blocklong former Nabisco plant between 15th and 16th Streets have cooked up a new recipe for profits that has put food on the ground floor and is now folding in tenants such as Oxygen Media, Major League Baseball Productions and New York 1 News on the upper floors.
When the celebrity chefs of the Food Network wield their whisks early next year, they will do so in a glassed-in street-level kitchen and studio that is to be installed on the 10th Avenue end of the building. The location is a natural for the cable television channel because it will be in the same building that houses Chelsea Market, an arcade of almost two dozen food stores selling products ranging from meat and fish to wine and baked goods. The landlord intends to wire the first floor so the channel can broadcast directly from the large wholesale food preparation operations that underpin the modest retail stores. 
 "If we are talking about fish or meat or produce, we can walk a camera down the hall and film there," said Eric Ober, president of the Food Network.
The network will have 8,000 square feet of what was once a loading dock on the first floor for the test kitchen and studio, with an additional 18,000 square feet in the basement for production and technical operations.
Mr. Ober said he hopes the ground floor kitchen and studio, which will be enclosed in glass on two sides, will communicate the energy of New York to viewers the way the broadcast networks have been using views of city street scenes to perk up their morning news and chat shows.
Although best known as a place where cooks can get supplies, the building, which occupies the block between Ninth and 10th Avenues, is rapidly becoming a media center as well. Oxygen Media, a cable and Web venture oriented to women, is already in residence, with New York 1 News, a local news and Internet service provider, and Major League Baseball's recording studios preparing to move in.
The media companies are taking advantage of the unusually large spaces available in the old factory building. Nabisco operated a large bakery in the complex of 17 interconnected buildings for decades before leaving the city in 1958. The first Oreo cookie was made here in 1912 by Nabisco's predecessor, the National Biscuit Company.
The market is largely the creation of Irwin Cohen, a lawyer turned developer who had previously specialized in industrial properties, mostly in Long Island City. Many real estate executives credit him with helping revive the neighborhood by attracting people from other parts of the city who wanted to purchase the freshest of foods directly from wholesalers.
"The building is a community and he is the mayor of Chelsea," said Stuart Romanoff, an executive director of Cushman & Wakefield who represented New York 1 News in its lease of 55,000 square feet in the top floor of one sector of the building. "He develops a relationship with his tenants and tries to please them."
"There is a warm atmosphere there; it's like a village," said Jeffrey Polikoff, the director of operations at New York 1 News, which will commence operations there in spring 2001. "I've already met most of the tenants in the building." Mr. Polikoff said that Mr. Cohen was welcomed by tenants as he toured the building, which is not always the case. "Usually, you run away from your landlord," he said.
"Irwin is a real visionary," said Barry Gosin, the chief executive of Newmark and Company, which represented Major League Baseball in its decision to lease 25,000 square feet on the fifth and sixth floors on the north side of the building. "Today the area has real energy that has been fueled largely by new media."
THAT foresight is paying off financially. Brokers report that annual rents in the Chelsea Market building have risen from the teens to the mid-$30's a square foot range for the most recently concluded deals.
Five years ago a lot of vision was needed. When Mr. Cohen purchased the building, whose official address is 75 Ninth Avenue, in 1995, the neighborhood was considered distant and unpleasant and the structure itself in bad condition. Mr. Cohen bought the property with a group of European investors who have since been replaced by American real estate investment firms including Angelo, Gordon & Company, Belvedere Capital and Scoggin Capital Management.
Although it fills the entire block and appears to be one structure, it is actually a combination of 17 buildings built at various times between the 1890's and the mid-1930's.
"Nabisco started on Ninth Avenue and built its way to 10th Avenue and leaped across it before going away," said Jeff J. Vandeberg, the architect of Chelsea Market.
As a result, the first floor was a rabbit warren of small spaces with floors of uneven heights. Some parts of the building are solid concrete, while others are steel covered with concrete and still others are largely built out of massive cedar columns and planks. Elevators are scattered throughout the building, rather than gathered in a single core as in modern designs.
"The heating system was obsolete, it was short of electricity, the plumbing was poor, the roofs were below poor, the elevators were barely operating and the basement was filled with 60 to 70 years worth of garbage," Mr. Cohen said.
Mr. Cohen said he originally thought of trying to attract the city's flower market to the building, but when that did not work out he decided to emphasize food. "The idea was to take advantage of the ethnic diversity of New York," he said.
To make the first-floor space accessible, he arranged to raise and lower floors until everything was on one level and, where necessary, broke through walls. There is ample evidence of this on the main first-floor corridor, which runs through two ragged-edged brick arches that were solid walls before the renovation.
Although it looks unfinished, Mr. Vandeberg said the effect was intentional and that the structure is completely stable. "It's a parabolic opening," he said. "I drew the outline on the wall and guys with jackhammers followed it." Other interior walls blocking the corridor were removed completely.
The basis for the central corridor, Mr. Cohen said, was an old railroad track that ran into the building from docks on the Hudson River bringing in flour and other supplies for the former bakery. Shoppers who look up at the peaked ceiling may notice the vent windows intended to draw out the smoke and sparks emitted by the coal-burning locomotives.
By drawing shoppers into the interior of the building, Mr. Cohen was able to preserve the outer wall for the loading docks needed by the wholesale businesses instead of converting them to retail spaces, as would be done in many renovations. Mr. Vandeberg said that the avenue-to-avenue corridor was part of the design from the first, but that many details of the conversion were decided on as work proceeded, rather than being rigidly designed in advance.
The corridor -- which Mr. Cohen maintains is the longest interior walkway in a single building in the city -- is decorated in a style that can only be described as eclectic. Slabs of stone are on display with remnants of the holes drilled in preparation for blasting clearly visible, and cast-iron body parts -- ears, noses, feet -- protrude from the bare brick walls.
The centerpiece of it all is near the midpoint of the corridor and can be heard before it can be seen. It is Mr. Cohen's idea for an urban waterfall: water gushing from a large pipe into a pit well below the corridor's surface. Mr. Cohen said that most people find the sound of falling water soothing and that it eliminates any temptation to pipe canned music into the space.
(An exception to the no-music rule is made around this time of year for school choral groups singing holiday songs.)
Mr. Cohen said the old factory building was well suited to wholesale food operations because of the large number of loading docks and space to sort and process raw materials. But he said the operators of wholesale businesses were leery at the thought of dealing directly with the public at retail.
"Every one of them said to me, 'We don't sell to the public, we don't know how,' " Mr. Cohen said. "I told them, 'Neither do I. We'll learn together.' " He said one of the advantages of combining the wholesale and retail businesses is that the people who prepare the food are right next to those who sell it. "Every tenant in this building produces what they sell," he said.
THE wholesaler-retailers in the building include Amy's Breads, Frank's Butcher Shop, Sarabeth's, The Lobster Place and Ruthy's Cheesecake and Rugelach.
Before opening the food concourse in 1997, Mr. Cohen mounted powerful lights on the outside of the building with the objective of driving prostitutes and other undesirable hangers-on to more shadowy parts of the city. After the ground floor was established, he continued moving out most industrial tenants, such as printers, and preparing the spaces for new types of occupants.
One tenant that takes advantage of the large, rounded windows on a top floor of the building is a photography studio called The Space. David Rose, one of the partners in the business, said that when they first moved in, some clients were somewhat uneasy about coming to the area. But, he said, "That was five years ago. Now there are other studios in the area. It's a hub."
Mr. Cohen said that the aesthetics of The Space's space was wasted in the Nabisco era, when that area of the building was used as a laundry.
Oxygen Media has taken 64,000 square feet on the top floors of the building, where the 55-foot-high, column-free space on the uppermost floor once housed huge ovens. The company has installed a mezzanine level around the periphery of the top floor that is reached by an open stairway in the middle of the space. Much of the space not devoted to studios is furnished with open work stations.
The company was looking for space in a nontraditional part of the city from the start, said Theodore Rotante, a vice president of Julien J. Studley, which represented Oxygen Media. He said Mr. Cohen was eager to attract a media company to replace the garment manufacturer that occupied part of the space.
Nevertheless, he said, it took almost a year to put the deal together as Oxygen officials struggled to be confident that the factory building would work for a media company. "It was exciting and intimidating," he said. Once Oxygen had demonstrated that the location was suitable, other media companies began to make inquiries.
"Major League Baseball, New York 1 and Food Network all came after Oxygen," he said.
Some tenants have taken unusual design approaches to fitting out their space, despite the constraints imposed by an old building. When the elevator door opens to the offices of Nick & Paul, a brand-development agency, there is no receptionist to greet visitors.
Instead, they are faced with a curving corridor made of sloping sheets of translucent plastic. Those who follow it -- and it narrows as it goes -- finally find themselves in a larger but still curved space with something that looks like a reception desk.
Paul Bennett, one of the founders of the company, said that the shape of the offices was intended to express its philosophy and encourage unconventional thinking. "We don't want boxed, rigid thinking," he said. "If you look at the space from above, you would see that the design is two overlapping circles, which is symbolic of what we do."
He said the design also helped create a community within the company by not isolating anyone from the center of operations. "We have this huge elliptical courtyard," he said, "and the corridor is designed to lead people into the middle."
Major League Baseball Productions is the programming and production arm of the game and it is planning to occupy 25,000 square feet in the building. Currently the unit produces commemorative videos and a television program, Baseball Max, which is seen on the Fox sports network.
But bigger things are in the offing, said Stephen Hellmuth, the general manager. "The place is designed for a 24 hour a day baseball channel, which is clearly in our future," he said. "We have a huge fan base, each team plays 162 games a year and with news about trades and other things we will have plenty of content for a round-the-clock channel."
The old factory, with floors capable of supporting 200 pounds per square foot, was more attractive than modern office buildings with much less weight-bearing capacity because it permitted the installation of all the equipment needed to keep the station in business regardless of power failures or other interruptions.
"Irwin let me set my space up my way," Mr. Hellmuth said. "I have my own generator and my own air-conditioning and we command a lot of access to the roof for satellite dishes."
The sturdy structure also allows the station to keep a large portion of baseball's historical films and videos on hand for use in current productions. Of the 200,000 video cassettes and 100,000 reels of film in its archives, Mr. Hellmuth said, about 80,000 tape cassettes and 20,000 reels of film will be stored in the studio for easy access.
ALL the media tenants said that the high ceilings in the building would allow them to place lighting and cameras in the best positions for good pictures. "We do everything in our newsroom, and the angle of the lighting is important," said Mr. Polikoff of New York 1. "We don't want our people working in a cave."
Mr. Hellmuth said the presence of the food market downstairs was a factor in the decision to locate in the building, particularly in view of the plans to move to 24-hour operations. "It's going to be a wonderful place for creative people to be able to get something to eat no matter what time it is, and meet other creative people," he said.
Although the retail stores are currently not open around the clock, Mr. Polikoff said he expects that the vendors will find a way to meet the demand as more 24-hour tenants move into the building. "They are here 24 hours for their other operations and I think they will work things out," he said. "As it is, if you want fruit baskets in the morning or bagels, they get it done."
He said that with the food companies on site, finding meals late in the day becomes an elevator ride, rather than a long walk to an all-night eatery. "In other buildings, it can take a long walk to find food," Mr. Polikoff said. "This really is a little village."
Although the building is now almost completely leased, Mr. Cohen admits that not all his ideas have worked out as planned. One of his innovations was to install tanks of water over the elevator lobby on the Ninth Avenue side of the building stocked with various types of aquatic animals for people to watch as they waited for the elevator cars to arrive.
The original eels, salamanders, frogs and crayfish have been replaced with more prosaic tropical fish. "The other ones ate each other," he said.
