HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
When a 'Hit' Is a Grand Slam

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
WHEN Paul Sagan left his job as president of the ailing new-media division of Time Warner three years ago, he described the frustration of trying to measure online success. "You have 'hits,' which don't really mean anything," he said. "So you were always grabbing at clouds."
With his new venture, a start-up called Akamai Technolgies Inc., Mr. Sagan has not had trouble finding signs of accomplishment, or the value of hits. When Akamai (pronounced AH-kuh-my) went public Oct. 29, it raised more than $1.3 billion, and the one-day surge -- 458 percent -- was among the largest ever for a new offering. For $533,100, Mr. Sagan received nearly three million shares, now worth $617 million. 
 As president and chief operating officer, Mr. Sagan hasn't had to run a gantlet of skeptics, as when he founded the New York 1 cable news service and championed interactive television at Time Warner. From his office near the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, he doesn't mind the lack of opposition. "Sometimes," he said, "we can jump over a step."
Mr. Sagan, 40, said he saw "the real thing" in Akamai, an Internet delivery service that acts like a traffic cop, using its servers to reroute Internet traffic to head off congestion. It has more than 100 clients, including Yahoo, Disney's Go Network, J. Crew and Infoseek.
While Mr. Sagan cannot read the company's programming code ("Fortran was the last language I really programmed in"), his feel for technology is better than one might expect from his background. In eighth grade, he took photographs for the suburban newspapers his father owned outside Chicago, eventually working as a reporter. A summer job at CBS in Los Angeles led to a full-time job as a field producer at the Chicago affiliate while he studied journalism at Northwestern University.
Between school years, he worked summers at WCBS-TV in New York. Peter Landis, then a writer there, said Mr. Sagan stood out as the only desk assistant to wear a coat and tie. "Initially some people thought -- myself included -- that here was this somewhat snotty kid who was coming into the newsroom and thought he was going to take over," said Mr. Landis, now news director at New York 1. "Of course, a few years later, he took over."
By the age of 27, Mr. Sagan had become the youngest news director ever at a CBS affiliate, and kept this grueling post for four years.
Some take Mr. Sagan's self-assurance as arrogance, Mr. Landis said, but most quickly come to respect him. Mr. Landis said he admired his energy and quick wit enough to follow him in 1991 to start New York 1 for Time Warner. Mr. Sagan saw New York 1 as a challenge. "They told us we'd fail," he said. "Within a year we were one of the highest-rated networks, period, in New York City."
Walter Isaacson, then head of new media at Time Warner, recruited Mr. Sagan in 1993 to join the team that created Road Runner, an Internet access service, and Pathfinder, an umbrella Web site for Time Warner publications -- and one of the most elaborate sites of the time. Pathfinder, derided by analysts as a "money pit," has since shut down.
But even when Time Inc.'s chief executive, Don Logan, said that Pathfinder gave new definition to the term "black hole," Mr. Sagan kept his sense of humor. "Nothing ever jangles him," Mr. Isaacson said. If he found a way to save money, "he'd say, 'Let's plug this part of the black hole.' "
Mr. Sagan became president and editor of Time New Media in 1995 but left after a year. Some industry analysts said the departure had more to do with company friction than with his proclaimed desire to spend time with his family.
Mr. Sagan disagreed. "I didn't have a horrible disease, I didn't get fired, I didn't help somebody embezzle," he said. He explained that he had wanted to slow down and take his three young children to live abroad -- a "secret fantasy" that he and his wife, Ann Burks Sagan, who once worked in corporate finance, had developed during his hectic days as a news director.
"I was tethered to the TV," he said, adding that the family television had three screens so he could watch the local newscasts simultaneously. "My children thought everyone should have three TV's," he said. "And I thought it was just a horrible, horrible thing."
So he whisked them out of Montclair, N.J., first to Colorado and then to Geneva, where he did consulting for the World Economic Forum -- and a lot of skiing.
When he returned to the United States last year, he wanted to help build a new media company rather than join, or rejoin, an older one. "The big media companies -- and I don't mean just Time Warner, but I think you can say this about all of them -- they've generally lagged behind the start-ups," Mr. Sagan said.
He settled in Boston and heard about Akamai, a venture developed by Tom Leighton, an M.I.T. math professor, and Daniel Lewin, a graduate student. They had spent four years working on algorithms that would unclog the backup at popular Web sites.
He signed on in October 1998. During his year in the job, he had found investors, expanded the staff from 30 to more than 350 and networked (the old-fashioned way) to find clients. "He's great at getting things done, at deciding, 'O.K., let's build an office, let's hire people, let's design a new network,' " Mr. Isaacson said. "Things that most of us think of as difficult, Paul does the way other people throw dinner parties."
Akamai, which has yet to turn a profit, is one of the first companies to offer a cure for the common "hot spot," the shutdown that can result when a site gets a surge of visitors. That fate could have befallen the sites for "The Blair Witch Project" and the Net Aid concert this year, had they not chosen to "Akamaize."
A company confident enough to have its own verb? It seems just what he was looking for.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
In Greenwich, More Is Just Too Much

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY

DATELINE: GREENWICH, CONN.

 BODY:
IT is not clear precisely what made the residents of Crown Lane believe that Steven and Alexandra Cohen had crossed the line. Perhaps it was the backyard ice-skating rink that turns into a basketball court in spring. Or maybe it was the two putting greens with sand traps, connected by a fairway. Then again, it might have been the swimming pool enclosed in a one-and-a-half-story glass-walled room, the crowning ornament on what eventually will be their 32,000-square-foot home.
There's no question that the Cohens are planning a Xanadu on Crown Lane. 
 And why not? They have multiplied and prospered, with six children and one hedge fund that Mr. Cohen, 43, has made fabulously successful. "The economy's been good, the stock market's been good," he said. "We're not building monuments to ourselves. We're building facilities to enjoy with our kids and their friends."
Last year, the Cohens paid $14.8 million for a stately house on 14 acres in what Greenwich calls its back country. Renovations have begun as they plan a new wing for the pool and basketball court (this one indoors) and the massage, exercise and media rooms, as well as formal gardens, a golf course and an ice rink on the rest of the property. There's already a tennis court.
It's a sport utility mansion -- large, pricey, robust. But it became a "there goes the neighborhood" allegory for the 90's.
Neighbors have concrete concerns. The lights from the pool at night. Storm water runoff from the newly landscaped property. And the disruption, including 283 dump truck trips to bring in dirt.
But the deeper reaction seems to be, in a word: yuck! "Do you absolutely need to have your own hockey rink, two-hole golf course and this athletic facility?" said a neighbor, Andrew LeSueur. Or, as Susan Hut told the Planning Board: "I feel that it's not a home. It's a showplace. It could be in the Bronx Botanical Garden."
Greenwich, it should be pointed out, is not a community of Airstream trailers where people sit outside on cinder blocks whiling away the hours by taking aim with their BB guns at upturned Buicks.
Greenwich is Monaco on the Merritt. The Cohens' house is in a neighborhood where the minimum allowable lot is four acres, and in a town where the produce store has valet parking and where there are more cars (64,000) than people (60,000).
This issue of taking excess to excess is a tussle between the haves and the have-mores, between the truly wealthy and the suddenly, fabulously wealthy. It is curious that it is being raised here, and now. After all, aren't the late 1990's supposed to be our spin on the autobahn, a joy ride with no limits? We long ago passed the exit for excess.
But Greenwich projects an air of excessively modest excess. Diane W. Fox, the town planner, said that in a recent survey residents listed the expanding size of homes as their chief concern -- this, in a town of grand manses. "In this town," Ms. Fox said, "the idea of not showing wealth is really the tune. People dress down here. The sloppier the dress, the wealthier."
Restraint may be fading. House trends here resemble those in many wealthy suburbs: bigger homes on smaller lots; big houses demolished to make way for bigger ones; lots that were subdivided in leaner times being reassembled into estates. Now, Ms. Fox said, residents "want people to be aware of what their asset is."
The Crown Lane Affair has, of course, been understated. Letters were written to the Planning Board and some residents spoke at the meeting where the plans were discussed. Then there were the whispers.
One woman was worrying to a reporter that the noise from the Cohens' basketball court would disturb the quiet of her swimming pool when her husband arrived and became aghast at his wife's going public. But the husband need not worry about angering his new neighbors.
"I don't hold a grudge," Mr. Cohen said by telephone from his trading floor in Stamford. "It's just a house."
He doesn't sweat the small stuff. He made his fortune trading rapidly. Some investments rise, others fall. He keeps moving. Excusing himself from the phone for a moment, he could be heard telling a trader, "I'll buy 500 at five and an eighth."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 16, 1999, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
The Our Towns column on Dec. 5 described neighbors' resistance in Greenwich, Conn., to a homeowner's plan to add a new wing, an ice rink and a golf course to a $14.8 million house on a 14-acre lot. The column commented that Greenwich "is not a community of Airstream trailers where people sit outside on cinder blocks whiling away the hours by taking aim with their BB guns at upturned Buicks."
The reference to Airstream, though jocular, was unwarranted. The brand is a luxury recreational trailer often referred to as a land yacht. It should not have been associated with shabby surroundings.

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES;
Ivy League or Briar Patch?

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
When Janice Harayda came to Princeton this summer to be the editor-in-chief of the Princeton Alumni Weekly, there was little she did not effuse about.
"I find Princeton a very romantic place and I want to capture something of the romance as well as the intellectual stimulation," she told a reporter for The Daily Princetonian, the student newspaper. "This is the most exciting job I have ever had. Here there is always something new. I could see being challenged by this job just about forever." 
 But forever lasted only a matter of weeks. Ms. Harayda, the first non-Princeton graduate to head the coveted Alumni Weekly in its 100-year existence, left her job late last month under an Ivy-laden cloud. Whether she was asked to find employment elsewhere or left voluntarily was a bit of messy issue that those close to the affair preferred not to air publicly -- mostly because that was part of an agreement between the former editor and the board that controls the magazine.
And while conflicts at magazines are not unusual, the one at the Princeton Alumni Weekly, affectionately known as "PAW" to Princetonians, leads to at least a little insight about what life may be like in the quiet cauldron that is an Ivy League institution.
"The Alumni Weekly has a long history as an independent publication, back to Jesse Lynch Williams, who was the editor early in this century and was an important literary figure around here," said Edward Tenner, a contributing editor to the Harvard alumni magazine and a researcher in Princeton's geophysics department. Mr. Tenner (Princeton '69) got his writing start as the "On the Campus" writer for PAW when he was an undergraduate, as did such later luminaries as Landon Y. Jones (Princeton '66), who became editor of People magazine, and was one of 12 members of the alumni board who oversaw Ms. Harayda's hiring and hasty departure.
"Alumni magazines are among the few widely circulating journals left that let writers talk about ideas for their own sake," said Mr. Tenner, whose latest book is "Why Things Bite Back: Technology and the Revenge of Unintended Consequences" (Alfred A. Knopf, $13). "So they are an underrated part of the nation's intellectual resources."
The board of trustees of Princeton Alumni Publications Inc., which oversees the PAW, chose Ms. Harayda to edit the magazine after the editor for the last 10 years, J. I. Merritt (Princeton '66), decided to take early retirement from the university.
According to news articles that appeared when she was chosen, Ms. Harayda had impressed the board with her ideas to jazz up the design of the magazine and make its content more accessible to younger alumni and women. The 40-ish Ms. Harayda had been an editor and writer at Glamour and Boston magazines and, for 11 years, the book editor at the Cleveland Plain Dealer. Her first novel, "The Accidental Bride," (St. Martin's Press, $23) was published this summer to decent reviews.
But what she was not was a Princeton alumna -- having graduated the non-Ivy University of New Hampshire -- or even someone who had been in the Princeton milieu. (Ms. Harayda's managing editor, who is now the interim editor of the PAW, Lolly OBrien, is also not a Princeton alumna, but she has worked at the magazine since 1987.)
Under the low-keyed Mr. Merritt, the magazine staff, usually from five to seven editors and business staff members, had been stable. But soon after Ms. Harayda rolled up to Nassau Street in July and took over the publication, three staff members left though they have declined, at least publicly, to say why.
Though it has kept its "Weekly" name, the magazine has actually come out only 17 times a year since the 1970's. Still, that is far more frequently than most alumni publications, which even at large universities tend to appear monthly, or sometimes quarterly.
"Certainly the independence of the Weekly is different if not unique," said Mr. Merritt, who is now a freelance writer living in Princeton. "That has given it a certain tone. It's not a house organ. It's independent without being confrontational, not The Washington Post covering the White House, more like a small-town paper covering its town, where everyone knows everyone else. I think you sense that reading letters to the editor in particular. They publish letters attacking the university administration, and then long sentimental notes as well."
Ms. Harayda's four issues seemed to focus on celebrities, with stories concentrating on the consumer advocate Ralph Nader (Princeton '55), Bill Bradley, the former senator New Jersey and current Democratic presidential aspirant (Princeton '65) and the new editor of Harper's Bazaar, Katherine Betts (Princeton '86).
There had been no public indication that anything was wrong at the PAW until Peter G. Brown (Princeton '70), chairman of the alumni publications board and editor-in-chief of "The Sciences," the popular magazine of the New York Academy of Sciences, issued a statement two weeks ago that read in part, "Janice Harayda is no longer serving as editor of the Princeton Alumni Weekly because of differences between her and the board regarding the management of the magazine."
Mr. Brown added, "A search for a new editor has already begun."
Since then, Ms. Harayda, who still lives in the Princeton area, has not answered telephone calls, and Mr. Brown said by telephone that neither he nor anyone on the board or at the magazine could comment further.
Little in the magazine's latest issue of Nov. 17 indicates any hubbub -- not unusual in the Ivy way, as muted as a heather crew neck. It has the profile of Ms. Betts, as well as a lamentation over the young rawness of the Princeton basketball team, a discussion about whether the university should drop the grade A-plus and a commentary on how corruption in Russia has affected Princeton visitors there.
"The Weekly is a bit of a different animal than you would find at other colleges,' said Justin Harmon (Princeton '78), a Princeton spokesman, who also declined to speak about the change in editors. "It is an article of faith that Princeton alums want to read it and want it to appear frequently. It's the type of community that likes to keep in touch."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 5 about the departure of the editor of The Princeton Alumni Weekly, Janice Harayda, referred erroneously to her availability for comment. The reporter was unable to obtain Ms. Harayda's phone number through the university, the publication's office or directory assistance; Ms. Harayda did not receive messages or decline to respond.
The article also misstated the number of staff members who left after Ms. Harayda's arrival; it was two, not three.
The article also misstated the number of assignments by the new editor. Two articles that appeared during her tenure, on Ralph Nader and Bill Bradley, had been assigned by her predecessor.

HEADLINE: Affordable Housing For the Homeless

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Joyce Purnick's Dec. 2 Metro Matters column shows how difficult it can be to get a segment of the homeless population to accept services. Yet we should not lose sight of the fact that thousands of people do use the services of outreach teams, drop-in centers and shelters throughout New York City each year and that many do move on to permanent housing. 
 The gains made are only as modest as the resources provided.
For every person housed, there is someone being released from prison or a hospital or being evicted from housing who has no place to live. The real debate is why we aren't creating sufficient affordable housing and stable communities so that families, the unemployed and the mentally ill do not have to reach the streets to get the housing and help they need.
ANNE R. TEICHER
Executive Director
Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter
New York, Dec. 2, 1999

SECTION: Section A; Page 31; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 583 words

HEADLINE: Soccer Moms vs. Standardized Tests

BYLINE: By Charles J. Sykes; Charles J. Sykes is the author of "Dumbing Down Our Kids."

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE

 BODY:
After decades of endless gold stars, happy faces and inflated grades, American parents apparently were not ready for a reality check about how much our schools are really teaching our children.
Across the country, new, higher academic standards that states adopted in a spirit of educational reform are being dumbed down, and supposedly rigorous graduation tests are being diluted or dropped, as evidence mounts that too many students will fall short of the higher expectations. 
 It is not surprising that more rigorous state standards have come under fire from the usual opposition coalition of civil rights groups, progressive educators and teacher unions. What is striking though, is the opposition from soccer moms.
In Wisconsin, where legislators backed off plans to require a high school graduation test, most of the opposition to the exam came not from troubled urban schools, but from affluent suburbs. A group calling itself Advocates for Education and based in the Milwaukee suburb of Whitefish Bay, insisted, "High-stakes testing will be detrimental to education and unfair to children." Suburban critics in many parts of the state fretted about the pressure that tests would place on children. After suburban parents lobbied parent-teacher organizations, the State Legislature voted to scrap the graduation test before a single student had taken it.
In New York and Massachusetts, officials yielded to pressure to set absurdly low passing grades for their new tests, while in Virginia and Arizona, state boards of education are already backing away from tests that proved to be too tough for even the so-called better schools. In Virginia, only 7 percent of schools met new achievement standards, and in Arizona, 9 out of 10 sophomores failed a new math test.
For much of this century, the educational establishment has behaved as if it were addicted to bad ideas, indulging its own wishful and romantic thinking even in the face of mounting evidence of failure. The new tests were supposed to counteract the trendy experimentation, watered-down curriculums and questionable teaching methods by introducing both accountability and consequences for failure.
But for decades, the schools had been allowed to obscure the fact that many children were not mastering basic subjects. The constant positive reinforcement of unrealistic grading and easy tests was meant not only for the children, whose self-esteem remained strong in the face of shaky math and reading abilities, but for their parents, as well.
For many of these parents, the new tests were a very rude shock. Accustomed to thinking of educational difficulties as somebody else's problem, they and their school districts suddenly faced the possibility of failure.
As reformers have belatedly discovered, they badly underestimated the extent to which parents as well as teachers and bureaucrats had a vested interest in believing that whatever else might be wrong with American education, their own children were above average. Support for high standards came with an unspoken caveat: they were quite all right when they were applied to someone else's school and someone else's child.
So instead of sounding an alarm about the need to change the way we teach our children, one state after another is fudging the test. And a remarkable number of parents have gone along with the move to ratchet down the standards, expectations and consequences.
Reforming the schools sounded like a good idea until it hit home. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Vienna Memo;
A Rightist Leader Stirs Tepid Dissent, and Assent

BYLINE: By ALISON SMALE 

DATELINE: VIENNA

 BODY:
The scene was a classic late-autumn afternoon in one of Europe's most unchanging capitals -- women wearing hats at round marble tables, aging men in green loden coats bidding each other stiff hellos, a waitress of iron formality serving coffee and cakes.
But even the undying rituals of a once-imperial city could not mask the unease rippling through Vienna about the seemingly unstoppable rise of Jorg Haider, the right-wing populist who captured the No. 2 spot in October's national election. 
 His showing has paralyzed national politics while the two parties that have dominated Austria since World War II try to figure out their future, and it has galvanized what Mr. Haider's opponents view as worryingly weak resistance.
"This is one of the most unpolitical countries in Europe," railed Harald Posch, a theater director. Mr. Haider is popular, he said, "because he has the only party which really still operates with faith, with a belief -- the others have lost their identity because they are just running things, managing affairs."
"Haider opens his mouth and says, 'No,' and to unpolitical people it feels good, as if finally somebody is against all this," he said.
"All this" is code for the cozy decades in which the two dominant parties simply divided the spoils of power in a system that parceled out control of everything from schools to banks along party lines.
It is a system that helped heal the deep political wounds of prewar politics that had facilitated the rise of Hitler. But it is a system that is increasingly unsustainable under the pressures of a modern economy.
Austrians may blame globalization in the abstract; in life, they often take out their frustration on the hundreds of thousands of foreigners living among them who were allowed entry during past decades to do the menial jobs few Austrians want.
Mr. Haider's party did well in Vienna with a simple slogan, "Stop the Uberfremdung," an appeal against "overforeignization" that, to a German speaker, carries connotations of Goebbels, as indeed do other aspects of Mr. Haider's speeches. Mr. Haider now disowns the slogan and says it was dreamed up by the Vienna branch of his Freedom Party.
Foreign furor over Mr. Haider's ascent has often focused on his statements in praise of Nazi labor policies and the steadfastness of former members of the Waffen SS. Since the election, Mr. Haider has set out to dispel suggestions of neo-Nazism, embarking on a kind of good-will tour to various Western European countries and to the United States, where he competed in the New York City marathon and told Austrian journalists about reconciliatory meetings with American Jewish groups.
In November, he summoned his Vienna faithful to the old imperial palace, the Hofburg, to deliver what he framed as an apology to anybody he might have unintentionally offended by his remarks. He has, he insisted, "not even a trace of sympathy for racist and totalitarian goals," and he pledged, using the local color-code shorthand for Nazism: "I will unequivocally explain my relationship to the dark past. And I won't tolerate any brown shadows."
On the same day, the speaker of Austria's Parliament, Heinz Fischer, promised that the legislature would pass a resolution against xenophobia. That evening, some 25,000 people rallied in Vienna against racism.
The rally drew Mr. Haider's scorn and sharply divided even his opponents over its size and its aims.
Doron Rabinovici, a writer and a rally organizer, pledged at the gathering that anti-Haider forces would not wait next time until after an election to come out against racism. He demanded a law against discrimination because "no one can be certain of their future in Austria so long as someone is exposed to persecution because of their origins." The rally was "the beginning of a political movement against people who whip up fear, the first of many manifestations of courage," he said.
At the Hofburg gathering, Mr. Haider inveighed against what he called frustrated left-wingers; an "organized witchhunt from abroad," and "this leftist, pseudo-intellectual nonsense about hating foreigners." To those who marched under the banner "Haider -- shame for Austria," his retort was, "It is certainly not a shame to feel responsible above all for one's own people."
Such language worries some Viennese. Ariel Muzicant, the leader of the small Jewish community that has re-formed since World War II, has said that anti-Semitic attacks are on the rise.
Neither the Social Democrats nor the conservative People's Party, which have governed together since 1986 and have dominated Austria since 1945, seem to have a clear idea how to counter Mr. Haider, or how to break the political stalemate.
Neither party seems keen to renew its political marriage with the other, yet neither can envision a minority government. And despite the conservatives' flirtation with the idea of governing with Mr. Haider, neither seems to want him close to power.
Peter Marboe, the People's Party politician in charge of the subsidies Vienna lavishes on its culture -- a favorite target of Mr. Haider's devotees -- noted that Austria is not alone in Europe in facing the problem of integrating immigrants. In America, he noted, immigrants were often much further away from their homelands, and came to a society founded by immigrants. Europe, by contrast, has yet to integrate.
Since Austria's former multiethnic empire disintegrated in World War I, Austrians have largely seemed to feel more at ease unter sich, among themselves, an attitude at odds both with their cold war generosity to waves of refugees from Communist Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland and now with the country's membership, since 1996, in the European Union, and tentative moves, first given voice almost a decade ago by Mr. Haider, toward NATO.
The lingering suspicion of foreigners is tangible. A French reporter, fluent in German but with a French accent, was recently looking for an apartment. Answering numerous newspaper ads by telephone, she was frequently told "it's already taken" before she could even ask a question.
Finally finding a friendly woman with an available apartment, the reporter hurried to see it. She was met by a Viennese man who asked what she did. Upon hearing that she was a foreign journalist, he said: "Ah, so you are the people who are writing the wrong things about Haider."

HEADLINE: Bangkok Opens Skytrain, but Will It Ease Car Traffic?

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 5

 BODY:
It's clean, it's fast, it's punctual and it offers a breathtaking view of some of the world's most spectacular traffic jams.
It is the long-delayed Skytrain, a 16-mile, $1.7 billion elevated rail system that opened for business today, snaking swiftly above a city -- like so many others in Asia -- that is strangling on its own traffic. 
 Called "the train that floats in the air" in Thai, it is just a small start in the city's 180-mile mass transit master plan. Nobody knows yet how many people will abandon their cars to ride it.
But the privately financed rail system is Bangkok's most ambitious attempt so far to confront the near-gridlock that is sometimes described as its defining landmark -- its Eiffel Tower or Empire State Building.
The English-language newspaper The Nation welcomed the Skytrain in glowing terms today, but glancing down at the traffic in this city of 10 million, it added, "The horror resides below."
It is not only the traffic that moves slowly here. The Skytrain was first proposed in 1970, and construction began five years ago. If additional lines, a new subway and a separate elevated road-and-rail route are also completed, planners say, traffic could start moving freely again sometime deep into the next century.
But even Skytrain's developers sound a note of caution.
"If it leaves a vacuum on the road, then someone jumps in a car and fills it," Howard Brooke, senior vice president at the Bangkok Mass Transit System, said two years ago.
That is a hard fact of life throughout the cities of Asia, as it is in other nations. Traffic jams have become one of the most debilitating and intractable side effects of urbanization and economic growth. "Most of the mega-cities in Asia are approaching gridlock for increasing portions of the day, with no real prospects of relief in sight," said Michael P. Walsh, an automotive traffic consultant based in Arlington, Va.
A recent improvement in the situation only underscores the problem. When Southeast Asia's economies crashed in 1997, city streets became less clogged as commuters lost their jobs, truck traffic shrank and banks repossessed whole fleets of cars.
Now, with tentative signs of recovery here in Thailand, the flow of traffic is expected to thicken again.
As in many other countries, a personal car is seen by a newly emerging middle class as something of a human right. When officials tried to restrict new car ownership here three years ago, the public outcry forced them to back off. "This infringes on the rights and freedom of the individual," Laddawan Nuamchapoh, 26, an office worker, told a local newspaper.
In cities like Manila, Jakarta, Shanghai and Bombay, car ownership is one of the first signs of emerging prosperity. Even in the economically laggard capitals of Hanoi, Phnom Penh and Yangon -- in Vietnam, Cambodia and Myanmar, the former Burma -- embryonic traffic jams hint at future gridlock.
The toll is heavy on these cities' quality of life, on health and on economic efficiency.
In Bangkok, urban planners estimate that the average resident spends the equivalent of 44 days a year in traffic jams, that 20 percent of fuel is consumed by vehicles that are standing still and that $2 billion to $3 billion a year is drained from the economy in lost hours at work.
Children often rise long before dawn for their slow commute to school, and teachers complain that the youngsters are sleepy when they get there. They are often sick as well with respiratory ailments that people here attribute to air pollution.
The traffic also seems to be frightening off foreign visitors. The Tourism Authority of Thailand recently reported that the average stay in Bangkok had been cut in half, to just one or two days.
"Many people now say that they go out only when it is really necessary, almost making them prisoners in their own immediate neighborhoods if not their own homes," said a Hong Kong-based consulting firm, Asian Market Intelligence, reporting on a survey earlier this year.
Residents of Bangkok have the region's longest average round trip to work, it found, at 82 minutes.
Their best solution, it said, is to make each car "a comfortable little home on wheels." Indeed, it is common for commuters to set up elaborate offices in their cars and to create family time by commuting together. To deal with emergencies, hospitals have prepared motorcycle ambulances to weave through traffic, taxi drivers and police officers have been given courses in midwifery and gas stations advertise colorful portable plastic urinals.
Throughout it all, Thais seem to remain remarkably cool in traffic, sitting and staring ahead for long, empty minutes. There is little road rage; people rarely honk their horns.
"I think that there is no point to shouting or pushing on your horn," said Adhiti Pinyowattayakorn, who works in a jewelry shop, "because even if you do, you are still sitting in traffic."
Bangkok, once a city of canals, has been fighting traffic jams almost since it built its first road in 1860. In the last 30 years, it has paved over most of its waterways. New toll roads and overpasses have saved the city from absolute paralysis.
Still, with about three million vehicles on the road every day, and with roads covering only 8.5 percent of its area -- compared with about 20 percent in some Western cities -- officials here estimate that the average speed of traffic at peak times is only nine miles an hour. On key arteries, for hours at a time, cars move more slowly than the pedestrians who walk past them.
So the next steps are only logical: up into the sky and, perhaps in another three years or so, down underground with the city's first subway line.
Today, on its inaugural day, the Skytrain was clogged with passengers. But when the workweek resumes, Bangkok will begin to face the crucial question: will people ever give up their cars for the train?
"If passengers cannot reach their destination faster and have to pay higher fares, then they will soon turn away from it," said Thirachon Manomaiphibul, deputy governor of the Bangkok Metropolitan Administration.
For now, the Skytrain runs along just one forked line -- with 24 three-story-high stations -- without connections to other transport and without its own parking lots.
"So what should I do?" said Apichart Pholomai, a secretary who says she will continue to drive to work. "I'll have to take a taxi to the Sathorn station, then ride to Asoke station, then take another taxi to my office. That's the problem for a lot of people."
Another question involves the price of a ride. The fare has been set considerably higher than the most expensive bus ride, which is 12 baht, or about 35 cents. The Skytrain will cost from 15 baht to 40 baht, depending on the length of the ride.
This suggests not only that the Skytrain has huge cost overruns to address, but also that it is aiming directly at people with cars rather than trying to tempt less affluent travelers to switch from buses.
"Because of the high price, it just might work," said a young government official. "You'll get a different class of people, and class is what it's all about. If you take a bus you're like everybody else, you're just part of the masses. But if the Skytrain is too expensive for the masses, well, let's see."

HEADLINE: Number of Foster Children in City At Lowest Level Since the 1980's

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
Following steady and sometimes sharp declines over the last several years, the number of children in foster care in New York City has fallen below what it was a decade ago, when the worst of the crack epidemic helped send the foster care population soaring.
The city's foster care population has declined by nearly 30 percent since 1991, from a record high of 49,100 to 35,200 this fall, according to the Administration for Children's Services. The reductions have helped ease the strain on a system swollen not only by the children whose families were torn apart by crack, but also by changes in local policy on child welfare. 
 City officials, while acknowledging that foster care populations can be influenced by a wide range of forces, say the recent, striking reductions have largely been driven by three factors: youngsters who flooded the system in the late 1980's and early 1990's are turning 18 and leaving the rolls; adoptions have increased by nearly two-thirds over the last six years, and children are not remaining in the foster care system as long.
The city officials say it is impossible to predict whether the decline will continue. But contrary to widespread fear, they have not yet seen the foster care population grow significantly in the aftermath of welfare reform. They and others are quick to say it is extremely hard to quantify how many children are entering the system for what specific reasons, and equally difficult to say how welfare reform or other policy shifts are going to play out over many years -- for instance, the mayor's latest threat, to take custody of the children of homeless parents who refuse to work for their shelter.
Child welfare experts, as well as advocates who monitor the city's foster care system, say the decline in the total population is to be expected after the aberrant spikes starting around 1987, when the crack crisis began to drive many thousands of children from their homes.
They note, too, that the official count of children in foster care was inflated a decade ago in part because of a change in city policy to include children who were informally cared for by relatives as a part of the official foster care system.
And while the advocates applaud the latest declines, they insist it is too early to tell whether they signal long-term improvements in the system.
In truth, making sense of trends in foster care is confounding even to veteran students of the subject. As with the ups and downs of crime rates, it is difficult to discern exactly who or what deserves credit for the ebb and flow of the foster care population and how much of it can be attributed to demographic vagaries.
For their part, city officials, who are eager to publicize the latest drops, acknowledge that the system is shrinking in part because some youngsters are "aging out." But they also attribute the declines to a bigger budget and a more efficient agency.
The Administration for Children's Services budget has peaked to over $2 billion a year under Nicholas Scoppetta, who became commissioner in 1996 after the widely publicized beating death of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo. More staff members have been hired, and the average caseload for a child protective worker has been cut by half in the last three years, Mr. Scoppetta said. Moreover, he noted in an interview last week, a record 11,000 children have been adopted in the last three years alone.
"That is a really dramatic drop in numbers," Mr. Scoppetta said of the decline. "The record-setting number of adoptions is one thing we can point to."
Much of New York City's decline came at a time when the foster care population nationwide was climbing -- to 546,000 in 1999 from 406,000 in 1990.
But the city's experience, said an agency spokesman, Michael Kharfen, may represent a harbinger of national trends. In the last year, he said, there has been "a slight decline" in the number of children coming into foster care nationwide. The drop has been starkest in New York and Illinois, which, after California, have the largest numbers of foster children. Adoptions are on the rise nationally, as well.
Those who monitor the city's foster care system are reluctant to draw sweeping conclusions about the latest trends. Still, even some of the system's most ardent critics, like Marcia Robinson Lowry, a lawyer who has sued the city on behalf of foster children for more than two decades, say there are grounds for "cautious optimism."
"There's no question that there's been more attention paid to the system in the last few years," said Ms. Lowry, executive director of Children's Rights, a national advocacy group. But she added, "I think it's too soon to judge what really is going on."
The one thing that is known now, said Fred Wulczyn, a research fellow with the Chapin Hall Center for Families at the University of Chicago, is that the foster care system has roughly reached the balance that it had before crack cocaine helped fuel its explosive growth.
"The system was stretched," said Mr. Wulczyn, who studies New York City's foster care system. "It's finally getting back to its stride on the admissions and discharges side."
That shift comes at a crucial time for city officials. Under a recent settlement of a federal class-action lawsuit, the child welfare agency is under scrutiny by an outside panel of experts. Early next year, that panel is expected to release its evaluation of how well the agency has overhauled its long-troubled foster care system.
Moreover, like other cities, New York is under considerable pressure to speed up adoptions. The Federal Adoption and Safe Families Act, which went into effect this year, requires the city to seek adoptions for all children who have spent 15 of the most recent 22 months in foster care. (The children adopted last year in the city had been in foster care for an average of 6.8 years.)
The foster care population has undergone dramatic shifts in the last two decades. The numbers had been declining steadily through the early 1980's, reaching a low of around 16,200 in 1984. Child welfare officials began to notice children of crack-addicted parents as early as 1985, when the numbers began to nudge upward. "It really hit high gear in 1987," Mr. Wulczyn said, pointing to the influx of newborns that came into the system starting that year.
The numbers spiked sharply in 1988 and 1989; the population grew by 10,000 children each of those years. It reached a peak of 49,100 in 1991.
At the same time, a wave of children who were being cared for by relatives officially came into the system under a change in the law. In the last couple of years, many of those children have turned 18 and ventured out on their own. In general, more children are leaving the system now than in years past: 12,700 were discharged in fiscal year 1999, compared with 11,600 in 1994.
Moreover, a larger share of children leaving the system is being adopted rather than returned home. Last year, around 30 percent of the youngsters leaving foster care were adopted, while 52 percent were returned to their birth parents or relatives. By comparison, in 1994, 21 percent of the children who left the system were adopted and 60 percent returned to birth parents or relatives.
Adoptions climbed steadily in the mid-1990's. In fiscal year 1997, a record 4,009 children were adopted, compared with 2,300 in 1994. Over the last two years, adoptions have hovered around 3,800.
When Mr. Scoppetta took over a reorganized child welfare agency in 1996 under the shadow of Elisa Izquierdo's death, many feared that the city would indiscriminately pull children from their homes to avoid similar tragic embarrassments. Indeed, the first few years of Mr. Scoppetta's tenure were characterized by aggressive enforcement. The number of children who came into foster care soared. It went from around 8,000 children in fiscal year 1995 to 10,000 in 1996 -- his first year in office -- to 12,000 in 1998.
But in the last year, the number fell significantly. Admissions to the system dropped to 10,200 at the end of fiscal year 1999.
Finally, part of the decline in the overall foster care population seems also to be driven by shorter stays in the system. The median length of stay for youngsters who came into foster care in 1995 -- the most recent year for which the agency has available figures -- was 1.76 years, down from 2.82 years for children who came into the system in 1990.
If unpredictable outside forces like crack addiction fueled the anomalous growth of a decade ago, it is all but impossible to divine what the next decade holds. Already, dire predictions have been made about how the new federally mandated time limits on welfare benefits will flood the foster care system. That does not seem to have happened yet. Then again, it is not yet possible to measure the full impact of welfare reform -- particularly because today's robust economy can cushion the blow.
"It's still too early to tell whether welfare reform will increase or decrease the number of kids in care," said David Tobis, director of the Center for the Study of Family Policy at Hunter College. "The big factor is what happens to the economy."
Moreover, no one is either pleased or satisfied that, despite the recent reductions, more than 35,000 children remain in foster care because of worries about their well-being. It is, everyone agrees, an enormous and unhealthy number.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Clinton Round

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE; Bob Herbert is on vacation.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the opening minute in the global trade arena he wanted to call "the Clinton Round," President Clinton took a huge swing and kayoed himself.
But cheer up: even as he permitted U.S. policy to be determined by organized anarchists joined by organized labor in the street battle of Seattle, the U.S. president ultimately scored a kind of negative victory. 
 Flat on his back, dumped on by dumping nations and object of catcalls of the undeveloped world, a frustrated Clinton did not abandon our interests. In aligning himself with street people and bowing to A.F.L.-C.I.O. pressure, Clinton became a trade realist: he allowed the talks to collapse and made Seattle his Reykjavik.
A trade realist is a multilateralist who has been mugged by the underdeveloped world and had his pockets picked by subsidized European farmers. That's Clinton after the World Trade Organization fiasco in Seattle. His "legacy" is his willingness to take the embarrassing count without giving up our most cherished principles.
Forget the outdated rhetoric about "free trade vs. protectionism" or "rules vs. walls" or "globalization vs. nationalism." That simplistic spin belongs to previous eras.
Here's today's debate: Do information-age democracies use their economic muscle to bring others up to their standards of human rights? Or do the world's poor nations, allied with dictatorial giants, regional cartels and multinationals, use their political majorities in international organizations to vitiate our leverage of trade?
The W.T.O. is a kind of U.N. General Assembly, with the U.S. having only one voice in the cacophony. Our power to encourage democratic capitalism worldwide is now constrained by our statist competitors. That was Clinton's doing five years ago as part of his obeisance to multilateralism.
But a strange bedfellowship is denying the Lilliputians the bonds to tie down Gulliver. As is disdainfully pointed out, this includes protectionist labor leaders; Naderite consumer gadflies; environmentalists ranging from reasonable greens to anti-worker ecological nuts, and a lunatic fringe of anarchists and hatemongers.
A few other groups, however, give more meaning to this odd amalgam. Human rights advocates who believe that American markets should not support the product of slave labor or child labor are being heard. And so are people who feel threatened by the growing power of global cartels that thrive on the antidemocratic secrecy of the W.T.O. -- while these merchandising monoliths invade the privacy of individuals everywhere.
Using e-mail and the Internet, this "strangebedfellows.com" has globalized the resistance to mindless globalization. In Seattle, it organized effectively to stop the handover of America's power to demand human rights and labor standards from nations dependent on our rich market.
In the midst of the melee last week, President Clinton made what his panicked aides told reporters was a terrible blunder: he dared suggest that the W.T.O. should someday apply sanctions to economies that abuse child labor. This roused the ire of third-world exploiters and contributed to the breakdown of the talks.
Mr. Clinton's staff, lusting after an agreement, was wrong to badmouth its boss. That was Clinton's finest hour. I don't care if he was polishing the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s apple to help Al Gore, or was pushed by women's groups, or felt he had to strain to empathize with the militants in the streets. Whatever his motive, our president blurted out a hint worthy of an elected American president and civilized human being -- and not a faceless multilateral bureaucrat.
I am not a global warmnik, union agitator, or stocking-masked anarchist; indeed, laissez-fairies have always been dancing in my garden. But by jingo, I believe the United States should be a light unto nations by virtue of our example of enlightened free enterprise. That means not lowering our health and labor standards to let investors everywhere make a buck, but applying those standards to others who want to make a buck with us.
International trade that does not use its leverage to encourage personal freedom does not deserve the name of "free trade." We accept the burden of importing many of the world's problems; our trading partners should note that America's most rewarding export is individual liberty.

HEADLINE: In New Hampshire, Forbes Works to Win the Skeptics

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: KEENE, N.H., Dec. 4

 BODY:
Listening to Steve Forbes at a pancake breakfast here this morning, Richard Card heard a lot that he liked, including Mr. Forbes's proposal for a single-rate flat tax and his straight talk on issues like China and health care.
But there was one nagging problem. "I'm concerned about how he can accomplish it," said Mr. Card, a 68-year-old retired cabinet maker. "He's never had to interact with Congress to solve a problem. You can have all the lofty goals in the world, but what good are they if you can't carry them out?" 
 For Mr. Forbes, convincing undecided Republicans that he can translate his experience as a wealthy publisher into the skills of governance may be the stiffest test he faces in igniting a stagnant campaign and closing the gap with Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Senator John McCain of Arizona, his two main rivals for his party's presidential nomination, before New Hampshire holds the nation's first primary on Feb. 1.
Mr. Forbes is trying to gain traction from a combative performance in last Thursday's debate among the six Republican candidates and from a new advertising campaign that criticizes Mr. Bush for considering raising the age of eligibility for Social Security benefits.
Winning the endorsement of The Union Leader of Manchester, the state's largest newspaper and leading conservative voice, has also bolstered Mr. Forbes's claim that he is the main conservative alternative in the primary, running against the Washington establishment.
"It's not a novice that's here," Mr. Forbes told Mr. Card after finishing his 25-minute stump speech. He went on to tick off his business and civic experience, as well as his stint overseeing Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty under President Ronald Reagan. "I'm an outsider. I think you can take the plunge."
In a meandering bus tour this weekend across southern New Hampshire, Mr. Forbes carried his outsider's message to 75 people at a town meeting in Milford and 100 people at this morning's breakfast. The crowds were enthusiastic but small in comparison to the 1,500 Mr. McCain drew at a similar event on Friday. The audiences were a mix of curious fence-sitters and committed Forbes supporters who had been part of his failed 1996 campaign.
If nothing else, the Forbes campaign is hard to miss when its two chartered buses, Victory Express 1 and 2, roll into quaint New England villages, blaring Sousa marches when they arrive and Willie Nelson's "On the Road Again" when they leave. On the stump, Mr. Forbes condemns "the huge disconnect between the political culture of Washington and the nation," pledges to restore integrity to the Justice Department and lambastes Vice President Al Gore, the administration's point man on Russia, for allowing "the good name of the United States to become associated with gangster elements in the Kremlin."
Mr. Forbes draws his themes from the Declaration of Independence and its promise of "life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness." He opposes abortion. He favors patients' freedom to choose their own doctors and to have individual medical savings accounts. He supports diverting most of the Social Security payroll tax into private investment accounts for younger working Americans. He takes occasional jabs at the Clinton administration in his speeches, but largely avoids mention of Mr. Bush.
But he is only warming up for the main act: his frontal assault on the country's tax system. In addition to proposing a 17 percent flat tax, Mr. Forbes wants to abolish the Internal Revenue Service and scrap the tax code. Indeed, heads shook in astonishment this weekend when he noted that the Gettysburg Address has fewer than 300 words and the Bible has 783,000 words, but the tax code has more than 7.5 million.
"Other politicians say they'll hold the line on taxes," Mr. Forbes said. "But that's political talk for 'We won't raise taxes until we need more money.' "
This is rhetorical red meat for many conservatives in the crowd who dispute public opinion polls showing less interest in tax cuts in today's booming economy.
But Forbes supporters say their candidate has broadened his ideas beyond his signature issue. "He has a message that has matured," said Richard Ptak, an information technology consultant in Amherst, N.H. "Four years ago, he had a hard time presenting where he wanted to go. Now he's putting substance behind the words."
The Forbes organization here, which was skeletal in 1996, has also grown modestly. Fifteen full-time staff aides marshal a grass-roots network of volunteers from state headquarters in Manchester.
Nonetheless, there are glitches. On Friday, the campaign changed locations for a meet-and-greet event in Amherst with Mr. Forbes, but forgot to tell anyone at the original stop, the Village Green Market, where two dozen supporters and several reporters were waiting.
After frantic phone calls from a top aide, the Forbes entourage arrived at the store, an hour late. Bounding off the bus, Mr. Forbes shook hands, picked up some plain doughnuts and a copy of The Union Leader trumpeting his endorsement, and shoved a $5 bill in a charity box.
"I believe he can win, and I believe he stands for the silent majority," said Jackie Beckmann, a Republican state committeewoman from Massachusetts who drove 95 miles from New Bedford with her husband, Bob, to meet Mr. Forbes at the market.
Narrowing the race, let alone winning it here, may hinge on massaging Mr. Forbes's image more than his message. Even The Union Leader's endorsement acknowledged that he was not charismatic and might look like a "geek" to some people.
Mr. Forbes is less awkward-looking in smaller groups than he is in televised debates and interviews. And when he shed his dark suit, starched white shirt and yellow tie on Saturday morning for chinos, an olive-green checked shirt and docksiders, he almost looked like a regular guy rather than someone worth $440 million.
"He came across as strained on TV with those facial expressions," said Robert Chamberlain, a 70-year-old retired Air Force colonel who came here this morning to help decide between Mr. Forbes and Mr. McCain. "Now that I've seen him, I understand that those facial expressions are just him. I was impressed by his ability to answer questions in depth. I think he can handle the job."

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 569 words

HEADLINE: The Collapse in Seattle

 BODY:
Many trade experts warned that a new round of global trade talks was premature. The world, they said, needed more time to absorb the trade-opening measures that were adopted five years ago. A week of protests at the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle and, more important, the embarrassing refusal of the W.T.O. to endorse President Clinton's trade-liberalization program proved that the warnings were prescient. But the failed talks augur no general calamity.
Trade will continue to be governed by rules that have served the trading community well for over 50 years. Globalization proved an easy target for an alliance of convenience between well-intentioned and more malicious protesters, yet the need for it to continue as the main vehicle of international economic progress still stands. 
 But to say that the march toward open trade will continue does not argue for minimizing the damage of last week's events. The failure in Seattle will keep needless barriers in place at least a few years longer. Also lost was the chance to make reforms that would have addressed critics, prevented future backlashes like the "battle in Seattle" and built confidence in the W.T.O.
Perhaps the most important of the three main reforms pushed by Mr. Clinton was a call to have the W.T.O. open up its judicial panels to public scrutiny and, where feasible, to wider participation. The organization's secretive ways breed distrust and conspiracy fears among governments and advocacy groups.
On the important issue of labor rights, President Clinton pushed the W.T.O. to create a discussion group to look at sweatshop conditions and child labor. But he encouraged a two-edged revolt when he told an interviewer he envisioned eventual sanctions on countries that violate basic rights. On the policy level, his candor left ministers from third-world countries fearing that the proposal would be used to prevent them from exporting their way out of poverty. On a grittier level, they suspected that the American president, who must lead on a global basis, was catering to American unions and the domestic election needs of his vice president. The goal of fair work conditions, however, need not die. The administration can urge other groups, like the International Labor Organization, to pursue the issue with or without the W.T.O.'s participation.
Nor need the collapse of trade talks halt progress on environmental issues. The W.T.O.'s charter embraces, in theory, the need to protect the environment. The Seattle protesters gave notice to the organization to strike a more sensitive balance between trade and environment in its rule-making.
It is unclear, to say the least, if Mr. Clinton has time to reclaim a leadership role on trade. Yet the underdeveloped nations that refused to endorse his recommendations in a final communique will lose the most from closed agricultural markets, anti-dumping laws and prohibitive pharmaceutical prices -- all problems that can only be addressed in talks like the round blocked in Seattle.
The World Trade Organization is not the Hydra-headed monster portrayed by its severest critics. But after Seattle, it is all the more important for this administration or its successor to help enhance the W.T.O.'s legitimacy through reforms on secrecy, labor rights and the environment. That is what the demonstrators demanded. That is what people around the globe deserve.

HEADLINE: After Riots, Seattle Is Chagrined Yet Cheerful

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Dec. 5

 BODY:
At the beginning of the week that was to showcase Seattle to the world as a friend to free trade and free expression alike, the city's Public Development Authority promised yet more good news for local merchants.
"PDA + WTO = Business as Usual -- Maybe Better!" proclaimed a bright yellow flier distributed to businesses as the World Trade Organization got under way here, adding: "Thousands of potential customers with time on their hands and money in their pockets will descend upon the Downtown area." 
 Ted Coffman, a butcher in the Pike Place Market, tore his flier down this weekend and threw it across the counter in a surprisingly cheerful burst of disgust. "One good thing I'll say for the week is, it certainly was exciting," Mr. Coffman said.
"As for business, that was down by 80 percent," he said. "Tuesday, we closed down with all the protests. Wednesday, the market got gassed, so we closed again. Thursday, some cops came running in and said, 'You better close, now!' One said it was something to do with President Clinton, another said it was more protesters. I still don't know what it was. I just want things to get back to normal."
The trade talks here may have ended, with negotiations in collapse and many Seattleites still astonished by the irony of riots and tear gas in a place where pedestrians normally exhibit scrupulous respect for the jaywalking laws. But for Seattle, the self-scrutiny is just beginning, as the city seeks to determine how what had been billed as a respectful "Seattle-style conversation" on trade issues turned into a civic fiasco.
The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on Wednesday, and is starting an investigation into why the police seemed unprepared to respond properly to either the thousands of protesters who gathered peacefully or the small number who went on a rampage.
Characteristically, though, in a city that has something of a sense of humor about itself, many people were looking on the bright side. As downtown streets were reclaimed this weekend by Christmas shoppers, lured by extras like free parking and free Starbucks coffee, many Seattle residents took pains to note one bottom-line fact: at least nobody got killed.
Others said there was no reason to fret over whether the city's golden image had been tarnished. "I mean, everybody's already freaked out that there are too many people moving here," said Chip Thom, a 29-year-old mechanic who was doing a brisk business selling "I survived WTO protest" T-shirts to the holiday crowd. "So this might encourage them to stay away. In that sense, it could be a good thing."
Still others said that in time, as the televised images of helmet-clad police, clouds of tear gas and boarded-up stores faded, the word Seattle might become synonymous, in a good way, with the moment when world engaged in a serious debate over the meaning of globalization and its effects on ordinary people.
"I wouldn't say it began here, but it will definitely be seen as the place where the conversation got serious," said Charlie Sheldon, a port worker who -- sheer coincidence, he said -- just completed a novel called "The Boomerang Heist," in which a hijacked ship sails into town just as a trade conference attended by the president and 17 other heads of state gets under way in the year 2000.
It is highly unlikely now that any such world conference will take place in Seattle anytime soon.
"It'll be a long time before we invite another big convention to the city while I'm mayor," the city's top elected official, Paul Schell, told a radio show over the weekend. Mr. Schell has borne the brunt of criticism from both merchants angry over the vandalism and citizens enraged over police actions. And he has wasted little time in beginning the process of restoring good will to the city and, of course, toward himself.
"Let's heal the city," Mr. Schell, who is up for re-election in 2001, said on Saturday as he reopened a holiday carousel for children that had been sealed off by yellow crime-scene police tape earlier in the week. "I understand everybody's angry and offended. I feel offended myself by the things that happened here."
Many people voiced regret that delegates, journalists and even the demonstrators from around the world had not exactly experienced the city at its best.
"I do feel bad that everybody who came here couldn't get to see what Seattle is really like," Mary Mermod, a retired Veterans Affairs worker from west Seattle, said as she sat outside a Seattle's Best Coffee kiosk. "The shops, the restaurants, the waterfront, the ferry rides, the museums," she said. "It sounds like a lot of people just got stuck in their hotel rooms."
Many others said that while they regretted the vandalism, the overall effect of the protests was positive.
"We lost a lot of business this week," said John Balogh, manager of a juice stand at the City Centre shopping plaza. "But from a personal point of view, if this whole thing motivated people to think about what's really going on, what globalization is doing to us, then it's a good thing. I really believe that."
The fallout from the week will be explored for a long time to come.
"Seattle has a reputation for reasonableness and collaboration, and that's contradicted by what happened here," said Matthew P. Stadler, a Seattle native, novelist and literary editor of Nest magazine.
The City Council's hearings will be open to residents, protesters, business owners and anyone else.
At least two civil-rights groups are calling for investigations into police conduct, and the local branch of the N.A.A.C.P. has been harshly critical of an incident last week in which officers stopped a black City Council member, Richard McIver, on his way to a W.T.O. reception. Even though he showed identification, Mr. McIver said, he was taken from his car, had his hands wrenched behind his back and was nearly arrested.
The American Civil Liberties Union has also asked for an independent panel to review the events of the week, including the city's imposition of what the group says was an unconstitutional no-protest zone in a 30-block area of downtown.
Still, things are calming down. The police and protesters reached a deal on Saturday, under which nearly all remaining protesters of the more than 600 arrested will be released from jail on their own recognizance.
Mr. Thom, the T-shirt vendor, predicted that the effect of the week's events would be short-lived. "When the Seahawks make the playoffs," he said, speaking of the local National Football League team that despite a loss tonight to the Raiders is now leading its division, "everybody will forget about the W.T.O."
But others said the week's legacy should be longer-lasting, even if it does not alter the city's character.
"Seattle's still Seattle, it's still a hub of high technology, and this isn't going to change that," said 22-year-old Jamaal Ali, who is studying computer programming at a vocational institute here. "But I hope that people don't just try to forget about all that happened this week. I hope, for a lot of different reasons, it really makes everybody think."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Vindication At Last For Collins

BYLINE: By BILL PENNINGTON 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 5

 BODY:
It has been a whirlwind year for Kerry Collins, one he began unemployed and apparently unwanted, since no National Football League team was threatening to end his status as a free agent.
He soon entered a rehabilitation center in an effort to curb his drinking. By February, he had signed with the Giants, an acquisition branded by many as foolhardy. 
 Then he did not play for months, the highest-paid offensive player on the team standing on the sideline in a baseball cap.
Late this afternoon, Collins stood in the Giants' locker room after he had thrown three touchdown passes, brilliantly leading the Giants to a 41-28 rout of the Jets at Giants Stadium.
"These are the type of games," Collins said, "that you ultimately see at the end of the rainbow."
Across the room, wide receiver Amani Toomer, who had caught the three touchdown passes, was marveling at Collins's play.
"He's just a great quarterback," Toomer said. "I can't say enough about him. On the first touchdown, if he throws it three inches to the left, it's a 7-yard gain."
Instead, Collins, by design, fired a crisp pass to Toomer's right shoulder, allowing him to grab the ball and twist away from Jets cornerback Aaron Glenn at the same time -- a move that allowed Toomer to run 61 yards for the score.
"On the last touchdown," Toomer continued, "he told me, 'This might be a jump ball; go get it.' But it was a really well-thrown pass. I caught it and ran for the end zone."
That play was an 80-yard score, with Collins lofting the football 40 yards in the air on a line -- a perfect spiral that hit Toomer right in stride and right in the hands. Toomer also caught a 9-yard touchdown pass from Collins, a well-timed fade pattern in the back corner of the end zone.
"Kerry just played a tremendous game," Giants Coach Jim Fassel said. "He made some spectacular throws."
Collins was named the Giants' starter last week, and though he played effectively at times in that game, he also contributed four turnovers in a crucial loss to Arizona. Today, Collins had no interceptions and, behind steady play from the offensive line, was not sacked.
With the rookie running back Joe Montgomery rushing for 111 yards and the quarterbacks coach, Sean Payton, calling the plays instead of Fassel, the Giants displayed an efficiency missing since the first two games of this year's preseason.
"Sean Payton is a cocky guy who takes risks," Giants running back Tiki Barber said. "I thought we'd be running the clock out with a 17-point lead, and he's throwing bombs. We need that."
It also suits Collins's disposition, since he likes to attack. Today, Collins was decisive in the pocket and saw the field extremely well, repeatedly throwing to second and third receivers in his pass progressions.
"Quick decisions make it hard for the defense to adjust to you," said Collins, whose 341 passing yards were the most by a Giants quarterback since 1993. "Today, the Jets were weaving when they should have been bobbing and bobbing when they should have been weaving."
It was an extraordinary performance, especially considering the Giants' ineptitude on offense for most of the season. None of their 11 drives began in Jets territory, but the Giants punted only three times.
When Collins came off the field for the final time, Fassel approached him with his right hand out.
"He shook my hand and said he was proud of me," Collins said. "I told him I was thankful for the opportunity."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Sharper Growth Seen In Spending on Ads

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
Advertising spending will grow more robustly than had been anticipated, according to the head of a leading media services agency, as a result of the spending burst by the dot-coms in traditional media and renewed confidence in the economy.
"We know every boom must end, but the outlook is still good," said John Perriss, chairman and chief executive at Zenith Media Worldwide in London, a joint venture of the Cordiant Communications Group and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. Mr. Perriss is to discuss his forecasts this morning at the opening session of the annual Paine Webber Media Conference in New York. 
 The acceleration in ad spending is being fueled by the recovery of economies in Asian nations, Mr. Perriss said in remarks prepared for the conference, and the strength of Western economic conditions, which "are ideal for advertising growth." He singled out what he predicted would be an "exceptional" climate in the United States in 2000.
Other forecasters who time their reports to coincide with the media conference are also issuing predictions. "The third millennium will come in with a bang for media companies," according to the Myers Group in New York, publisher of The Myers Report media newsletter, which predicted that at the beginning of the 21st century, the interactive media would be "at the same stage as the assembly line at the beginning of the 20th century."

HEADLINE: Rite Aid Names a New Management Team

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The Rite Aid Corporation, the troubled drug store chain, has chosen a new top management team, the company said yesterday. The new chief executive wasted no time in saying he would try to sell fewer assets than had been expected.
Robert G. Miller, 55, who will take over today as chairman and chief executive, said Rite Aid would continue to try to sell PCS Health Systems, a company that administers pharmacy benefits. But he said he would halt efforts to sell some of the 1,000 West Coast drug stores owned by Rite Aid. "We think the best approach is to fill the stores up with merchandise, clean them up and take care of the customers," Mr. Miller said in a telephone interview. 
 Mr. Miller conceded that the recent history of Rite Aid did not look good, but he said the company had "a powerful brand name and excellent store locations" and could prosper.
Mr. Miller was vice chairman and chief operating officer of the Kroger Company, a food and drug retailer, until he resigned Friday. He joined Kroger in May, when Fred Meyer Inc., the retailer he had run for eight years, was acquired by Kroger.
The rest of the new management team that Rite Aid hired yesterday had been with Mr. Miller at Fred Meyer.
The others are Mary F. Sammons, 53, who will be president and chief operating officer; David R. Jessick, 46, who will be chief administrative officer, and John T. Standley, who will be chief financial officer.
In addition, Deloitte & Touche was named as the new auditor for Rite Aid, with the duty of auditing the restatement of the company's profits for the past three fiscal years, as well as auditing the results from the current fiscal year, which ends next February.
The auditing firm said it would not be able to complete its work until Rite Aid implemented whatever changes are recommended by Swidler Berlin Shereff Friedman, a New York and Washington law firm that is being retained to investigate the company's accounting. Mr. Miller said he hoped the audits could be completed by early summer.
Rite Aid has been beset by one problem after another. The top officers of the company were forced out in October amid an accounting scandal that led KPMG to resign as the company's auditing firm, saying it had no confidence in the company's management. Rite Aid was indicted in Florida on charges of overcharging customers. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the company.
But an immediate financial crisis was averted when Leonard Green & Partners, a private equity firm, invested $300 million in the company and Mr. Green joined the board as acting chairman. Lenders agreed to renew financing commitments, albeit at increased costs.
Mr. Miller said Mr. Jessick, the new administrative officer, had spent last week going over Rite Aid's books and operations. Mr. Jessick also knows the West Coast operations, having been chief financial officer of Thrifty Payless, the chain that Rite Aid acquired in 1996, before he joined Fred Meyer.
Mr. Green will remain on the board, but be replaced by Mr. Miller as chairman. Timothy J. Noonan, the former president of Rite Aid and interim chief executive, will remain with the company for a transition period.
Rite Aid grew rapidly under the leadership of Martin Grass, the son of the company's founder, who was chief executive from early 1995 until he was forced out in October. Under his leadership, the company became a Wall Street darling, with the stock price more than quadrupling to a high of $51.125 in January.
But with the company saying in October that it expected to restate profits at levels far lower than first reported, and with the company's bond rating cut from investment grade to medium-quality junk, the stock price has crumbled. It closed at $8.25 on Friday.
KPMG, which resigned as auditor on Nov. 11, had warned the company's audit committee in June that the company's accounting procedures were sloppy and needed to be reformed.
But a major dispute remains between KPMG and the board, one that the investigation will no doubt address. KPMG says it told the June 30 meeting of the audit committee that it was no longer willing to rely on the statements made by Frank Bergonzi, then the company's chief financial officer. The company says that members of the audit committee deny that KPMG officials said any such thing. Mr. Bergonzi, who had announced on June 14 that he planned to retire in the fall, was replaced on July 14.

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about new management at the Rite Aid Corporation misstated the type of legal action faced by the company. The Florida attorney general has filed a civil complaint accusing the company of overcharging customers; Rite Aid has not been indicted.
