HEADLINE: OBSERVATORY

BYLINE: By HENRY FOUNTAIN 

 BODY:

Vegetarian Dinosaurs
It may not do much for their reputations, but new research shows that some dinosaurs may have had something in common with chickens. 
 Researchers from the United States, China, Mongolia and Japan, examining the fossilized remains of 12 relatively small dinosaurs from China, have discovered masses of mineral grains inside their rib cages. The grains, the researchers write in the journal Nature, may be the remnants of gizzards, which the creatures may have used to grind up plant matter much as poultry and other plant-eating birds do today.
The dinosaurs, which date to the Upper Cretaceous period, about 70 million years ago, resemble ostriches, with long legs, small heads and toothless beaks. While they have some birdlike features, they are considered nonavian; they are called ornithomimids, or bird mimickers, and belong to the large group of two-legged dinosaurs known as theropods (the most famous member of which is T. rex).
Just what ornithomimids ate has long been a subject of debate. The presence of a gizzard and lack of teeth both point to this variety, at least, as eating plants, not meat.
 
Good News on a Pollutant
Acid rain brought on by sulfur emissions from industrial smokestacks has been a cause of much concern in the Northeast. But a new analysis of sulfur emissions worldwide shows that the United States, along with parts of Europe and Russia, has generally stabilized its emissions over the last two decades. A growing problem, however, exists in China, which now leads the world in the amount of sulfur put into the atmosphere.
The study, by a professor at Washington University in St. Louis and published in the journal Atmospheric Environment, analyzed oil and coal consumption and metal-smelting activity, all contributors to sulfur emissions, from 1850 to 1990. The results show emissions in the United States declining since the 1970's, when new pollution laws took effect and many factories and power plants were forced to switch from burning high-sulfur coal to low-sulfur coal, oil or gas. Industries in the former Soviet Union and some European countries have also switched to natural gas from coal.
But in China, which has abundant supplies of high-sulfur coal feeding a rapidly growing industrial economy, sulfur emissions have increased markedly. In 1990, China emitted 22 million metric tons of sulfur, compared with 15 million by the United States and Canada.
Along with the increase in emissions has come an increase in complaints about acid rain from China's Asian neighbors, similar to the complaints of Northeastern states about sulfur pollution from the Midwest.
 
Genetically Altered Soil
Genetically engineered corn has become very popular among American farmers. About 20 percent of last year's crop was of the modified variety, which exudes a toxin in the leaves and pollen that kills caterpillars and other pests that attack the plant above ground. But what, if anything, happens in the soil?
Researchers at New York University have discovered that the toxin, known as Bt because the genes that produce it come from a bacterium, Bacillus thuringiensis, is exuded from the roots of the corn plant, too. In fact, the researchers found, about the same amount of Bt toxin enters the soil through the roots as is introduced from pollen that comes off during tasseling and from the residue of stalks and leaves left behind after harvesting.
The researchers, writing in Nature, note that the toxin apparently binds with soil and thus persists for long periods -- at least 234 days, the longest period studied. As to whether the presence of all that pesticide in the soil is good or bad, the scientists were noncommittal, saying further research is needed to show whether it helps control harmful pest populations or wipes out beneficial insects.

HEADLINE: Whose Prosperity?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While economists say a resurgence in productivity growth is "the single most important factor in explaining the nation's prosperity" (news article,Dec. 5), I hope the presidential candidates aren't that narrow-sighted. Our prosperity also results from the globalization of the business world and of the entrepreneurial business people in the United States who have taken advantage of this reality. 
 Our own prosperity will keep expanding only to the degree that we create a stable, open, global economy. It's the global economy, stupid! might be the best campaign slogan for 2000.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
The news about industry growth is all good for 1999; forecasts for 2000 call for more of the same.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
HOW upbeat are the two leading forecasters of advertising spending about the prospects for the marketing and media industries in 2000?
At a conference yesterday, they almost warbled a medley of "Blue Skies" and "Cockeyed Optimist" in outlining their predictions for strong, sustained growth next year. 
 O.K., maybe that was an exaggeration. But unusually rosy glows permeated the presentations of Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at Universal McCann in New York, and John Perriss, chairman and chief executive at Zenith Media in London, at the opening session of the 27th annual PaineWebber Media Conference. The conference, at the McGraw-Hill Building in midtown Manhattan, continues through Friday.
The fluctuations of ad spending are closely watched because they often prove to be important indicators of the strength of the overall economy, especially offering clues about consumers' intent to spend. There had been some concerns that the economic turmoil in late 1998 in Asia and Latin America would seriously slow the growth in ad spending, but Madison Avenue has emerged virtually unscathed.
"Financial people were running around wondering if the world would end in 1999," Mr. Coen said. "But 1999 turned out better than we thought possible."
One reason, said Christopher Dixon, a managing director at PaineWebber who introduced the presentations, is "the extraordinary growth of dot-com advertising."
"Who would have thought that 10 or more companies that didn't exist two years ago would be willing to spend up to $3 million on a spot on the Super Bowl?" he asked with a trace of surprise in his voice. His reference was to the record sums being spent to advertise during ABC's coverage next month of Super Bowl XXXIV.
"A year ago, our forecast was more conservative," Mr. Perriss said. "I'm delighted to say we've been proved wrong."
"The global economy has been extraordinarily strong," he added, "and we expect three years of very steady growth" in ad spending from 2000 through 2002.
Mr. Coen predicted that marketers would spend a record $233 billion to advertise in the United States next year, an increase of 8.3 percent from the $215.2 billion that he now forecasts for 1999 after revising upward some previous estimates. Both he and Mr. Perriss make their predictions twice a year and then revise them based on updated data.
The 1999 figure from Mr. Coen represents a 6.8 percent increase from the $201.6 billion spent in 1998. That gain is the smallest in percentage terms since 5.2 percent in 1993, reflecting to some degree the worries early this year about the tumult in overseas markets.
The 8.3 percent increase for 2000 would be the largest in percentage terms since 1994, when American ad spending rose 8.7 percent. And it would also set a record for ad spending as a percentage of gross domestic product at 2.48 percent, compared with 2.37 percent in 1998 and 2.4 percent in 1999.
"Usually when advertising has reached about 2.3 percent of G.D.P., it then grows less rapidly than G.D.P.," Leland A. Westerfield, senior analyst for broadcasting and publishing at PaineWebber, said in an interview after the presentations. "The numbers today could signal a breakout from historic norms."
Mr. Westerfield suggested two trends are powering "this increased level of consumer brand competition." One is "broadband coming into the home, cable modems, which will be a driving force of new advertising" in the interactive realm. The other is "deregulation in Washington, which is enabling increased competition in telecommunications, drugs, health care, financial services, utilities."
When Mr. Coen initially predicted ad spending for 2000 at a presentation in June, he estimated it would total $230 billion. The rise reflects the fact that "we see strong, heavy spending by national marketers" next year, he said, in part because of the millennium and the Summer Olympics, and also because of spending for political ads and the first paid ads to promote participation in the federal census.
Increased budgets are likely for traditional advertisers, Mr. Coen said, in categories like automobiles, computers, drugs, mutual funds and telecommunications as well as for dot-coms. And the gains are likely to be registered in traditional media like national cable and broadcast television networks, he added, as well as in the new media.
Speaking of new media, for the first time Mr. Coen broke out spending for online advertising as a separate category, which he estimated at $1 billion in 1998, $1.8 billion in 1999 and $3.2 billion in 2000.
Overseas in 2000, Mr. Coen forecasts ad spending of $231.4 billion, up 7 percent from a revised figure of $216.3 billion for 1999. That, too, represents an increase from his initial prediction in June, when he estimated ad spending overseas next year at $224 billion. The 1999 figure represents a 5.3 percent rise from $205.4 billion in 1998.
The change in Mr. Coen's international figures for 2000, he said, reflected strengthening economies in countries like Brazil, Indonesia, Mexico and Taiwan.
Mr. Coen's worldwide total for 2000, then, is $464.4 billion, which would represent an increase of 7.6 percent from a revised worldwide total of $431.5 billion for 1999. The 1999 figure is a gain of 6 percent from the $407 billion spent in 1998. The rise in 2000, if it occurs, would be the largest since 1995, when world ad spending rose 11.5 percent.
Though Mr. Perriss uses a different methodology than Mr. Coen, tracking only major media, he was similarly effusive.
"The world looks pretty rosy going forward," Mr. Perriss said. "There don't seem to be any clouds of any consequence on the horizon." Two reasons he listed involved the American economy, which accounts for more than 40 percent of the world's ad spending. One was this country's "consumer boom" and the other was the "incredible" growth of dot-com ad spending in the United States, where he tracked campaigns from "over 800 brands" through the first half of 1999.
Other reasons for Mr. Perriss's optimism were the nascent trend of "dot-coms becoming a European phenomenon in ad spending" and improvements in Asian economies, except for Japan.
Mr. Perriss predicted worldwide ad spending of $319.1 billion for 2000, which would represent an increase of 6.5 percent from his revised estimate of $299.7 billion for 1999. The 1999 figure is an increase of 4.9 percent from $285.6 billion in 1998.
Mr. Perriss also offered forecasts beyond 2000: $338.8 billion in 2001, an increase of 6.2 percent from his expected total for 2000, and $359.2 billion in 2002, a gain of 6 percent from his predicted total for 2001.
Universal McCann is the media services division of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising. That agency is a unit of the McCann-Erickson World Group, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies. Zenith is a joint venture of the Cordiant Communications Group and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.

HEADLINE: Visiting U.S., British Cabinet Minister Urges Investment in Ulster

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Britain's senior minister for Northern Ireland called on the Clinton Administration today to work with American businesses to step up investment in Northern Ireland to support the peace agreement by ending "the very real poverty and deprivation" there.
"It would be nice to see an early dividend from the peace that has been created," said Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, after meeting at the White House with administration officials to brief them on the accord that has brought home rule in Northern Ireland. 
 Even as he was promoting investment to cement the peace, Mr. Mandelson acknowledged that, without continued cooperation between pro-British unionists and pro-Irish republicans, the negotiations that have ended decades of violence in Northern Ireland could be set back "to square one."
"The parties now realize that they need each other," he told reporters. "This is the essence of the accommodation that has been struck."
But, he said, "we still have to go the final mile."
Last week, London transferred local government authority for Northern Ireland to a new power-sharing assembly drawn from the Protestant and Catholic parties. Last weekend, the outlawed Irish Republican Army sent an emissary to meet with an international disarmament committee to discuss the turnover of its weapons, which is required under the peace settlement.
Mr. Mandelson said that as a result of the peace effort, Northern Ireland had undergone a "transformation" that should have obvious appeal to American business executives.
"It's a completely different place -- no road checks, no roadblocks, people going about their day's business, their normal lives, as anywhere else in the United Kingdom," he said, adding that he wanted "to bring home to the American business community the huge return from their investment in Northern Ireland, if they were to commit to that."
The United States is already the largest single foreign investor in Northern Ireland. According to British government figures, American companies have invested about $1.9 billion there in the last five years.
Last year, two-thirds of all first-time investment in Northern Ireland was made by American companies, including several electronics firms seeking to take advantage of its well educated, relatively low-cost work force. American companies employ about 10 percent of the nearly 140,000 people who work in manufacturing jobs in Northern Ireland.
"We have good people, good skills," Mr. Mandelson said. A close political ally of Prime Minister Tony Blair, Mr. Mandelson was appointed to the Northern Ireland post in October.
The mood of the talks today between the British delegation led by Mr. Mandelson and Clinton administration officials was that of a mutual admiration society.
Mr. Mandelson repeatedly praised President Clinton and former Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, who oversaw the negotiations that led to home rule in Northern Ireland, for their peace efforts.
He said that Mr. Clinton had made use of the "the persuasive skills for which he is famous" in the peace negotiations and that "he has not spared any effort, any ounce of energy."

HEADLINE: The Deceptions of Swiss Banks

 BODY:
Switzerland's reputation and especially that of its banks has been battered in recent years as new evidence revealed surprisingly close cooperation between Swiss institutions and those of neighboring Nazi Germany and in particular called new attention to disgracefully shabby Swiss treatment of Nazism's Jewish victims.
Yesterday's long-awaited report on the Swiss banking industry's handling of Nazi-era Jewish accounts added little fresh damage, finding no conclusive evidence that Swiss banks had systematically conspired to conceal or loot those accounts. But the report, by an international panel headed by Paul Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, found that Swiss banks had somehow managed to lose track of a shockingly large number of these accounts over the intervening decades and that many banks had cruelly and deceptively turned away family members trying to recover lost assets. The Volcker panel was able to trace some 54,000 of these missing accounts, far more than the Swiss have previously acknowledged. 
 To ward off court suits and pressure from every level of the American government, Swiss banks last year agreed to a $1.25 billion settlement that resolved claims arising from these and other Nazi-era financial abuses. That total will not be affected by the new Volcker findings. But the report substantially reinforces the evidence supporting that settlement.
The Swiss bank settlement, the first in which a major European industry agreed to repay victims of Hitler-era economic crimes, set an important precedent that surviving Nazi victims are now rightly trying to follow up in other areas, most notably in talks with German industry about compensation for their use of slave and forced labor.
The German government, to its credit, has tried to nudge these negotiations toward a successful conclusion. But Switzerland's government has thus far been defensive and even resentful about acknowledging its responsibilities. That lack of leadership may have contributed to the growing anti-Semitic tone in Swiss politics in recent months. With the release of the Volcker report, and another report due later this week on Switzerland's treatment of refugees fleeing Nazism, Swiss leaders have a fresh chance to acknowledge the less attractive features of their country's wartime record and embrace efforts to compensate the victims.

HEADLINE: Clinton Remark on Child Labor Irks Brazil

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Labor Minister Francisco Dornelles was furious. "Has the United States resolved all its racial problems?" he asked. "No. But the country criticizes us without considering its own issues."
The source of the Brazilian official's anger was a little phrase uttered by President Clinton at the abortive World Trade Organization talks in Seattle. The President said he wanted to end child labor, giving children a way "out of the soccer ball industry in Pakistan, out of the shoe industry in Brazil, the fireworks industry in Guatemala." 
 The phrase backfired like much else at Seattle, where ministers failed to agree on a new round of talks to liberalize trade. In general Mr. Clinton meant to encourage developing countries to keep up their efforts to do away with child labor.
But as the world's ninth-largest economy, Brazil does not take kindly to being lumped with Guatemala. And as a developing nation grappling with the turmoil caused by the forces of globalization, Brazil tends to grow testy when it feels that its problems are misrepresented by an all-powerful United States busy handing out lessons.
Brazil had much to gain from success in Seattle. Agreement on agricultural trade alone could have brought an addition $11 billion in annual export revenue. The opening of trade in the farm and textile sectors of the developed world remains a critical issue for countries from Brazil to India.
But the perceived insult came to dominate Brazil's perception of the Seattle fiasco, a measure of the growing unease in developing countries over a global system that tends to apply the same economic recipe to nations at vastly different stages of economic development.
"Clinton made a big error," said Edmar Bacha, a banker and leading Brazilian economist. "By addressing Brazilian child labor, he wanted to ease the worries of unions and other interest groups over an invasion of cheap, labor-intensive goods. In an American election year, that is good politics. But to Brazilians it looks like a cheap political shot."
Sensitivity here is particularly acute because the last decade of economic liberalization has been so tumultuous.
The country as a whole has secured huge benefits from opening to the world, including a privatized phone system that works, access to imported goods, more efficient industries and a booming Internet business.
But the price in a country of 165 million people always marked by a glaring abyss between rich and poor has been onerous. In the Sao Paulo area alone, unemployment has doubled in recent years to nearly 20 percent as businesses have closed, moved or merged in the face of global competition.
Brazil has been battered by what some critics here call "motel capitalism," characterized by money that is always on the move. Although it has recovered from the financial crisis of two years ago, the country still has growth that is too sluggish for a swelling population, and interest rates that are too high for all but the wealthy, who can prosper by depositing their cash.
High unemployment in the developed world does not often mean desperation, since social insurance acts as a buffer. But in developing nations, high unemployment may push the very children of whom Mr. Clinton spoke into the streets to shore up a family's income.
"We have at least 3,500 children living in the streets today," said Celso Pitta, the mayor of Sao Paulo. "We are trying in various ways to help, but economic conditions are against us. And the easiest, cheapest business for these kids is drugs," often crack.
Violence has also soared in Sao Paulo, Brazil's industrial capital. More than 4,000 people have been murdered here this year, many of them adolescents killed in shootouts over territory in the drug trade.
"You only have to look at the fortresses of the bourgeoisie surrounded by growing walls of barbed wire," said Raimundo Bonfim, a social worker, "and the city's spreading slums, where drugs are a means to survive, to see that what is needed is a mass movement to change the global economic model."
While those who govern developing countries regard Mr. Clinton's sentiments about worker rights and child labor as worthy, they are not convinced that the United States understands the problems.
They wonder whether granting those rights might not destroy the competitive advantage they need for development and whether the West is prepared to provide the billions of dollars needed to eradicate the poverty that lies behind child labor.
The Brazilian shoe industry, an important exporter to the United States, today described President Clinton's remark as a lamentable mistake. Nestor de Paula, the president of one of the main associations of shoe manufacturers, said, "Our opposition to child labor in the shoe industry is widely known."
In fact, the industry -- buffeted by globalization and the loss of thousands of jobs -- has made huge progress in recent years toward eliminating child labor. In Franca, the main production center in the state of Sao Paulo, child labor has been eliminated, and it is fast disappearing elsewhere, United Nations studies show.
The bulk of the more than 700,000 children aged 7 to 14 at work in Brazil are now employed in the coal industry in rural areas and in various informal jobs in the underground or criminal economy of big cities.
"If Mr. Clinton had been well informed, he would have condemned the use of children in the coal business and the criminals who exploit children," commented Klaus Kleber in Gazeta Mercantil, Brazil's leading business paper. "But it so happens that Brazil does not export coal to the United States, or street children."
That sentiment reflects the widespread view in Brazil and in countries like India that behind the pious sentiments of the United States lie down-to-earth political and economic considerations.
"When the United States no longer knows how to protect its industry, it turns to social issues," said Francisco Renan Proenca, the president of the industrial federation of Rio Grande de Sul, a state where the shoe industry is large. Mr. Dornelles, the labor minister, said, "The United States is open in its language but closed in practice."
Such suspicions feed the growing conviction that behind the seemingly neutral terms of "globalization" and "free trade" lies a calibrated calculation by Washington of its own interest.
Brazilians have responded by trying to attack what they see as inconsistencies in American trade policy, including barriers to Brazilian orange juice and sugar. But the unease seems broader. "Most Brazilians favor globalization," Mr. Bacha said, "but not at the price of subordination."

HEADLINE: Pataki Aide Is Selected To Lead SUNY

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON

 BODY:
Struggling with a large deficit, the State University of New York, the nation's largest university, is on the verge of choosing Gov. George E. Pataki's budget director as the next chancellor of the 64-campus system.
The selection of the budget director, Robert L. King, announced yesterday by a search committee headed by the chairman of SUNY's trustees, strengthens Mr. Pataki's influence at the university. Since he took office, several former officials and allies have taken jobs there. 
 Thomas F. Egan, SUNY's chairman and head of the search committee, said he thought that Mr. King had the skills to work with the campuses and to advance SUNY "to the front ranks of American public higher education."
But some critics have questioned whether the appointment of leaders linked to the governor has politicized the university. They say they fear that Mr. Pataki's intention is to install administrators who will stress budget-cutting and efficiency, rather than academic quality, and raise tuition while reducing the share of the budget carried by taxpayers. Students at the four-year colleges now pay $3,400 a year.
The search committee voted unanimously yesterday to recommend Mr. King to the full board of trustees, which is expected to approve the appointment when it meets next Tuesday.
Mr. King will replace John W. Ryan, an experienced educator and longtime president of Indiana University, who started as interim chancellor in 1996 and became permanent chancellor the next year. He will remain a consultant and chancellor emeritus.
The selection comes at a time when the university, which has 370,000 students and 27,000 faculty members, is facing a $77 million deficit in its $1.65 billion annual budget, caused by the impact of the managed care era on teaching hospitals affiliated with SUNY campuses.
The State University is a sprawling archipelago of campuses in virtually every corner of the state. It includes four research universities -- in Binghamton, Stony Brook, Albany and Buffalo -- as well as four-year colleges, community colleges and specialized agricultural and technical colleges.
But to the frustration of its own officials, none of the campuses have the reputation of the great flagship campuses in state systems like those in California, Texas and Michigan.
Mr. King, 52, has little experience in higher education other than his work as a trustee for the Monroe County Community College Foundation. But he is well versed in politics, finance and administration, having served as a state assemblyman, the county executive of Monroe County and, most recently, as state budget director.
Randy Daniels, a trustee who served on the search committee, said Mr. King's extensive knowledge of the state and its budgetary and political environment were significant factors in his choice.
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the governor, said yesterday that Mr. King had "played an important role in the changes Governor Pataki has brought about in this state over the last five years."
In an interview yesterday, Mr. King, who describes himself as a strict conservative politically and fiscally, said he thought his friendship with the governor would be an asset for SUNY.
"If anyone can persuade the governor about the rightness of something for the university, it is me," he said.
Asked whether that relationship might give the governor a greater chance to shape SUNY policy, rather than the other way around, Mr. King answered, "Whatever it is I've been asked to do or chosen to do, I've done with the guideposts of the best interests of the people I'm serving."
He added, "The last thing that he would want or that I would want at the end of the day is for someone to say, 'These are the guys who ruined the university.' "
Mr. King will be SUNY's first chancellor appointed from outside academia, at a time when universities and higher education systems in states like Massachusetts, Oklahoma and Ohio have increasingly looked outside their own ranks for top administrators to bring managerial skills and a sense of accountability.
A graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, with a law degree from Vanderbilt University, Mr. King worked as a prosecutor in California and in Monroe County, N.Y., before being elected to the New York State Assembly, where he became friendly with Mr. Pataki. He has also worked in business and run his own law practice.
In 1995, the governor appointed him director of the new Office of Regulatory Reform, with a mandate to do away with rules stifling business. In February 1998, Mr. Pataki named him budget director.
Mr. King said that he had not yet discussed salary, but as chancellor, he will be paid far more than the $147,490 a year he receives now. SUNY's board recently voted to pay their new chancellor $275,000 to $350,000.
George M. C. Fisher, chairman and chief executive of Eastman Kodak in Rochester, who worked with Mr. King when Mr. King was county executive, called his nomination as chancellor "a stroke of genius," saying he would benefit not only the university, but also companies like his.
"He'll look on companies as customers and say, 'How can I better serve you?' and I like that," Mr. Fisher said.
Mr. King said that one of his priorities would be to build the relationship between the university and industry as a way to improve the state's economy. He said he also wanted to manage the system more efficiently and to build its reputation so that it would be the first choice of the top-performing students in the state.
As county executive, he said, he borrowed managers from local companies, including Kodak, to help him develop training programs for all 5,000 county employees.
As an example of increased efficiency, he said the county's welfare fraud investigation unit pared its investigation time to six weeks, from two years. At the same time, he said, it became more effective: the district attorney, who had prosecuted only 30 percent of the cases the unit recommended, began to prosecute 90 percent of them.
On tuition, Mr. King said he would not try to dissuade the trustees from their pledge to hold tuition steady next year. But he said he favored a system that might link tuition to some kind of inflation index, so students would know what to expect.
Mr. King's candidacy moved very quickly. He said he rebuffed a feeler during the summer, before the state budget was approved. But when he was approached after it passed, he jumped at the opportunity.
"I have always thought that when my time in government came to an end that I'd be interested in securing a job as a college president," he said.
SUNY's search committee first interviewed him during Thanksgiving week, and SUNY's chairman and the governor's staff actively pressed for his candidacy.
Besides Mr. Egan and Mr. Daniels, the committee included two other trustees, Paul Perez and Pamela Jacobs, as well as Shirley Strum Kenny, president of SUNY Stony Brook; Joseph Flynn, the president of the university senate; and Fadeyibi Adeboye, a student from Hudson Valley Community College.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Bad Quarter in Japan Shows Recovery Is Fragile

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Japan's tentative recovery from its worst recession since World War II suffered a setback last quarter as economic growth fell at an unexpectedly steep rate, hurt by sharply declining spending on public works projects, the Economic Planning Agency reported today.
The agency said that the gross domestic product declined 1 percent in the July-through-September period. Although economists said the data did not suggest that Japan might slip back into recession after two quarters of expansion, it still illustrated the country's dependence on public-spending projects to stimulate growth. 
 The data also re-established the two-steps-forward, one-step-back pattern that has characterized Japan's economic activity. All measures of domestic demand -- which account for more than half of the country's economic growth and which the government has been trying so hard to stimulate -- turned negative in the quarter. Consumer spending slipped 0.3 percent, corporate capital expenditures fell 2.1 percent and housing investment, previously strengthened by tax incentives, fell 3.2 percent.
But by far the biggest factor in the economy's retreat was a plunge in public spending, which fell 8.5 percent as the government exhausted its last supplemental budget. Hiroyuki Inoue, senior economist at the Japan Center for Economic Research, said, "Although we have seen some recovery and expect a moderate recovery going forward, we cannot forget the fact that it was pushed ahead by special economic policies such as enormous public spending, historically low interest rates and massive credit guarantees for small and mid-sized businesses."
Exports were the only major area of growth, increasing 4.7 percent, a trend that may not last because of the strength of the yen, which has made Japanese products more expensive overseas. The yen has risen to nearly four-year highs against the dollar, settling in New York today at 103.03 to the dollar.
"The saving grace in the quarter was a substantial rise in the trade surplus," said Richard Katz, senior editor of The Oriental Economist, a newsletter. "Without that rise, G.D.P. would have fallen 1.3 percent."
Japan's Parliament is expected to approve another supplemental budget this month, which could inject $61 billion into the economy, but the effects of that spending will not be noticeable until some time next spring or early summer. Most economists expect the economy to flounder until then, though some think the government's forecast of six-tenths of 1 percent growth for this year will be achieved.
Officials had taken pains to dampen expectations. The Japanese central bank, in particular, has been reluctant to describe the growth of the first two quarters of 1999 as a recovery. And Taichi Sakaiya, the head of the Economic Planning Agency, warned economists and investors that a prediction of 1.4 percent Japanese growth made last month by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a group of affluent industrial nations, was overly optimistic.
"Consumption is down and will probably stay depressed," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter here. "There's weakness in the public works component, and exports are likely to become flat-to-negative because of the stronger yen. This is not the environment for strong G.D.P. growth."
Nonetheless, the stock market here seemed to shrug off the bad news, with the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues continuing to rise, up three-quarters of a percent to 18,507.20. Other indexes rose more sharply.
The figures released today were in some ways difficult to interpret because of revisions to the previous two quarters' statistics. The Economic Planning Agency increased its figures for growth in the April-June quarter to 1 percent from one-tenth of a percent, which aroused some skepticism among economists. "Some of the upward revision in the second quarter looks questionable to me," Mr. Feldman said. He noted that the figures for public investment had sharply reversed, going from a 4 percent drop in the initial announcement to a 2.8 percent gain in the revised data, an unusually sharp adjustment. Other economists noted that capital expenditures for the fiscal year from April 1, 1998, through March 31, 1999, had been revised upward by 6.5 percentage points.
"The numbers are bound to cause confusion because of all the revisions we've had," said Brian Rose of Warburg Dillon Read here. "As an economist, one of the basic things you'd like to know is the size of capital expenditures, and that's just changed, which means forecasts and models have to change, too."
Mr. Rose noted that the latest quarterly data still showed that the economy grew by nine-tenths of a percent compared with the quarter a year earlier. "The economy won't be great," he said, "but the supplemental budget will kick in early next fiscal year and that should keep the economy going next year. But if you were relying on the economy to go into a strong recovery, you should be worried."

HEADLINE: Taking an Early Exit in Atlanta;
Awash in Troubles, Coca-Cola Chief Quits Unexpectedly

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
After a grueling year of falling profits, scuttled acquisitions and the biggest product recall in company history, Coca-Cola's top executive said yesterday that he would step down in April.
The outgoing executive, M. Douglas Ivester, 52, said only that he wanted to "move on to the next stage of my life." But his decision to retire so young after barely two years as chairman and chief executive, a job in which he clearly took delight, stunned shareholders and the business world. 
 Douglas N. Daft, a senior vice president who oversees operations in Asia and the Middle East, was named president and chief operating officer immediately and will assume the top role next year, Coca-Cola said.
Mr. Ivester presided over one of the worst patches in the company's performance since World War II, and that might have exhausted him or led the board to believe it was time to look for someone else.
His rocky path was a marked contrast to the smooth machine that was Coke under Roberto C. Goizueta, the chairman who oversaw a soaring stock price and global sales growth for 16 years until his death in 1997 from cancer. Mr. Ivester, a onetime accountant who designed Coca-Cola's interlocking system with its bottlers, took over from him shortly after the Asian financial crisis erupted.
Since then, the company has been buffeted by disappointing sales and a raft of other problems, including a racial-discrimination lawsuit, government challenges to its acquisition plans and a product contamination scare in Europe this summer, all of which have caused it to slip from its perch as one of the most admired companies.
Though board members had publicly restated their confidence in Mr. Ivester's leadership, he had been increasingly criticized by some investors and company insiders as arrogant and insensitive, most notably in failing to quickly relieve consumer concerns in Europe. In addition, his refusal to name a No. 2 was a sore point with Wall Street. Mr. Ivester was fond of jetting around the world to visit with Coke employees and with customers, but seemed to lack the diplomatic skills to deal effectively with European regulators and others whose agendas were at odds with his own.
In a time of soaring share prices, executives with poor stock performance can find themselves under extraordinary pressure from impatient investors who will take their money elsewhere. Over time, concerns about Mr. Ivester's management style and slowing sales in the United States and abroad had knocked billions of dollars off his company's value. Coke's share price, which exceeded $88 in mid-1998, plunged to $48 in October before rebounding.
Mr. Ivester's resignation, which followed a special board meeting on Sunday, punished the company's stock once more. One stock analyst, Andrew J. Conway of Morgan Stanley, downgraded Coke for the first time in five years. "It's the equivalent of a major earthquake in Atlanta," he said. The stock closed at $64, down $4.3125. That price represents an 11 percent increase in Mr. Ivester's tenure, compared with a 50 percent rise in the broad market.
"Coke used to be all about consistency from an investor perspective, in terms of earnings results and volume results," said Jennifer Solomon, a beverage analyst for Salomon Smith Barney. "We've had nothing but inconsistency the last couple of years, and this just adds to that."
Adding to the confusion yesterday was the release of Coca-Cola's volume numbers for the fourth quarter. The company estimated that sales were ahead of those for the third quarter, suggesting that the tide is turning in Coke's favor. That led many to wonder why Mr. Ivester would make his decision now.
"Doug has informed the board of his desire to retire as chairman and chief executive officer in April, a decision the board has reluctantly accepted," the company said in a statement attributed to James B. Williams, a board member who is also a major shareholder.
A Coca-Cola spokesman, Rob Baskin, reiterated that it was Mr. Ivester's decision. "He decided at the end of last week that it was time for fresh leadership at the Coca-Cola Company," Mr. Baskin said. "He had some conversations with a few board members, they called a special meeting, and they reluctantly accepted his notice of retirement."
Among the board's 12 members are Warren E. Buffett, the value investor who leads Berkshire Hathaway; Herbert A. Allen, chairman of Allen & Company; former U.N. ambassador Donald F. McHenry; and James D. Robinson III, former chairman of American Express. Efforts to reach several board members were unsuccessful yesterday.
"Within the board, there has been underlying unhappiness with the sequence of negative events," said Emanuel Goldman, a global consumer-products analyst at Merrill Lynch. "It's been one after another after another. No single one would necessarily be a determinant, but it's the sum total that probably resulted in this."
Stock analysts scrambled to hold conference calls with their clients yesterday, but came up short on details. "The explanation for his departure at this point in time for the reasons I've been offered seems incomplete," said Marc Cohen, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs. "It strikes me as odd timing, if indeed the business has been repaired and is heading in a positive direction."
Mr. Ivester publicly delighted in the challenges of running Coca-Cola, where he was known to put in long hours, seven days a week, with few interests outside the office. "Even on a bad day, it's still the best job in the world," he told a group of analysts and money managers in July.
Bottlers also seemed perplexed. "I don't understand any of it," said J. Bruce Llewellyn, the chief executive of Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Philadelphia, who said he learned of the announcement while watching television. "I've known Doug Ivester for a long, long time, and I thought he was very good and very knowledgeable about this business. It's his troops and his plan that are in place for the globalization of Coke."
But it is completely out of character for a Coke executive to step down early.
In October, Coke hinted that a succession issue was rising. In a sweeping management change, it gave additional power to three executives, including Mr. Daft, setting up an apparent race for the top spot. A 30-year veteran of Coke, Mr. Daft was passed over for the top spot after Mr. Goizueta's death.
Mr. Ivester, who the company said chose Mr. Daft as his successor, may be leaving after weathering some of the worst problems abroad. Economic crises in Russia, Japan, parts of Latin America and Europe have curbed volume growth over the last 15 months, with currency changes eroding earnings as well. Coca-Cola derives about 75 percent of its profits abroad.
Efforts to expand the company abroad through acquisitions stumbled over regulatory issues. A $1.8 billion purchase of the Cadbury Schweppes brands in most of the world had to be scaled back to exclude much of Europe, after objections from the European Commission, and a two-year effort to buy the Orangina brand from Pernod Ricard S.A. collapsed last month after the French government blocked it.
In June, Coca-Cola had its biggest product recall ever after hundreds of Belgians said they became ill with nausea and other symptoms after drinking Coca-Cola and Fanta, another Coke brand. The incidents prompted a 10-day ban on Coca-Cola products in Belgium, the shutdown of two bottling plants in Belgium and France, and an estimated $200 million in costs to Coca-Cola in Belgium and beyond, as fears spread across the region. Its bottler in Belgium, Coca-Cola Enterprises, took a $103 million charge to earnings from the recall, in which 17 million cases of Coke were destroyed.
Coca-Cola spent heavily on damage control, giving away Cokes to individuals and stores. Mr. Ivester appeared in a television commercial, apologizing to the Belgian people. Still, the company was widely criticized for responding slowly to the crisis; those apologies came a week after the first reports of symptoms. Four schoolchildren said last week that they had still not fully recovered.
Coke is also contending with a racial-discrimination lawsuit filed by four employees who say they were denied pay increases and other promotions because of their race. And the management shuffle in October reassigned the highest-ranking black executive, Carl H. Ware, who resigned days later as senior vice president. His departure was a source of concern for some in Atlanta's civil rights community.
Most of Coke's 29,000 employees were sent an e-mail yesterday telling them of Mr. Ivester's decision. Mr. Baskin said Mr. Ivester has no health problems that influenced his decision. Mr. Goizueta died at age 65, a few months after being diagnosed with lung cancer.
Now the focus shifts to Mr. Daft, who will have a chance to influence a planned reintroduction of Coca-Cola Classic early next year and a strategic change at the company to raise prices even if it means slowing case sales.
In an interview in Atlanta last year, Mr. Daft described the driving force behind Coke's sales abroad. "We all see Coke as being way past a soft drink," he said. "It can represent a way of life to people. It can represent a change. You drink a Coke and it makes you able to cope with an environment that isn't all that fun."

HEADLINE: Bradley Says Ruling Out A Tax Hike Is Dishonest

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Saying it would be irresponsible and dishonest for any presidential candidate to take a "no new taxes" pledge, former Senator Bill Bradley refused today to rule out raising taxes to pay for his plan to make health insurance available to almost every American.
But Mr. Bradley, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, said he did not think a tax increase would be necessary to pay for the $65-billion-a-year proposal because of the nation's robust economy and a projected $1 trillion surplus, which he says is large enough to finance the plan over the coming decade. 
 Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Bradley's lone rival for the Democratic nomination, has been steadily attacking Mr. Bradley's health-care plan as too expensive, and last weekend he criticized Mr. Bradley for leaving open the option of paying for the plan by raising taxes.
"He's being dishonest in saying that I want to raise taxes," Mr. Bradley said today. "I haven't proposed raising new taxes. I'm not proposing raising taxes."
But, he added, "nobody can predict the future of a trillion dollar economy."
Mr. Bradley also dared Mr. Gore to take a pledge of no new taxes, suggesting that it would be disingenuous if he did. To bolster his point, Mr. Bradley noted that then-Gov. Bill Clinton effectively attacked President George Bush for his 1988 promise of "read my lips: no new taxes." Mr. Bush later supported raising taxes to close a budget deficit.
"When Bill Clinton ran in 1992," Mr. Bradley continued, "he said it would be irresponsible to take a no new taxes pledge. I am not taking the no new taxes pledge, and neither is the vice president. So we have the same position.
"My view is, you be honest with the American people. If you think you cannot predict the future, then it would be irresponsible to say, no new taxes. But he thinks if you utter the word, somehow or other it's bad politics. I think people respect honesty and think that's the difference. And I truly thing that people are really tired of politicians who only tell them part of the truth."
Chris Lehane, a spokesman for Mr. Gore, said today, "Vice President Gore has ruled out raising taxes to pay for his programs barring some drastic change in the economy."
That was a "far cry from what Bradley says," Mr. Lehane said, asserting that Mr. Bradley seemed willing to raise taxes even if the economy was not in recession.
Mr. Bradley denied that today and said that Mr. Gore was making a mistake in being willing to raise taxes to finance programs during an economic downturn. Recessions are the best time to cut tax rates, he said.
"You don't raise taxes in bad economic times," Mr. Bradley said. "That's when you cut taxes. Raising taxes in dire economic times makes the economy worse. That's when you put money in people's pockets."
Mr. Bradley tried to turn Mr. Gore's latest attack on its head, saying the vice president was resorting to the "ultimate conventional approach to politics" by being negative.
"That's the old politics," he said. "If you don't have confidence in your own positive vision, you attack somebody else. And you try to do that as often as you can. That's what the name of the game is. I think people are fed up with it. They've been fed up with it for a while."
Mr. Gore began his latest attack in reaction to remarks Mr. Bradley made to The Washington Post last week about his health care plan. In that interview, Mr. Bradley was asked if he would consider raising taxes to pay for the plan. Mr. Bradley said it would depend on the health of the economy. And he said he would consider it only after other options had been reviewed, including closing tax loopholes and reducing federal subsidies for certain industries.
Mr. Gore seized on that opening in an interview with The Post on Saturday. "I'm talking about tax cuts," he said, "Senator Bradley is talking about tax increases."
Today, the Gore campaign accused Mr. Bradley of making contradictory and confusing statements about taxes and the economy.
"Senator Bill Bradley's zigs and zags over the past few weeks raise questions about his steadiness as a possible steward of the American economy," Mr. Lehane said.
The chairman of the Republican National Committee, Jim Nicholson, had also leaped into the fray. Anyone who refused to rule out tax increases was likely to increase taxes, Mr. Nicholson said.
Told of that remark, Mr. Bradley said today, "Tell him to ask George Bush," the former president.
After pausing, he turned the remark toward Mr. Bush's son the Republican presidential candidate: "Tell him ask George W. Bush to take a no new taxes pledge."

HEADLINE: PROSPERITY'S LOSERS: A special report.;
Homeless Defy Cities' Drives to Move Them

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6

 BODY:
When the police car pulled up, the dozen of them were sitting in a tired heap with 15 shopping carts and two dogs along a landscaping wall outside the Trinity Plaza Apartments on Market Street.
Not an hour earlier, two officers had chased them all from a park across the street, at the tourist-filled United Nations Plaza. Not 10 minutes earlier, one of them, Caesar Cruz, a resident of the alleys for three years, had said he felt like crumpled paper in the wind, tossed from here to there all day long. 
 Now, an officer was saying someone had complained about them. Mr. Cruz, holding two $76 summonses for "camping in public" (sleeping in a doorway), worried about getting another. So he nodded again and again when the officer said he would like for Mr. Cruz to "move along."
No one uttered a word in protest. Everyone scattered.
But it is not always that easy to make people who live on the streets disappear. In San Francisco, homeless people haunt the city: cocooned in doorways, pushing overloaded shopping carts, standing on corners announcing their troubles on cardboard signs ("Veteran, homeless and hungry").
And San Francisco is far from alone. At the richest time in the nation's history, housing that the poor can afford is at an all-time low, fueling an increase in homelessness, according to the United States Conference of Mayors. And with complaints about beggars and bag ladies and mumbling, stumbling vagrants growing as well, cities are fighting to move homeless people out of public spaces as never before.
In Sacramento, officials give homeless people one-way bus tickets out of town. In Santa Ana, Calif., it is illegal to sit in the Civic Center with belongings that occupy more than three cubic feet. In Atlanta, a person who asks for money more than twice from a passer-by who ignores the request can be arrested. In Seattle, those caught sleeping in parks can be banned from them.
For many cities, the model is New York, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's quality-of-life initiative swept Midtown Manhattan of panhandlers and squeegee men in the mid-1990's. Thousands of homeless people were ticketed or often arrested for offenses like sleeping in parks or obstructing sidewalks.
(While Mr. Giuliani recently announced that homeless people will have to work for a shelter bed, New York is the only city that guarantees any homeless person shelter on demand, and it has the nation's most extensive services for the homeless.)
Ordinances intended for people on the streets have become popular in the last 10 years, and even more so in the last 5, as the booming economy has brought real estate developers, tourists and well-to-do home buyers back to downtowns. The scramble for space has made once overlooked neighborhoods, the kind where single-room-occupancy hotels thrived and the very poor lived unnoticed, hot properties. The catch is they must be scrubbed clean.
Downtown revitalization or business improvement plans often include park curfews and ordinances popularly known as quality-of-life laws that make sleeping, lying, and sometimes, sitting and standing in public, offenses punishable by jail.
Of 49 cities surveyed last year by the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, 73 percent were enacting or enforcing such ordinances, up from 26 percent in 1994.
City officials talk about "tough love" approaches to forcing homeless people to seek help, and of the growing impatience for what some, echoing President Ronald Reagan, call "the homeless by choice."
"There are those who fail to realize that we have to pay a price if we want to improve the quality of life," said the Rev. Amos Brown, a San Francisco supervisor. He has proposed a city ordinance that would ban standing on a corner or street median for more than five minutes to discourage panhandling. Loiterers would face a $250 fine and up to six months in jail.
"We need to decide, are we going to be a society where there's a sense of order," Mr. Brown said, "or do we want a disorderly society where anything goes?"
 
The Change
From Society Ill To Personal Problem
Whether fueled by highly publicized attacks by mentally disturbed people described as homeless, or exhausted by the seemingly intractability of the problem, the current policies and positions toward the homeless are a stark change from barely a decade ago.
In 1986, six million people formed a 4,000-mile line coast to coast to raise money to fight hunger and homelessness. These days, solving homelessness has faded from the public consciousness. Poverty, despite President Clinton's two forays this year to down-and-out communities, barely rates the news.
"Homelessness has gone from being a societal problem to being a messed-up individual's problem," said Paul Boden, board member of the National Coalition for the Homeless and director of the San Francisco Coalition on Homelessness. "There is an attitude that with unemployment at record lows, with the stock market at record highs, if you're poor, it's your own damn fault."
Officials in communities enforcing quality-of-life laws say they are doing all they can to house and to provide medical and mental health services for the truly needy, despite increasing competition for state and federal money.
But advocates for the poor say many communities are spending more energy and resources on plans to police and prosecute the down and out as quality-of-life offenders than on tackling the causes of homelessness.
"It's not rocket science to figure out that people become homeless because of the lack of affordable housing and support services for those who are mentally ill or addicted," said Mary Ann Gleason, director of the National Coalition for the Homeless. "Yet it's true that in many communities across the country, cities are responding in not very helpful ways to the growing need for affordable housing and accessible health care.
"We continue to discharge people from prisons and hospitals into shelters. We continue to put people who need help with substance abuse on long waiting lists. And now, putting people in jail for doing in public what other people have the privilege to do in private seems to be the way to go."
 
The Sweep
Using the Law And Persuasion
California's capital, Sacramento, began cracking down on street people about four years ago, pushed by business people trying to improve the city's image. The Downtown Sacramento Partnership, which represents about 550 businesses, employs about 20 people it calls city guides to patrol 65 blocks. The patrols, concentrating on tourist areas and shopping zones, call the police when they find someone sleeping on the street or panhandling.
"To make this a destination and encourage continued revitalization, we need to continue to make it clear that downtown is not going to be a place where panhandling and other negative activity is tolerated," said Michael Ault, the partnership's executive director.
Sacramento has become "tired of the constancy" of homelessness, said Heather Fargo, a councilwoman, who said the city was spending $14 million on homeless programs this year, up from $1.6 million 10 years ago.
In a move many other communities have made, Sacramento, after weeks of coaxing scores of people from an encampment along a river parkway, began offering them bus tickets out of town. City officials said they sent away only those who had a relative or friend who had agreed to take them in.
Nearby communities have found even more creative ways to police their streets. In Roseville, a suburb about 25 miles east of Sacramento, the police go undercover to catch panhandlers in the act. Homeless people say they are often escorted out of town.
Marysville, an old gold rush town of 12,500 residents about 40 miles north of Sacramento, has painted 10 parking meters red, removed the timers and called them homeless meters. Signs on the machines say: "Donation here will help the homeless. Please do not give cash to panhandlers."
The city has also banned shopping carts from city streets and rummaging through trash, or "dumpster diving," except with permission of the property owner.
Mark Siemens, the Marysville city administrator and chief of police, said the city began cracking down on panhandling five years ago, after "a huge backlash from the business population in town."
About 40 to 50 transients and street people would haunt a two-square-mile area, Mr. Siemens said. Many came by freight train, he said, drawn by the city's rescue mission and other services for the homeless.
Now, he said, "When they realize, 'Gee whiz, it just doesn't do any good to stand on a corner and beg for money,' they find someplace else to go. If there's no good fishing in the lake, you find another lake."
In San Francisco, police sweeps and crackdowns on homeless people have become so well known that in October, the National Coalition for the Homeless chose the city as the site to open a national campaign for civil rights for the homeless. This year, the police here issued more than 20,000 citations for violations of ordinances like trespassing, camping, carrying an open container and violating park curfews, compared with 17,500 in 1998 and 15,700 in 1997.
Because the citations do not appear to be making a dent in the homeless population, the city's Board of Supervisors recently approved $250,000 for the city attorney to set up a special unit dedicated to prosecuting those offenses.
Many people seem to approve. In random interviews with three dozen people in San Francisco, many had qualified sympathy for the homeless but most were also harshly critical of people they felt were unwilling to change their situation. Only a fourth of those interviewed named high housing costs as a cause of homelessness; a third blamed laziness or addictions.
"I don't really sympathize," said Leia Sutton, a waitress. "I feel they are already taken such good care of with financial aid and food stamps. They get free food. And I think it's making a lot of them not get off their butts and survive for themselves."
Aaron James, a parking control officer in San Francisco, blamed housing costs.
"Yuppies from Silicon Valley are coming in and sending the prices soaring," Mr. James said. "Studios are going for $1,200 a month."
But Nabil Salem, 30, who owns the McCallister Market and Deli, in the Tenderloin district where many homeless people live, sees a lack of personal responsibility in the people he brushes from his doorway.
"It's a very big problem for retailers," Mr. Salem said. "Every morning I come in to open up the store. And they're sleeping in the doorway. Or they have left boxes, where they've slept. Or food. They urinate or sometimes defecate. And it smells. I get so mad. It happens all the time. Every morning. It takes me two hours to clean it up sometimes. Why should I have to put up with that?"
In October, the city announced a plan to confiscate shopping carts as stolen property from the hundreds of people who use them to carry their belongings. The plan was canceled when the public protested the idea as cruel.
Still, in recent interviews with dozens of homeless people, most reported having their possessions thrown away by teams hired by supermarkets to retrieve the shopping carts, or by the police, who seize the carts as abandoned property, even as the homeless person stands by.
"They just took my stuff and dumped it in a Dumpster, and I had all my papers in there," said Tyrone Saunders, 35, who has been homeless for four years. "I have AIDS, so I had to go fishing through the garbage to get my stuff back. I don't ask nobody for nothing. I clean floors at the corner store for my money. And everyone still sees me as dirt."
In recent weeks, the police have also started arresting volunteers for handing out food to homeless people (without having a permit to do so) at United Nations Plaza. (The catch: the city will not grant them a permit.)
"I have never seen anything so mean-spirited," said Sister Bernie Galvin, director of Religious Witness With Homeless People, an interfaith advocacy group, who was one of those arrested and held in jail for 24 hours.
George Smith, the director of the Mayor's Office on Homelessness, and a former homeless drug user, acknowledged that the police crackdowns had done little to help matters. He said the city was in the process of increasing teams of outreach workers to offer street people help.
"We have people moving through the system successfully all the time," Mr. Smith said. But, he said, "San Francisco can't be expected to solve a national problem."
 
The Shelters
Rising Opposition To Growing Need
In many cities, officials insist that the people wandering the streets night and day come from elsewhere. They say the homeless are drawn to a place by its weather or welfare allowance or reputation for tolerance.
In fact, studies of homeless people have suggested that most of them once had homes in the communities where they became homeless. Dennis Culhane, a professor of social welfare policy at the University of Pennsylvania, who has studied homelessness, said that based on analyses in New York City and Philadelphia, homeless people were, predictably, the very poor.
They come from the poorest neighborhoods, where people pay the most for their housing relative to income, they crowd together to afford housing costs, and they have the highest unemployment and temporary employment rates. Their neighborhoods have the worst levels of housing abandonment. Professor Culhane said most people living on the street have been evicted from their homes.
No one, it seems, wants homeless people in their backyard. In communities where homeless people are regularly cited for begging or sleeping or trespassing, officials are encountering mounting resistance when they try to open shelters to house those they have swept off the streets.
In Atlanta, where an estimated 22,000 people are homeless, two proposed shelters are stalled by opposition. Earlier this year, a donor bought a building on Peachtree Street, the city's main thoroughfare, for the Metro Atlanta Task Force for the Homeless. The task force proposed converting the building, which housed an arts group, to a shelter that that would also provide counseling for abuse of drugs and alcohol and help in getting jobs and long-term housing.
But the building is in the renovated downtown, where more than 9,000 homeless people were arrested in the 12 months before the 1996 Olympic Games for violating newly enacted quality-of-life laws, and opposition to the shelter was swift and loud.
The city requested that single men be housed in a separate building from women and children in order for the project to proceed. But when the task force then signed a contract to buy a former nightclub in an industrial neighborhood, that, too, met protests, and city officials earlier this month refused to support the shelter.
Although the closest real neighborhood is across a highway, the area is in the process of revitalization, with landlords converting warehouses into loft condominiums.
"If we can't open it here, than where?" said Anita Beaty, co-director of the task force, as she looked around the pocked landscape surrounding the empty building on a recent visit.
Some 85 to 90 women and children have been sleeping in the task force office on recent nights, Ms. Beaty said.
The other day, about two dozen men were lying a stone's throw from the building where the men's shelter would be built. They live under the highway, not on the ground, but tucked under the top of supports that hold an elevated section. In broad daylight, they were shrouded in darkness. Only the glint of eyes and teeth were visible, and several of the men covered their faces when they noticed people noticed them.

HEADLINE: Republican Candidates Gather for Courteous Debate

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Resisting their first opportunity to spar directly with each other on national television, six Republican presidential candidates instead treated each other rather courteously tonight as they touted their stands on foreign policy, taxes, education and campaign finance.
Unlike in a Republican forum last week in New Hampshire, in which Gov. George W. Bush of Texas shared the stage for the first time with his rivals, the contenders were subtler this time in contrasting themselves with Mr. Bush, the front-runner. 
 Mr. Bush drew criticism last week for too often drawing from his stump speech. Tonight, he appeared a bit more at ease but still offered rather rote responses on matters like tax cutting and foreign policy.
Asked what he had learned about foreign policy from a biography of Dean Acheson -- Mr. Bush said last week that he was reading the book -- the governor repeated statements from his standard speech and gave no specifics about Mr. Acheson, the secretary of state from 1949 to 1953.
The lesson, Mr. Bush said, "is that our nation's greatest export to the world has been, is and always will be the incredible freedoms we understand in the great land called America."
Moments later, Senator John McCain of Arizona seized the opportunity to demonstrate his knowledge of foreign affairs and history. He answered a question by saying: "Let me talk about Dean Acheson for a second. When Dean Acheson walked into Harry Truman's office in June of 1950 and said, 'North Korea's attacked South Korea,' Harry Truman didn't take a poll. Harry Truman knew what we had to do."
For about half of the debate at the Orpheum Theater, the competitors were allowed to question one another. But mostly their questions sounded like recitals of their own credentials. The event, which lasted about 75 minutes, was carried live on CNN.
Mr. Bush repeatedly talked about recasting the Republican Party as a compassionate party that cared about everyone, and he underscored his concern for the less fortunate.
Mr. McCain, who has emerged as a potent rival to Mr. Bush in New Hampshire, trumpeted his prescriptions to reform the campaign finance system. Although he was hooked up to the event by satellite from a television studio near Boston, Mr. McCain, as he did last week, seemed particularly comfortable fielding questions.
Steve Forbes, the publisher, sought to establish his conservative credentials and hawk his plans for the economy. Gary L. Bauer, who headed a grass-roots conservative group, played up his crusade against most-favored-nation status for China because of human rights abuses. Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah spoke often about his seasoning after years in the Senate. And Alan Keyes, a former State Department official, pressed his conservativism.
When the candidates had the opportunity to ask questions, it was no surprise that the first up, Mr. Bauer, turned his attention to Mr. Bush.
Mr. Bauer asked Mr. Bush why he, like President Clinton, favored more open trade with China, as opposed to a sharper confrontation.
Mr. Bush replied, "If you give people a breath of freedom, a taste of freedom, I think you'll be amazed, Gary, at how soon democracy will come."
Then Mr. Bauer asked, "Is there no atrocity that you can think of that would tell you to put trade on the back burner?"
Mr. Bush, in perhaps his most spirited answer, said: "If we turn our back on China and try to isolate China, things will get worse. Imagine if the Internet took hold in China. Imagine how freedom will spread." The governor used his question, to Mr. Hatch, to boast about how in Texas he had drawn significant support from Hispanic voters.
Mr. Hatch said, "I think Governor Bush deserves a lot of credit." But the senator questioned Mr. Bush's qualification for the Oval Office. He said many people had suggested that Mr. Bush would be a perfect vice president given that Mr. Hatch had more foreign policy experience. "You should have eight years with me," Mr. Hatch said to Mr. Bush. "Boy, you'd make a heck of a president after eight years." The audience erupted in laughter.
At times, the good manners seemed forced. When Mr. Forbes told Mr. Bush he could call him Steve, the governor, who is not known as being particularly fond of the publisher, appeared not to know quite what to say. Later in the evening, Mr. McCain joked that he did not know whether to call the governor "George," "W" or "Bush" or "whatever."
In his question for Mr. McCain, Mr. Bush promoted his proposal for tax incentives for faith-based institutions. Mr. McCain complimented the governor's proposal. But he tried to draw a contrast by suggesting that Mr. Bush relied on rosy, and perhaps unrealistic, projections of surpluses.
"There's a big difference," Mr. McCain said. "I do not envision surpluses forever."
The first round of questions for all six candidates concerned education, and each candidate used his response principally as an opportunity to state his general views on the federal government's role in public education. Those views were nearly identical: all the candidates emphasized clear, finite limits to federal involvement and many advocated at least some experimentation with vouchers.
Both Mr. Bauer and Mr. Keyes rued the flight of prayer and religion from classrooms, with Mr. Bauer citing that as a reason for violence in schools. "I don't think this is a gun problem, as some might suggest," Mr. Bauer said. "I think it's a problem of the heart and soul."
Mr. Keyes agreed, saying, "Since we took prayer out, we seem to have let violence and decline in."
Both Mr. Hatch and Mr. Bush talked up the virtues of vouchers, although Mr. Bush did not use that word. Mr. Bush reiterated his belief that schools that receive federal funds should face consequences if the children in those schools are failing.
"I believe that if the federal government spends money on the poorest of the poor children, we need to ask a simple question," said Mr. Bush. "What are the results? What are the results?"
Mr. McCain was reminded of a statement he had repeatedly made that good teachers should make more than bad senators, whose salaries will raise to $140,000 in January.
"You know that I would never allege that there are any bad senators," Mr. McCain joked. Then, making light of questions that have been raised about his temper, he added: "I win Miss Congeniality every year in the Senate."
In an effort to prevent Mr. Bush's rivals from ganging up, CNN set ground rules that prohibited the candidates from asking all their allocated questions of the same person.
Mr. McCain did not travel to Arizona to share the stage with his competitors because, his campaign said, he had long-scheduled events in New Hampshire and New York today and Tuesday, but CNN agreed to include Mr. McCain by satellite. Despite the civility of the discourse compared with last week's, there were a handful of thinly disguised digs at Mr. Bush. "Instead of running on their name or their wealth," Mr. Keyes said at one point, "let's seem them run on their abilities, as I'm doing."
"Amen," Mr. Hatch said.

NEW YORK LIFE TO ACQUIRE MEXICAN INSURER

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The New York Life Insurance Company, the seventh-largest life insurer in the United States, said yesterday that it would pay $570 million to acquire Mexico's third-largest insurer, Seguros Monterrey Aetna S.A., from Grupo Financiero Bancomer S. A. and Aetna Inc. to expand its business in Mexico. Bancomer, Mexico's second-largest banking group, said it would receive $290 million for its 51 percent stake in the insurance venture. New York Life gains a subsidiary that sells life, health, property and casualty policies in a growing insurance market where insurance premiums proportional to economic output are less than in other Latin American countries. Aetna rose $1.8125, to $59.5625. Seguros Monterrey has 23 percent of Mexico's individual life insurance business.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
A Bid to Save a Theater

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The Crossroads Theater Company, in New Brunswick, N.J., long acknowledged as one of the nation's most prominent black theaters, announced an endowment drive yesterday in the face of a financial crisis.
The 21-year-old company, which won a Tony Award this year for outstanding regional theater, carries a debt of $1.2 million and canceled six preview performances of its current production, "Play On!," because it could not pay for sets, costumes or actors. 
 Crossroads' co-founder and artistic director, Ricardo Khan, said yesterday that he planned to take a yearlong sabbatical to raise an endowment.
"What might have closed down most organizations has not closed down Crossroads," Mr. Khan said at a news conference. Black politicians and church leaders also pledged to raise money to save the theater, which brought "Ain't Nothin' but the Blues" to Broadway.
Crossroads, which has attracted actors like Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee, also appointed its board chairman, Dale Caldwell, as president and chief executive, with a mission of focusing on the company's finances.
