HEADLINE: Panel Advises Adding to Life Expectancies

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The Social Security Administration is not being optimistic enough about how long Americans will live in the 21st century, and as a result it has underestimated how much their benefits will cost, a federal advisory panel said today.
The Clinton administration underestimated the financial problems of the Social Security program because it understated likely improvements in life expectancy, the panel said. Federal officials already assume that Americans will live longer in the next century. But the expert panel said that the assumptions were too conservative and that life expectancy would probably continue improving in coming decades, just as it had through the 20th century. 
 The 12-member panel said the decline in mortality rates had financial implications: "Longer lives imply more years of Social Security benefits," it said.
The panel reviewed the economic, demographic and other technical assumptions used by the trustees of the Social Security program, including the Secretaries of the Treasury, Labor and Health and Human Services. The panel's report was commissioned and issued by the Social Security Advisory Board, an independent bipartisan body created by Congress and appointed by the president and Congressional leaders. The trustees may incorporate the panel's suggestions in their own annual report. But Social Security tax rates, the formula for computing benefits and the standard retirement age can be altered only by changing federal law.
Life expectancy at birth increased to 76.7 in 1998 from 63.6 years in 1940. The Social Security Administration predicts that it will rise to 79.3 in 2030 and to 81.5 in 2070. The expert panel said these numbers should be higher; it predicted life expectancy would probably reach 81 in 2030 and 85.2 in 2070.
"We think life expectancy will increase more rapidly than the actuaries have estimated in the past," said Richard D. Lee, a professor of demography and economics at the University of California at Berkeley and a panel member.
President Clinton has often described this type of situation as "a high-class problem," because it reflects improvements in the well-being of Americans.
The panel, led by C. Eugene Steuerle, an economist at the Urban Institute, also said that wages and productivity would rise a little faster than the government has assumed, and also suggested other changes for the trustees' report.
Taking these changes together, the panel concluded that Social Security's long-term financial problems were about 25 percent greater than indicated by the official government estimates. To cover the shortfall by raising taxes, the panel said, annual payroll taxes would have to be increased by 2.6 percentage points above current levels -- not just 2.07 percentage points higher, as would be required under the Clinton administration's assumptions.
For a worker earning $30,000 a year, that means the payroll tax would have to rise by $780 a year, rather than the increase of $621 needed under the assumptions now used by the government.
The panel said that Social Security officials had made the pessimistic and implausible assumption that life expectancy in the United States would continue to lag far behind that of other countries.
For example, it said, Social Security actuaries assume that American women will have to wait until 2033 before they achieve the life expectancy already achieved by French women in 1995 (about 82 years). Likewise, it said, the actuaries assume that American men will have to wait until 2029 before they achieve the life expectancy recorded by Japanese men in 1995 (77 years).
The experience of other countries shows that "U.S. mortality can fall a long way without encountering biomedical limits," the panel said.
Jane L. Ross, deputy commissioner of Social Security, said the panel's recommendations would be "carefully considered" as her agency prepares future annual reports on the program's financial condition.
Stephen C. Goss, deputy chief actuary of Social Security, said: "Everybody agrees that mortality will continue to improve in the future. The point of debate is how fast that improvement will be." 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: December 11, 1999, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about life expectancy and Social Security misstated the given name of the professor of demography and economics at Berkeley who predicted that life expectancy would increase more quickly than actuaries foresaw. He is Ronald D. Lee, not Richard.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Forum With G.O.P. Candidates

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the forum last night in Phoenix for the Republican presidential candidates, Gary L. Bauer, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, Steve Forbes, Alan Keyes, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah and Senator John McCain of Arizona, as recorded by The New York Times: 

Mr. Forbes
 
Q. Look back at the past seven years. We have 20 million new jobs, 4.1 percent unemployment, low inflation, more than a tripling of the stock market, yet you have been critical not only as many of your rivals here have been of the incumbent president's economic stewardship, but also of the job performance of the Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan. What in your view has Mr. Greenspan done wrong? And if you are elected president, who would you nominate to replace him?
 
A. First of all the prosperity that we're enjoying today, those foundations were laid by Ronald Reagan in the early 1980's. Let's not forget that. And it was the Republicans who stopped some of the destructive nonsense of the Clinton-Gore administration that enabled us to enjoy the prosperity we have today.
Concerning the Federal Reserve, as I've said before, Mr. Greenspan did a very good job in the early 1990's. But in the last couple of years he's fallen prey, fallen for this crazy theory, John, that prosperity causes inflation. And so they're trying to slow the economy down by raising interest rates. Why? It's like going to a doctor. The doctor says John you're in great health, so we have to make you sick a little bit. It's a bizarre theory. And it's already wrought havoc in agriculture.
It's going to hurt our economy and in terms of a replacement, there are a number of good people out there, Jack Kemp, the head of the Dallas Reserve Bank as well, the people who understand it. . . .
 
Mr. Bush
 
Q. While we are considering America's place in the world, you volunteered at last week's debate that you were now reading the biography of Dean Acheson. And my question is, what lessons do you take from the successes and the failures of Acheson and George Marshall during that critical period in U.S. history and how would you apply that to a Bush international policy?
 
A. The lessons learned are that the United States must not retreat within our borders, that we must promote the peace. In order to promote the peace, we've got to have strong alliances, alliances in Europe, alliances in the Far East. In order to promote the peace, I believe we ought to be a free-trading nation in a free-trading world, because free trade brings markets and markets bring hope and prosperity.
In order to keep the peace, the United States must be strong militarily. The speech I gave in the Citadel in South Carolina I talked about the need to not only make sure that the morale in today's military is high, but also to make sure that we reconfigure our military.
You see, if we get to redefine how war is fought, we get to redefine how the peace is kept. The lessons of Atchinson and Marshall are, is that our nation's greatest export to the world has been, is and always will be, the incredible freedoms we understand in the great land called America. . . .
 
Mr. McCain
 
Q. Tonight there is both an emotional and a diplomatic trauma playing out about a 5-year-old boy from Cuba who lost his mother as they tried to enter the United States by water. The boy's father back in Cuba says he wants his son back. If you were president of the United States, what would you do?
 
A. I'd say to Mr. Castro, let his father come to the United States and enjoy peace and freedom and be reunited with his son. We don't want his son to grow up under Communist tyranny.
Let me talk about Dean Acheson a second. When Dean Acheson walked into Harry Truman's office in June of 1950 and said, North Korea has attacked South Korea, Harry Truman didn't take a poll. Harry Truman knew what we had to do. If he'd have taken a poll, maybe Americans wouldn't have let us go.
This administration is poll driven and not principle driven. We didn't have to get into Kosovo. Once we stumbled into it, we had to win it. And the fact is that this administration has conducted a feckless photo-op foreign policy for which we will pay a very heavy price in American blood and treasure.
You have to have a concept of what you want the world to look like. Well, our interests and our values lie in how we are going to bring this world into the next century and call it, again, the American century. . . .

They persecute their people, arrest those who practice their religion, forcible abortions, etc. And yet you've embraced the policy of Clinton and Gore, you want to give them most favored nation status and membership in the World Trade Organization. I think it's in our nation's best interests to open up Chinese markets to Arizona farm products, to Iowa farm products, to high-tech manufactured goods.
It's in our best interests to sell to the Chinese. It's also in our best interests to make sure that the entrepreneurial class in China flourishes. I think we make China make an enemy, they'll end up being an enemy. I think if we trade with China, and trade with the entrepreneurial class, and give people a breath of freedom, give them a taste of freedom, I think you'll be amazed, Gary at how soon democracy will come. And so, I also believe, so therefore I believe China ought to be in the World Trade Organization. I also believe that Taiwan ought to be in the World Trade Organization. But let me make this clear to you and to the Chinese.
I will enforce the Taiwan relations law if I'm the president, if the Chinese get aggressive with the Taiwanese we'll help them defend themselves. . . .

MR. HATCH -- Well, I think minority parents owe you. And I think Republicans owe you. You've been a great governor. My only problem with you, Governor, is that you've only had four, going into your fifth year of governorship and a constitutionally weak governorship. That's why I'm think of you as a vice-presidential candidate. Because if you had -- just think, just think: Ronald Reagan picked your father because he had foreign policy experience. Somebody suggested the other day they should -- you should pick me because I have foreign policy experience. They've got it all wrong. I should be president and you should have eight years with me and boy, you'll make a heck of a president after eight years, I'll tell you.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
For Unusual Tower, It's All About Signs

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
The newest addition to the Times Square neighborhood is a 300-foot-tall steel supporting column for the illuminated signs characteristic of the area, with a 550-room hotel added almost as an afterthought.
The shell of the building, at Broadway and 47th Street, has been completed and the hotel is expected to go into operation in May. It was originally planned as the first Planet Hollywood hotel, but the bankruptcy filing by the restaurant company in October stopped that plan, although Planet Hollywood still owns retail condominium space in the building. The developers of the project are negotiating with hotel companies to find an operator. 
 Some temporary signs, including advertisements for Sealy mattresses, Banana Republic and MetroCard, are now attached to the tower. Eventually, they are to be replaced with the animated displays and moving mechanical elements that the industry calls spectaculars.
"I have been thinking of doing a sign tower since 1987," said Robert Gladstone of Madison Equities, one of the principal investors in the project. The tower, he said, will provide additional income from sign rentals while still letting him build the hotel as large as allowed by zoning regulations.
The 340,000-square-foot building, which runs 45 feet along Broadway and 145 feet along 47th Street, consists of four full floors at the base, which is to be used for stores, restaurants and meeting rooms.
The sign tower starts on top of the fourth floor on a platform facing Broadway at about 60 feet above the street and extends upward an additional 240 feet. The tower is an internally braced steel truss that is not connected vertically to the reinforced-concrete hotel.
The guest-room section of the hotel is shaped like an L on two sides of the tower and is to have signs on the roof whose tops are to be almost 500 feet over street level. Because of the layout of the hotel, Mr. Gladstone said, none of the windows of the guest rooms will face directly onto signs. He said there were 12 guest rooms per floor, with 6 facing north and 6 facing south.
The unusual design of the building underscores the economic value of the signs that are required by city regulations in the Times Square area. In 1997, a German investment company, the Jamestown Group, paid $1,000 a square foot for the largely vacant building at 1 Times Square when fully occupied, high-quality office buildings were selling for $300 to $500 a square foot.
That is because the real value of the building is as a base for the signs that are seen by thousands of tourists each day and by millions worldwide on New Year's Eve, when the ball signaling the end of the old year is lowered from the building's roof. The signs on 1 Times Square, which is between 42nd and 43rd Streets, have been reported to generate $7 million in net income annually.
Mr. Gladstone said his tower at 47th Street was specifically designed for the installation and servicing of the largest heaviest spectaculars made. He said the tower was anchored to bedrock 50 feet below the street surface to prevent it from swaying as winds caught the sail-like surfaces of the signs.
Excavating the 14,000 cubic yards of rock from the site was one of the most difficult parts of the project, which is being managed by J. A. Jones-GMO, a construction company. Because of performances at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater on 46th Street, drilling and blasting often had to be halted and the landmarked theater carefully monitored for damage.
The air rights over the theater were added to the hotel site to increase the size of the building.
Inside the sign tower, an elevator system capable of lifting workers and equipment has been permanently installed, and catwalks are being placed every 8 feet vertically so that workers will have a foothold for repairs. In addition, a crane is being installed at the top to lift the signs into place.
The positioning of the tower on the east side of the property means that signs attached to its north face will be visible to anyone traveling south on Broadway, because of the setbacks on the building to the north of 47th Street housing the Morgan Stanley Dean Witter financial services company.
With the tower and building combined, Mr. Gladstone said, the project will be able to support 70,000 to 75,000 square feet of signs, the largest such installation in the Times Square area.

HEADLINE: Where Most See Ramparts, North Korea Imagines a Wall

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 7

 BODY:
A North Korean diplomat used a rare news conference here today to rail against a nonexistent 150-mile-long concrete "wall of division" that the South Koreans supposedly erected 20 years ago across the buffer zone between North and South.
The diplomat, Chu Chang Jun, is North Korea's longtime ambassador to China, one of his country's few allies. He demanded the "immediate dismantling of the cursed reinforced concrete wall that artificially bisects the nation that had lived in harmony generation after generation." 
 In a "never to be pardoned criminal act," the wall was erected across the peninsula 20 years ago this Dec. 29, Mr. Chu said. It is "a huge structure," he said, 16 to 26 feet tall and 33 to 62 feet wide at the base. Far from a defensive rampart, it is a "northward invasion bridgehead," he said.
The wall exists only in North Korean propaganda, according to South Korean and American diplomats and others who have visited the area. But with a hostile North Korea keeping large numbers of troops and tanks near the border, the South Koreans, aided by the United States, have strewn large concrete tank barriers and sentry stations as well as fences and minefields along their side of the tense demilitarized zone.
The bitter Korean War of 1950 to 1953 ended with a truce but no treaty, and the buffer zone that divides the peninsula has been volatile ever since.
At the news conference, Mr. Chu gave an implacable summary of North Korean views on relations with the South and its sponsor, the United States. He spoke beneath large pictures of the late North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung, and his son, the current leader, Kim Jong Il.
Mr. Chu's comments seemed out of step with diplomatic developments, making the news conference seem even odder. Reeling from years of economic collapse and famine, North Korea seems to be opening its doors a crack in a quest for more economic aid, diplomats say.
North Korea and Japan are seriously discussing a restoration of diplomatic relations. The United States lifted many trade restrictions after North Korea agreed not to carry out a second test of a long-range missile, and talks on improving ties have proceeded fitfully.
South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, has pursued a "sunshine policy" of broader economic and cultural contacts with North Korea, and the North has recently allowed more exchanges. Mr. Chu said, "the sunshine policy brings confrontation instead of reconciliation," and called it "very dangerous."
Mr. Chu also denied reports -- verified by many journalists and diplomats -- that tens of thousands of North Koreans had crossed the border into China to escape famine and hardship. "There have been no illegal border crossings," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Rise a 3rd Day as Inflation Fears Ease

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond yields fell for the third consecutive day yesterday after government reports showed a rise in productivity and a drop in labor costs, easing concern about inflation.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 17/32 , to 991/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.20 percent from 6.24 percent on Monday. 
 The government raised its estimate of growth in third-quarter productivity to a 4.9 percent annual pace, the fastest in almost seven years, from a prior estimate of 4.2 percent. Productivity measures output for each hour worked.
In another report, the Labor Department said unit labor costs for the third quarter declined 0.2 percent, which brought the year-over-year trend to just 1.5 percent, down from 2.3 percent in the second quarter.
Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management said: "It soothed the market's inflationary concerns at least for the time being and resulted in a further decline in bond yields. However, this drop in bond yields is not likely to last into the first quarter, as investors' inflationary expectations and desired real rate of return will likely push bond yields back up.
"Indeed," Mr. Fine said, "with the economy continuing to grow very strongly, and with the unemployment rate at 4.1 percent, the Fed is likely to remain in a tightening mode until it sees definitive signs that economic growth is slowing to a noninflationary pace. While no move is expected at the Dec. 21 Federal Open Market Committee meeting, to ease the transition through Year 2000 concerns, the central bank appears to be on a direct course to raise short-term rates once again during the first quarter of the year 2000."
The government also auctioned $10 billion of a new 52-week bill. They were awarded at a rate of 5.35 percent, which was a bit better than expected, with the bid-to-cover ratio, or the number of bids compared to the total amount being sold, considered decent at 3.21 to 1.
Treasury prices also received a lift in the afternoon after the Federal Reserve Board entered the market to buy long-dated issues, and Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, did not mention monetary policy in a midmorning speech at the Commerce Department.
While daily high came after Mr. Greenspan's speech, most market participants attributed the gains to a "coupon pass" or the purchase of Treasury securities by the Fed, which bought $915 million worth of securities maturing between Aug. 15, 2022, and Nov. 15, 2027.
With trading activity on the decline heading into the end of the year, traders said the Federal Reserve's purchases were enough to lift prices.
"In this thin market it doesn't take much to push the market either way," said Robert Pugliese, a senior vice president and director of fixed income for the J. W. Genesis Financial Corporation in Boca Raton, Fla.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of one-year bills:

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: In Language You Can Understand;
S.E.C. Edict Revives Push to Keep Documents Simple

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A streamlining process designed to add value for consumers of content by reducing their comprehension experience is currently being efforted by public-sector entities and bleeding-edge corporations.
Huh? 
 Both government agencies and some companies are now trying to use clearer, simpler writing than they did in the past.
Ah-ha!
The plain-language movement is enjoying a resurgence, and this time it could have staying power. Disdaining jargon and celebrating short, conversational sentences with active verbs, the latest effort began two years ago when the Securities and Exchange Commission ordered mutual fund companies to rewrite their prospectuses by Dec. 1, 1999. With the help of consultants, the movement has expanded to other government agencies and to companies like Ford Motor and Charles Schwab.
President Clinton instructed federal agencies last year to rewrite by 2002 all documents that the public sees. The Food and Drug Administration this year mandated that labels on over-the-counter drugs be easier to understand by 2005. The S.E.C. is mulling similar rules for two popular financial products sold by insurance companies.
Behind the push is a recognition that new sources of information -- like the Internet, 24-hour cable television and an explosion in junk mail -- have overwhelmed people. "The volume of information that people get and the speed at which they get it has grown exponentially," said Irene A. Etzkorn, an executive vice president at Siegel & Gale, a New York consulting firm. She oversees the division that rips up and rewrites documents.
"If people can't quickly discern information," she added, "they discard it."
Government officials hope their use of simple language will make Americans more likely to trust what they hear from Washington. Marketers, for their part, see a golden opportunity to rise above the cacophony and convince consumers that they should buy a product. Plain English can also help corporate managers explain their company's strategy to employees and thereby increase workplace efficiency.
At its best, simpler writing bolsters revenue and cuts costs. The Veterans Benefits Administration, for example, said it expected to save about $500,000 a year because, after training employees in its life insurance division how to write more clearly, the response rate on one of its letters shot up to 62 percent, from about 35 percent. One telecommunications company, which Ms. Etzkorn declined to identify, came to Siegel & Gale after its confusing bills caused cellular-phone customers to spend an average of 45 minutes a month talking to a service center, she said.
At its worst, the detractors of plain English say that it can dumb down documents, making them less accurate or less useful to the experts who make up much of their audience.
Of course, the debate over sparse language is not new. Aristotle, Renaissance philosophers, the authors William Strunk Jr. and E. B. White and the investor Warren E. Buffett have all weighed in on the topic. Others, including some in the Carter administration, made pushes to encourage plain English that did not stick.
But today's effort is more sustained, partly because it intersects with several economic trends that favor it. Deregulation can cause onetime monopolies like local phone companies to want to communicate with their customers more clearly. And the Internet forces marketers to think about presenting information in catchy new ways.
In fact, the S.E.C.'s ruling on prospectuses has created a cottage industry of plain-language consultants, like Simplify in New York and Firehouse Communications in Malden, Mass., that are seeking to drum up new business by rewriting annual reports, 401(k) statements and financial-services brochures. Siegel & Gale, which pioneered the business almost three decades ago, has seen its document group double in size since 1996. Some big law firms have also tried to become experts in the area.
When the consultants finish with a report, the differences can be stark. Consider Texaco, whose executives began to think more carefully about how they write after hearing about the S.E.C.'s ruling on mutual funds. Many sections of their 1996 annual report -- the last before their plain-language initiative -- appear as a sea of uninterrupted text, highlighted by bureaucratic words (heretofore) and oil-industry jargon (maturing fields).
Try wading through this one: "Texaco's total cash provided by operating activities of $3.8 billion for the year 1996 reflected strong operational earnings and a net inflow of $375 million, primarily comprised of a cash dividend from Caltex (related to the sale of Caltex' interest in NPRC), proceeds from advanced payments on long-term natural gas sales agreements and the collection of nonrecurring receivables (primarily insurance recoveries relating to environmental matters), which were partially offset by payments related to litigation and other matters."
If you picked up the report, said Joseph DeNardo, a Texaco accountant and one its authors, "you'd want to throw the book out."
The most recent annual report, by contrast, features narrow columns of text, which are easier to read, and short, explanatory sentences. Many sections start with a definition, rather than a string of revenue numbers: "In our upstream business, we explore for, find, produce and sell crude oil, natural gas liquids and natural gas." The first sentence of the letter from Peter I. Bijur, the company's chairman, contains 15 words, down from 51 two years ago -- despite the hard times for the oil industry that might have given him reason to obfuscate Texaco's 78 percent decline in net income.
Making such changes is not easy, however. "People think it's like a translation, that you turn big words into small words. That's not it at all," said William M. Lutz, an English professor at Rutgers University in Camden, N.J., and perhaps the most famous plain-language advocate today. He has his own consulting business and earlier this year published "Doublespeak Defined" (HarperCollins, 1999), a dictionary of jargon.
Recently, Professor Lutz joined two Postal Service employees at the agency's headquarters in Washington to make final changes in its annual report. They had sent a rough draft to 40 of the agency's top officials and were now squirreled away in a cubicle the size of a conference room, surrounded by Thanksgiving leftovers and McDonald's wrappers, scribbling away and dodging yet more bureaucratic bullets. Colleagues kept stopping to drop off their own suggestions. One manager debated which preposition to use in one sentence. Their intentions were usually good, said R. Timothy MacDonald, one of the writers, but convoluted language crept in.
"People say, 'You have to be perfect and exact and include every little nuance,' " Mr. MacDonald said. "Finally, you've got this beast." So he and a colleague, alongside Professor Lutz, sifted through every comment, at one point wrangling for 20 minutes over a single sentence. Professor Lutz left at 7 p.m. to take a train to Philadelphia so he could teach a class the next day. Mr. MacDonald stayed at the office until 1:30 a.m.
Nobody will confuse the final product with an E. B. White essay, but the emphasis on simplicity is apparent throughout the report. It uses "we" and "our," rather than "the Service" and "U.S.P.S.'s." The section on transportation is only 27 lines, down from 42 last year, because many of the statistics that had previously appeared in long-winded sentences are now part of a small chart.
Such struggles are common, particularly because the changes often involve blunt criticism. "There was a tremendous objection to this at the beginning," Mr. DeNardo of Texaco said. Almost three years later, though, the practice has become ingrained, and some managers use plain language even in internal memos, he added.
Similar changes have happened at Schwab and at American Century Investments, both of which have simplified many documents besides prospectuses. When employees "saw we could do this with something as complicated as a prospectus, there was a shift in perspective," said Roberta Laughlin, American Century's manager for education and guidance. "It's almost a mantra now."
Plain-language advocates hope they can next persuade phone and cable companies to simplify their materials as they begin competing with one another. Already, AT&T has hired Siegel & Gale to design monthly bills that the company sends separately from local phone companies.
But with a few notable exceptions -- among them the annual report by Texaco and sales and leasing contracts for Ford cars -- plain language is not yet common outside of the government and the financial services industry. Even in finance, said Paula R. David, the director of client marketing at the Boston consulting firm, Funds Distributor Inc., "We had expected the industry to embrace this more than it did."
"The majority decided merely to comply" with the S.E.C. rules rather than rewrite all of their documents, Ms. David said.
The language mavens say that raises a disquieting question, particularly in the ninth year of an economic expansion: If a recession comes, will companies decide that cutting consulting costs is more important than cutting words?

SECTION: Section C; Page 12; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 414 words

HEADLINE: Productivity Grew Sharply In 3rd Quarter

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Worker productivity grew at a faster pace in the third quarter than originally estimated and labor costs fell for the first time in more than two years, government figures released today showed.
Productivity -- an index of output per hour worked -- rose at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the third quarter, up from initial reports of a 4.2 percent increase, the Labor Department said today. That follows a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter and is the biggest gain in almost seven years. 
 "We're in the midst of a significant productivity surge that's of a long-run nature," Robert Parry, the president of the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank, said today.
The higher revision for productivity follows a higher estimate of third-quarter gross domestic product by the Commerce Department. Last month, the government revised G.D.P. for that quarter to show a 5.5 percent annual rate of increase, previously estimated at 4.8 percent.
Unit labor costs -- a measure of worker compensation tied to shifts in productivity -- fell at a rate of two-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter after rising 4.2 percent in the second, the Labor Department said.
In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said borrowing by consumers grew at a slower-than-expected $4.2 billion in October as shoppers cut back on credit card purchases for the first time in almost a year.
"People were fine-tuning their debt and getting ready to spend big time during the holidays," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM MoneyWatch in New York.
After languishing at about 1 percent a year in the 1970's and 1980's, productivity growth in all businesses has been more than 2.5 percent in the last three years. Higher productivity helps companies raise profits while containing labor costs, which account for about two-thirds of all business expenses.
Productivity is on track to match last year's 2.8 percent gain, which would be the best two-year showing since 1991 and 1992. It would also be the fourth consecutive year that productivity has grown more than 2 percent; the last time that happened was 1961 to 1966.
Compared with the quarter a year earlier, productivity was 3.1 percent higher. Productivity growth close to 3 percent "will allow real earnings of employees to increase at the fastest rate in a generation, thus helping to support strong consumer and economic growth," said Joseph Liro, an economist at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J.
